Description:
Mama's Jiaoziria!!
In Mama's Jiaoziria, you play as the main employee at Mama's Jiaoziria, a brand new dumpling shop in town. You must handle taking customer's orders, preparing dumplings, cooking them, and preparing sauces, all up to the customer's wishes. 

Making Mama's Jiaoziria has been a very thrilling ride to say the least. Me and my partner Lubaba started working on this game about halfway through the Juice event, which meant we were on quite a significant time crunch. We originally had a completely different idea, which utilized Godot's 3D capabilities but scrapped that after some technical limitations. This was rather inconvenient, as it left us kind of scrambling for ideas. Thankfully we (mostly Lubaba) came up with the idea for Mama's Jiaoziria, taking inspiration from the Papa's series of games where you similarly manage restaurants. Developing the game has been quite difficult at times, as this is me and my partner's first time encountering Godot and the first time we've made a fully-fledged game that we shipped. Me and my partner decided to split the work evenly with me as the programmer and Lubaba as the artist, so we were constantly messaging back and forth bickering about different ideas for the game and how to implement it. I personally ran into a bunch of roadblocks trying to understand how to do certain things I wanted to in Godot, and I had a bunch of moments where I just felt really unmotivated to continue due to some issue I was running into. However, seeing all the other Hack Clubbers in the #juice channel in the Slack also working on their Juice game greatly motivated me, knowing that we were all in this together. Despite not being done with my game at the time of writing this little blurb, I am pretty motivated to finish this game. It's been challenging, but it's also been quite fun.

I really had to bang my head about trying to figure out how the heck i was going to implement customers to the game. However, I think I figured it out? All it took was a big old Excalidraw session and some more headbanging over file structures and datatypes. Plus a few quadribillion google searches. Yippee!!!!!! I love game development!!!!!!!

I got the ticket to now be customizable :) well technically i did this a few hours ago but i hadnt verified it was working at all until now
FINALLY the ticket can now be moved to the ticket line or hooked onto the line hook, with proper animations as well!
There is now (placeholder) assets for the prep screen, with a movable dumpling wrapper too

been trying to work but i have been forsaken and now my stomach hurts. not yippee. gotta weather the pain though, juicing is more important!!!!! obviously couldn't do much as i was hunched over, but i got some small planning done.
moved the tickets to their own node, and fixed mouse inputs not working after that change
me and my partner added icons to the ticket :)
i can move!!!!!!!! in the environment!!!
made my main menu to actually exist in game. still not interactable yet, but this took long enough that i think its a good checkpoint for a stretch
Updated the background colors for the main fillings to be accurate to the assets
formatted a proper icon for my game, for when I eventually compile a desktop version or mobile version
Modified the animations on the ticket so it shouldn't be as terrible anymore
made a card swipe task (this took way too long........) for use later
Migrated everything regarding orders to a new OrderData datatype to keep things organized
swapping between stations works now!!!!!!!!
Decided to change game ideas because my team was struggling HARD with Godot 3D. Also switched to Godot 2D. Finally got working station switching for our papa's pizzeria-esque game
fixed a bug where setting the clock position on tickets wasn't working right

got lost in the absolute mess that is my passing of signals between nodes and manual creation/ linking of nodes. I had to connect to the customer's get order button's signal manually, then pass it's output up the tree of nodes to move to the customer order scene. figuring out where i went wrong along the way while passing the signal via other signals took too long. you can't see it, but it hides the get order button above the customer when its pressed, then goes to the screen where you take the customers order.

After a lot of faffing about trying to connect unconnected nodes via a rather inefficient web of signals, globals, and classes, I can finally take customer's orders!!!!!! I had to basically completely rewrite the ticket class I had before because I structured it in a way that wouldn't allow me to just show one bit of the ticket at a time. I also implemented a transition, a fade-to-black so it looks a bit more polished. That alone took a bit of time, figuring out how to get completely different nodes to do the exact same thing. In the end, I just use a global variable that keeps track of the status of transitions. Quite janky, but it works!

addendum to previous moment: i actually hadn't put in the last piece of code that actually hides the button, whoopsies. forgot that the code for that was broken so I had commented it out. fixed it now!

Description:
Parasito
by Filip Mårtensson
I made Parasito for Juice. It’s a game where you control a hivemind of lab-grown parasites trying to escape a high-security lab. Each run gives you a new chance to explore, fail, and try again. I had plans for a full evolution system where parasites would learn from each other’s deaths, but I didn’t manage to finish that in time. Still, the spirit of it is there: trial, error, and persistence.
Since we weren’t allowed to use any understandable language, I decided to get a little creative. I learned Baybayin, a precolonial Filipino writing system, and used it in the game. I didn’t use any actual Filipino words, just the script. I made up my own language and even created a custom number system, since Baybayin didn’t have one. That part was honestly the most fun. It let me connect with something cultural in a way that still felt completely original.
At around the 80-hour mark, my parents told me I wouldn’t be allowed to go to China. That was rough. I lost motivation for a while. But I kept going. Partly because I really wanted that jacket, and partly because I didn’t want all those hours to go to waste.
Parasito isn’t perfect. It’s weird, unfinished in some places, and definitely messy. But it’s mine — and Juice reminded me how powerful it can be to make something just because you care about it.

Our game is inspired by the Tom Hanks movie, "Captain Phillips", in which he must fight off pirates from his cargo ship. We thought this same idea would be interesting to implement in VR, so we decided to make Modern Day Pirates, an immersive VR experience in which you must take up arms, and fifth back to protect your cargo as you sail across the world!

juiceStretches.description: Distance values difficulty values now have a UI, meant to be displayed on seperate boards next to the campaign map (think the risk video game map). This session was mainly drawing flags of other countries, but this is the last thing I need to do in pixel art for the campaign menu (I think)

Finished implementation of Buttons, shop button now moves to a shop scene, and added working VR camera to shop scene along with adding some objects. Fixed some Bugs relating to scene changing, which also was preventing scene changing and preventing the play button from working - also made the game freeze when clicking the play button. Now fixed.
First version of shop menu is done! Bronze and silver menus are completed, just waiting to test before adding items to silver and creating gold.

Batch spawning now actually works. I also removed the boats moving, because in reality the wont actually be moving - just a quick animation not move them to a set points, because it will appear that they are moving but wont actually be.

One of my teammates made a very good point about the map I was creating, and suggested we make it more like the risk(video game) map, which I thought was a fantastic idea. I went ahead and isolated the map section, updated the animations, and actually imported the animations into the game. I also created the (untextured) campaign menu, where you can use the map for the very first campaign from Seattle to the Panama canal. Next up is adding direct buttons and labels inside the cargo hold to show difficulty and a dedicated start button.

Added shop art to the game, implemented buttons properly for switching between shop categories, and added collision boxes from upgrades (but did not implement functionality yet, thats going to take a long time)
I finally got the animation to look good! This took way too long of studying how people walk lol. In the end I ended up surprising myself with how good it looked!
I made our first sprite! I have not done pixel art in a couple years, so it was fun to get back into it, and i think it looks pretty good!
Designed icons to replace the campaign level info text behind the player.

Greatly improved bomb spawning, and laid out the entire difficulty scaling system for the future. Campaigns are all set to go, so as soon as the first level is smoothed out its as simple as changing a single variable and maybe the skybox for the rest.

Ships actually have good batch spawning and animations to bring them foward. Also debugging... so much debugging... Bombs shouldnt be an issue anymore (hopefully :pray:) becasue the code was actually not well made at all and i spent a while fixing it really well so we will see. I had to learn physics formulas to make the bombs work properly lmao. Anyway that was this session.

Moved back to BR! Made the campaign menu to scale in VR and set up hand with pointers. This is going to get better, I just spent so long setting everything up in the scene and getting OpenXR working and getting the hand model and pointer working and reading the controller.
GREATLY improved design for virus, as we are changing the style to a more nitty-gritty dark souls type. Also learnt tiling to make the background look better, especially the path.
Created icons/buttons for 3d campaign menu scene
Shop logic is now (pretty much) fully finished, and cost and inventory system for coins is now working.
Difficulty and start/end positions are now in the game, and change based on the campaign you are on!
Idle and Running animation! Works great, except the legs looks kinda but, but that is going to be updated next time.

All shop code and ui is now done. Meaning, every interaction in the shop works, inventory system works, pricing works, upgrade levels work. Huge session because I finalized pretty much every feature. Only thing left for the shop menu is to create some surroundings for it, but my teammate had some ideas for that so I will leave it to him.
Bomb physics greatly improved, bomb stop in nice arc night near player now, still somewhat randomized, but it looks SO MUCH BETTER.

Campaign system works now on the backend, and on the front end we are able to change map animations in the 3d campaign menu based on the backend campaign value. Also, fixed a bug that caused blurry pixels when importing pngs for some reason.
bombs work, player damage works. enemies are now actual enemies who can kill you.

Huge stretch, added pretty much all player side functionality - shops, upgrade trees, permanent upgrades, round system, wave system, batch spawning, campaign mode, campaigns. Game looks terrible but the functionality for all player side stuff now exists so we have an MVP. Now to make it looks better and start adding the extra stuff, first vr, then multiplayer.
Started working on background. VERY rudimentary - spent most of the time learning how to tile, do backgrounds in aseprite, and refining the idea.
Core game loop has been added! Spawning works, and boats have health, and player can defeat boats and the boats can defeat the player. The main mechanic is here!

3D campaign menu fully finished! In this session I finalized silver items and finished gold items. Honestly just spent a while looking at designs and trying to make it easy to select without language, and I think it works quite well. Next is adding it into the game!
Updated campaign menu map and updated each route for new campaign menu screen. Not much significant, just tedious work.
Controller mapping works! Also, controller direction is now actually being registered. Replaced hands with lasers (only for menus).
Adding buttons for starting, stopping, and shop menu. Also a bunch of controller related bug fixes, so we now have proper good controller detection.
More bug fixes, fixed multiple collisions causing bombs to deal 25 instead of 5 damage, fixed re spawning preventing enemies from attacking, and fix an issue with batch spawning on re spawn.
Finished an MVP of the campaign screen! Now it has no words, so it and the map looks really great, also finalized level locations for future bg work.

Added level upgrade system for each upgrade, individualized per menu screen. Took a while because it has to interact with a game manager to remember upgrades and use them throughout the game. Looks pretty good! Next up is cost.

Fixed an issue with scene intilization that was really annoying - that single bug pretty much took up this whole time - that and the bugs that happened while fixing it. ALso fully got OpenXR working in the new scene, so now I have a framework that I can really move from scene to scene. Also finished basic interior/exterior for shop scene. Rays working properly in new scene as well.

Added icons to the shop menu. Sorry for the session being so long- I had to redesign multiple times. Pretty tough to represent some of these upgrades in icon form lol. But yeah, I added half of the icons for the silver menu
Fully finished 3d campaign menu (except for texturing.) In this session I added button functionality, fixed some bugs with collision boxes, and added haptic feedback to controllers.

Created a test file for the Gunstock 3d printing. I have to design and print this before designing the rest of the controller mount because i need to be 100% sure it fits and can be adjusted properly.

Description:
Time Harvest
The idea for Time Harvest came long before Juice. I was so excited about it, but all I managed to do was code some basic movement and a simple camera system. Juice was an opportunity for me to finally bring my idea to life.

I was so enthusiastic at first, spending 2 hours each day working on the game, excited to see it published on Steam. I was amazed by the fact that I didn't experience any burnout for two weeks—something that is very rare, as I get bored of EVERYTHING if I do it for more than 6 hours total. That was when I realized how important a community is. The fact that I got to share my work with other like-minded teenagers is what kept me motivated for so long.

After a bit, though, I started to slowly lose interest in the game due to multiple factors, like my hopes of going to China being crushed by my parents not allowing me to, or the progress slowing down due to having to rework half of the game. After a last push for the Tamagotchi event, I dropped the game entirely in a pretty basic state.

Although it is the most impressive and complex game I have ever created, I’m not very proud of it. BUT, because of Jungle, I got a grant that is just enough to purchase a Steam license, so I might return to it. You can follow my progress on my personal Slack channel (#this-is-dumi). I’ll also be giving away free keys for my game (if) when I release it on Steam.

Description:
The Siderooms

An exploration game where you navigate shifting rooms, collect rubies to unlock each level’s portal, and evade enemies to escape back to the Frontrooms.

Creating The Siderooms has been an exciting and rewarding journey, especially with the constant flow of ideas that improve its features and gameplay. The most enjoyable part of this process has been playtesting, gradually implementing new features, testing them with different people, and using their feedback to make the experience better and more engaging.

At first, I wasn’t sure where to begin or how to bring my game to life. But I soon discovered a great deal of online resources and a community of developers, particularly those working with Godot, who were always ready to help. This support allowed me to quickly adapt and start developing. I initially tested new features on my own, but over time, I connected with people online and within my friend group who contributed a lot through playtesting and providing feedback, which made the development process much smoother.

I’m really grateful to Hack Club and especially the Juice team for creating an opportunity that made it possible for me to finally start building a game I’m proud of that I can share with others and continue improving.

Added a camera, set it to start with the player and follow the player, and also fixed quite a few bugs with animations while the player walks in curved walls. Also changed collision shape for a better dimensional experience.
Working on drawing and making my 32x32 tiles (going from 16x16).

Finally made the sprint indicator follow the player and smoothly moved.

Also worked on a lot of bugs with the player's pointlight and where it would significantly amplify the light if fullscreen was toggled.

Description:
Not an idle started off as something completely different, and honestly I almost didn't even join the game jam. I remember sitting there, scrambling to come up with an idea, minutes before the jam started. I decided to wing it and send in the first idea that came to mind. This initial idea was nothing like the end product we have today. The concept was a clicker game focused on deleting a massive cube, one small cube at a time.

Early on I realized the typical idle game wouldn’t hold attention at the cafe, I switched gears. Instead of players passively earning money, I decided on a minigame system. Each minigame needs intermittent attention to continue earning money. Players can buy more minigames and upgrades in the shop. 

After a round of playtesting I quickly realised the cube concept was over complicated and didn’t serve much of a purpose. I scrapped the cube and moved onto exploring new concepts. I introduced a window system and themed my game around a late 90's operating system, and Added upgrades to keep the player progression moving. With these improvements and more, I was feeling confident in my game.

At this point the game was starting to look a lot like what you would see if you booted up the game now. After some polish, and implementing other features like music, sound effects and more. The game was done. As i’m writing this - it’s a week before I go to the cafe to show off my game. I’m incredibly excited and grateful for this opportunity.

juiceStretches.description:
QOL and balance tweaks for the chat minigame:
Cursor caret now displays
you can press enter to send a message
new message sound effects
new send icons and icon displays when your message is finished
instead of getting messages more often the more you upgrade, you always get the same amount of messages but they're worth more the more you upgrade

I finally updated the shop icons to use pixel art.

I made a new icon for every game to be used in the shop at 32px x 32px

I also added one upgrade for the dvd game that makes it slow down half as fast.

I made a new start menu. 

I styled it after the windows 98 one, It has shut down, log out (new), and the settings and music player apps.

I made it so if you click outside of the start menu when it's open it hides. I also used this for my volume slider because it's functionality is pretty much identical.
I've considerably upgraded the games visuals, with a wallpaper, taskbar, os logo, shop item icons, and a window to display money
OK so i made a brand new minigame and it's a terminal that automatically gives you money, but it has the downside of crashing every now and then. while it's crashed, it doesn't work.

I updated saving to use emojis instead of english text.

- I made 9 emojis (8 normal, 1 question mark blank guy) for the players to choose from in aseprite. 
- Update save slot ui to use 3 emoji's instead of text
- Found out about NinePatchRect's
- Replaced all of my previous UI with them
- Made a rounded corner NinePatchRect texture
- Made the UI for the emoji pop up
- Made them save (This took forever because I hate working with saving)
- Made the emoji menu actually update the emojis in the save slot
- Make that work with saving
- Re-use some code from the start menu to make the menu go away when you click off it
- Fix bugs
- DONE

I changed the default resolution to 1920 x 1080, 
I completely redesigned the ui to use anchors instead of direct positions so now it works at any resolution.
I made shop code that auto populates the image and price to shop items.
I made code that increases the price, takes away money, and updates a record of how many automations you own when you click on a shop item.

I made the button game bouncy! I got feedback saying that it felt a bit stiff and there was no feedback when you clicked the button so I wrote custom (simple) physics for it.

I made the button have a position value mapped to the scale of it. When you click the button the velocity of that position gets added some number and i programmed a spring that tries to return it back to center. If it goes too far and reaches a pre-defined maximum then the spring strength get proportionally larger stopping it from getting way too large, acting as a soft boundary.
Updated the chat minigame to use the new UI

I started off by starting work on a tab system for the shop ( I want to add upgrades that function similarly to cookie clicker) but then I got distracted and cleaned up the file system, it's been bugging me and I wanted to do it before I make a public github for this project.

All minigames now work with windows!

I had to redo the design of task manager, loading, and dvd, but now it's done. I also re-did all the game icons to look nice in the task bar.

I made window position, size, and visibility save between game sessions. Everything will be right as you left it!

I did this by modifying the script that manages the initialisation of the windows to read and apply a dictionary thats saves data about the position size and visibility of the window that's persistent between game sessions.

When the game realises it's trying to be closed it saves the position of all the windows before allowing it to be closed.

More QOL stuff.

I got feedback saying they didn't understand how the terminal game works, so I made the error pop up quicker the first time you play

Games automatically show when they're first initialised

Games pop up next to the mouse when they're first initialised

I refactored the tab system to allow scripts to be added to each tab. I used this to make a script that counts how many upgrades I can afford (and are available) because I saw the upgrades kinda being overlooked.

The number that counts how many are available will need a bit of a re-style but the functionality is there.

I added two features, a settings menu with settings that save. Currently I have only implemented a way to toggle the particle system. but in future I may add volume sliders, other graphical toggles and more.

I have also implemented a feature that hides shop items until the one before has been bought. each shop item fades in when the game loads or the one before is bought, I think it's pretty cool

I have implemented pooling for the particles and I have implemented 'clumping'

I noticed my game had large lag spikes when lots of particles were on screen so I decided to optimise. I first added pooling but that didn't do a lot. then I added 'clumping' I reworked how multiple of my minigames handled spawning lots of particles at once so now when they're spawning a lot, they clump into one larger lot of particles, helping performance a lot. there's still things that bring down performance but I feel like this a great start.

QOL STUFF!!

- New Settings UI & the one setting I have remembers it's value properly ( the value was technically being saved but the thing using the value didn't check it on startup so that didn't really matter)
-Upgrades only show if you own the minigame associated with them lol
- Volume slider no longer blasts your eardrums if you touch it ever so slightly

I got a little stuck trying to style scroll bars.

I've never worked with styles before, just style overrides but this was a good introduction.

I wanted to replicate the style that I use everywhere else in my game. This is pretty simple, solid color center, shadow on the right and bottom, and highlight on the top and left.

Problem is: You can only have one border in godot. I've got around this in the past by using multiple different panels. 

I ended up doing a weird combination of margin, expand margin, and shadow for it to in the end only sorta look how I want it to in one situation.

I've done 2 major things and 1 minor thing!

1. I HAVE FINALLY MADE MINIGAMES PLAYABLE IN THE NEW WINDOW SYSTEM! or more spesifically, buying an item in the shop (and loading in) adds the corresponding minigame (with icon) to your taskbar.

2. I added the score counter as a new class I'm calling a widget. widgets stay on your desktop at all times, and cannot be closed. they are always behind windows and cannot be moved forwards.

3. when windows are instantiated, their icon matches the task bar app that opened them

Ok so I made a new minigame, it works by putting  fruits in a juicer and pressing the button and it will slowly subtract stuff from the square. only problem is I wrote a script that scales the node2D but I didn't realise Godot really really doesn't like that and doesn't allow you to scale children that are of a node2D type. so I basically made this minigame for nothing because it just doesn't fit on screen.

I'm going to have to revamp both of my minigames to use control nodes instead of node2D nodes. In the case of the minigame I just made I will have to pretty much scrap it entirely because it's entirely reliant on node2D to work.

Things I did in this session:
Made a physics draggy thing so you can pick up fruits using pinjoint2D

I found a soundtrack on itch.io that has a permissive license. You can use it in your game (even commercially) without attribution! (I'll probably make an attributions section later for my game but for now I'm focusing on other things)

Once I found the soundtrack I built a music player. I combined a progress bar, an hslider thingy, buttons and a label to make a music player!

It has an array of previously played songs so that you can skip backwards. When a song ends or you skip next it picks a random song to play. The label displays the song name (although in alien gibberish)

This wasn't a difficult project but it was fun!

NEW MINIGAME ALERT! This one is supposed to be like a task manager. it periodically removes bugs, but every now and then a process will use too much memory! you need to end that process to earn a bonus and to restart the periodic bugfixing.
The grid of upgrades now dynamically adjusts how many columns it has. very simple script. (also made a public repository for the game)

I've started balancing by adding upgrades.

Whenever I felt a bit stuck or that one of my minigames was lacking in it's power, I made a new upgrade for that game at the price of how much money I had in that moment.

doing this I have added and implemented 3 new upgrades.

Terminal_Upgrade_1; cheap and just makes the terminal not crash so much.
Chat_Upgrade_1: Get messages twice as fast (you get money when you respond to a message) 
and Terminal_Upgrade_2: Doubles the production of the terminal (it generates twice the ammount of money)

Also when you first play the game and buy the chat minigame, instead of having to wait the normal 15 - 30 seconds, it's 5 - 7 seconds. I made this change because I feel players need a chance to figure out the minigame, and they will get confused if it just sits there doing nothing for a while. I did this by making a new variable that gets saved between sessions. if that variable is true (it's true by default) set the delay to a random number between 5 and 7 seconds and set that variable to false.

Ok, So I have the basic framework for clicking in. My next step is to make a shop system to buy upgrades that increase the size of the thing you're clicking on (more money) and automate clicking ( maybe a minigame for each, idk)

I added click sound effects, one for mouse down one for mouse up, and I made it so windows only have the lag effect (delaying showing for half a second or so) if its when the game is just starting up. They show immediately if they're bought

I have stopped the windows from being able to be taken off the screen. it can only go halfway off the left and right, the top bar cannot go off the bottom of the screen and the top stops the window entirely. When you resize the window it also applies the same limitations.

I've also added the shop as a new item in the taskbar.
Code for mouse hovering didn't work on web. Refactored so it did and added mouse hover functionality to allow it to be added to more than just buttons and added it to the volume slider

new minigame!

Every 50-70 seconds you get a message, and you need to respond. it replaces your input with alien language and once you've typed out fully one of the pre-set phrases you can click send. once you have sent it rewards you by clearing one screen and the cycle repeats.

I made cursors in aseprite and then I implemented them into my game.

I wanted a "software cursor" rather than the built in "hardware cursor" because I wanted the cursor in my game to snap to the grid

Godot doesn't have a way of detecting what shape your cursor is taking, so I had to write that myself.

When you hover over (or click) on a button it sends the cursor it wants to set and a unique ID

these cursors are held in a stack and the one on top is used (in case for some reason multiple cursors are trying to be set at the same time)

I'm using a canvas layer to put the cursor on top of everything else. This is autoloaded so it is automatically put into any scene

I've made some additions to the task bar, a clock, volume menu, and beginnings of a start menu with a shut down button. The clock displays your real computer time. the shut down button actually closes your game.

I have implemented windows properly! Every window is closable, scalable and draggable.

I've only setup this system with settings because I am tired, but tomorrow I will try to add the shop and all of the minigames.

Along with the window system I have also made a system for the task bar that's fairly scalable, but it's still fairly up in the air if I wanna keep it working how it is.

the shop and settings window don't show by default when opening the game for the first time, but when you do open them they open in the middle of the screen rather than the top left corner.

I also massively refactored all of the code that manages opening and closing windows. I have implemented tweening for opening and closing windows, the windows animate from and to their icons in the task bar, and also scale in and out as they do this. This took ages because I made a state machine that allows you to spam the button and get snappy feedback.

when you click it slowly, the window naturally animates in and out. But when you click it while it's animating it instantly snaps to to the state you want without animating, making the interaction with windows feel very snappy.

I also had to fix a bug where if a window had been hidden by animation if you closed the game it would remember it's location as off the screen, so I had to fix that. (That's why I show off restarting the game in the video)

I HAVE ADDED PARTICLES!

I made a custom system that implements velocities, air resistance and other physicsy things into control nodes, specifically my particle things. I then gave them a target and constantly added an acceleration towards their target with the amount of acceleration based on how close the particle is to the goal. when the particle reaches the bounds of the goal (custom hitboxes) it plays a different particle of it exploding and removes a bug.

This is a basic overview but I'm pretty happy w/ it
I added a shop that allows you to increase the size of the grid. this may seem simple but I had to rework a portion of the code that handles the grid.

I Added a startup sequence (bios looking thing) login, and updated the font again.

I started by making the startup sequence. I based it off some windows 98 bios I found on youtube. Copying the text line for line and somewhat modifying it to fit my game. I needed more characters in my font for this so I modified my font to include <>().- I then made each line load in one by one. I animated the text, and then I made a bit of a splash screen that shows up after the bios.

After the splash screen I moved on to the login screen.

I based this off windows 98 as well.

This was by far the most complicated thing I did this session. I started by making the ui, This needed individual buttons with a name, icon and delete button. I also needed a way to add saves so I added a button at the bottom right.

To make this work was a tedious process. I started by making the script that saves things support multiple save files. Each save file is just named savegame_slot_1 2, 3, etc but the name you see in the game is saved within the save file. This allows for characters not allowed in a file name.

Slots can be created, re-named, and deleted.

This was a pain lol

I made an upgrade system from scratch!

Grid of upgrades each with a flag that is modified when bought, globally accessible from  any script. 

I also made a system for hover menus. The built in system looked too daunting so I made a really simple one quickly.

 - made ui for upgrade menu
- made icons for upgrade menu
- made new button for upgrade menu
- made new tiny font for upgrade level https://nanomars.itch.io/3x5-pixel-numbers-font
- wrote script for upgrade buttons
- wrote script for hover menu
- made icons for hover menu
- made ui for hover menu
- made ownership of upgrades save between sessions ( flags are calculated off ownership so flags are not saved)

I've finally started to work on the visual identity of this game. I'm going for a windows 98 look, or at least a competitor around the same time.

This was a major overhaul of pretty much all of the UI, and I'm not done yet.

Moving forward it should be quicker because now that I have the templates it should be pretty drag and drop along with redrawing and replacing assets.

Soon I will replace the current UI layout with a system of windows. Each minigame will be an app, and you will be able to open and close each one to your liking.

I made a new version of the standard intergalactic alphabet font for use in my terminal game. I added 13 more characters so that I can keep the timestamp feature in the terminal

I added these characters to the font: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 0, [, ] and :
I ADDED SAVING, HOLY CACA! It saves everything to a json file when the game closes and loads it all when it starts up!

I made a wallpaper system in the settings menu!

I started by making some wallpapers to select from,

then made the UI. This by it self is quite complex, not even taking into account the left and right scroll thing.

I then realised I would need a way to scroll the wallpaper icons left and right without a scroll bar, so I made a script and buttons that do that. 

This took a while because for some reason 
scroll_container.scroll_horizontal -= 1 * delta works and
scroll_container.scroll_horizontal += 1 * delta doesn't work. strange thing is if I get rid of the delta on the += 1 then it works. And so that's what I did. This may come back to bite me in the future, but I'm tired so whatever.

Once I did that I started work on the script that controls this section of the settings.

This was what most of my time was dedicated towards, and I will not go into detail because it's kinda complex. All you need to know is you click on one of the texture buttons that are displaying the wallpapers small, to put it on the preview, and you click the tick button to set that wallpaper as your actual wallpaper.

 The path of the wallpaper is also saved to settings (which is persistent between sessions) So your wallpaper doesn't get lost when you come back to the game.

I did all of this because I got feedback saying that my old wallpaper was kinda confusing, I *was* gonna just make a new wallpaper but then I came up with the idea of how this would work and got kinda into it lol.

I've made the chat history allowed too be longer than 2 and made it so that instead of making the window larger as the history grows it crops it and has the bottom line (most recent) at the bottom. ( I know this might seem simple but godot's ui system is kinda complex in how it works)

I also applied the same thing to the terminal.

I fixed the score not displaying ( script got removed for some reason)

I made the description of upgrade icons editable, so I can start making more upgrades :D

I've replaced my first minigame. It's functionally similar but a lot more polished. I couldn't bring over any code or ui elements so it was basically a drop in replacement.

The new minigame is a progress bar that fills up as you make progress on the squares, when it's full you can press the button and it clears a whole lot (4 grids) I will be uploading on itch.io

I got rid of the grid of bugs! the game is entirely centered around getting money now.

This makes the game much more simple to understand and more fun (imo)

Getting rid of the grid was a bit of a challenge. it was very much deeply ingrained into my game. Getting rid of it was tough but it gave me the opportunity to rebalance my game.

Now instead of getting some arbitrary upgrade when you buy another thingy from the shop, each upgrade doubles the output of a certain automation. to stop players from abusing this prices increase exponentially (the prices thing hasn't changed I just thought it was relevant)

I had to rework the progress bar game and I think it works pretty cool now.

I've added another minigame and fixed an issue with how minigames are loaded and displayed.

The first hour was dedicated to minigame display and bugfixing. I've gone from just hiding and showing pre-existing minigames to instantiating them all together, stopping scripts from running before you own a game and keeping the order of the minigames, this didn't take that long, but the next 40~ ish minutes I spent trying to figure out why one of the minigames was displaying and the other wasn't.

After doing that I added a new minigame that works like the dvd logo bouncing around, but it's speed diminishes over time and you have to click on it to speed it back up, only problem is that it's behaviour isn't exactly what I want it to be.

The first minigame now works, I had to write a custom script to define the behaviour of this because it has no upgrades. (frustrating bugfixing to get this one working)

Also games load in in the background when you start the game now. (before they only started generating money when you opened them up manually which instantiated them, but now it instantiates them hidden when the game starts)

I updated the terminal minigame to use the new ui system.

This took a while because it pointed out a ton of errors in the way I set up the window, button and texture box preset ui elements. I fixed them and now for the window, you can set the icon in the top left with metadata. some changes to other things too.

I've updated the first minigame to use a control node instead of a node2D. This has made life much easier for me.

The dynamites are no longer physics based meaning they can't fall out of their spot anymore lol.

The number that keeps track of how many you have & the limit of how many you can have now updates more reliably

I'm using a gridcontainer to display the dynamites now

No major changes to the actual functionality really, but I've finally balanced, and added the rest of the upgrades.

I forget how many I made exactly, but I think I started with 6 upgrades, and I've ended this session with 12.

I've had to play through the game multiple times to set the prices of these upgrades and games to something that doesn't feel overwhelmingly expensive, or too cheap.

When I would play through, I would note down where the game felt stagnant, and I would either place an upgrade, tweak the production of a game, or change the price of a game.

Upgrades are the small icons on the second tab of the shop, the prices of the games are on the first tab.

I fixed the cursor flashing. this was because the software cursor was blocking other items, this is fixed now. I added cursor hover things on a whole bunch more buttons. I got rid of the shadows in the cursor sprites. I designed them to have an offset so that they can be positioned how I like (for example the middle of the window resize and reposition cursor is at the tip of where the default cursor is)

And thats it !! :DD

OK so I added the first minigame. To make this idle game actually interesting, I'm not making an idle game. each upgrade doesn't automatically make you money forever, but instead unlocks or upgrades a certain minigame. for example my first minigame is a bomb and a detonator, it explodes the grid according to how many clicks you have fed it.

It was lowkey a struggle getting a node2D node to dynamically scale to fit inside a control node, and it lowkey messes up the physics but this is a prototype and I'm tired.

- added system for minigames
- added minigame
- minigame scales within control node
- counter for how many upgrades you have bought

Little number has been re-styled. this also meant I had to change how it worked but that wasn't crazy. I went from using the built in method of using the text on buttons to adding a margin container and a label.

I also finally made the chat game have the little icons next to them properly. In the past I just replaced the notification icon functionality with two little guys, but now i've moved to a vbox container with custom scenes that have an icon and a label.

Formatting this so that they start at the bottom and move up while getting clipped by their container was a bit of a pain but I got there. ( I PROMISE I'M MOVING ON TO ADDING MORE GAMEPLAY SOON :sob:)

Godot has a built in tab system but it's visual customisability is very lacking. So I made my own.

This system is expandable for future use and uses icons instead of text.

I designed a font, and icon to make my chat game look a little better.


I've spent a while designing and generating a font file for my game. I needed an 8px non-english / language font for some of my minigames, and I couldn't find one I liked online, so I made one!

Actually designing the font in aseprite didn't take very long, but getting the website I was using to make it work took a while.

I have also uploaded the font to itch.io, free for anyone to use in their games, or anywhere else.

https://nanomars.itch.io/standard-galactic-alphabet-8px-free-use
Bugfix: Shop prices would reset when you close the game, they're now saved

Description:
Party VR
This game is a multiplayer Co-location VR game. You can play minigames with up to 30 friends. Games like Dodgeball, Lazer tag & Volleyball
I spend most of my time on networking and implementing the meta XR SDK.

I published my game to the meta quest store, this was only possible because I was allowed to borrow 30 quest 2's from my school. So thanks Media College Amsterdam!

And thanks HackClub for making everything possible

https://www.meta.com/en-gb/experiences/partyvr/9355384034552901/

i also made a collision system that sends the room corners to every player/client and makes some wall/floor colliders to  the scene. and now i'm going to work on the last part of the gamemanager. and i want to add where the players vote on what game to play bepending on their location in the scene.

100 HOURS!!! I did is yall.
All i have done for now is the following:        
I made use of the Meta XR VR Spatial Anchors
with after some struggles gave me a good starting point with the co-location.           
I also made some very beautiful scripts can i can easily use and adapt for what i need later in development.      

i also had a bug for a long time where the Network Transform Just did not work. but after some very long nights of thinking i rewrote my own version of the system and that worked like 7nd try.

Where I'm also very proud of is the host scene setup logic where i made lines to represented the boarder and make box collisions depending on these boarder's. All shown in the demo vid here.
(Hostlist.cs in github) 

I also want to take this time to thank HackClub and the team behind all of this for making this possible and giving me the best motivation to complete this that could ever ask for. Thanks!

I filaly figued out why things were not working, i have ritten everything down in my notebook and i did a lot of moddeling work in blender for some nice assets for later on.

now i really want to get the basics layed down
i think it work but i will test it later today

When making a room, i now added the ability to make a rectangle instead of a square for more diversity in rooms, and when setting up the room size you can see the area for the eliminated players.

i also separated the main player networking scripts into 3 for better orginization (and with a serialized loopup script, be able to get data out of the player script with just the clients id. PERFECT!)

And a TON of qol improvements + the V74 version of the Meta XR SDK

in the git i pushed over 1200 lines of new code, i need sleep

so, it's been a long journey making this game. but I definitely got a great start to continue working after this jam. and I definitely will!
I think these are my last hours I will submit. 

in for this session, I definitely made some good backend progress with the  thinks like nametags and game management. and i actually started on making the actual minigames, (mostly copy and past work and changing a bunch of variables for balancing )

And, the unity netcode networking decided that it does not like me, again. 
so I had to redo that *again* with a different approach for the 2td time now. I hoped this project would have been easier, but here we are. I really had to keep track of the amounts I had to redo stuff in this project. next time I really should make a good approach on how to do something before beginning.

I said it a bunch to all the organizers but i really want to say that you guys are incredible for making this possible and getting back into programming. I stopped programming like a year ago but because of hackclub i started again, and I'm really grateful.

Thanks HackClub

And Lopa (if you're reviewing this)
I make the networking working and the meta XR SDK, and stared work on some scripts to make my life easier.

Hello! i made updates on the nametag color for displaying the teams of the other clients 
and 
i know last time the gamecontrollers were done but i found some extra bugs that i had to fix with the correctly spawning of the objects for other players. and i added a way to limit the amount of objects spawned and randomizes who gets them,

i also separated the object spawning and the game starting to give the players time to get ready and later maybe add some team base building thinks.

i also edited some minor things with the room collision generator.

thanks HC!

Description: On one fateful day, me, Joel and Aaron showed up to OUR house (Aaron\`s house) starved and decided to make some garlic bread in the kitchen: this was the start to our new adventure. We started getting together and making food quite often, hanging out more and more, leading up to Juice and our game representing our hangouts and the pleasure of making food together8 :)

juiceStretches.description: This should be the right video, but we decided to redo our theme a little, to attract to more audience, since we needed to increase our tile size anyways. SSo here I have some sketches and a new map with finished wooden and tiled floors, This did take me quite a while, and changes will probably still be made (especially to the bear).

Made some buttons for the game, such as the leaving button, the sound button and the shopping cart (which were all added to the tile map).
Then I added a few decorations and accessories to the kitchen to make it look more appealing and cozy.

Then took way too long to draw out and plan out the shape of the cafe and the start page to our game.
I made a bunch of new character sketches, testing out different eye sizes to the map and character size in game so we can decide which fit best.

That start page looks really goofy right now so I didn't soon in, but it's got me tweaking. I made it didn't like it and am planning on making more adjustments to it. It also took me forever to just draw the building itself.

Then I finally animated our chef and made a map for each frame, I would say they are pretty smooth. I also updated the decorations in the kitchen and am in the process of adding table to the dinner area.
Also forgot to record in the video, but I made some banners that would allow the order to be displayed at the top of the screen.

Cropped and updated the main map a bunch of times, while testing object placement and game requirements ( as well as aesthetic). Then made multiple components for the cooking part of the game, testing them with the character, the counter placements and the different steps the user takes to make each food option.
Made more sprits for the salad and the bubble tea to add to our tilemap. Honestly, that's all but took me a while. ;-;
Figured out which drawing program to use and downloaded brushes, then drew our chef with different hat upgrades and the counter + stove! :D

Made a map of the interior of the restaurant, keeping in mind the tile placement. Then made new and improved counters and stoves for the proper perspective, along with temporary floor and wall tiles. The avatar's body size was also decreased to match the perspective and then everything was added to a big tile map (to be uploaded to Godot). Basic avatar walking animation has also been made- it is to be completed.

This took me way too long to make, trying to learn how to use studioone, and mixing the music myself, when there were many easier platforms to use to make a melody for the game. I did make a main theme for the game, and then added some pizzaz to make the night time music, and a boss theme  (both being spinoffs of the original music!). :D 

Also experimented with a bunch of different effects that might be used for when you are on your life, or the start screen and many other silly things.

I tried to make a satisfying video but then I realized that I needed to manually play each sound track so it didn't really work. T^T

I updated the game map, and made all the rest of the tiles and handheld items to create a final kitchen layout. 

Then experimented with different colours and different characters to make my player 2, along with adding the hats for the different tiers of chefs.

Then I uploaded them all onto a tile map (very well-organized tile map if I do say so myself). :)

Fixed a lot of minor details of things that just didn't seem quite right, such as making the smile for the panda chef a little smaller, and the eyes a little darker. As well as many small mistakes in my strokes and transparencies.

I also made a cute logo? start screen? mascot? thing with the two chefs holding all the food options on the menu, which will be incorporated somewhere in the game.

I made (re-made) a bunch of new accessories for our new tile size, they are new and improved, as well as more handholdable items for our chef that actually match where his hands go.As well as a fridge and item stacks where the player is supposed to grab items from.

Description:
Maven Knight
Maven Knight is a game about a knight who is tasked with clearing dungeons of skeletons. The knight has to go to the dungeon, and defeat all the skeletons present to keep the villagers at ease. Making this game has really been a roller coaster from rejoicing when things work and lamenting when a specific bug keeps haunting me. Since it was my first time making this kind of game, it has been a challenge but a good one at that. I learned so much in the short time I spent making it and I still learn everyday. My main motivation has been to create a game I like and other people might enjoy so it makes me really happy to be able to finally do that and let my creation into the world. I am really happy with the progress I have made both personally and in terms of the skills I gained and I thank Hack Club for letting me do this. It has been a blast!

Description:
It began as just a flicker of an idea: a lone monkey against the odds. But I poured myself into it. Code blurred lines on the screen during those first all-nighters, turning a simple square into my dashing, fighting primate.
Fueled by caffeine and determination, another all-nighter saw the jungle expand, spawning deserts, snow peaks, and volcanoes under my fingertips. Enemies multiplied, demanding new tactics I had to code in.
I kept pushing, pulling another late one to add the shield, the magnet, the satisfying boom of the explosion. Fixing bugs, tweaking sprites, adding that skull icon – every detail mattered. Through sheer grit and sleepless nights, I hammered "Monkey Mayhem" into the frantic, feature-packed adventure it is today.




- Written w/ AI

juiceStretches.description:
Intro Screen Music -- went for a classical vibe cause I don't wanna keep the game too violent :D. 
Soundtrap is amazing- the majority of this is my composing, a bit of the fine-tuning is through soundtrap & so is the bass. I might edit this to maybe add a kick drum later

this is version one of my game, ie the 'core mechanics' of the entire game, it has at least 30 minutes of playtime but arguably you could play it for the whole day depending on how fast you wanted to beat the villains, and your skill level. For the reviewers: the 1700+ minutes was not at one stretch, I did it over multiple stretches over a couple of days, I didn't bank individual hours since there wasn't much to be seen (I used LOVE2d (based in lua!). My next steps are to polish the UI, and work on art for the monkey, bananas, villains and more :D. if anybody is reading this on slack please suggest what villians my monkey should have (he's such a good monke)

Description:
Okay, so...
This game isn't gonna be fun for you. At all. I promise.
Don't even try scanning the QR code. I guarantee you won't like it.

...you scanned the QR code? I told you not to. Oh well, it's not like you'll play the game on itch. 

...
...right?

Okay, all jokes aside, this is a game that I originally prototyped on Scratch a few years ago, then planned on making it in Godot for Juice. Unfortunately, school and band got in the way, and I just didn't have 1.6 hours every day for two months to devote to making a game, however much fun that would be. So here's what I managed to get before I got busy: movement mechanics and three enemies. Awesome, I know. Yeah, there's not much else backstory, I just kinda... stopped working on it. Hopefully I can continue working on this in the future, and maybe make it into an actual game! If you wanna check out the scratch game I made, here's the link: https://neildembla.com/zombie-horde-link
(yes I know you can't click it, but this is the best I could do)

Oh also shameless plug time, check out my website! 😃 https://neildembla.com/

Description:
Ossatura
Ossatura is a Rhythm Game RPG made by a small team of high schoolers from Southern California. 
We started making Ossatura with inspiration from indie RPGs such as Undertale, Deltarune, Omori and Oneshot, and combined that influence with our collective love of music!
In our game, you play as a skeleton navigating the afterlife after a tragic accident to find his former band members and friends.
However, to find them, you must fight in music-inspired battles with a variety of enemies, ranging from a duck with a violin to a crocodile with a harp!
Making our game was an incredible adventure, and while very stressful at times, was 100% worth the effort, both in terms of how our game turned out and the memories we made together making it.
It's incredible how two months can change a person, and we all feel like we've truely accomplished something incredible working together.
We hope players enjoy our original, made in-house soundtrack, our fun, rhythm-based battle system, and our (still under development) world and story.

Description:
Hi, I'm Max. I made the game DriftMetal. Its a PS2 style first person fishing game where you play as a robot who was scrapped for parts and thrown in the ocean. you get marooned on an island with a single arm remaining. you have to fish, to get money, to but new parts such as legs or arms that allow you to explore deeper into the island, finding better fishing spots and eventually finding a cargo ship that you can bribe you way onto.
      my story starts two months ago. It was the weekend and I had gotten pretty sick. I figured I wouldn't be going to school for a few days and I started thinking about what I would work on. curios to see if there was anything happening in hack club I checked my phone. I saw the announcement for juice (posted only a few minutes prior) and immediately knew I wanted to participate. earlier in the year I had seen the hype around boreal and it made me want an adventure of my own. juice seemed to be the perfect opportunity since I love making games and I have always wanted to visit China. with plenty of motivation, free time, and schoolwork to procrastinate I juiced nonstop that whole week. by the of the welcome call I had 40 hours, and 50 by the end of the weekend. the next week I had to go back to school so my pace slowed a bit. I spend like 15 hours or so on making water that didn't even work, but apart from that I was making a lot of progress on other features. I continued working on my project every moment of free time I had. I reached my 100 hours right at the start of march. at this point I was mostly focused on art and a LOT bug fixes. for the next month I continued working on my project. progress slowed significantly due to being busy with school and my project becoming increasingly messy. around hour 80 I gave up an pretty much all forms of organization from folders to naming conventions and this came back to bite me throughout march. I started getting ready for the trip I renewed my passport, looked at flight options and learned about visa applications. a few weeks before the trip I found out I couldn't go. I was devastated, but I had still gotten a lot out of juice and I defiantly don't regret participating. I kept working on my project, trying to get it ready for a steam release. that brings us to now. I'm pretty sad I wont be able to meet all my fellow juicers, but I'm exited to finish my game and start a new project. I hope it goes well for everyone going and I look forward to playing everyone's steam releases!

sorry for the long session, I got a bit carried away. I made 4 different rafts/boats/barges! I have two more to finish, but this session is already quite long.
working on the player controller and fixed the bud I was having, never had this issue in the passed so I was a bit confused.

I made it a second shop and the sprites for it! Unfortunately, I had to redo the whole shop system, and I ran into some very time consuming bugs, It FINALLY works! well, sorta... I still need to make it so you can actually buy things lol.
I made a model for the fishing rod and got it working in my game!

lots of bug fixes and small reworks, then I spent a good chunk of time planning and building the later part of the map, and then I spent a while working on some sound effects, there not implemented, and the volume is way off so idk if you can here it in the video. if you are reviewing this session shoot me a dm for the audio or, I will probably spend the next session implementing it, so it might be there too. Im very sick rn so sorry if its hard to hear what im saying or if I seem kinda out of it lol
added a pixel shader, made UI symbols and backgrounds, and just general bug fixing and value testing!

I got the radiation system working!!!!!!!!!! this was a really tough part but its finally working, I still have ways I want to improve it, and I still need tweak the values but I am SO happy its done. I also did some stuff related to my itch page, and figuring out mac exports.

redid the UI for the prosthetics shop, I still need to make new icons tho, I also made money actualy work! now we can only but things if we have the required funds, and when we do, the cost is removed from out money!
I modeled stuff and worked on the dialouge on the second robot
I made it so that the players height is dependent on whether they have legs or not, I spent a bit longer on this because I wanted to ,=make sure it didnt interfere with future animations.
I made a ladder model, and I made it so that the climbing is based on an area 3d seperate from the colision shape, this way I can make the ladder feel a little better to climb by extending the area3d
I finally have waves that I dont hate! idk how im going to do buoyancy, but we will worry about that later.
I made it so that the game pauses when you open the buy menu, this way you cant move or cast!

I did the brainstorming and planning and Im really happy with what I decided on! I also made my pull request. I made a video showing everything off but the size limmit isnt letting me use it, for now I will just put a quick clip of my miro board :( I also did some work on paper but I dont know how to show that and I ended up scrapping it anyways.
wanted to make sound effects, turns out its very hard :(
settings menu!!
bugs and more save system stuff.
I got buoyancy partially working with the Gerstner waves!
value changes and testing.
after some debugging I got the hand working again!

I made two sound effects from scratch (recourding, editing layering etc...), I think Im starting to understand the software a bit more, then I implemented them and did some fancy suff with the secondairy sound effect I made. happy with how everything turned out, I think all the time I spent fiddling with the sounds paid off.
new building and I have two robots now!

I hated how the icons looked and decided to photobash some images instead, I added some damage manually after I did the layering and editing, pretty happy with the result, I think it will match the theme of the game nicely!!

I redid the math that the fishing is based off of. after a lot of tinkering, I realised that the reason it felt so bad before was because I was setting the value of line strength (the furthest right progress bar) to fishpull + pullforce instead of adding fishpulll + pullforce. Now it actually feels how I imagined!! I also got the loose condition working :)
I made a cargo ship model and then implemented it into my game! I tried to do material glow, but I settled on using lights instead. I think this turned out to be a good choice.

Finished the player controller and added a start up menu! had to redo the menu because I made it with words, this is going to take some getting used to. I had some issues with video compression, hope that the 4mb thing gets changed :(
I implemented the sounds I made last session, I ended up doing it twice because the way I did it originally didn't sound very good.
I made it so that you can skip the first cutscene, then I redid most of the UI on the main menu and added a few things. had an issue with mouse pass/ignore settings but its working now
made a new camera shake script and make it shake when a fish is caught!!
I made a covered bridge!!!
I fixed the fishing rod clipping, added jump animation, and made the speed of the walk animation match the players velocitiy!
I got basic saving and loading set up!
Boxes * 3, and they float!!
new arm sprite
modeled and textured an npc, setup there interaction with the player, and did some bug fixes with the ladders and casting.
you ride the boat now
spent 45 min on a mistake (had to toggle one button), was very boring. on a positive note, we can buy bait now!
arm fixes, decals, and dying!!
made shop icons and learned about Godot themes, I have the buttons working a bit more how I imagined but I will definitely be tweaking them in the future.

added cutscene, though it looks bad and you cant leave it. it made a tone of bugs i had to fix. I also added the ocean sounds, though I didnt make the sounds, implementing took a while because of how I do the intro comic. after trying a few different solutions I finally got it working
I made tent raft!! modeled, textured, and made it float!
I made the first fish!
I started working on the fishing rod and lure, I had a bug with instantiating, turns out I was preloading the lure script, not the scene. working now though!

Description:
Cavern's edge was always a dream of mine, achievable yet unattainable due to time barriers, When juice started I had this amazing idea of a game which was based on Dreams and Cakes, I added the cake part later when I realized I would reach shanghai the same day as my birthday. I started with programming all the elements in the ecosystem of my game and later created levels, the environment is still half-baked and I have not yet used all of the objects but my dream is to make this big! The graphics are inspired by sub-pixel art which seem interesting to me, the shader does it's job perfectly. At the end the game looks almost exactly as I wished it to look like.
It's a dream in the making!

I added Coyote timer, variable jump, buffer jump and fixed some parameters for player walking
ok so I implemented a checkpoint system but now the dynamic camera system broke, I am trying to fix it or else I would have to shift to a normal camera system

I added a lot of new stuff, like lasers that you can pass through if you are dashing, I also added an enemy that follows you if you are in front of it, also added a test path following enemy, also added an intelligent slime enemy that bursts if you are in it's range

Also fixed the box where, the player was able to pass through it, also fixed the moving platform with spikes, the raycasts messed them up, also added a controllable platform and a rest state to it.Also added a new laser with raycasts the player can stop by standing on them or placing boxes over it. also added a no dash zone and also now with the powerup the player also gains double dash and jump. Added Day Night Cycle, Improved visuals by adding occluders to obstacles and lights to flares, also added a red death effect on death
Nothing works lol, I will have to spend some time debugging this so that I dont just inflate the hours with my debugging

Ok so I have the stage set up for ledge climbing and hanging, I just need to code some logic!

I tried my best to find a solution to these errors but no luck, I tried everything

So I worked on the wall climb which is still half finished, wall grab is a bit glitchy as well but wall slide works fine as of now, It is my first time with state machines so i am still getting the hang of it!
Added 3 things, A danger mirror that shows spikes and other obstacles in the mirror world, also added a bubble that can carry the player as well as a object that slows the time of everything down

Description: Depthscend is a dungeon crawler game where you control 3 characters at once and you have to fight enemies to clear rooms. There are abilities and we plan to add multiple weapons, more abilities, enemies and atleast one boss fight. The first game idea was also a dungeon crawler but there you only had 1 character, the world was less magical and money was a really important aspect of it, after some back and forth with my teammates we settled on the idea that the current game is based on. Which kept the dungeon crawler style, but added the 3 characters, set the environment to be underwater and added magic.

juiceStretches.description: after lots and lots and lots of trial and error with shaders and backbuffercopies i finally managed to create a backbuffercopied shader that can clip tiles + worked on a pause menu that can take the player to the main menu and resume the game (no options menu yet)

starting to get the hang of shaders, enemy hit effect (took me a long time because i did not understand how the animation system worked)

stick tilemap, dirt patch tilemap extension, tree shadows (wanted to create it with a shader but couldnt fix the uv clipping issues), removed islands from the tutorial to not make it look so packed

fixed an issue with the explosive orb ability that let the character damage enemies without actually attacking, added the explosion animation to the orb on hit, cthulhu enemy, that attacks, had some issues with it's movement animations and they are still a bit scuffed, + created another island in the tutorial
finally finished the chest for the levels outside of the tutorial, it gives a random ability which can either be picked up or replaced with the current abilty.
"soul tear" ability that releases 4 soul fragments that when it touches a player it heals them but if it touches an enemy it damages it.

fixed an issue with duplicated nodes playing an effect on both instances instead of only one, dirt texture in tutorial, tutorial expansion, slight rework for character1's damage (it now uses a basedamage and maxdamage variable but I didn't showcase it because functionality remains the same but it's easier to expand upon)
randomly orientated tiles, orientation based on a shader, shader also gives a slight movement to the tile, extra tutorial decoration

fixed switching characters reseting the character's attack (2 deleted lines), took me 8 minutes because I completely missed this part of the code (+ scripts for previous OMG moment)
lightning orb ability update, shaders, remade tileset because of camera scaling issues
Created a very simple projectile system, a training dummy for damage testing, a very simple mellee system
created sound effects with chiptone and audacity, wrote scripts to use them, explosion
priestess character now faces the next pathfinding position + healing circle

rooms created for "tutorial2" - now it's the entire game, pressure plate script, pressure plate texture, heal altar script + textures, + some bug fixes regarding enemy movement (contact for more info if needed), balancing changes

added WASD movement override to the first character and started working on the tutorial level
edited the character's movement animation (so it is actually animated now)

rewrote some things on the tutorial's characterscript to restrict character switches when the player has to use the third character, had to create a tileset from previously used textures so that the bridge looks better, on the flying dummy i had to create a new frame so the animation would look smoother, + decoration
ai pathfinding, ai death and damage on player, death screen, background, health texture, custom cursors

created a "puzzle" that requires the characters to work together and break the orbs in a given amount of time (represented by the grey and purple flowers) which opens the portal to the second part (WIP) of the tutorial
log obstacle texture, brick fence tileset, bridge tileset, a part of the brick fence takes damage, after that it gives access to the other characters

Tutorial charged attack with better charge animation, chest with ability charm that gives the tank character a groundslam ability that damages more and has a bigger range, also fixed rubberbanding and jittery movement

updated godot project from 4.3 to 4.4 which caused a few issues mainly roundings which had to be fixed, tutorial2 basics are complete, door texture, tutorial1 gives char2 ability, abilities can be dropped at chests (bug turned feature)
added 2 sprites, pathfinding movement that avoids objects, health bar that scales with the players current health
created a very basic menu which will be improved, the very basics of the multi character movement is "complete"
dirt textures, particles for flowers, trees, butterfly floaty shader and particles,
inklet enemy (very similar to slime)

charged attacks for character1, expanded the tutorial

juiceStretches.description: got the dialogue to work! sort of... added referenceRects to help and I decided that since it's really only npcs that are having dialogue nodes, i would just keep the interact signal not global and later when i instance npcs as a whole, it'll work ... i think ... each dialogue node is still instanced though, bc an npc will have multiple! had to fix some of the positioning (now based on some exported vars per each npc instead of hard coded px size yay) and some other things ... dialogue is taking way too long T^T also still wondering whether i want interact range and dialogue visible range to be the same or not ahhhh
drew an npc and some button prompts, had them y-sort properly + have a detection range

honestly the bulk of this time was spent on a couple large errors that I just could not fix -> first was scaling bc I added the first ui elements on a canvas layer and they weren't scaling and i changed the game settings to be 1080p, i just changed camera scaling after a coupld of hours -> second was collision problems with the camera which i spent so many hours just trying different methods, classes, node types, signals and just everything though it still wouldn't work QAQ i did get the camera node made though, and i can open it correctly so that's nice, just gonna switch to working on other things now and come back to this sometime else :sob:

fixed dialogue things: having multiple dialogue scripts for one npc and making sure they are triggered properly bc they were triggering immediately for some reason. also skipping conditions for taking photo for now, but if photo is taken, marks story item as done -> added part in dialogue node that will show confirmation before 1st img + increases character variable gacha token for gacha token later :DDDDD also changed the dialogue scene for the images within the chat bubble itself to function off a single animated sprite with each img being a frame of an animation instead of the different sprite2ds i had before
made a new node to detect interaction that checks for space / click (toggleable) within a certain area + instanced in door node and npc to replace previous interaction detector
got the base tile map to work with y-sort functioning, world and camera borders, and player movement with acceleration

today was mostly getting ready the final art -> a lot of file organizing ahhhhh and started on making a theme for the godot nodes (? took a long time and i'm still so confused ) ... continued working on the gacha node, made clear indicators for pulling again if the player has enough currency and also not allowing if they don't have any at all .. also actually used control nodes sort of correctly for the currency count which took so long T^T a large part of that was also making a whole custom font from different pngs QAQ (very annoying i recommend making an font like it is actually meant to be made :smiley: but hey! it's pretty!) think imma work on a canvas mechanic next though so ending this here
drew + implemented a door that connects the player to another scene ... had so many errors that needed to be fixed QAQ

made a new (v imp) node: story item! will interact with camera (not made yet ._.) but for now it should change visuals once it is visible +  signals. also added new things to dialogue manager to organize variables (have to connect different parts of story to each other) and made an array for specifically main npcs (set w/ export var in dialogue :D)

made the navigation for the big story part! same doors as before, but its delayed so it loads a different scene (bus one) and then the targeted one. set different game mode for this to have different navigation too :D currently automatically loads into the next scene after dialogue is finished but will have a timer + smooth transition in final prob :3 big changes big changes T^T

nothing actually works yet but I don't have any more time today so i'm just submitting this:
working on making the dialogue node instancable (?) so it can be used with more than one npc using a global dialogue script that manages all npcs and their storyline (multiple dialogues w/ each one being a different interaction)
things are broken rn bc of detached signals but I will see if I can fix it tmr!
made a dialogue system when user interacts (space/ click the npc) with the npc, follows user movement

grindinggggggg to make it in man ... all nighter let's gooo QAQ ... :sob: anyway connecting everything together (so many errors here oml i could not find what i was doing wrong) + putting in final art for everything, making the scenes themselves with everything instanced, making the rooms and formatting everything, ahhhhhhh prob make it fully finished tmrrrr (connect the doors + title screen + other minor stuff? ... i'll see when i get there)
fixed some things w/ switching scenes and character spawning ... took so long to find what was causing the errors T^T mostly changed some variable assignmetns / organization

worked on the story item a bit more + redid the variables for npc stuff (separate dictionaries bc it's just easier ig Q.Q rip arrays in arrays i did not want to work with you) anyway now it only appears after the last dialogue (with a main npc so i can have side ones) that was played is the one the item is corresponding too from the correct npc! :DDDD

started sketchbook node! drawing / redrawing / editing assets, properly formatting everything, setting up buttons and layers, getting the drawing itself to work properly with _draw function , getting them to stay the same color and width instead of changing everytime that variable changes (bc of how draw works) QAQ ... things not working anytime i add something new ahhhhhhhhhh im going crazy
