Description:
Sylvoria
Building Sylvoria was one of the most challenging and satisfying projects I've ever undertaken. I knew from the very beginning that I didn't just want to cobble together a generic RPG, I wanted to create a polished, engaging experience which was easy to play and tidy under the hood.

The most challenging thing to do was implementing the core systems, and mainly the scene manager and quest system. The scene manager had to handle fluid switching between the different parts of the game world without breaking immersion. It took a lot of iterating to make it perfect; addressing memory management, fade-ins, saving states, everything mattered.

The questing system was another beast altogether. I wanted it to be able to branch, monitor progress, and have dynamic conversation, all without having to hardcode every possible scenario. After a few early failures, I ended up deciding to implement a modular quest handler that pulled from JSON data, which made it a cakewalk to add new quests later.

There were days the code wouldn't cooperate and nights I stared at bugs for hours… but seeing the game come together, piece by piece, made it all worth it. Sylvoria taught me more about game development than any tutorial could ever possibly hope to, especially the importance of persistence and troubleshooting when creating something from the ground up.

Description:
Trench of Shadows - Memma & Fralas

"In a parallel world, would you come to Shanghai with me?" asked Memma. And that’s how we started developing Trench of Shadows.

We spent a week figuring out the core mechanics, setting up GitHub, and configuring all the necessary tools. Each of us worked hard every single day, and after a month, the game was finally complete.

Development was a thrilling yet challenging journey. Learning Unity and exploring its features was no easy task, but it was incredibly rewarding. Throughout the process, we gained valuable skills, faced countless obstacles, and, of course, shouted a few bad words along the way.

But in the end, every effort was worth it. Trench of Shadows is not just a game—it’s the result of passion, dedication, and countless hours of hard work.

Description: House of Whimsies is an interactive map environment game. Navigate through the city for fuel coins.

I’ve got this idea for a game where you roam around, looking for a mysterious door that leads to another world or dimension.

I actually got into game dev a while back, just exploring and learning—not working on this particular game. At first, I was just doing it on my own, and honestly, it got overwhelming without any clear goal or challenge to keep me going.

But then I joined this “Juice” event, and that changed things. Even though I didn’t hit the full 100-hour mark, I still learned so much—especially about game mechanics, which I’d never really paid much attention to before. What surprised me the most was how much I enjoyed it. It really pushed me to think creatively and technically, and it kind of reignited that spark.

Now I actually feel motivated to get back into it—and this time, maybe even start building a proper game like the one I’ve been thinking about. Doesn’t have to be perfect—just something I can be proud of.

Description: It all started when I was traveling. In the middle of the journey, I saw a notification on my phone. I opened it, and it turned out to be the introduction to Juice. At that moment, I thought,"I can do this. I can create games. Since I love playing games, why not create one?"However, my exams had started, and I was always thinking about how I could make the game, especially the planning part. At first, my plan was to push through the last 10 days, working 10 hours a day. But since I was in the middle of my exams finals, to be specific there was also the pressure to perform well.  That’s when Thomas really helped me reflect on what I was trying to achieve. In game development, you can’t just give 10 hours a day if you’re a beginner(you have to give yourself time). He motivated me to start right away, and that motivation hit hard. I began, and after a few days, I completed my 100 hour goal. When I saw that three-digit number, it felt like heaven. It made me truly realize that “Yesterday is history, tomorrow is a mystery, but today is a gift. That is why it’s called the present."Master Oogway

So, it finally worked! At first, I didn’t think it would. When I came up with the idea, I thought it was simple, but I wanted to make it more unique. The concept was similar to existing games, but with a twist—players would collect only the fruits needed for a specific juice recipe. My biggest challenge was handling the scene. I tried creating it separately and importing it into the code, but it didn’t respond. I struggled with different methods, but nothing worked. After multiple attempts, I finally got it to function. Once that was resolved, I moved on to the fruit collection system, which was easier. The recipe would be shown in images, and players had to collect the right fruits. Creating pixel art for the game was fun, and implementing the collection mechanic was smoother. Initially, adding groups and using different techniques didn’t work, but switching to global variables finally solved the problem. Now, everything runs as expected

But if it touches the platform, the chain resets. If the block neither touches the platform nor crosses the area, it gets reset.

Description:
Before the hackathon officially began, we were required to spend 100 hours developing a game in advance. By the time we arrived at the venue, we had already completed a game with that time. However, we quickly realized that the game wasn’t nearly as polished or engaging as we had hoped—it simply wasn’t fun to play.

So, during the three-day event, we made a bold decision: to start over from scratch.

With barely any sleep each night, we poured all our energy into building a brand-new game within those 72 hours. What we created during that time is something we’re incredibly proud of. In fact, the core concept of the new game was directly inspired by the theme of the event—Juice.

juiceStretches.description:
I've spent many days, constantly making changes, and finally created a version that I'm relatively satisfied with. Although it might not sound much different from the previous versions, it seems that's just how music production is. After spending a lot of time making changes, you might find that the previous version was better, and then revert back to the original version haha.
I've added some different effects and sounds, which are somewhat different from before! (But I'll probably keep making changes in the future haha)

I made a BGM for a game, and this is my first time trying to create music with a creepy and eerie atmosphere ( I swear this is the first time I’ve made something so chilling, haha ). It took me a long, long time... I hope it works well in the game 🙏🏻

This is the third background music I've made for the game! Every time I make music for a horror game, I have to research for a long time... it's really unfamiliar to me. But I think I'm slowly improving. I hope my skills will get stronger and stronger in the future🥹
Starting from 0 for the whole game, I made various scene realizations and some art adjustments!

Finally... I’ve completed the last one, I’m so moved🥹 This time, I made the fourth and final background music demo for the game. I hope they’ll like it, and I also hope these tracks will be put to good use!
This is a part of background music of our game.

I made this for our game's background music.

Description: My game, Untifted is like a 2D platformer but the world is 3D, you only see a slice of the world a time and have to navigate with normal controls in combination with rotating the slice by 90d.

juiceStretches.description: Layers, game on itch.io

This took so long! I started by organising and rewriting most of the code because it was getting really hard to work on. Now it uses some really neat tricks I learnt/invented mostly so that everything runs in the right order. Here is where I struggled the most, there just isn't a very good way to construct complex entities of many components but in the end bundles help alot.

Then I separated the debugger (what I called the editor previously but it doesn't edit anything) into it's own window, now it's more practical to use because I can look at it and the game at the same time.

Implemented physics and a very (I mean very) basic player controller (just WASD). It also comes with debug info when the debugger is enabled.

Then I added support for a texture atlas on blocks, so now I can easily chose different textures. I had to handwrite a mesh, the vertices, uvs and indices, because the default cuboid is messed up. The groundwork is also ready to support a different texture on each face.
Beginning of a level editor, also some background work on the game for the next sessions.
Menu and game app states, both with basic UI for entering and exiting.

Now only blocks in the slice are visible, with animation! This session is so long because I started by implementing physics, collision and movement from scratch (so fun), but felt I needed this first. The next session will be just finishing those.

- Drew some art, basic ground, mario-style pipes, a character and spikes.
- Fixed a bug where I was actually just placing new blocks instead of editing.
- Fixed the save shortcut.
- Cleaned up the info in the debugger.
- Added a visible player (the collision box was already there)
- Fixed the filtering of blocks not happening the first time (just runs every frame now).
- Generalised the block code so that I could use it on the player too.
- Removed tonemapping because this is a 2d game.
- Started building the first level.
Editor keyboard shortcuts and debug display

Player movement state machine! Now I can run and jump around the plane with gravity in the down direction regardless of plane rotation. It's so fun even thought not perfect but I love it.

I really struggled with this because I'm don't know physics well and the way Rust/Bevy are, dynamic dispatching was hard until I just put everything in one function.

Organised some of the debugger UI code and added a text for the state machine state.
Levels save now :)
Texture selector for the editor in the debugger.

Really long session because I did many things simultaneously (I will really try to do shorter stretches from now on):
- Switched from a 2D camera to an 3D orthographic camera and set up the coordinate space and window. Now the game runs with nice world units (1 per block/tile) at the right resolution (320x180) and scaling (current hardcoded to 5).
- Switched from tiles to blocks (they continue to look like tiles in game). Had to manually write UV maps (not fun).
- Implemented animated rotation, OMG it's so smooth! It started out with so much vector and quaternion math involved while I was learning but gradually I reduced it to basically nothing.
- Moved the editor into the game, and added an origin gizmo.
- Added a screen for the editor, and game subscreens for the loading, playing and paused states.
- Enabled native Wayland windows.
Redid the editor orbit zoom pan camera controller, to be more intuitive and to understand the code better (previous one was copied). Added axes gizmos.

Refactored the texture selector buttons to use observers on the `Pointer` trigger, instead of `Interaction` component on an `Update` system, because that is getting deprecated in the next release.

Changed the block mesh to work kinda like a billboard. And now it has a different texture atlas index per each of the three faces. Also disabled backface culling for this to work.

Added a few debug axes to the camera and camera rotation plane.

Wrote a game file loader and level file loader, still quite basic but it loads `~/.untifted/game.json` to read the level and then loads `assets/$level.json` to spawn the blocks.

And then I added texture atlas index editing to existing blocks.

Now I think I can move on to the player controller and start having a playable game finally!

Nothing finished but I need to feed my egg and won't be able to Juice in the next few hours, so here goes: Started drawing some sprite art, loading and unloading of level data, and a viewport-to-world cursor.

Placing blocks! The basics are working, there are a few small things I need to fix later.

Btw it's laggy in the video but that's just because of having OBS running, it runs really smooth otherwise.
Initial setup, simple player movement.

Description:
Castle Hardcore 
You are a exiled barbarian who is always looking for thrill. While being adrenaline deficient, you stumble upon an ominous looking castle. Your eyes glisten with blood pumping throughout your body. You are ready to take on this adventure. Go on, pickup your sword and fight those monsters to pump up your heart's desire

Our team has had the biggest learning experience. We learned about state machines, revised and beautified our code countless times. And did it all together, as a team. We had a goal in mind, to make it unforgiving, and we think we really delivered on it. There were some sleepless nights and burnout days but it was still all worth it

Description:
This is the first time I've ever made a game, and Juice was one of the most fun coding experiences I've had! I learned so much about game development, from how game engines work (we used Godot) to working with tilemaps and procedurally generated levels. 

Asgard's Draw is a top-down 2D pixel art RPG game. The objective of the game (currently) is for the player to go around the world, solving randomly placed puzzles and completing dungeons scattered across the world. 

The game uses a procedurally generated world map with over 16 million tiles, a plethora of different biomes that the player can travel through, and a collection of dungeons. Combat is card-based, and puzzles work by having the user push boxes around to disable forcefields and reach the end. Dungeons typically have a collection of puzzles and combat encounters that grow more and more difficult the longer you play. I hope you enjoy our game!

juiceStretches.description:
ive been cooking so much in the last couple of days!! :D
NOTE: half of the things in our project are crashing rn because of our broken save system, so i'm just going to show the snow particle effect in my video

- finished procedural world generation (it looks like real continents. i cant show it because the game's crashing since we're working on adding saving right now but that doesn't work)
- added dungeon and POI (point of interest) location generation (still working on actually adding the dungeons though)
- added rain/smoke/snow/spark particle effects
- working on adding a water shader
- added world boundaries inside the game so the player can't walk on water anymore
- moved all my WIP code into the main git repo
- started adding chunk loading/unloading
- we are working on a save system now
- reorganized the folder structure a LOT

After hours and hours of trying and failing to create a procedural terrain system, I finally created a minecraft-esque generation system. It's super fast, and generates HUGE maps (it prioritizes the closest chunks first, and then generates the rest in the background). There's almost no performance lag now, and this is something I can probably put into the loading screen at the beginning. I still need to add building/other terrain features like mountains
Started working on boundaries!!

After hours and hours of trying to get it to work, I'm finally on the right track for the procedural map generation 🥳
I had to get rid of the chunk system since it doesn't work with the fractal generation map system I'm using. Maybe I can get it back in the future? It's not a #1 priority though. I also got it to print the percent so hopefully one of us can get a loading screen setup
user can't go on water anymore. took me a while to figure out how raycasts work lol
fixed up box pushing mechanism and added wasd at the beginning. also cleaned up ui a bit and increased movement speed.
Finished adding rain, snow, and lightning effects
Scrapped the original idea for how levels work and we're moving to a procedurally generated world. First attempt :)
Finally got a base save system working with the existing code. This is going to need a huge overhaul once Juice ends.
Finally got the base movement controller and puzzles down!!!
Overhauled UI, and added pause and restart buttons for the level.
I unironically spent the last 8 hours trying to get the player character to animate. At least some of it works 😂
Completely revamped generation using OpenSimplex and a square gradient image. Much more natural continents now. I also implemented a water depth system (as you can see in the video)

Description:
Space Hitchhiker Stop:
"At first, this was going to be a mix between Paper's Please & Papa Louie games, but in the end I decided to get Paper's Please out of the image and improvise. The game doesn't have a lot of story, you're basically an alien and your ship is a Space Hitchhiker Stop (& also Gas Station, but without the Gas), you live here and attend all the customers that come, you must resuply the store and you can also upgrade it for it to be more efficient at money making! The end goal is to get yourself enough money to retire.

At first it was going to be a group project, with me and another guy, but that dude baited and I've had to do this with 0 coding experience, It's been fun, It's also angered my and made me pretty frustrated, but in the end it's given me a more broad view of what coding is and how it's done, now I may feel a bit burnt out from it, but I'm sure that in the future I'll more motivated on creating new games & experiences!
Now that it's complete I am very excited to attend Juice." - La Popi <33

Description:
Farmworks
After a shipwreck, you find yourself stranded on a deserted island with nothing but a few scattered resources and some old, rusting tools from a broken-down hut. But you're no ordinary survivor—you’re a farmer. Armed with your agricultural know-how, you set out to cultivate the land, raise chickens and cows, and carve out a life for yourself, completely cut off from the outside world.

The Making of Farmworks:
Farmworks is inspired by my love for farming games, particularly titles like Stardew Valley. I’ve always wanted to create a game that captures every little detail of farming while adding unique elements like fishing, dairy production, and even juice-making.

Initially, the concept was entirely different—I planned a game about farming light in a dark, mysterious world. But as development progressed, I realized it was too complex and niche for the scope I had. I’d previously made a farming game with a magical theme for a game jam (which won first place!), so I thought, why not build on that experience? This time, I wanted a broader, more immersive take on farming—something that could stand out from other games in the genre.

With Juice providing the perfect opportunity, I dove in. I scoured YouTube for useful tutorials, found incredible assets on Itch.io, and got to work. Laying the foundation—building core mechanics and defining the character—was the hardest part. But once that was in place, development picked up speed.

In the 100+ hours I’ve spent on this game, I managed to implement farming, harvesting, and raising chickens and cows. While I couldn’t squeeze in all the features I envisioned—like a juice factory, stables, trading, or fishing—Farmworks still captures the essence of what I set out to build: a farming experience that feels detailed, rewarding, and uniquely my own.

I also made a website for showcasing the game: https://farmworks.irtaza.xyz/

Description:
Before the hackathon officially began, we were required to spend 100 hours developing a game in advance. By the time we arrived at the venue, we had already completed a game with that time. However, we quickly realized that the game wasn’t nearly as polished or engaging as we had hoped—it simply wasn’t fun to play.

So, during the three-day event, we made a bold decision: to start over from scratch.

With barely any sleep each night, we poured all our energy into building a brand-new game within those 72 hours. What we created during that time is something we’re incredibly proud of. In fact, the core concept of the new game was directly inspired by the theme of the event—Juice.

juiceStretches.description: I created a baby monster and a pacifier. The monster's effect is that it reverses the player's movement—when the player inputs forward, they will move backward instead. The player can stop the boss by pressing F to pick up the pacifier, which will be stored in the inventory. Then, by going near the monster and pressing E, the monster will disappear, and the pacifier will be consumed.
I add the model and the animation for the character.
We stayed up late and finally successfully implemented unity realtime editing collaboration and created the first character

I made two types of chests. The first is an normal chest that players can open by pressing the e key, and the other is a mimic chest. When the player gets close and presses the e key, player will be freeze, unable to move, and will be taking damage.
Made a door model
I created a Title Screen for our game.

The biggest challenge when writing this music was how to express the complete story in a short time. Ending music is usually not too long, so each note must convey the desired emotion accurately. I kept trying different melodies and orchestrations, listening and adjusting them over and over again to make sure it fit the theme of the game and resonated with the players.
I created a monster that will jumpscare the player if they don't hide in a cabinet when it appears.
This is my first time using this software to create music. It took me some time to get familiar with the interface and operations, but in the end, I successfully created a bgm for our game.
I made a model of the table and added textures.

I've added a new jumpscare. When the player opens the wrong door, a jumpscare will occur. I also updated the previous monsters so that during the jumpscare, the player's movement will be restricted. Additionally, I fixed some bugs to prevent errors when the previous monsters are generated.

I later chose to use Playmaker to rebuild the character. Now, the character's jumping speed varies when crouching, walking, or running. Additionally, when crouching, the character will be blocked by obstacles instead of standing up and clipping through them.

Description:
Ossatura
Ossatura is a Rhythm Game RPG made by a small team of high schoolers from Southern California. 
We started making Ossatura with inspiration from indie RPGs such as Undertale, Deltarune, Omori and Oneshot, and combined that influence with our collective love of music!
In our game, you play as a skeleton navigating the afterlife after a tragic accident to find his former band members and friends.
However, to find them, you must fight in music-inspired battles with a variety of enemies, ranging from a duck with a violin to a crocodile with a harp!
Making our game was an incredible adventure, and while very stressful at times, was 100% worth the effort, both in terms of how our game turned out and the memories we made together making it.
It's incredible how two months can change a person, and we all feel like we've truely accomplished something incredible working together.
We hope players enjoy our original, made in-house soundtrack, our fun, rhythm-based battle system, and our (still under development) world and story.

juiceStretches.description:
-Pause menu!
   - Spent way too much on time on this following tutorials that were either incomplete or bad
   - Honestly kinda disappointed w myself because I've literally made a pause screen before for Counterspell
   - Things learned:
      - CanvasLayer is powerful, I should really look into how it works more
         - I spent hours trying to figure out how to pass the pause menu between cameras & scale it up and down, which was all made totally irrelevant when I used a CanvasLayer
      - Shaders are crazy, but also really complicated - I want to look into them in the future to add polish
         - Background - The blur effect on the pause screen is accomplished with a really basic shader that I had fun fiddling with
         - I tried to make a better one but couldn't figure out the basics & ended up going with one I stole from a tutorial D:
-Basic Save & Load!!
   - Oh my god is this complicated
   - I have no experience w data serialization, different file formats, all of the above
   - Godot tutorial docs saved me, but still spent so many hours banging my head against a wall
   - Right now saving saves player health, player position, and current map
   - Todo currently is make saving save what enemies have been defeated, any changes to playerstats, etc. but I have a good backbone now
   - advice to anyone making a save/load system - use the system from the godot docs saving game tutorial, and have an global node that controls saving and loading, and have an extensive list of everything you need to save & load & how it would work

Despite struggling more as the project size increases / fighting burnout & a bit of impostor syndrome, I'm really happy w how our game is turning out!
Shoutout to my team members putting in hours on art, code, & music I would have gotten demotivated at the 2 hr mark without yall <3

- Update to main menu UI
- Spent way too much time creating pixel portraits of devs
- Started work on scene transitions - lots of theory but currently not much to show
- Helped codevs implementing & fixing their projects, had my old horrible code dredged up & patched ( also took way too much time )
Music update is soon!!

added new mechanics to combat w precision zones!
Almost done with particles - currently they're semi random, but I have a solution in mind after a couple hours of work
Should be done tomorrow!

Kinda lost track of what I was doing for all these hours?
A lot of backend work, for sure - had to redo a lot to get new music in
And then I had to manually map out like 104 notes for a single attack, and map out tracks and paths for the attack!
It looks cool asf, but it's grueling work & I want to perish
One more step towards 30 min gameplay though!

Stuff done:
1. One track is done! 
Apparently I'm going to need to manually extract & enter timestamps for every song in the game...
(Unless the composition software unbreaks in the next 24 hours lmao)
So there may be a submission or 2 of me just mindlessly pressing buttons in Audacity D:
Unfortunately, it takes a very long time to get good results (i'm a perfectionist) & there isn't really much to show?
Other than lists of numbers like [6.723, 7.003, 7.282, 7.559, 7.840, 8.118, 8.397, 8.676, 8.955, 9.235, 9.514, 9.791, 10.071, 10.350]...
However, it has to be my #1 priority for the next couple days, because it's the first step in rehauling combat.
Last thing for combat is hook up the new timestamp method to the note pattern arrays & we should be rolling!
2. FINALLY MAP IS FIXED!
Turns out the bug I have been tearing my hair out was caused by code I wrote, meant to delete, and forgot about...
Abt an hour's worth of debugging has finally lead to results!
Due to changing the map's z-index in a prior build, the y-sorting was breaking when a room was exited & reentered!
Very simple fix, deleted 1 line of code, but took me so long to find & fix the error D,:
Guess that happens more when working on larger projects, but I'm still mad about it

Added:
- Backend change for note BPM to add more music later
- Can now only hit one note at a time (bugfix)
- Added a target to gameplay to make timing obvious ( Playtesters consistently frustrated about vague timing )

Short session today, made enemies explode when they're defeated! 
I love godot's particle system, it's so easy to use
Will be back again later hooking up enemy data to the save system!

-Redid entire combat backend!
   -Based on timestamps instead of beats
   -Approx. an hr was honestly just reading docs & code, looking for a good way to rework the backend
      -Ended up going with timestamps because it was both relatively easy to implement & work with in the future & had some level of support built-in by the tools we already were using
   -Pros: Much easier to work with, allows for greater flexibility, more future-proof
   -Cons: More complicated / prone to breaking, may be hard to get accurate timestamps out of audio track
   -Extra cons for fun : I have a solid blueprint now, but the code is absolutely filled with hard-coded magic numbers! Next juice session is probably going to be removing as many of those as possible
   -Next step: I want to write some sort of tool to make it easier to get accurate timestamps out of music tracks, because the current way involves sending it thru the old method & a print statement D:

- Worked cooperatively with team members
   - Once again, explained a lot of horrible spaghetti code I wrote a month ago & reworked some of it
   - Struggled with github for a solid hour getting code merged
      - Seriously, a solid 45 min to an hour was struggling getting code into the main branch. I would've stopped the timer if I had known, but it was actually absurd how difficult Git can be sometimes

Made a basic metronome in Bosca Ceoli Blue, then figured out how to sync up ingame actions with audio using the RhythmNotifier from the Godot Asset Store, then used the path tool in Godot to make notes that would follow unique paths to the target and a rudimentary scoring system. Way harder than it appears!

Worked on settings menu for uhhh 5 hours?
I may have spent an extraordinary amount of time on this, burnout is real D:
Lots of ideas that seemed promising but ended up going nowhere
I now have an entirely revamped settings menu though!
Read a lot abt control nodes, did a lot of research on how they work & Godot's themes
Themes seem really powerful! I used the very basics but will do more soon
Settings are saved in an Autoload node & passed back & forth, currently they're not being used anywhere but that'll be next

I also have like 30+ min in here of me setting up a Steamworks acc for the game?
I figured that would be counted in the "website development" category but if it's not lemme know!

AUDIO SETTINGS FINALLY WORK!
Probably kinda important for a rhythm game, huh?
It was actually suprisingly easy to implement, once I figured out Godot had existing tools built in.
Around a half hour of (untimed) planning was rendered useless when I found out about AudioStreams / AudioServers!
And a half hour of timed work was rendered useless by an existing linear_to_db() function...
But hey, it's working now! All you can ask for at the end of the day.
Now I just need to do video & input!
Although I might switch gears & work on more actual gameplay?
Starting to get burnt out, IDK

Also:
Lot of bugfixes... as the project grows the bugs grow exponentially D:
& added a shield to combat! Should portray the rhythm section as "blocking" better!

Implemented an entire combat system!
I meant to do this in smaller uploads, but I was never satisfied enough to submit anything until now...
Here's the complete list of added features!
- Player health
- Enemy health
- Attack
- Heal
- Flee
- Enemy attack (Rhythm game)
- Healthbar logic (smooth animations)
- Background logic for multiple attack types
- QoL changes to the rhythm game

This was my first time really dealing with control nodes,
and my first time with any sort of turn based battler, so
I'm really happy with how it turned out!
I'm hoping to post a demo to Itch soon w my team, so keep an eye out!

Spent a whole lot of time debugging & optimizing to reduce lag
Added a new field to the attack datastructure to allow for predetermined lanes (like most rhythm games)

scene swaps works! I have hopefully a future-proof solution that swaps to a scene (that you can change in-editor) and moves the player to a position ( also changeable in-editor ) whenever the player runs into it.
Also considered updating to Godot 4.4, took a long list at the pros / cons, & decided that I'm too lazy lol
The fabled music update is not here yet but it will arrive Soon ( i hope )

Long session today, but got some really important work done!
- IDK if this counts, but I spent about an hour sitting down w my team & planning!
We now have a good schedule for what we need to do in the next 2 weeks to get 30 min of gameplay.
I have a good plan for what I'm getting done in the next week too!
Short list is:
- More settings! Although that's incredibly boring so I'm putting it off...
- More combat variations! Once we get music from our composer this weekend, we'll need new gameplay to spice up combat over time
- Full on leveling system? Still not sure abt this one, but doing more combat -> more HP & ATK can't be that bad

The rest of my time I spent overhauling our spawn area!
Our level design guy is currently sick & dying, plus isn't planning on going to Shanghai, so I may have taken his job...
Figuring out collisions & y-sorting was a lot of fun, but I spent way too long getting everything lined up correctly.
(I also may have had to totally remade the map from scratch in order to get everything sorted...)
(( In essence, I totally remade the map in order to make it look & feel nice in-game ))
Ah well, should make it easier to add stuff later on, now that I know what's needed!

In addition:
- Cowork with team on shaders, design choices, art, etc.
   - Shaders are crazy dude, should've used these earlier
- Changed combat backend to squash like ~7 bugs with the animation player
   - long story short, don't try to change camera position with code when you're using control nodes

Whole bunch of bugfixes to get the web version up to scratch!
The tool I was using to sync gameplay to music was not working at all on web.
This may have taken over an hour to figure out, as I thought it was an issue with the renderer instead of the code...
I eventually had to rewrite part of the code in a new web-specific branch to get a proper demo working!
I also added a lil thank you screen to the end :D

FINALLY EVERYTHING (mostly) WORKS!
My last couple of moments have been somewhat unproductive in terms of full results, but I managed to get everything working today!
As always, my biggest headaches were caused by small errors.
My issue with particle effects was caused by telling the particles to emit when they left the target, and turning off the collision at the same time.
This had the same effect as leaving the target! So the code ran twice without me realizing how.
As for my issues with branch merging, I managed to steal code from an older commit that wasn't corrupted!
It took a bit of work to get it fully working, but now our main branch is up-to-date and functional.
I'm very happy with the progress we've made so far!

Enemy data is now saved inbetween scenes!
Much more complicated than it looks, even with a save system prebuilt.
I wanted something that would let us keep using the same workflow for level design, which meant I had a lot to consider!
Ended up going with a solution that takes a list of all enemies in a scene, extracts the useful variables, and saves it to a singleton.
Then, on load, compares the original list of enemies, compares it to the saved list, and if there's a difference, deletes all the old enemies & creates new ones with the data provided.
Not a very easy solution to design! I spent multiple hours seeing if I could save them as objects, attach them to the save / load system directly, etc. but it didn't work due to my desire to have all the logic centralized.
However, this system should work on any map scene we make in the future, with any enemy type, and is easily extendible!
Currently the saves aren't actually attached to the save/load system because my brain is fried, but it can't be that hard, right?
Right?
(In reality I do have a plan to just get the data in the global save node, but honestly it'll probably break and take another 2 hours D: )

BREAKING 90 HOURS!
apparently all I needed was an unhealthy amount of energy drinks to get me motivated again
Because this is a long session, I'm gonna break down what I've been up to & what's still in progress hopefully as granularly as possible
1. Map changes!
A. Pathfinding!
Apparently all the work we did to get our enemies to have proper navigation was going completely to waste!
This was something we were kinda aware of but nobody bothered to fix as we had bigger issues.
I decided to take this on when waiting for our composer, & it turned out to be a simple fix!
All we needed was to enable debug mode on the pathfinding node to see the issue - they were attempting to pathfind through everything D:
I ended up separating the pathing to it's own separate layer & painting over the prebuilt maps, then making that layer invisible.
Took a while (30-45+ min, don't remember) for a super simple & easy fix that should work for everything!
B. Fixing the map!
Our map designer is back working with us again, so the placeholder might be gone in a bit, but I also spent a bit of time cleaning it up.
He's gonna use the placeholder as inspiration for the layout though, so I'm rather proud as a code guy :D
This was probably just like 15-25 min because I tried to set up a terrain for the trees and it Did Not Go Well so I ended up throwing it all out anyhow...
I did make it impossible to just walk through some of the objects though, which counts for something I hope!
2. Game Over screen!
When testing for bugs, I realized there was no death screen - the game just quit to desktop D:
So I whipped up one really quick, learned how animations work, and then put it into the game!
Took abt 30 min? not sure exactly, worked on this piecemeal over a couple days, could've been closer to an hour
2. MUSIC!
This is the big one. I got to spend like 3 hrs with our incredibly talented student composer to get the horrible placeholder music out of the game!
We now have some absolutely incredible overworld music for both the graveyard and the lake area, with more on the way for combat and other zones!
The combat music (as you can probably tell in the video) is totally screwy right now, but that's an issue with me & not him.
I'm so excited to get more of his music ingame & show off how incredible it is!
However, one major issue with the new music was it kinda broke my next point:
3. Combat!
We've had the horrible placeholder music ingame for so long that trying to change it has led to everything breaking...
Not to mention that I'm totally redoing the backend of combat to make it work with our new music.
Is this a smart thing to be doing the week before our game is supposed to release? Absolutely not!
Is it the only way I can implement enough of his work ingame to get to 30 min of gameplay? Probably!
I have spent 4 hours debugging esoteric errors and trying to remember what buffoon wrote all this horrible code & didn't comment it (it was me).
& as seen in the video, it's still not working!

Currently, I've broken the problem down into 2 big steps - get the music to play correctly, and get the notes to spawn correctly.
There's some issues with the music playing correctly (When the music loops, it totally breaks), but I got starting and ending on time to work as I expect.
Once I fix the way audio plays, I should be able to use something similar to my old implementation for note spawning?
It'll be a lot different with starting at arbitrary points in the passage, but I think I can do it pretty well if I just put in a few more hours!

It's so nice feeling everything falling into place, both with the project and with the whole Shanghai trip itself.
Off topic, but getting my visa in the mail today was unreal - like there's no way this is actually happening!
So to whoever reads this, thanks for your hard work & everyone's hard work getting an event like this working, it's honestly incredible & I'm hoping to meet you in Shanghai!

Spent like an hour working on different additions to the combat system, ended up scrapping most of them but I have a couple ideas thought out to implement next time.
Then I figured i'd take a quick break to merge a couple branches and get all of our team's work in one place, which mostly worked excellently but made one file unable to be parsed...
I still cannot figure it out & it's highly demotivating, which sucks
I'm clearly not going to figure it out tonight, so I'm just submitting these hours and going back to tackle it tomorrow

went through a whole bunch of revision, but there's now a very basic attack bar!
works undertale style - hit green do more damage
game is much more fun, hope to have an updated demo / website / itch page Monday!

Mapped out track #2!
Immediately ran into a bug - because of the new implementation, tracks are overlapping & spawning notes after they're supposed to stop D:
This was an easy fix, I just had to reinstance the rhythmnotifier for every melody :D
However, getting the right position in an array for the notes was MUCH harder...
I tried getting the position and matching it to the position in the array, but microsecond differences made that impossible!
I tried adding a field to the function I was calling, but that didn't work at first either!
After a whole bunch of fiddling with both ways, I finally figured out (in sheer desperation because it seemed stupid) that I could .bind an integer to the signal I was calling and adding a variable to the method I was calling!
This means THE COMBAT BACKEND IS FINALLY DONE!
All I need to do now to rack up gameplay minutes is map out the rest of the charts!!
Very exciting, game is 99% there!

Whole lot of work got done! ended up working w teammates on call for a really long time after I had already done some work day prior, so this is a big one!
- New features!
   - Bomb notes!
      - New animation when they get hit - small explosion
      - Hitting bomb notes does damage
      - Made a new material for the explosion, added a new field to the backend, etc.
         - Note: Currently no visual difference, waiting for a new sprite from artist
   - Visible paths!
      - Dashed line to show the path notes will follow
      - Figured out how to use tessellate to turn a curve2d into points for a line2d
   - Both were surprisingly easy, most of my time was spent on research & bugfixes
- More backend changes!
   - Got rid of magic numbers in backend
      - I'm dumb, issue was with settings I had changed in the node prior
      - Still haven't figured out how to get useable data out of music nodes, but i know a lot of ways that don't work now!
- Small visual polish!
   - Changed settings on all note particles until I was happy with them
   - Main menu has an animated sky now it's so pretty!!
- & finally more bugfixes!
   - Note target hitbox extended farther back than intended when combined with new changes, fixed by just making it smaller
   - Attack bar was totally broken & i didn't even realize! Only the critical portion would cause damage because I had my < & > flipped, rookie mistake

& sneak peek of music update in main menu :D 
our composer is actually incredible & my horrible placeholders sound even worse now

DONE:
- Started a GitHub repo with a blank project & couldn't import code
     - Ended up rewriting most of it because it was bad
- Readded all the old features 
     - (sync gameplay to music, target destroys notes & increases score)
- Added some new features!
- New melody / attack feature
     - Secondary music player that starts & stops on-beat & spawns notes
- New way of mapping attacks to music
     - Current implementation is somewhat sturdy, still hope to improve
- New testing audio tracks
     - Less likely to make my ears bleed out

Next goal is to work on a basic battle system & implement this into it!

~3 things done, but many lessons learned D:

1. Camera limits! 
There's not a super easy way to have a tilemap set these automatically, so I ended up using a combination of some old code from Godot 3 or something & magic numbers...
However, this should work for any future maps we make!
2. New zone!
Currently a prototype that I spent way too much time giving detail because it was horrible to look at and design, & the artstyle dissonance is horrible, but it's decent enough for now.
However, as soon as I made a new map, the camera limits broke totally D:
All the position numbers were off, the camera was positioned wrong, everything was horrible...
I had to redo the scene swapper & some associated code to fix it, but it works now!
3 (& 4 I guess) - Readded some features to combat!
Bomb notes are now back in-game, and all the notes have outlines!
I had to make them bigger too to increase visibility, and I also made the notes swap between two different sprites randomly.
This should give the game a more polished feel and help with gameplay!

Did a whole bunch of conceptual work, I have a lot of stuff totally planned that I just need to implement now with combat, scene loading, etc.
The thing that actually works is transitioning between combat & overworld!
Still kinda janky but I want to submit something rn for the tamagotchi lmao

-Redesigned combat UI - more polished, but still needs work 
(hitboxes are unclear without dev tools & note color scheme is hard to see)
-Improved backend of overworld -> combat transition
Still quite buggy, but very happy with the work so far!

This took way too long to do, but I finished up a backend system that allows for multiple attacks!
I tore out a whole bunch of hardcoded work I had done to get a basic prototype because I wanted it to be data-driven & easily modifiable later.
I managed to get the system working with a global dictionary set, so now it should be incredibly easy to sync together new audio tracks, new note patterns, and new paths for the notes to follow.
It took me WAY too much time to figure some of this out, but this'll save a lot of time and even more headaches later!

Description:
A theory of evolution,
Lets go back to the beginnings, its January 29th and me and my friend set out on an awesome adventure to make this cool game based on evolution. We planned on having all these cool and different mini adventures that we called levels. We originally split the work but sadly my teammate had other things to prioritize and had to leave juice, but credit for the original idea goes to him and kudos to him for letting me pursue this idea and go to a popup cafe. This game starts out as a fish and you adventure through treacherous and dangerous landscapes, to finally end up as a human who successfully invents the first car. (full gameplay is in video and feel free to check out code in the GitHub).

juiceStretches.description:
9 hours session
Additions:
Made a whole new monkey level with all the mechanics: Beehive, antsnest, rat, monkey movement and all of those animations and arts. Made vine climbing and made the void, added sound effect for walking. The vine climbing was the main hard part and i had to write like 400 lines for that and this entire session was atleast 1000 lines to get all the mechanics physics working better than unities normal physics and stuff. So id say 50% art session 50% technical/coding session am burnt out will do the actual level building next session which im looking forward to because no more coding hopefully if i use mechanics from other levels too.

### 5-Hour Game Development Session Log

**Session Focus: Bullet Collection System, Game Mechanics, Tilemap Updates, and Optimization**

---

**Hour 1: Bullet Collection System Implementation**

The session kicked off with a focus on implementing the bullet collection system. The goal was to create an interactive environment where shooting bullets would trigger a mechanism, specifically unlocking a door. This was a crucial game element, adding depth and challenge to the gameplay. However, right from the start, I ran into some issues with bullet physics. The initial design caused bullets to behave erratically, not properly colliding with surfaces or objects as expected. After some tweaking, I got the bullets to work, but the physical interactions were still not ideal—collisions didn’t always register correctly, and the bullets would sometimes fly through walls or even miss their targets entirely.

After quite a bit of trial and error with the physics engine and collision layers, I was able to fine-tune the bullet's behavior. The bullets now interact with objects and walls properly, and hitting the target door works as intended. It was a hassle, but I was able to finally get it functioning. 

**Hour 2: Sign Implementation and Communication**

Next, I focused on improving communication within the game, adding signs to indicate what is happening and warn players about potential dangers. I created simple, yet effective sign graphics that explain the mechanics of unlocking doors with bullets, as well as highlighting any obstacles in the area (such as spikes or traps). I worked with the tilemap to position these signs in key areas, ensuring they were both visible and informative. It was important to convey the message clearly, as players would need these cues to understand how the bullet mechanic worked and to prepare for hazards ahead.

**Hour 3: Tilemap Adjustments and Frog Placement**

I spent a considerable amount of time refining the tilemap. One of my main goals was to make the frogs more prominent in the game environment. Frogs are supposed to be one of the main environmental features, and I noticed that they were getting lost in the background. I tweaked the placement, behavior, and animations to make them more dynamic and noticeable. This added life to the level and further pushed the theme of the game. 

I also fixed a portion of the level that had been previously impossible to navigate. Players would get stuck, unable to progress due to an error I had overlooked. After identifying the problem, I adjusted the geometry and tile placements to allow smooth traversal, ensuring there were no dead ends or impossible obstacles.

**Hour 4: Spike Implementation and Player Challenges**

To increase the difficulty and prevent any cheating or shortcutting, I introduced spikes into the game. The spikes now kill the player on contact, adding an extra layer of challenge and ensuring players couldn’t bypass obstacles too easily. I placed them strategically, particularly in areas where players might try to avoid dangers or cut corners.

As a follow-up, I added a special section of the level where only the player character can fit through—a narrow space that requires them to navigate tight spots while avoiding hazards. This presented a new type of challenge: players now have to deal with collider-based challenges, requiring precision and careful timing. It provided a unique break from the regular gameplay and set up the next sequence of the level after the more difficult area.

**Hour 5: Final Touches, Optimization, and Bug Fixing**

The final hour was spent dealing with various bugs and compiling issues that had popped up throughout the session. Several optimizations were necessary to ensure the game ran smoothly, especially given the complexity of the bullet physics, tilemaps, and new elements like spikes and narrow spaces.

I spent a lot of time making sure the final version was as optimized as possible. This involved refining the asset loading, reducing unnecessary processes, and ensuring the game ran at a steady frame rate without major dips. I also fixed a lot of smaller bugs related to the new features—collisions with the spikes, the player getting stuck in tight spaces, and ensuring that the bullet mechanic triggered the door unlocking mechanism without failure.

Overall, this session was all about polishing the game’s core mechanics, tightening up the level design, and making sure everything was working together as smoothly as possible. There’s still a lot of work to be done, but I’m happy with the progress made today.
Fixed camera added sound effect (vine one) and the ground one was from last session i forgot to show off.

Made idle and walking animations for both player and horse, added animations in which was a hassle that i showed in the video wit the goofy ahh animater window, i also made both move and the horse riding system work which was the majority of the work and i scrapped 3 systems to make it work in the end.
made a working health system with hearts that kill you and the bird now doesnt deal damage even when not hitting you, ready to build level.
Made music for the fish level
Movement works and it is a bit buggy but i also spent a lot of time making an extra crouching thing to work and also a tilemap, this is the second evolution level.

### **5-Hour Game Development Session Write-Up**

---

**Session Overview:**
In today’s 5-hour development session, I focused on improving the level, adding new hazards like **sawblades**, implementing a **Void** mechanic for instant death, fixing UI and collision detection bugs, and adding a simple transition cutscene that hints at what happens next. Here's a detailed breakdown of what was accomplished:

---

### **Hour 1: Level Design and Layout**

I began by expanding the level design, creating a few new sections that would introduce more challenges for the player.

- **Level Layout**: 
  - I focused on balancing platforming challenges with obstacles, like **moving platforms** and **gaps** to jump over. The goal was to make the level feel fun but not too frustrating.

- **Hazard Addition**:
  - I added **sawblades** to some tricky areas of the level. These sawblades move back and forth, requiring the player to time their jumps and moves carefully to avoid getting hit.

---

### **Hour 2: Implementing the Void and Checkpoints**

Next, I implemented mechanics to make the game more challenging and rewarding.

- **Void Mechanic**:
  - I added a **Void** zone that instantly kills the player if they fall into it. This is a simple area where the player will be respawned at the last checkpoint, adding risk and forcing careful platforming.
  - The Void was implemented with a **trigger collider**, and a script resets the player position when they enter the Void.

- **Checkpoints**:
  - I also worked on the checkpoint system. I added checkpoints at strategic points in the level where the player can respawn if they die. 
  - The checkpoint system works by activating invisible checkpoint objects when the player touches them, which triggers a respawn at that point if the player dies.

---

### **Hour 3: Collision Detection & UI Bug Fixes**

I then shifted my focus to fixing various bugs that were affecting gameplay and the UI.

- **Collision Detection**:
  - I fixed issues with **platform collision detection**, making sure that the player character no longer clips through platforms or gets stuck in walls.
  - I adjusted the physics materials and colliders on platforms to prevent these problems from occurring.

- **UI Bug Fixes**:
  - I noticed some bugs with the **UI not loading properly** after respawning or transitioning between levels. I fixed the issue where UI elements, like the health bar or score, weren’t updating correctly.
  - I also cleaned up the **game over** screen to ensure it properly reset when the player respawned.

---

### **Hour 4: Simple Transition Cutscene**

At this point, I worked on a simple but effective **transition cutscene** that hints at the next part of the story.

- **Cutscene Design**:
  - At the end of the level, I added a **brief cutscene** that triggers once the player reaches the end of the level or a specific "finish line" area.
  - The cutscene consists of a **simple camera zoom** or fade-out effect as the camera focuses on the next area (which could hint at an enemy or a mysterious object). There’s no complex animation—just a smooth transition.
  
  - The cutscene ends with a **fade to black** followed by a quick **loading screen** for the next scene. This keeps the flow of the game simple and smooth while still providing a sense of progression.

---

### **Hour 5: Final Testing & Polish**

In the final hour, I tested everything thoroughly to ensure everything was working as expected and made a few last-minute tweaks.

- **Testing the Level**:
  - I ran through the level multiple times to test the Void mechanic, sawblades, and checkpoints. Everything seemed to be working smoothly.
  
- **Cutscene Testing**:
  - I tested the **cutscene transition**, ensuring it triggered properly when reaching the level’s end, fading to black, and transitioning to the next scene without issues.

- **Polishing**:
  - I cleaned up some of the visuals and added some minor polish to make the level feel more cohesive, like adjusting the lighting around key hazards and adding a little more atmosphere.
  - The overall gameplay flow felt smooth, with the Void and checkpoint system adding a nice level of challenge, and the cutscene providing a simple but effective hint about what’s to come.

---

### **End of Session**

At the end of the session, I had successfully completed the following:

- Developed the level with new hazards like sawblades.
- Implemented the Void mechanic for instant death and checkpoints for respawn.
- Fixed several collision and UI bugs.
- Created a simple but effective **cutscene** that hints at what comes next in the game, smoothly transitioning the player to the next scene.

The game is progressing well, and the next session will likely focus on adding more levels, expanding the cutscene system, and implementing new gameplay mechanics.

Time Log - 3 Hours (Game Development Session)
Total Time Worked: 3 hours

1. Extensive Level Building (1 hour 30 min)

Spent a significant portion of the session focusing on designing and refining the level layout.
Made sure the level was challenging but still passable, adjusting obstacles, platforms, and gaps to create a tight yet achievable progression for the player.
Ensured that every section of the level required careful timing and skill, giving the player a sense of accomplishment when completing difficult segments.
2. Created New Jump Pad Object (30 min)

Designed and implemented a new jump pad mechanic that adds a vertical movement option for the player.
Integrated the jump pad into the level, making sure it interacted well with the player’s physics and the surrounding environment.
Fine-tuned the jump pad’s functionality to ensure it provided the right height and distance for platforming challenges.
3. Added New Obstacle Types (20 min)

Got creative with existing assets to develop new types of obstacles.
Reused elements already in the game but combined them in fresh ways to keep the level feeling dynamic and unpredictable.
Designed obstacles that forced players to adapt their movement strategies and test their skills in new ways.
4. Updated Horse UI (20 min)

Added an extra heart to the horse UI to increase the horse's health due to the rising difficulty of the game.
Updated the code to reflect the change, making sure the new heart appeared and functioned properly within the UI.
Ensured the horse’s health was adjusted correctly in response to in-game actions.
5. Fixed Collider Issues (20 min)

Resolved issues with colliders, specifically focusing on making interactions with enemies and obstacles more accurate.
Ensured that collisions between the player and obstacles/enemies felt smooth and precise.
Tested collision boundaries and adjusted the hitboxes for better performance and gameplay experience.

### 2-Hour Game Development Session Log

---

**Hour 1: Adding Collectible Rotating Bananas and Fixing Collision Issues**

The session began with a focus on adding a new gameplay mechanic: collectible rotating bananas. The concept was simple: players would need to collect these bananas scattered across the level. I wanted to make them visually interesting by having them rotate, adding a dynamic aspect to the collection process. I added the necessary code and set up the animation for the bananas to rotate smoothly.

However, when I tested the mechanic, I ran into a major issue—**collision detection**. The bananas, despite rotating, were not behaving properly when the player tried to interact with them. The rotation caused them to "flicker" or "fly off" when the player character touched them. The problem was related to the way the rotation affected the collision box, which was causing the bananas to miss the player or get flung into the air randomly.

I spent the next 40 minutes trying to fix the issue, experimenting with different physics settings, adjusting the collision box to match the rotation, and recalculating the rotation angles. It was a frustrating back-and-forth as I tweaked the values, trying to make the bananas rotate and collide in a way that felt natural and fair. Eventually, I was able to get the bananas to behave correctly: they rotate smoothly without causing erratic physics, and the player can now collect them without any issues.

---

**Hour 2: Creating Tutorial Art and Icons**

With the banana mechanic working as expected, I shifted focus to designing art for the game's tutorial. I wanted to introduce players to the game mechanics in an easy-to-understand, visually engaging way. I decided to use simple icons and brief descriptions to show what each control does and explain how some items, like the bananas, work within the game.

For the next 50 minutes, I created icons for actions such as movement, jumping, and interacting with objects. I also designed an icon for the rotating bananas, highlighting how players can collect them. The design process was fun, but it took a bit longer than expected since I wanted the icons to be clear and visually appealing. I made sure to keep the tutorial style consistent with the overall art direction of the game. 

Once the icons were designed, I integrated them into the video tutorial system, making sure that the tutorial played smoothly alongside the gameplay footage. The video now shows the player how to move, interact with bananas, and avoid common obstacles, giving new players a helpful guide to the game’s controls.

---

**End of Session**

The session was productive despite the collision issues with the rotating bananas. The problem took up a lot of time, but in the end, it was worth it to have that mechanic functioning properly. The tutorial art was also a great addition, giving the game a polished, professional feel. There’s still more to do, but I’m happy with the progress made today!

Total Time Worked: 4 hours

1. Added Frogs from Another Scene (1 hour)

Imported frogs from the previously created scene into the current scene.
Ensured their behaviors and interactions were correctly replicated in the new environment.
Adjusted spawn points and position to fit the new level layout.
2. Fixed Gravity and Physics-Related Issues (1 hour 30 min)

Troubleshooted and fixed gravity issues affecting the frog and player characters.
Adjusted the physics engine parameters to ensure smoother interactions and better jumping mechanics.
Fine-tuned the physics for proper object collision handling, especially in areas where the player and environmental objects interacted (e.g., frog movement or falling mechanics).
3. Addressed Tilemap Collider Issues (45 min)

Identified and fixed errors in the tilemap collider setup that were causing issues with collision detection.
Corrected problematic areas where the player or other objects were passing through tiles or being obstructed incorrectly.
Reworked collider boundaries to fit the tiles better, improving overall level interaction and player movement.
4. Adjusted Horse Interaction Radius (30 min)

Reduced the horse’s interaction radius to make the player approach the horse more realistically.
Implemented a distance constraint so the player can no longer mount the horse from an unreasonable range.
Added a height-based restriction to prevent the player from mounting the horse if their vertical position (Y-level) is lower than the horse's.
5. Built Level Structure (45 min)

Began constructing parts of the level layout, including terrain, obstacles, and platforming elements.
Focused on early-stage placement and environment building, ensuring the foundation of the level is solid for later sections.
Left placeholders for future elements that will be added in upcoming sessions.
Focus for Next Session:

Continue building and refining the level.
Add more complex interactions and enemy placement.
Fine-tune any remaining physics or collision issues based on testing in the new environment.

Description:
Untitled Juice Game

This was a game I made at the start of Juice! It's pretty simple - arrow keys to change direction, SPACE to shoot.

Deep-Roots

Sooo, hey! Lopa here!
Basically, my game is a farming game where you plant seeds, sell your crops, earn money, and use that money to buy farmland or upgrades. As you progress, you can purchase better seeds that give you more profit, and the cycle continues! There’s also a bit of exploration—if you wander around, you might stumble upon rare chests containing special seeds. 👀

I was super inspired by Stardew Valley—it’s such a well-made farming game and one of my all-time favorites! One thing I really love about Juice is that it’s mostly textless. That makes it more accessible to players around the world, regardless of what language they speak or how old they are.

I also want to talk a bit about the game development process! Honestly, it went surprisingly smoothly. This is probably one of the few projects where I didn’t suffer much from debugging nightmares. The art side was more of a challenge for me though—art wasn’t really my thing before Juice, but now I’ve actually created a couple of super cute characters! (Okay, it’s just two, but still—they’re adorable.)

I also took a lot of inspiration from the Sprout Lands asset pack. When I say inspiration, I mean I kinda just used some of the textures 😅.

Anyway, my thoughts are a little spaghetti right now, so I might have missed a few things—but I’ll wrap this up by saying:
Dm me

Description:
Minebound
You are a miner who got seperated from the rest of your group. You also unlock a mysterious "dash" power which gives you some force and lets you move forward really quickly. You must navigate treacherous paths and dangerous lands to find your way and escape the mine. You must collect a mysterious substance called 'Aetherium" which is used to power up your pickaxe. Once you reach the end, fall below the void and embrace the void.
