Description:
Spacegoose: 

You are a goose stranded on Earth. One day, you encounter a golden goose who gives you a daring quest to reclaim the stolen golden egg from the tyrannical duck overlords. Your journey takes you across the plains of Earth, through the Moon’s craters, over Mars’s red deserts spoiled by the ducks’ asteroid machine, past the unforgiving asteroid belt, and finally into a strange, dreamlike realm. Only then, do you reach the ducks’ massive mothership. You face the evil grey duck in an intense battle, defeat him, and claim the golden egg. With your mission complete, you finally return the egg to its rightful owner. Be ready to be challenged by the vigorous obstacles and puzzling layout of levels! 

Our story:


There was a flood of bewildering ambition as we pondered the prompts given to us in that fateful markup document that we had to pitch our game in. Being the sadistic psychopaths we are, making players suffer is an obvious inspiration for the game mechanics. However, we also wished the game to be of enough quality such that the players wouldn’t be bored to death in part due to the difficulty. Despite our beating hearts, we had practically zero knowledge in game development with a sophisticated engine like Godot. Nevertheless, we were stably progressing in our initial weeks by flopping between tutorials, improvisation, and some vibe coding sinning. Interestingly, we found our knowledge to grow quite quickly with this model of creation. However during spring break, we were forced to lock in to speed up progress. Throughout this process, we were proud to see our game grow feature by feature, level by level, and our experience grow with the passing of each productive day.

juiceStretches.description: I added many game optimizations including a FPS counter and chunk manager for the terrain. I also tried adding optimization for the duck enemy and bread, but I couldn't get it to work since the duck and bread will not spawn.

I created the fourth level, an asteroid belt. Asteroids are made using Piskel, and they are scattered, making parkour challenging. Some astroids contain ducks on them to make the challenge before the final levels even harder than before.

I added the golden egg and doom duck boss improvements. When the doom duck reaches 100 health, it will start a eating animation that eats the golden egg for 5 seconds; moreover, after the duck eats the golden egg that it was holding, it gains 1000 health and has 2x speed, jump, and duck spawn rate, providing an even harder challenge for players.

For this session, I first fixed the bread spawning script to spawn the appropriate amount of bread with the use of random predetermined locations. Because I added the basket, the spawned bread from the basket are adding to the total bread count; therefore, if I set the max bread to 10, no bread will spawn because there are 5 bread per basket and two baskets. Not only that, but I also changed the duck death sound from a weird fart sound to a duck quack sound. I also found and added a rocket ship blastoff sound, so when the goose enters the rocket ship, the blastoff sound effect plays which syncs with the rocket ship blastoff.

I added dripstone mechanics to the game. First, I added the spawn dripstone command in the level script so it spawns each dripstone into its appropriate position. Then, I formatted the dripstone with a collision Polygon2D and a drop area. Afterward, I made and attached a script that detects if the goose is in the drop area, and if the goose is in the drop area, the dripstone will pick a random drop interval from 0.1 to 0.5 seconds. If the dropped dripstone hits the goose, it's game over. Some problems that I ended up fixing when writing the script were that the dripstone would still kill the goose when it was already dropped, and the dripstone would not kill the goose when it jumped in the dripstone.

I made a level switching function inside the global script that changes the level from a function. When I first implemented the function, only the root node2D would change when I called it. Then I realized that I needed to import the existing level into a levelContainer node which would store all the elements. This also fixes the GUI stacking when switching levels. Next, I needed to remake the helmet function that toggles the helmet since it was broken by the levelContainer scripts. After a long time of debugging and many debug prints, it successfully toggles the helmet on or off with a function. Finally, I remade the duck script so the duck switches to its space animation once the level gets past Earth, using the same logic as the helmet.
added camera scrolling when the main character moves. I also added a camera shake script that determines the level of shake based on the fall height of the main character.
I added terrain and the sky as tilemaps for the second level (moon). This is going to be the level layout but I still need to add enemies and hazards.
The basket now spawns random bread pieces (2-10). I also added debug prints so it's easier to find problems.

I added animations for the Doom Duck boss. This includes the walking animation and jumping animation. I also created the Doom Ducky, a smaller version of the boss that the boss will spawn for more intense gameplay.

I rescaled the death screen so the pixels are more square-like instead of the rectangle pixels before; additionally, I added possible bread spawn locations to spawn 10 pieces of bread in the second level. I added 16 possible locations so every time the level runs, the bread will spawn in different locations.
remade clouds and made the sky darker. I also added a version with stars.
I added the meteor breaking animation. When I shoot the meteors, they will play the breaking animation then delete itself so the goose can continue without getting blocked by meteors.
I basically finished the first (tutorial) level; remade the rocket ship sprite and added a launch animation to it. I also incorporated accurate rocket physics.

I added a game icon by combining multiple game elements into one pixel art. The finished icon shows a goose floating in space, but I tried many icons, like a goose head, which looked like the goose had been decapitated.

I added code to the baskets so that pieces of bread (the currency) would explode when the goose touches it, acting like a loot box for the game. The bread pieces would also fly in random directions and have accurate physics.

I made the helmet sprite2D in the goose node the ability to move with the goose. The hardest part was making the helmet move with the idle animation; which took lots of trial and error to sync the helmet and the goose idle animation together.
I refined the goose death screen by remaking it to a goose skull and crossbones. I also implemented it into the game so once you die, the death screen will appear.

I added the galactic basket scripts that first uses the level script to spawned the baskets in the desired locations. After, I made the galactic basket spawn 5 randomized juice boxes each with unique abilities that can be activated.

I made the golden egg collectable by the goose. It adds the golden egg to the inventory. Not only that, but I also created a golden goose that appears in the start of the first level. It asks for the golden egg, and if you get the golden egg and touch the golden goose, you complete the game. The storyline is basically the evil ducks take over the goose world and steals the precious golden egg that gives insane powers, and the space goose is supposed to save that golden egg by travelling across planets.
I added a sprite sheet for three different variants of juice power-ups (orange, apple, grape). Each juice is animated and will make the game more intuitive.

I made the gravity change on the moon level. The jump velocity changes depending on the level, so the jumping velocity is higher on the moon than on the Earth level. This took way longer than expected since I had to debug a lot, trying to figure out how to apply the gravity to only one level instead of applying it to all levels. Additionally, I added spikes underneath the void poles so the goose would die if it fell into the void.
I animated the death screen so it shakes around for a while after you die.
Added a moving platform and made a better finish line.

I first merged the levels branch to the final boss branch and resolved all the merge conflicts. I also added the refined duck space ship icon, which took me very long to create and refine so it's bigger than the older version. I also added pickups like galactic basket and ducks to the space levels and cleaned everything up for the release of the game.
I added a moon background for the second level. It took SO LONG adding the shades and stars.
I created and animated a meteor sprite that will appear in space levels after Earth. It will randomly fall and if it hits the player, the player will die.

I added the sky for the third level, Mars. It is a 128x128 tilemap. Using piskel, I meticulously gathered a lot of colors from various mars sky pictures and added saturation to make it look better for the background. I then added some clouds for it to look better. After, I added the sky into the game.
made the sky of the "Earth" level of our game "Space Goose" using Pixilart

I created a new sprite, which is a duck wearing an astronaut helmet. The duck will act as a weak enemy on levels other than Earth. I also remade scaling so that it retains the aspect ratio when you expand the window or go full screen. Previously, if you expanded, you could see the entire level, and nothing scaled properly.
I made a duck-shaped rocket ship that appears at the end of each level. It replaces the finish line, and in the game, it blasts off once you go inside it.
I finished the mars terrain tilemap for the third level. That includes a pole, cliff, hill, and rock. All made using piskel 32x32.

I created and added signs into the game to guide the player. One sign shows the way for the player to defeat the duck while another sign warns about the spikes, and the other one teaches the double jump mechanic.
I added pickup animations to the bread and egg items. I also halved the gravity when the goose is gliding for a realistic experience.

I redid the color pallet so the moon terrain's colors would be more consistent; additionlly, I remade the level to have more interesting portions. Not only that, but I added barriers so the goose would not just fly out of the map.
I added a restart button on the deathscreen which will reset the game when pressed; however, the code still needs to be implimented but I finished the design and the placement.

I added the Doom Duck AI into the game. It detects if the goose is near and chases it. While it chases the goose, it spawns evil ducks, which are like normal ducks but robot-like.  Additionally, I also added more animations like death and damage animations so the final boss fight with the Doom Duck is more "intense" and "visually appealing".

I first created the mars level node for the third level of the game, but when I called switch level function, the level won't switch. After correcting that error, the helmet wont show, so I redid the helmet code and put it inside of global instead of the level script, so now it shows when the current level is inside the show helmet array. After fixing the helmet, I built the third level and added the rocket.
made a goose death screen that shows a dead goose since there are no words in the game. I drew multiple variants and ended up with this death screen.
Added juice powerups (orange juice, grape juice, strawberry juice). These powerups will make the game more fun.

I added juice boxes to the Mars level and remade the logic of juice. I also added a collection that will add the juice to the inventory and the random juice type spawning, which will randomly spawn three types of juice boxes; "apple" "grape" or "orange".

I added many changes to the game. First, I added duck spawning, which spawns three ducks in their desired locations; additionally, I added egg spawning locations near the duck, so it's like the ducks are guarding the eggs. The hardest part is adding the astronaut helmet to the goose. First, I made the helmet as a separate sprite, which never worked out since I could not find a way to move the helmet onto the goose without causing a plethora of errors. After moving the helmet into the goose node, for some reason, most functions inside the goose script would work; as a result, I spent a long time debugging and found out it's calling the level_ready function improperly. After fixing that, I added a function inside global.gd that toggles the helmet so it can either show or hide depending on the level.
Created a chunk manager. It divides 16x16 tiles into 32x32 tiles to optimize performance in the game since it can get laggy.
I added the duck enemy that would call the game over function when the goose touches the duck; however, if the goose jumps on top of the duck, it won't call game over.

I added a spawn bread script that spawns bread pieces throughout the game. There is a limiter that limits the bread spawn and the location is randomized. If the bread touches the player or the enemy while spawning, it will delete itself.
added the first enemy, a duck. Then, we added the duck walking animation. Afterward, I will add the attacking and idle animation.
added moon (second level) assets using piskel. I added craters and hills along with the blocks and poles from the previous stretches. I also added dripstone that will drop from moon caves.
I added baskets that will contain different power-ups upon collection. There will be two different types of baskets; the galactic basket will have rarer drops than the normal basket.

I added the basket into the second level via a spawn script inside the level node. There were many problems with the initial script since we added a plethora of new features into the game including a bread counter. Problems included the basket not colliding with the goose on contact since my teammate remade the goose hitbox. After fixing all these, I noticed that nothing was added to the bread counter, so I implemented that into the game. Last but not least, I made the bread pieces spawn in a line since it would be all clustered up which does not look nice. I also remade some parts of the animation for a cleaner feel.

I added the meteor sprite into the game. It clones itself and falls down on random intervals. When it hits the goose or the goose touches it, game over is triggered. It switches to the idle animation when it hits the ground, and particles acting like an explosion emits after collision.

I expanded the tilemaps for the moon level, mars, and asteroid belt levels since the camera is not zoomed out more, so it shows the void instead of the sky or the terrain. I also changed the cameraman death sound so it does not use the duck death sound.

I added the final level to the game, the boss fight. You enter a room witht he doom duck which is the final boss. The evil ducks that the doom duck spawns die after jumping on them for 5 times instead of only one time before. After defeating the doom duck, you are greeted with the final obstacle course that will eventually take you to a rocket ship headed for earth, where you can return the golden egg back to the golden goose and beat the game.
I finished the mars level by adding bread and duck enimies. I had to rewrite the duck script so the duck will switch to its helmet animation.

Finished the first level (tutorial level), added another duck enemy, and added collision shapes to stone blocks. The finish line is going to be replaced with a rocket ship; hence, the name of the game is Space Goose.

I added the first element of the next level, Mars. I added a tile for the terrain, which was challenging since my first iteration had way too light colors for the "red planet", so I had to change the color pallet and alter between multiple color pallets to get the desired colors.

I first added sound effects so the golden goose honks sad when you don't have the golden egg, but it honks happy if you do have the golden egg. After, I added a shader to the gold goose so it glows and changes golden colors.

I created the final boss for the game, Doom Duck. The doom duck will hold a machine gun and chases the goose while shooting. This is the idle animation since the doom duck is half duck and half robot, it can "sleep" when the goose is not near.
Added tiles for the next planet, "moon". Includes blocks and border

Description:
Orienteering VR

This game is, as the title suggests, about orienteering, which is a sport, where you have to complete specified route, in correct order, as fast as possible, using only a map and a compass. The goal of the game is the same — the player gets a map with a route on it and a compass, with which he/she navigates through the virtual forest. The name of the game comes from the original platform, that the game was made for — VR. Thanks to the Virtual Reality you can feel like you are in the forest and truly immerse yourself in the game. PC version is also available for all platforms and it provides much fun too. Now you know what the game is about, so I will proceed to the story of making it.

I decided to create game about this, because I'm an orienteer and I felt like there wasn't any good game about my sport. Every game that I know of was either abandoned or unfinished, so I wanted to change that. I was thinking about making it before I knew about Juice too, but I never felt like I would be capable of doing that. This game jam changed it — I finally got the motivation to make it. The beginnings of this project weren't easy, as I had no experience with Unity nor C#, but I was familiar with C++, so with some help of the internet I was able to add first things, like the ability to move the camera in game using the VR headset or moving the player. For first two weeks of the game jam, I was away from home (on an orienteering camp :p) and thus I could only use my laptop, which made it harder, because it isn't very powerful. But I managed to get the core features working — running and punching the controls, with which I made the demo. Because this game is 3d, everything was much much harder to make than I thought. Besides learning Unity I also had to learn a little bit of Blender. I managed to make some models there, but unfortunately I couldn't get all of them optimized (like trees or grass), so besides that I also used some assets that were already made by someone. After I had everything that I felt was necessary, I made a proper map. It took a long time to get it done and I think that it still isn't perfect. Small features and bug fixing consumed most of the time, but it was required to make the game playable. After that I added some sounds and post-processing and voilà, there is this somewhat playable game ^^.

I found myself feeling burnt out many times while making this game, the school also didn't help, in that matter this year is very hard for me, many times I just wanted to go to sleep, but I kept pushing, because I knew that I can make something nice. The games that other people shared on slack on one side gave me the motivation to work on the game more, but on the other side I had a feeling that my game is not good enough and people won't like it, but considering my experience with game dev I think that it turned out quite well.

The last eight weeks were crazy, it was a lovely adventure and I'm glad that I didn't miss out on this opportunity. Two months might seem like a lot of time, but in reality it isn't that much to learn almost everything from scratch. Of course my game is unfinished and probably has a lot of bugs and imperfections, but I still want to implement new features, like the ability for players to import their own maps that are real life terrains or add multiplayer. Who knows, maybe one day it will be used to host orienteering trainings and virtual competitions?

I think that the game turned out well. One piece of advice, that I can give to someone who would like to make their own game is that everything that you need is somewhere out there on the internet, you just have to give yourself some time to learn it and trust that you are able to build something amazing.

I think that this is everything that I wanted to write, I will still continue to develop the game. Also, feel free to play it, test it and message me on Slack @Mejpek or Discord @mejpek, if you would like to ask me about anything. Thank you for reading this and have an absolutely fantastic day ^^

P.S. Thank you, Filip, for the support and playtesting of the game <3

Mejpek :3

But making a game like that would be kinda lame : just copying another one's game :(. That's why I added 2 twists to it! Isometric because I wanted to learn pixel art at that time and French food because everyone on the slack was bullying me with baguette :D

Description:
SLIFT
The making of SLIFT is a story of both old and new developers, who came together to create SLIFT. In other words, I had never touched a game engine and my friend had to do most of the project. So, a young aspiring to be game developer and an more experienced dev set off. There were many challenges in the way, including Git Kraken horrors and buggy code, but after trial and error, they made what would be the best project they had done yet, and they did it together. All in all, it was probably my most rewarding and surreal experience I had ever done - being able to make a game and call it my own is something, truly, incredibly cool to me. So after months of grinding, the pair had made a game they could proudly present and enjoy, and that is the story of SLIFT.
PS, Dm me iykyk

Description:
The Juicer

By: Adharsh

Here I am, two months later, about to board a plane to Shanghai, China, with a game set to be published on the biggest game-sharing site in the world. But how did I get here? Is it safe? Did I even know anything about making a game? Let's focus on that last question. I had dabbled in game-making before, messing around with Pygame and Scratch when I was younger, but a full-fledged game engine? That was a whole new level. I felt completely out of my depth. If I was really going to make a game, I needed a plan. So, I started drawing.

At the time, two things were on my mind: my upcoming trip to Shanghai and running a juice café. That’s when the idea hit me. Why not gamify that? A simple game where you catch fruits, make juice, and sell it before time runs out. Straightforward, but with plenty of room for improvement. Once I had my notes, I dove headfirst into Godot. I started with the basics, setting up the screen, adding the player, and creating a floor. Then came movement, collisions, and spawning fruits in the air for the player to catch. The game grew from there with seven levels, blenders to process fruit, a juice stand to sell the final product, and extra features like a time limit, combo multipliers, scores, and power-ups. 

Of course, this journey wasn’t as smooth as I’m making it sound. Every new feature came with its own set of bugs and fixes. Halfway through development, I realized my code was a complete mess, hard to understand and even harder to expand. So I spent around 15 hours restructuring everything, breaking it into smaller, more manageable parts. In the end, the game functioned just as it did before, but now adding new features was much easier.

Looking back at what I’ve created, I still can’t believe it. After all this time, I finally did what I had always wanted to do. Make my own video game.

Description:
Cafe Cafe
This long journey started long long ago, when we, Aaron, Ivy, and Joel, were hungry. This led us to making food in our kitchen. This is when we were presented with the opportunity to do juice. Deciding on the topic of our game required alot of thinking. And the thing is that thinking makes us hungry, which made us think about food. This began our long birth of our cooking game. Over 2 months and many dishes made and meals eaten out, we completed our game and it was time to take on juice in Shanghai. Getting there, fighting to get our visa, losing a passport and delayed flights, we made our big debut, with only one thing left, our game name. Being named "Cafe Cafe", requested by Issac.

Description:
What is the meaning of life?
For some, it is experiencing the dopamine that comes with each and every step of progress.
For others, it is to carry out the duties that our creators have given us.
However, for me, it is the intangible force that pushes me to a cook meal even more perfect than last.
I wish to share my passion with those who do not share my vision, even though many may disagree with my objective. 
How can I accomplish that? Influencing children while they're young. What appeals to children? Video games.
And so I decided to make meaning of my life by making a gamel. A game addictive enough to manipulate people worldwide to embrace the art of the chef.
Do what you wish to see happen in the world.

juiceStretches.description: finally finished a mechanic that displays the item the player is holding

the sound system was finally made!
used jsfxr to produce a number of sound effects, each of which plays based on the player's actions or at specific game events, such chopping or an order timing out. 
extremely pleased with how the audio system turned out, which makes it simple to play music anywhere or when adding new sound effects by automatically importing and organizing the .wav and .mp3 files from the filesystem.
ivy, one of my teammates, composed our unique background music! i set it up such that it repeats endlessly, with each loop beginning at a different time after the first iteration (ended up spending lot of time trying to make the loop sound seamless...)

replaced the static sprites with animated frames of the chef walking for up and down, which required rewriting a lot of the player generation function which previously only loaded in sprite files rather than animation frames.
i also implemented our new background for the start screen, replacing the previous texture and moving around the buttons accordingly. replaced text inside the start screen buttons with emojis, except for the tutorial button which is currently "???"
also fixed a bug that was annoying me for a while where you couldn't bring fried chicken directly to the plate source tile to plate the chicken.

buns, plates, and burger assembly created!
using a counter, you can now assemble a burger with lettuce, buns, and patties.
for now, the burgers can only be assembled on an existing plate at a counter.
this probably would have been easier to implement with better code infrastructure before hand, but im decently happy with how this current system turned out!

also made a button at the top right to quit the game. required me to experiment with resource files and custom button sprites. maybe useful?
ordering system set up - random food items can be ordered at random intervals and the player is rewarded money for completing the order. rewired the code to be node-based rather than tileData-based

customer spawning system
- customer spawns in and automatically navigates to an empty table using a system i made. navigationagent2d was original approach but didn't work well so I made my own custom navigation logic.
- customer spawns an order when they reach a table
- complete all orders to advance to next wave
- will deduct lives for not completing an order in future developments

player movement is not tile-based anymore and now has much more freedom to move

sorry about the extensively long session, it's just really easy to find something else to do after finishing a mechanic, but that's what I love about game development!

plates implemented!
while they work similar to bowls, the plates will be specifically used to plate the fried chicken and burgers in the future.
some debugging and error fixing was done as well, such as the trash crashing the game when you try to trash cooked chicken on a plate specifically.

✈️ PLANE SESSION ✈️
worked on implementing building burgers on counters, regardless of what you put first. decided that plates should only work on items that are serveable, so i transistioned the code from being able to plate anything and made a system to only be able to plate certain food. im off the plane now, but this took a lot more time than it usually would, largely due to my scuffed laptop setup on the plane and the extremely limited internet resources to refer to.

underwent psychological trauma figuring out how to compile aseprite (0/10 experience just grind jungle instead lol) but now we at least have access to a much better and more versatile pixelart software which will be invaluable to the visuals of our game.
migrated project to Godot 4.4, implemented smooth camera movement, implemented day counter that increases after a certain number of orders are completed

multiplayer functionality!

2 chefs with their own keybinds, can perform exact same actions and have the upgrades they choose independent from each other. camera will pan out accordingly depending on how far the players are from each other.

title screen created, player can choose to play either one or two players.

UI adjusted and improved:
- coin sprite instead of dollar sign for money
- player2 gets their own held item box
- life count (hearts) moved to top of screen

spent a lot of time sorting through merge conflicts which is inevitably occur when multiple people work on the project simultaneously

not mentioned in video but game music WIP!

sorry, another long submission from me!

finally ditched the lettuce and customers now have a variety of options to order!

the serving system was previously hardcoded to serve lettuce so I spent a lot of time on making it compatible with other dishes. the system i'm using now just compares the sprites inside the bubble with the sprite in the player's held item box, but i had a previous prototype that compared node/scene data which was a lot more complicated and messy.

for the boss, it now displays all its orders simultaneously, doing some math to automatically scale to fit within the order bubble.

boba system complete!
- required rewriting the player interaction system
- programmed it to where it doesn't matter if you put tea first or tapioca first into the cup

also implemented an actual texture for the progress bars using some pngs i drew up in aseprite, will replace customer waiting bars later!
got the core movement mechanics of the game working, using tile-based movement with basic collision logic that will be relevant later on.

counters implemented! can pick up and place any item on counters. will need a little more work once we get to implementing building orders on the counters, but they're usable for now.

made the title screen look nicer with an 8bit font and a temporary background. will look a lot nicer in the future.

replaced the map sprite with a newer version, but it's 99% the same map so not many adjustments were needed.

i realize that im starting to work faster as im getting more experienced with game development, go me!

lives mechanic done!
player now loses a life when failing to complete an order in time. i drew up a custom heart sprite in aseprite that will represent how many lives the player has. after the player loses all their lives, the game will restart.

POST-JUICE DEVELOPMENTS! 
this session was just implementing some feedback we received at Juice IRL and fixing existing jank in the game. Player no longer runs in place. boba cups actually move to the appliance being interacted with. music toggle button was added and custom button sprites were implemented for both the music toggle and exit button.

boss mechanics!
a boss customer will now spawn every 5 waves.
multiple bosses will be implemented in the future, but  the first boss will require the player to complete multiple orders instead of only 1. needed to heavily modify the order generation logic to handle a customer ordering multiple dishes. will work on those dishes all being displayed simultaneously in the future!
core mechanics almost done, player can now move around items and interact with other blocks. a lot of bug fixes and brainstorming with team done as well
player code largely recoded and optimized; much smoother movement and chef actually holds items instead of getting slapped in the face when moving
buying items will add to player stats and money actually decreases when you buy items

wow, a brand new set of sprites!
the past few days have been dedicated to transitioning to our new sprite sheet and finally importing our first actual map design. the code has been updated to cooperate with 64x64 pixel tiles, as well as revamping and cleaning our project setup along the way. a lot of effort was spent sorting through github merge conflicts, but it is getting easier as we become more experienced with working on big projects as a team.
have been also working on the music and learning sound effects, hopefully a sneak peek soon..!
successfully figured out currency counter, increasing after every order is served. a lot of brainstorming and file management done as well

great progress on shop mechanism; this is the second version of the shop as the first one corrupted the game due to funny accidents i'd rather not talk about, but at least the version we have now is even better then the one we had earlier ig :)
also a ton of optimizations were done to other parts of the game to prepare for our future implementations
new sprites added in to replace old sprite package, fully switched from 16x16 to 32x32 TileMapLayer, many bug-fixes and resolved merge conflicts

chicken created!
programmed the chicken fridge to pick up a chicken wing when interacted with and the fryer to cook the chicken. unlike the other appliances, the fryer will continuously cook without any involvement of the player. in the future, i'll consider implementing burning, where the chicken will need to be thrown in the trash when it's being fried for too long.
I spent an unnecesarily long amount of time trying to figure out how to create and use a Trello board for project management.

patty implemented!
grab a patty from the fridge and throw it on the grill to get a cooked patty.
will be used for the burgers, but gotta implement some more mechanics before we get to that.
github was also being weird again and i had to sort out some missing file conflicts with joel.

y-sorting done, sprites are now properly drawn in the correct order!
had zero idea on how this worked so resorted to youtube; however, most of those tutorials use the deprecated TileMap instead of TileMapLayer, but i ended up finding my own solution in the end!
drew up a sprite of the sun to replace text that existed in-game, added a node to the scene tree and modified the code to implement this change.

GitHub Username: juanes10201 (we published the game using this account)
Description:
My game is a speedrun focused 2d platformer, inspired by the precise Celeste movement and the fast paced action from ULTRAKILL, with a minimum time requirement for beating every level. That idea ended up becoming SPEEDTICKERS.

SPEEDTICKERS is a high-speed platformer that focuses on the player movement, featuring sliding and ground-smashing mechanics that push players to master momentum and precision.

I wanted for it to have a very Neon pixelart style, so i started learning using Aseprite(I really recommend it) 

The game follows Sam, an ordinary human piloting a half finished robot, commpeting for medals in almost impossible competitions. It's set in a post-cyberpunk world, the game takes place in a extreme competition that's held every five years, where thousands of contenders race in advanced robotic suits to prove their survival.

I made the music of it for creating an enviroment that immerse the player in the experience,  and trying to create an immersive and emotional atmosphere that complements the gameplay feelling, All of this I made with GarageBand that I think that it´s a great Apple app to do that.
