Description:
I started #juice late - in March, less than one month before the event (thank you, inconveniently scheduled examinations)! So the first challenge was actually getting over the "I won't be able to do it" and "I give up before beginning" mental hurdles. The main thing which persuaded me to do that was seeing everyone in the Hack Club Slack being supportive, helping one another, motivating people to not give up - I wanted to do it, if only to be a small part of this amazing group of people. 

The second challenge was the fact that I had never made anything I considered "publish worthy" - sure Hack Club's Arcade had taught me how to make games with Godot, sure I had open-sourced the code on GitHub - BUT NO ONE SAW THOSE THINGS LONG ENOUGH TO CARE! THIS IS STEAM - NO I CAN'T DO IT! (The capitals represent the (VERY loud and demotivating) internal monologue I was having). But again, that's the beauty of Hack Club - we don't give up (I think Thomas said this too, in a YT Short for Trail which I was somehow coincidentally recommended just when I was giving up (thank you Universe!)).

So - the decision was made - I was going to make a game, and publish it, no matter how bad I thought it was, no matter how demotivating the internal monologue got. For the exact concept of the game, I decided to make a Puzzle Platformer - mainly because I was (a bit) experienced with the genre, and also because I had heard of games like Celeste and Hollow Knight - and wanted to make something challenging, something I might want to play, even if very casually. The second reason was the languageless part - my favourite genre is RPGs (mainly thanks to Pokemon), but that wasn't very feasible in a languageless game (which was a very nice mini-challenge in the event - thanks Thomas and Paolo!) Finally, I needed a name - for a game about leaping (jumping) with a pixelated art style (in my defense, I am horrible at Art anyways) - and Pixel-Leap - the idea, the concept was born. A concept that was then forced to undergo way too many revisions, way too many last-minute changes, all while being supported by a big, badly written code base (this was my first big game okay?)

So, I gave it my all, some days coding for up to 10 hours, some days, slacking off a bit and only doing 5. And I made Pixel Leap! A puzzle platformer. My first game - my first project that I could truly call "publish worthy" (or rather, HAD to - nothing is ever truly perfect!). My biggest lesson from everything was - don't give up! It sounds (and is) very cliché, but trust me, you DO need to hear this sometimes. Nothing will ever truly be "done", and nothing can ever truly be called "publish worthy" - yes not even the big titles like Celeste and Hollow Knight. What matter is, not losing faith in your ability to do remarkable things!  

So, to the random person reading this - just do it! Take that risk, make that project, send that email - you never know, it might just end up being YOUR Pixel-Leap!

Thank you if you read the entire thing!

juiceStretches.description: I added a new enemy! A Duck! This was one of the most confusing enemies to work with as I had many ideas for what I could have done with it. I decided to make it "passive", where it doesn't hurt the Player (unless touched - it doesn't actively hunt for them). I first set up the animations. Then for the movement, I wanted to try something different, so I decided to have it jump left and right continuously, with an interval of 2s between each jump! This was the hardest challenge of the session - as I first had to debug issues, then I made a rudimentary mechanic that made it jump to a given point, but instead of jumping, it just flew there and back in a triangle. This didn't really look good, so I decided to implement projectile motion. I first tried using a CharacterBody2D to make it easier, but gave up due to a weird glitch where the animations played randomly (still no idea why that happened - probably an error on my part). Then, since I wanted to use an AnimatedSprite2D, I had to make a movement system from scratch - without the convenience of is_on_floor() and velocity. I decided to use basic physics concepts instead - where, in projectile motion, the horizontal velocity remains constant, but the vertical velocity decreases due to the effect of gravity. Then, I had a very practical system ready, but it didn't look good for a bird, so I adjusted the values of vx, vy and gravity to make the parabolic (projectile) motion a lot smoother. Finally, I created a system for the Duck to turn after each jump, and fixed some bugs with the "anticipate_jump" animation! And then, I set up all the collisions. I think it is good now (and bug-free (hopefully)!).

I added a menu for when the level is finished! I did not expect it to take (more than) an hour, but it was very confusing working with HBoxes and VBoxes. My initial idea of using a Panel Container with a Sprite2D for the trophy and a RichTextLabel was working, but I realised that if some levels took longer than 99 seconds, the label having a fixed position and width would make it look very bad! Hence, I had to make a proper layout system. Then, I realised that a Sprite2D (used for the trophy icon) was not a Control node, and hence text was being written over it. I fixed this by using a TextureRect instead. Then, I got all the buttons working and properly styled. Lastly, I also wanted to stylise the Pause Menu a bit so experimented with using an animation for a black background, which didn't look good, so I just settled for a simple, slightly blurred black background!

I added a fan trap! It has a 5s timer, which switches between the on and off states. I set up the animations for both, and gave it a simple static body collision. In the on state, the fan rotates and can push the Player upwards with a certain force, while in the off state it is just a static body. I also spent some time making a CPU Particle system to give visual confirmation that the fan is on even when it is not visible (took some time but again, I think it will be useful when I'm designing levels later on!). I think everything works as expected now!

First I fixed the Plant Enemy's bullet (which had more bugs than I'd originally assumed!). The problem was that the bullet was not disappearing when it touched the terrain or the player. When I fixed this, the bullet started disappearing along with the player for some reason (I later discovered that the player was not disappearing, just its physics process wasn't being reactivated after being deactivated because of the hitbox of the bullet). After fixing the player, I worked on the animations for the Plant Enemy, and fixed the idle, attack and death animations completely! Then I worked on the scaling for the enemy (as it was too big and the bullet's weren't properly colliding with the player). Finally, I created a death system (using a simple Area2D instead of a Raycast 2D like before), so that when the player hits the top of the enemy, it plays the death animation and disappears!

I added two new types of terrain! One is Ice (which can be slid on, and the speed is about twice that of normal walking), and the other is Sand (which you can walk on, but the speed is halved for both normal walking and dashing). My original idea was to just have a Sprite2D with an Area2D which detects the Player on it and halves the velocity, but I realised that wasn't looking good as the Ice (and Sand) was blocked and the entire game is tiled. So, I added two new layers - one for Ice and one for Sand, and gave the Player two Raycasts which detect these and modify the speed (from within the Player script, as compared to being in the Ice and Sand scenes). It took some while to make (and debug minor issues) but I got it working! Then, since I don't have a separate animation for sliding (yet), I made it play the first frame of the "idle" animation only. I think it looks good for now! Oh and also, I removed the deprecated Tilemap node and instead added a TilemapLayer for everything! I had been meaning to do this for a while but got sidetracked with all the enemies haha!

Added the last enemy (for now!) - a hopping Bunny! This one was particularly hard because it has a dual state mechanic again - one is the movement state (left and right) and the other is the attacking and normal state. In the attacking state, the enemy runs really quickly at the player and if it touches, the player dies. In the normal state however, the enemy just hops around. First, I set up the animations. Then, I worked on the attack state (running), and then on the normal state (hopping). This time the hopping mechanic was harder (than the Duck enemy) as I had to use Raycasts to turn at the walls - which took some time to properly implement. My first major bugs came when I had to write code to smoothly switch between these two states (based on the Player detection Raycasts). This was very confusing but I got it working. There were many more bugs, including one where the enemy was running at as well as turning around at the same time when the Player stood near the wall. I solved it by using an Idle state timer of 1s. Then I had to adjust the collisions and all the hitboxes. I think everything works well now, and this was also the last (proper) enemy I had planned!

New enemy - a flying Blue Bird! Relatively straightforward - it just flies left and right, and turns when a wall is spotted. I used Raycasts again! I have set up all the animations, all the collisions and tested to make sure everything works as expected! I don't notice any more bugs, but I am 100% sure more will come up, so I'll fix those as I go!

Okay, another enemy added - a Chameleon! This one was VERY hard, since it has a tongue animation, and only the tongue can harm the player! First I had to load and get all the animations working. Then, I noticed that since the sprite (the chameleon body specifically) was not perfectly centered, and there was a slight offset at the ledges/walls. So I made an allowance to remedy that. Then, to solve the tongue problem, I gave the enemy two separate hitboxes, which only activate between the 14th and 18th frames (the tongue animation frames) - one for the left direction and one for the right (one is active at any given moment, while the other is disabled). I made a similar system for the static bodies and the Hurtboxes. There was a bug because of issues with layers and masks for all the collisions (it was interfering with the Raycasts for walls/ledges), so I had to spend some time to fix that as well. Also, this time, I used a Raycast for detecting the player, instead of an Area2D like I did earlier, and it seems to work a (bit) better, so I might have to change the others too (hopefully not?). Luckily, for now, all seems to be fine so I think this enemy has been added properly!

I added levels 37, 38, 39, 40, 41 and 42! These are again HUGE levels (around 1.5-2 mins of playtime) - and Level 39 is also a night time level (with shadows and lighting effects). I think the next moment will be the last of level design (I am confident I have about 30 minutes of playtime now - technically more as there is replay-ability!) I have tested to ensure everything is perfect (the most important being the level time saving system - which is holding up pretty well so far, thankfully!). I think after the level design, only audio will be left, which should be done pretty soon too! Then I'll be able to export!

I added a trampoline that pushes the player up ward with a variable amount of force. Then, I loaded the backgrounds, and used shaders in Godot (for the first time!) to make the backgrounds move! I made a dynamic system that will allow me to select the speed and the axis of movement (X, Y or both!). Finally, I got started on a Plant Shooter enemy! It is currently very buggy, I just got the basic things to work. I have to fix the "queue_freeing" when the projectile hits terrain or the player. Oh and also, I added confetti when the end point (trophy) is reached, using CPU Particles and Atlas Textures!

Added a Skull enemy! It moves up and down, and when it collides with the ceiling, becomes a fiery version, when it can hurt the player, and when it collides with the floor, it becomes a timid version (horns down) that can be killed when it is touched. After getting the animations working, and setting up the collisions, I spotted one bug - where the hitbox was not turning on and off immediately after switching states and instead was turning on and off when the respective animations (for the state change) finished! I managed to fix this, as it was causing weird stuff to happen, so all is good now (I hope!).

I fixed everything wrong with the Trunk Enemy, and got the bullets working! Now the bullets are shot properly, and the shooting animation (which earlier had a bug I did not notice, where the animation only played once every time the Player entered the detection area - fixed now!) also works. I also added the hurtbox for the enemy, so that the enemy can be killed by jumping on top of it, and a hitbox to the enemy's bullets, which kill the player. I also made it so that the enemy can only look in front of it, and can only shoot when a wall/terrain is not in front of it. I think everything should work now!

Experimented with the Phantom Camera 2D plugin for Godot! I had heard about it but this is the first time I am actually using it, so I learnt how everything works. Made a temporary demonstration using a Phantom Camera set to Framed, with 0.15x dampening and a dead zone!

And the Bat enemy is done too! It took longer than I had expected to get all the animations to work in the proper order (it's only noticeable sometimes, but I still wanted it to look good). I also got the hurt and hitboxes to work properly - so that the Bat can be killed by stepping on its head, but only when it is flying. All hitboxes are disabled when it is resting! I was initially unable to get the Remote Transform to unlink, but managed to fix it. Also, since this time the Parent node is not a(n) (Animated) Sprite, it caused some issues with the Hurtbox (used to kill the enemy) - but thankfully, I go it working too! I think the enemy is good to go now! Future bugs are future me's problem!

A LOT of changes in this session! First, I improved the Scene Transitions by using an Autoloading script instead of the super (and unnecessarily) complicated solution I was using before. Now, I can just call SceneTransition.load_scene(packed_scene) or SceneTransition.reload_scene() instead - which is not just cleaner but also better (as I am ensuring the scene properly transitions and not just putting a bunch of await statements). So, I went ahead and changed everything to use this new method. Then, I decided to create a Main Menu (finally)! I realised that the buttons weren't looking good so I made them better too (now, when you press them, they return to their original size - which in my opinion is better than no press feedback) - I did this to all the buttons. Then, I added code to the Pause menu and the Level Finished menu scenes to come back to the Main Menu when the back arrow is clicked (used to represent the Main Menu). I got a bug here - which said the menu scene wasn't loading properly. I assumed the file got corrupted somehow, but after a lot of trial and error, I found out that it was because of circular referencing as I was using preload() and not load() - I made that change everywhere then. Then, I also created a Level Button scene (I needed a separate scene for this so I did not have to code a "go to X level" method for each button, and could just use an export variable to get the level instead, like I am doing in other places). Then, I made a level selection scene (which is what is loaded when you first press Play in the Main Menu), and added code to load the level button icons (again using export variables). Finally, I added a button to go to the next "slide" (as at once, I am only showing 20 levels). I also added code so that the buttons become darker and don't give hover feedback if the level isn't unlocked (right now, represented by an active variable only). I think the game is really starting to come together now - which is just wonderful!

I worked on adding a new Walking Trunk Enemy and got started with the animations! I am using Raycasts again, and an Area is used for detecting the player. Currently, I have gotten the walking animation working, and added an idle timer (it waits for some time when it touches a wall). I have also made the bullet. Oh and I debugged some issues with flipping the shapes (when a wall is touched), and the timers!

I designed levels 4 and 5! I also fixed bugs in the Plant Enemy and the Mushroom Enemy that I had failed to notice while coding them separately. Level 4 is relatively straightforward (I did test it extensively so it is still very hard, but I'd say the game is still in the introductory phase till this point). Level 5 is what took the most amount of time in the long session - it is VERY big and INSANELY hard (my goal was to make a "puzzle" platformer that encourages people to come back and beat their personal best scores, which is why I made it so). I have played through the entirety of Level 4 in the video, but only a fraction of Level 5 (as it will take close to 4-5 minutes (probably more) to complete with all the retries and retakes (the jumps have to be timed PERFECTLY (the "puzzle" part)). I tested it and ensured that all parts of the level are still "beat-able" but it will be challenging. Finally, I spent some time fixing the moving platforms (both the brown and the grey one) - as they were moving autonomously, which did not look good, so I made it so that they only move when the Player is standing on them (used multiple Raycasts for this). Finally, I spent time fixing a "Zero interval error" which I had completely forgotten about - it was related to the Path2D nodes in the Saw enemies. Everything's fixed now, I think!

I added the remaining collectibles (fruits)! There are Kiwis, Bananas, Oranges, Pineapples, Strawberries, Melons, Cherries and yes, Apples from before! I think I might have gone a little overboard with everything haha, but I am planning a LOT of levels (so the game remains fun for a long time), and I think having all of these would benefit and help make it non-redundant (which it might have been with just coins). I used Node2Ds for all of them, and a global update_collectible_count(collectible) signal, which is emitted by the collectible with its name. This signal is received by the Main script, which it relays onto the Collectible UI Layer, where the item name is identified and then the relevant count is updated (yes, I made it more modular and simplified!). I think everything works as it should now!

I added falling spikes (currently with a shaking animation - subject to change later!). At first, I gave them a constant speed but that did not look good, so I gave them a very tiny amount of acceleration. It took some time adjusting everything so that they weren't too difficult to cross, and at the same time, not too easy (this is a Puzzle Platformer after all!). Then, I added a new enemy - a Spike Enemy (with animations for top_hit, bottom_hit, left_hit, right_hit, idle and blinking!). It is similar to the Rock enemy I added earlier, but this time, instead of having two variations - one left-right and the other top-down, I added an export_enum with the two states (LEFT-RIGHT and TOP-DOWN), to make level design a lot easier later on! I have added all the animations and set up collisions. I also fixed a bug where the Pause Menu could be opened on top of the Level Finished menu - which did not look very good!

I added one of the most unique levels yet! Level 9! This time, the idea was to give it a "dungeon-esque" feel, so I added the Bat enemy, the Ghost enemy, and the Skull enemy. Still, something felt off, so I decided to add light! Or rather, remove it! I created an entirely new Tilemap layer with an occlusion layer added to all the tilemap squares (which is essentially a Polygon that is used to render light and shadows - in this case, it blocks light). Then I added a Point light to the Player. It didn't work immediately because of silly mistakes on my part, but I got it working. It still did not look like a dungeon though, so I added a LightOccluder2D to all the falling platforms (giving them the ability to make shadows too). Finally, I added PointLights to all the enemies too, but they behave differently for each - for the Bat, I have 2 separate PointLights - one when it rests, and one when it flies - and both alternate; for the Skull, it has a dimmer and smaller light when it is not "on fire" (inactive), a sort of visual indicator that it is weaker and can be killed in this state, the light becomes brighter and larger in the "fire" (active) state when it can hurt the Player; finally, the Ghost has a simple PointLight that disappears when it disappears and reappears with it too. Finally, Level 10 was not being unlocked, so I fixed some bugs in the if conditions in my level unlocking code too! Everything is perfect now! I don't think I'll spend so much time on one level again - I'll only have around 5 or 6 of these dungeon like levels in total I think.

I made Levels 12, 13, 14 and 15 (a bit quicker now, with the autotiling set up, but I still need to design a LOT faster)! I think I missed a few enemies (like the Slime and the Angry Pig), so I added those here. I am also experimenting with a new format for the levels, where the level end trophy is placed directly next to the starting point (but you can't end immediately because of the minimum number of collectibles (and enemy kills) required in the level. which acts as a threshold to ensure you have explored the ENTIRE thing before giving you the win - I think the system is working REALLY well so far). The puzzles are also getting better (I am struggling with them in the demo video too haha), so that's good for player engagement. I think I have about 10 minutes of confirmed playtime now (more realistically, around 15-20, but I'll lean on the safer side), so progress is good in that department!

I have managed to add another enemy! This time it is a rhino that attacks by running at the player, with a little knockback. My original implementation had several bugs and used Area2Ds to implement the player detection, but then I experimented with using Raycasts again, which ended up leaving me with more bugs! Sometimes the rhino detected one wall correctly, but not the other. Sometimes, the collision shapes mistook the player for a wall. Also, the knockback took a LOT of tweaking to get working. After all that, a very basic implementation of the Rhino is ready! There is one more bug I wasn't able to fix - if the player jumps when the rhino's hitbox is colliding with it, the player disappears for some reason! I think this is the last bug, but I am probably wrong! In the demo video, I have left the collision shapes on for the time being, to better illustrate the types of bugs I had to solve since this was a comparatively longer juice session.

I added an Angry Pig enemy! It has a normal state and an angry state - the normal state (slower movement) just happily pushes you around, but the angry state (twice the movement speed) can hurt you upon being touched. There is a 10s state change timer - 10s for normal and then 10s for angry. For the movement itself, I am once again using a state-based system (LEFT, RIGHT and IDLE state), so really, the enemy has a dual state mechanic. I have added all the hitboxes and ensured everything (including the animations) works smoothly (the enemy can be killed in both the angry and normal states, but they have different "hit" animations). I encountered a bug right as I was wrapping up to submit, and it took some time to fix. What happened was that sometimes the Idle Timer (a 2s timer when the enemy reaches a wall/ledge - where it plays an idle animation) timed out at the same time as the state timer (the 10s one) - and it caused some weird bugs. Happened rarely, but I still wanted to fix it, so I (think I?) did!

I spent time debugging the issue with the player not respawning when an enemy is killed. Apparently, since the Hitbox was managing the respawn, and the Hitbox was queue_freeing along with the enemy, the physics engine got confused and things broke. I fixed this by rewriting a major portion of the code so that the respawning would be handled by the player's CharacterBody2D instead. Finally, I went through the code for all the enemies and fixed the major bugs in the enemies (mostly caused by references to the Hitbox's internal respawning system - which I rewrote to use the Player's now!) Then, I followed the GDScript compiler's suggestions and resolved all the warnings. There are still a lot of bugs and issues to iron out, but mostly everything works now!

A lot of new improvements! I first added a system that uses export variables to hide the fruit counters which we don't need (in the demo video for example, I ticked off the strawberry, orange and pineapple counters and hence they are hidden!). I wanted this system because the UI bar was looking very cluttered, and no matter how big my levels may be, I don't think I'll ever need all of them at the same time (maybe in the last few levels?) - hence the system. It is checkboxes made using export variables, and then when the scene is initialised, it reads the checkboxes and determines which counters to hide. Then, I realised that the Player had no initiative to kill the enemies, so I first experimented with adding a random fruit drop system, and even though it (mostly) worked, I decided against it because of a few minor issues (like the Player colliding with the collectible immediately after the enemy is killed, which resulted in the counter being updated but no visual feedback). So instead, I designed a skull pixel art sprite, and used it to create a kind of "kill" counter for enemies. Now, to tie everything together, I added a way to select how many collectibles are REQUIRED to be collected on each scene, and then used that to determine if the level can end when the player touches the end point trophy. For example, in the demo video, there are 25 collectibles, but I can put the threshold at 20 and only when the player collects and kills more than 20 fruits and enemies, will the level end. If the player touches the trophy without collecting/killing this amount of enemies, the level doesn't end and a little "cross" is displayed for visual feedback (I might add in a buzzing audio later). I think everything works as per plan now!

I added a new Mushroom enemy! It just walks left and right, with an idle waiting state of 2s when it touches a wall/reaches a ledge. It doesn't actively seek out the Player like the others, but does hurt if it is touched. I also completed it with the hurtbox too, apart from the hitbox. And yes, all the animations work perfectly, and are tied well with all the timers.

I created a saving system! My initial idea was to use a binary file (since it would be non-editable and faster) but I decided against it as it would be more complex than other solutions. I finally stuck with using Resources to store information about the level times (so far, that's the only thing that needed saving). I do this by having an autoloading script with all the functions to save, load, reset a SaveData resource, which contains the @export variables which I need to store. Currently, it has a dictionary called level_times. In the Main script, I now assign a Level Name (01, 02, 03, ..., 50), which is passed on to the Level Finished (the menu thing) scene when the level is finished (after all the fruits have been collected and/or enemies have been killed). There, the scene calls the autoloading script's save_level_time function, where it updates the saved dictionary if the stored time is 0.0 (the level is begin attempted for the first time) or the new time is less than the stored time. Finally, I also decided to being work on the Settings menu, which right now just contains a hand-drawn Delete button that resets everything. I am happy with how everything looks so far!

I added a floating platform that flashes and falls down when it is stepped on. I also created a hitbox scene that all enemies can inherit from, and made a simple spikes enemy. I also made a moving saw enemy that moves along a path, and highlighted the path using a simple texture. I also played around with Physics layers, and now all the entities are on separate layers and masks. Also debugged an issue where the saw hitbox wasn't interacting with the player.

I finally added a new enemy! It is a Bee - that follows a set Path, and periodically shoots stingers (bullets)! I first had to create the basic animation player and make the bee follow the path, then I created the stinger scene and had to figure out a way to spawn the stinger at the bee's current location (it kept spawning a few 100 pixels to the right for some reason - fixed it by adding it to the root of the scene instead of as a child). Then, I noticed that the bullets being fired from below the bee don't look good as it starts moving almost immediately, so I added a small cooldown timer (it waits for 0.8s every time a bullet is fired before moving - giving ample time for the animation to play), then I made the fifth frame of the firing animation persist 5 times (it looked better that way). Lastly, I encountered a bug with the enemy kill hurtbox - where the Bee refused to die! I fixed it by rewriting the code with the PathFollow node as the root and not the actual root (the Path2D itself), as the global hurtbox only emits the signals of its parent (in this case the PathFollow2D).

I added a rotating spike ball enemy, and animated the rotation. I also added two different "smash" type enemies - one that travels from left to right, and one that travels from top to bottom (using raycasts). I also animated them properly (this took the most time, as there are four different states - smash left/top, idle, blink and smash right/bottom, and I had to try several different approaches to make sure they all worked properly (sometimes, two different animations played together, sometimes they played without delay), as well as create a modular system using export variables to set these things differently in each scene).

I added a UI for the level times! The initial idea was to have a TextureRect icon and a RichTextLabel for the level times, but I quickly realised doing that is simply not feasible for 50 levels. So, I first created a separate scene with the UI for the time (an icon and the time label). Then, I created a script that can manually add the times for each level based on a dictionary (I am most probably going to use this format to store the game data), and if the time is 0.0, it assumes the level is not reached yet, and makes its icon a bit darker (this part is handled by the level time UI scene (the icon and text)). Finally, I decided to add a red back button (to go back to the main menu) to the level selection and the level times scenes!

I was able to fix (hopefully?) the last bug in the Rhino Enemy! I limited the FPS to better analyze what was happening and the player sprite was being forced into the Rhino's collision box if it jumped just before it was hit by the Rhino, which caused both the Rhino as well as the Player to die at the same time. I first isolated this issue, and then fixed it having the Rhino treat the Player as a wall too, so (atleast in most cases) it will turn back before the sprites collide.

Set up my platformer game, coded the movement mechanics. Added double jumping, and Celeste inspired dashing (to be refined later). Also added CPU Particles 2D for dash effect (temporary solution, probably will refine later). Made the base animations for the Player Character.

I had to first fix the Rhino enemy (yet again!) as it was, for some reason, considering the Player a wall too. Then, I added a new enemy - a flying bird that falls down after reaching a max height, and that can only be killed when it is sitting on the ground. It has two primary states - one is rising (when it can be ridden on, like a platform), and one is falling (when its hitbox becomes active and it can hurt the player). It took a while to do the basic rising and falling, then I set up the collisions and hurt/hit boxes, and I think I have mostly resolved all the bugs.

I added Levels 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, and 26! I am doing Level Design a lot faster now, I think. I also realised I forgot to introduce the Chameleon and the Bee enemies - two of my favourites (they have some of the most complicated systems, hence why I like them so much) - so I properly did that in these levels. I think EVERY SINGLE enemy has now been introduced, so that's good (it took 26 levels haha). My level design is also getting a lot better in my opinion, as I can see that games feeling more engaging now. I think I will now work on mini-levels with harder puzzles (I have a LOT of ideas for that), as these 2 minute levels are getting (a bit) boring (but still fun to do, I think , thought I can obviously do a LOT better, and I will).

IT'S DONE! Level 50 is now finished - I went with a dual system where the level is half in sunlight, and half in a night like environment. The point light for the player only emits when the player crosses the ground level (demonstrated in the video). My original idea to do this with a DirectionalLight2D didn't work, so I just added 3 very big PointLight2D objects to the scene (no resultant lag, fortunately). I also added Music and a basic coin collection sound effect. I was planning on doing more but these look good for now. I also made a basic logo for the game, and added the volume/mute button to the settings, and added an effect that darkens it when the sound is muted. I also found out how decibels and linear sound volume are different in Godot (rookie mistake, I know!). I think the game is done now, so I'll work on exporting it.

I added Levels 16, 17, 18, 19 and 20 (Level 20 is again a night level - where the shadow tilemap and LightOccluders are used for lighting effects + shadows). I think the combined playtime is around 15 minutes now. With these 5 levels, I have also added all the levels for the first panel of the Level selection menu (shown in the video), so the game is really starting to come together now. I'm designing much faster now, since we have to publish in the weekend. I am also experimenting with a new type of puzzle, where I use multiple fans in a row together - I wanted to see if it's still possible to walk (fly?) when one is being pushed up by the fans, and apparently, YES! It is possible! I now have several more ideas for combining these with other elements to make more puzzles, and increase player engagement as well as player enjoyment! Also, I realised I had forgotten to set up autotiling in the new ShadowsTilemap, so I added that really quickly (only for the orange tiles right now, but I'll add for the rest really soon!). I have tested everything extensively and nothing has broken, so I think after level design and audio, I'll be more or less done!

I added moving platforms! They were tricky because I was originally just using an AnimatedSprite2D with a StaticBody2D, but quickly realised that wasn't working (the player wasn't moving with the platform). I was originally trying to solve the issue with an Area2D to detect if the Player was standing on the platform (and move the Player with the platform). But thankfully, I decided to use an AnimatableBody2D, which was better as it saved me the hassle of implementing a different system for keeping the Player on the platform, as now the Player moved with it! The animations and collisions work perfectly too, and so do the Raycasts (which I am using for detecting terrain and switching directions!).

I got started making one of the hardest enemies in the game - the Bat! What's hard is that it has an idle state, where it rests on the bottom of a tile, and then follows a set Path to fly, before going back to the resting spot! I have set up all the animations, and using Remote Transform (which I am using for the first time!) I was able to make something that "resembles" my initial idea! The hitboxes and other collision areas are still to be done, but I think this is good enough for this session! The Bat rests for 5s and then flies for 10s, and repeats this! It has a Path too, and it reaches this Path('s starting point) using linear interpolation (lerp() in Godot!) - another first time (I think)! I learnt a lot in this session!

I had to rewrite a lot of the movement code. Plus, I made double jumping better by adding a rolling animation for it! Then, I made the dashing a bit more like Celeste by removing the original CPU Particles and instead leaving a disappearing "trail" of sorts! Also, I added wall jumping, for later platforming, and also reduced gravity when the player is sliding against a wall!

First, I added a checkbox for the dashed line to appear for the saw enemy (this way it can be half embedded in the ground too, like in the video!). Then, I added one-way platforms (that only collide with the player when it is above them, and not when it is below). Also, I fixed a bug in the enemy killing signal (it was being emitted globally, so all enemies died when one was killed - changed the code so it was emitted locally). Finally, I created a new walking spiked turtle enemy! It has two states - spiked and unspiked. When it is spiked, it can hurt the player and walks left and right, but when it is unspiked, it can be killed by stepping on top. Currently the two states alternate (5s for spiked and 1.5s for unspiked - probably will change)!

I added a working checkpoint system, and all corresponding animations! The flag is furled at first, but unfurls and then waves once the player crosses the checkpoint! The last checkpoint the player activates becomes the active one (not the last "reached", but the last "activated"). Then, I added a spawn location (which also doubles as the first checkpoint) and an animated sprite for it. Lastly, I added an ending locations with an animated sprite that emits a global signal (using a Globals.gd script I made too), which pauses the player movement and the timer (and makes the text yellow for now, but later, will be used to save the best time).

I created a level unlocking system! Now, the subsequent levels will only be unlocked and become playable when all the previous levels have been finished. I did this by adding a levels_unlocked list to the Saved Data resource, and adding the next level's name ("01", "02", ..., "50") to it. For demonstration purposes, I also made a 3rd level to show how the levels are being unlocked! Oh and I fixed a bug where a previously unlocked bug remained unlocked even after the data was cleared from the settings, by updating the if-else condition for level unlocking. I also made the buttons (in the level selection) for the remaining 10 levels (had skipped on this earlier). I will be working exclusively on level design now!

I added Levels 10 and 11! So far, everything is working perfectly, and the levels are super fun too - both in designing and playing (if I do say so myself). These are again MASSIVE (about 3-4 minutes of playtime on each - I want to make the game long + as engaging as possible!). Level 10 introduced the Duck enemy and the Trunk enemy (as well as revisiting some of the older enemy types like the Saw Enemy and the Spike Ball Enemy). Level 11 is mostly already introduced ones (I think - not sure about the Chicken enemy) - the Snail, the Rocks, the Rhino, the Chicken, the Rock Smash and the Spiked enemy (I might have gone a little overboard with how many enemies I made haha). I have tested and ensured the level updating and finishing system works for both of them too (after the bug I encountered on Level 9). Finally, I also added auto-tiling (I think this is the first time I am using it). It doesn't work perfectly all the time - there are still a few bugs left to find, but I got the base system working (I think) for the three platform types - green, pink and orange (demonstrated in the video).

Added a new Ghost enemy! It appears and move around for 5s, and then disappears for 5s! I pivoted back to the simpler Raycast and Collision Areas approach again, instead of using Path2D. When the Ghost disappears, all its collision areas are turned off (as demonstrated in the video), and it can neither be killed nor can it hurt the player (both of which can only happen when it is moving). It floats above the ground and is relatively a faster enemy. Oh, and all the animations are working smoothly this time - no bugs there!

I finally got around to adding a very important mechanic - Collectibles! I have so far only added Apples, but I was able to set up the entire system! I am using an autoloading Global script which contains the signal for incrementing the count for Apples (emitted by the Apple Scene), which is received in the Main script (which all the levels inherit from) and used to increment the Apple count. I created a separate scene with the Collectibles UI Layer, which a CanvasLayer in the Main scene parents. This Control Node for the UI Layer with the HBoxes and VBoxes took a very long time, but I have made it so that even for 3-4 digit apple counts (hopefully won't be reached, but I might have a really long level so worth adding), the placement and order doesn't break. It took a while because I was trying a lot of things, but I am happy with how everything looks for now!

I added a LOT of levels - 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35 and 36! Level 29 is a night time level again - with dark tiles and shadows and special lighting (I like to think of these as special levels, and I think I will make it so that the final level is a mix of both dark and light levels (and it will probably also be the longest so far (currently I think the average time is around 1 minute per level (generally more)))). I also fixed a few bugs here and there (I notice them while designing the level's puzzles) - where the Plant Enemy was being killed twice somehow(?) - I have no idea what caused this, but while removing the StaticBody (the collision shape), it threw an error that a Null Instance couldn't be removed - I figured it was because it was being removed twice (or something was attempting to do this). Managed to fix it with a few if-else statements here and there. There were similar bugs with other enemies, but thankfully, everything is fixed now (or atleast the ones I noticed).

I created a scene transitioning system for the levels! Currently, I am using a simple rectangle with pointed edges(?). I made Level 1 inherit the World scene, made it local, and created a simple level. Then I added an export variable which allows a PackedScene to be uploaded to the Main Script, which is the next level. Then I created a new scene with a Texture Rect and a Polygon2D for the transition, and gave it an animation player and a simple script with functions to call the type of animation. Then, when the next button is clicked, this transition (which is an always on top CanvasLayer which gets added to the root, so it is preserved between scene changes) is called, then a timer runs for 1s. In this time, the scene is changed behind the CanvasLayer, and the transition rectangle moves right. I think there are definitely better ways to do this, so I will look into those, but for now, this seems good enough!

I finally added a Pause menu (should have done so a long time ago, it would have made demonstrating stuff s much easier)! First, I designed a custom button. Then, I created a new scene with a UI (Control) node, and created a very basic design (I am thinking of ways to make it more pleasing!) with three buttons - Back (for the Main Menu when I add it), Play (to resume) and Restart (to reload the current level, with all the enemies respawned, and the level timer at 0). Then, I made the Pause menu accessible by pressing the Escape key! I also debugged some HBox Icon placement issues. Then, I also added the Pause button (for accessibility!). Finally, I fixed the outline that comes on all buttons by default! I think it should do for now!

I spent this session debugging again. I still had many references to the Hitbox's safe_to_queue_free variable, so I first had to deal with those and make them use the Player's respawn function now (earlier a part of the Hitbox). Then, I noticed a bug in the Rhino enemy that caused the player to keep standing on it for exactly 1.5 seconds - turns out I had left a timer on it (as the hitbox queue_freed before the player respawned, causing a glitch - I used the timer to try and remedy this) which was not needed now as the Player script managed the respawn. Then I also noticed a problem with the Rhino's knockback which caused it to embed into the wall for some reason. Finally, I fixed some more bugs in the Chicken, Slime and the Turtle, as well as the Falling Bird enemy, and tested everything (the video shows how - visible collision shapes!) to make sure it was done.

New enemy! I added a Snail! It is actually not one but two enemies - the snail itself, and its shell. The snail is slow (for obvious reasons) - with its speed about 1px a frame, while the shell is comparatively faster (speed about 3px a frame). The snail first moves trying to hurt the player, but once its shell is jumped on, the shell itself spawns (the snail body fades away) and tries to kill the player. After the hurdles of coding the snail itself, with the shell, my first challenge was spawning it exactly where the old snail's shell was (as they are separate scenes) and it took some time to perfect. Then, I noticed that the shell was not flipping properly, and then when I fixed that, its Raycasts behaved weirdly for some reason (one of them randomly turned off) - so I brute force assigned them in the snail's code itself, based on the direction it was facing before dying. Finally, a huge bug was that spawning the shell with its hitbox and hurtbox intact caused either the player to die immediately after killing the snail, or the shell to die immediately after the player has killed the snail. I tried many approaches to fixing this, before sticking with an immunity timer of 1s (again, values might need tweaking) where the shells collisions are turned off (illustrated in the video with visible collision shapes). Everything seems to be working well now!

I added Levels 43, 44, 45, 46, 47, 48 and 49 (this was a PRODUCTIVE session haha). I will need ONE last level design session now, to design the final level (I could have crammed it in this one but it was getting too big, and I have no desire to anger the reviewers). All the levels are working as expected. I had also accidently deleted an important folder, but thankfully I was able to recover the project, so no progress was lost (hopefully - something might have broken that I haven't noticed yet). I also fixed an internal error in the editor (which did not come while running for some reason), where the SaveLoad GDScript's _load() function had some problem with the file not being a tool script (I had written some _ready() code which I removed, but I don't know if that broke something - hopefully not (again, I haven't noticed anything yet))!

I added a new enemy! This time it is a Chicken - very similar to the Rhino, but this time, instead of charging at only stopping when there is a wall/terrain, the enemy only attacks when the player is either to its left or right - using Area2Ds. I noticed a bug with this approach, and that was that the enemy would sometimes go straight through a wall to hit the player, or would fly (which in hindsight makes sense for a chicken haha!). I solved both these problems by using Raycasts, so that the enemy only moves when there is ground beneath and no wall in front. This time, I used my state based movement mechanic again (LEFT, RIGHT & IDLE states). Finally, I noticed the same bug - where the enemy would queue_free before the player respawns - I solved it by looping till the player has respawned before queue_free-ing (not the best approach, I'll solve this next, I think).

New enemy - Flying Radish (I have no idea where I got the idea!). It has a 10s timer, and it helps it switch between walking and flying states. It rises up gradually when flying, and has a slightly different animation and then falls when normally walking. I got all the collisions and animations working. The moving up gradually part was a bit difficult, but I got it working using move_toward() (I used lerp() for the Bat, and wanted to see how this is different!). There is also a 2s idle timer for edges/walls again - and it works! I hope nothing breaks again, but for now at least, all is well!

I removed the temporary Static Body 2D Nodes and added a dedicated Tilemap for the terrain! I set up the Physics and Collisions for all of the tiles too! Also, updated the timer display to be static relative to the Phantom Camera. I also made a custom .ttf font using a .png image and an online tool, to use in the game!

Added a new enemy (actually 3 at once!) - Rock(s)! These have a straightforward movement mechanic to just turn at a wall/ledge. The unique thing about them is that there are three of them! A huge one that moves the slowest, a medium sized one and the small one that moves really fast! My biggest hurdle was not knowing about shared resources in Godot (I think that's what they're called?) which repeatedly caused all the hitboxes to go haywire when I tried to copy-paste the collisions, so in the end, I just had to remake all the boxes from scratch. The big and medium ones are good, but the super-fast small one will usually die when it hurts the player once. This is technically a bug, but I will keep it as a feature haha!

Designed levels 6, 7 and 8! All of them are huge (I think 7th took the longest and is also the biggest yet)! I have also ensured that every single one is fun to play and VERY challenging (as I said, the point is to make the player want to come back and play again, to beat their personal best scores). 6 is an "air level" of sorts, with the falling bird and the flying (blue) bird enemies, and the spike, while 7th is a complex one with the Rhino and the 3 types of Rock Enemies being introduced. Finally, to keep the gameplay engaging, I designed the 8th level to be completely horizontal (minimal up and down movement so the player gets some sense of variation) - and it introduces the Bunny Enemy, the Turtle Enemy and the Snail Enemy! The idea was to make it to be a "grass level" or something similar haha. I think I'll spend time to properly introduce all the enemies first, and then design even more puzzling and challenging levels afterwards! I have taken care to ensure that nothing is broken (so far!).

I added one of the simpler enemies - a Slime! This time, instead of using my normal approach for enemies with a single Raycast and a "state-based movement system" (which produced a TON of bugs), I decided to use two Raycasts (left and right wall), and a movement system which just flipped the sprite and negated the speed whenever one of them collided (in hindsight, this is much better - I'll prefer this approach going forward). Then, I had to (obviously) resolve a lot of bugs with the Slime, particularly one where the player and the Slime both died when the player hurt it. I fixed it by adding a Static Body so that the player doesn't reach the Slime's hitbox, and the Static Body only gets deleted when the Slime is "queue_freed". Lastly, I added a very simple arrow animation, in case I need it later to guide players to specific locations in the level's map.

Description: In my opinion, the best types of games are those which reward speed and fluid movement, since they end up with incredibly satisfying sequences once the player gets good. That's what I sought to accomplish when making Quicksilver: inspired by combat sequences from games such as Cyberpunk, highlighting executes, dashes, and mobility, I created a roguelike game that would reflect the game I enjoyed most.

juiceStretches.description: Began implementation of a "last stand" system, where you get stat buffs + a unique screen when on low HP. also redid models for weapon cases, the shotgun weaapon and rebalanced them while fixing some bugs among enemies.
Finished low health mechanic where screen turns red + you get buffs, added a pulsing effect to timer + gold counter whenever they update.
Redid and completed art for a lot of icons throughout the game, such as damage and time icons.
Nearly Finished 4th floor, finished unique new boss (spawns a bunch of turrets, has unique actions based on hp), added enemies with mounted turrets, added some roooms to 4th floor.

Description:
Echoes Of The Past 
You play as person with suffering from overthinking, guilt and fear etc. You find your way to kill the monster within yourself. 

I love playing story based horror action games such as Resident Evil 7 & 8 and Cry Of Fear, I love the concept of puzzles and physiological horror game. Taking the elements of mental instability from Cry of Fear and for puzzles from Resident Evil. The house in my game wasn't big enough but I quickly came up with an idea to introduce looked doors and special code in the room filled with boxes.

juiceStretches.description: Made a function to random lock and unlock the drawers to give a sense of dreaming where weird things are happening.
completed the night sequence, we now have  a working TV and scary crying sound effect.

This stretch was quite long so here are bullet points.

1. Made a function to open only enabled doors.
2. Wrote script to make special interaction with interactables.

For example - The door has will be first locked when the player will interact with the it the woman will stop crying and then player can open the door.

3. added a crying animation.
4. Added new sound effect to make suspense
5. Made a dizzy effect
6. fixed minor issues with the doors
7. added fade in and fade out animation but can't unable to call them as per logs say in the above video.

The first nightmare sequence is completed. will work on the settings menu now

This is basic interaction system with drawers. Instead of putting actual 3D models into drawers i made a simple ui. Each drawer can have max 2 items. This information is loaded from a JSON file. 

In the next update i will polish this system.
The images shown in inventory and drawer interaction system are for test purposes.

Added a gun mechanism to the game, and yes this game won't have any limitations on ammo, so no ammo system. Also added a recoil function.

In this stretch i also worked on terrain design but i didn't like that one so i had scrap it out.

After investigating the issue of doors throwing away player I fixed this issue without compromising with interaction manager. last time i asked players not to stand in front of the door while opening them. This was due to physics collisions. Now i have added lines to ignore physics collision without making changes to the actual collider.

Also added a sound effect for item pickup, made this sound effect using python and numpy.

In the previous stretch I showed a big terrain with a lot of paths and a cabin and a church. But this time I streamlined my thoughts and made it more specific. Also added a zombie, with animations and sound effects. Also made a script to spawn zombies and attach components to it. Before completing the zombies scripts, I will work on optimizing my code specially references to scale my codebase.

Completed the sequence. The player needs to find the code, lighter and gasoline to burn the monster. 

after player have all these things he/she has to careful and go around the monster and put gasoline on it,, make sure to be quick otherwise player will die out of anxiety. 

After this monster burns and the game ends.

Will be building the middle seequences now.

First prepared a scene to with blood splashes took a screenshot wrote a basic python script to give image an old and creepy effect. 

Wrote sequence of 2nd nightmare to be demonstrated properly in next stretch

*The photo can be added to inventory

Made an anxiety system. So if the player is close to the monster for a long time then the player will pass out and wake up on bed. And the sequence will restart.

Added an anxiety meter with a beating heart.. Will add sound effect soon. 

Also added a battery meter. But not linked to scripts yet.
Made the new house, added post processing effects, made some optimisations, added player breathing effect. Also made fine adjustments to first nightmare sequence to be covered in the next video.
Door opens dynamically, interior design completed for the living room, now working on the first nightmare sequence.

1. The padlock code was a fixed code, so it was easy for players to get it. Now the code is random so even I don't know what code is correct.

2. The padlock timer was not working correctly because I was using OnEnable and OnDisable  which resulted in stopping the padlock as a whole.
Added a lock fade in and fade out animation, this tells the state of the door. The function is scalable and can be used to represent state of other intractables like fuse box etc.

Added sequence manager script. Made optimisations in enemy script - replace List data structure with Dictionary. Fixed cursor not getting locked. Added church bell sound. Added collider to church 3D model.

Radio now has 3D spatial audio so if the player walks away from the radio the music fades away and gives a realistic experience. Made some improvements in the environment - added trees, new bed, a table and a table lamp.

Added a flashlight, animation for opening and closing the door. A nice house and creepy environment. Its all core mechanics in this video. Only triggering nightmare is the part which I have not included here because its mostly the part of storyline.

Sorry for bad audio

The music in the game is Idea 22 by Gibren Alcocer so credit for this music goes to him

and the assets are downloaded from Unity Asset Store credit for these assets goes to their respective artists.

Last time the GenLocation was not giving correct y component. It's fixed now. Completed the enemy manager. Now zombies can be spawned on random location near player and the number of zombies is also random between 10-15. My cursor is not getting locked during playmode that's why it was difficult for me to kill all zombies. However, in actual cursor does get locked.

he friend told me that the monster part was kind of boring and might have been better. So i added a heartbeat sound, so if the player is too close to the monster the heartbeat sound is played and once player is away from the monster the sound stops.

Made a script that checks if an interactable item is nearby and shows an interact icon. This lets user know the interactables in the environment. 

had to scratch my head reading documentation of OnTriggerEnter and OnTriggerExit but it finally works

In the last stretch i wrote a drawer interaction script. it was working good when running standalone function but when i tried to incorporate it with inventory manager i.e moving items from drawers to inventory it raised issues. 

In this stretch i fixed the bugs, optimised code in terms of in-game references.

Made a monster type of thing that roams around the first floor. The player's object is to find the idol of lord buddha or similar entity that represents positivity. But the more time player takes the faster monster will chase player. Also implemented footstep sounds.

Due to complexity of animation graph there were few bugs:

1. the monster was repeating scream and audio (currently disable, more work required)
2. I know the walk animation looks non-sensical so i will change that too.

Integrated raw mechanics into game story. When the player comes out of the long lobby type area. The blob  starts makinng sound right 48 sec lights are off and monster is spawned. 

Gave monster his voice back. Sometimes it makes problem with animations but after a while it works fine.

Added first nightmare, if door is open then it is closed with a banging sound, light bulb is blown up and if the radio is active then whispers are played on it. Once the player comes out of house, a creepy woman (a test prefab is spawned there.)

This one was easy peasy :)))

For the second part of the story i made a script which rings the bell until player reaches to a particular area and discovers a map.

In this stretch i made the function to repeat ringing bell, spawn the map, and a skeleton structure of the inventory.

In this stretch i also worked on Fade In and Fade Out effect which i am not able to build properly so i haven't displayed them in this video.
Completed a padlock, if the player enters wrong passcode it beeps and if the failed tries exceed 3 the door is locked for 2 minutes.
Added an image if another drawer is empty. Add callback functions. Manually positioned objects into a seperate scene took screenshots ad now they are being used to display items.

I play tested my own game to make sure there were no bugs or issues with the first 4 mins with the game. 

Issues found:
1. Torch stopped working due to mess in input scripts.
2. The gun object was null and disturbed other function because no gun is required in the game except the forest fight.

Fixed both of the issues and made made changes in the house.

The house represents the mind of the player. Some negetive photo frames have been displayed to represent negetive feelings of the player.
Added this house, with floor and wall textures, the basic structure is ready more props will be added here.

Made a new terrain level, a forest with a lots of path. The player will introduced to some enemies and he will have to fight them off. 

This terrain is the terrain talked about in the previous stretch

added a missing line that resulted in zombies with no sound.

Tried to make a cutscene, built a one but I didn't like it. Also made some radio and table for the new house. The stuff I made in the shift was good but they didn't fit the story so I making the house. The old one will be replaced with the new one.

1. Added functionality to navigate through the settings menu.

2. added function to get supported resolutions and add option to drop down.

3. Improved lags when loading another scene.

Added basic open and close drawer. Fixed small bugs with drawer interaction system.

Now i will work on adding actual item images and sfx.

Upon releasing the previous build @tan on slack reported that the door of the TV room throws player to some position and the player keeps falling. So fixed this bug. The reason was that the doors were marked as static and baked for occlusion culling. It was also having issues with Box collider, fixed this for all doors. Also made optimisation in player movement script - removed unused variables from it and ran analysis on this build, noticed 5 FPS gain. Switched to point lights instead of spot lights, this fixed weird shadows and made the shadows more clear.

1. Made a sequence manager script that sets up sequences once previous one is over. 

2. Made a new sequence - Player hears door banging goes to check, goes through the lobby and in the room he hears a child laughing, a ball is thrown toward the player if he does not pickup  the ball within 10-15 secs the mother gets angry lights go off, color of light turns red, a lady screams and the player dies out of anxiety. But if the player takes the ball then he can proceed, wheen he exits he sees blood stains he follows the blood stains and the chandelier falls but he wakes up in his bed. And then the same monster sequence.

3. Fixed door opening very quick, now doors open in a more realistic way and closes too, which was an issue before.

4. Added rain sound

Will now work on scripting for this menu.

Had an issue with OnTriggerEnter it had a return statement within OnTriggerEnter resulting in unreachable code. Debugged it and fixed it. Baked Nav Mesh surface.

Made first loop where the statues changes from load Buddha to a creepy animal head.

In this strech:
1. made basic ui
2. wrote Inventory Manager

In previous version of Inventory System raw datastructure i.e list/dictionary was used. In this version AssetReference object is used for memory optimisations.

after uploading windows and mac build of the game @spc and Aarush (dm) reported game crashing when loading another scene. Also, the transition between two sequence was not working. 

In this long stretch i did the following things:

1. Tried diffferent ways to load different scenes - but none of them worked yet. Upon diagnostics (Unity  Profiler) i found that it is due to memory overload. 

2. Tried different ways to setup transition scripts, 

3. Made a basic pad lock.

@spc reported that "E" key for interact was not working. 

4. Fixed it, reason - _OnInteractDoor function was not updated correctly.

I spent most of my time finding ways to fix the memory issue. But maybe i dont have enough experience to handle my own work :) so i am moving forward with whole game in single scene (priority and then include that another scene).
I implemented the core player movements and a radio that WORKS. The music you will hear is Idea 22 by Gibren Alcocer so thanks to him.

Worked on optimisations, enabled occlusion culling and disabled ambient occlusion saving 56% of CPU usage.

The house is under construction :) will upload it soon, this one is a sequence where the game starts, player is watching tv and electricity cuts off. Player uses torch to go to fuse box and restart power when the player comes back and is in a specific range a scene starts up on the TV that hints towards the past.

Description:
I wanted to give people a sense of repetition, but not the bad kind, the kind that is still fresh and gets you motivated to keep going, it's about zombies, but there was going to be easter eggs, hidden stories, THE LOREEE. You die, but that's not the end, you could do another run, on another body, without the whole charade of pressing play, create a new character, all of that. It's just a new person entering the same room you died, looting you, and that same person is you, that's it. 

Even though the idea of the game was created 30 minutes before the first call of Juice, i got some pretty good laughs with my friend, and generally was a good short experience for us! Thank you Juice!

DungeonForge
We're a bunch of high schoolers who just made our first game! When we first heard of this opportunity, we couldn't believe our own eyes! 4 of us came together to make our first game! Only two of us were able to go to Shanghai. One didn't even want to go in the first place, because he wasn't ready for a trip this big. The other one wanted to go but he couldn't get the 100 hours of Juice. At the start, we had pretty big expectations and much on our minds, but we weren't able to fulfill all of them. We had lots of ups and downs. As we were coming to the end of the campaign, we ran into more problems than expected. In the very end it was a rush, but we managed to put the game together.
We have a blue-colored main character with a blue gem in his chest, which functions as a backpack. His job in this world is to explore and get to the top of the food chain by killing various enemies and bosses while also collecting cool stuff.

juiceStretches.description: Helped with making the map layout and bugfixing in Unity, fixed mistakes in my previous drawings. Also made the main menu elements, drew a background for the cave section in the game. Although I've come to the realization that I struggle with drawing clouds (Tried making them alone - didn't work, so tutorials helped a lot haha), I also made a generic background for the "overworld". I might improve on it in the future, but there are more important stuff to focus on rn. Even if we talk about backgrounds, I think it looks better than downloading random premade assets, so there's that.

Made a "respawn anchor" for our checkpoint system. Tried out 3 color palettes (lol) before we agreed on one.
Finally made a logo for the game! It is put together with assets from the game, like the two main tilesets, a sword, and the iconic blue gem which our main character has in their body. Making it was really a hassle because - although the tileset was there to work with - there are many edge-cases with writing letters with 16x16 tiles so this is why we couldn't draw it in Unity and then "screenshot it out". Every tile was placed by hand. At first, we made it 1 tile (16 pixels) wide but it was too slim so I had to remake the whole thing to get it with 2 tiles width (32). This also opened the opportunity to make it more detailed, and so we did.

I was chosen to do the scenery for the game. Due to some IRL stuff I couldn't work that much in the recent weeks (hence the few hours), but hey, better late than never right? These are just some basic arts to get me into drawing (since I know nothing about pixel art and arts overall), most of them are gonna get improved on.

Redrew some of the available items in the game, also made 16x16 and 32x32 versions of them. Added keyboard and mouse icons for the tutorial section of the game. Added a hotbar with 4 slots to show what the player currently has equipped.

Helped out importing the tilesets in Unity cuz there were some problems with the slicing, also made a "barn" backgrounds. Slowly but surely learning how to make these kinds of stuff, also finding out some basic Aseprite shortcuts now D:
My lack of knowledge in arts is really showing

Made a tileset for the cave section of the game. Had to redraw the pattern a few times cuz the team didn't like it and there were some mistakes/problems with the color palette, but in the end we settled on this one. The tileset has 20 tiles (my other one had 22 but we'll still have a job of putting these tiles together).

I drew a few more armor types because we are planning to add more armors into the game in the near future (could be possible before Shanghai but the guys are tired so Tuesday will probably be about chilling). In this time, we playtested a few times with the available stuff to be able to push the game to a sort of playable state while trying(!) to fix bugs that occurred (like play button not starting game or the game throws us to main menu if we die). Also we struggled a bit because one of our level just disappeared so we had to remake it (classic Unity). Besides that, we should push out the 30 min demo soon if everything goes as planned.
I also made a plain wheat field background from my previous "barn" background to have some diversity in backgrounds. It still took some time to finish it because I didn't really want to have too many repeating patterns. I also made some icons for the inventory, because the game needs to be languageless and we still have some text left over from stats. Also made a "Back" button for the main menu since it was missing.
Some previous starter arts that I forgot to show in the previous vid, also made a cool looking dirt-y tileset

For the first section of the video, you can see a few bugs with the player movement, I spent a little time trying to fix these. Although we are learning programming at school, they didn't teach us how to read each others code, so it was a pain in the ..., but managed to fix a few of them. After that, I edited the map layout and placed down a few items that you can pick up during gameplay. I finally made our cave entrance the guys have been waiting for since a long time. Worked so much on those flowers and rocks in the hillside to look good lol (this will be a frequently visited place so it has to look great) (I used tutorials again, tested out many things but in the end I think it looks neat, I placed the "flowers" and the "darker grass" by hand on the hillside so it doesn't get messed up)

Description: When I was participating in High Seas, I saw the Juice event and told a friend who's an artist and could make sprites for me. He's interested in China and speaks Chinese. Description:
Spacegoose: 

Story of game:
You are a goose stranded on Earth. One day, you encounter a golden goose who gives you a daring quest to reclaim the stolen golden egg from the tyrannical duck overlords. Your journey takes you across the plains of Earth, through the Moon’s craters, over Mars’s red deserts spoiled by the ducks’ asteroid machine, past the unforgiving asteroid belt, and finally into a strange, dreamlike realm. Only then, you reach the ducks’ massive mothership. You face the evil grey duck in an intense battle, defeat him, and claim the golden egg. With your mission complete, you return the egg to its rightful owner at last. Be ready to be challenged by the vigorous obstacles and puzzling layout of levels! 

Our story:


As we pondered upon the prompts given to us in that fateful markup document that we had to pitch our game in, there was a flood of bewildering ambition. Being the sadistic psychopaths we are, making players suffer is an obvious inspiration for the game mechanics. However, we also wished the game to be of enough quality such that the players wouldn’t be bored to death in part due to the difficulty. Despite our beating hearts, we had practically zero knowledge in game development with a sophisticated engine like Godot. Nevertheless, we were stably progressing in our initial weeks by flopping between tutorials, improvisation, and some vibe coding sinning. Interestingly, we found our knowledge to grow quite quickly with this model of creation. Though during March break, we were forced to lock in to speed up progress. Throughout this process, we were proud to see our game grow feature by feature, level by level, and our experience grow with the passing of each productive day.
