Description:
Awakened - You wake up again, it's been a hundred years since you last roamed the earth. Your duty calls and... wait wait that's not it. You are a space traveler who crash landed into this bizarre planet and have to go around trying to find bits of you're broken ship that - uhmm wait that doesn't sound right. You are a time traveler, oh how about a time traveler cyborg orphan! Wait no ditch the time travel, we got no time for that. 
Before the game even began, our game never seemed to have a clear identity. It was always morphing and changing, retcons left and right. What we didn't realise was while we were spending so much time worrying about everything around the game, the deadline loomed closer and the juicer remained empty. Eventually - through the hard way - we realised when it came to making a first ever game, practicality and simplicity was king. This game is the culmination of our blood sweat and tears. Our mistakes, our frustrations, our laziness. But also our creativity, our diligence, our skill. This game was nothing I wanted it to be, and yet, I couldn't be prouder.

juiceStretches.description: Finallyyyyyyy, finished the tile maps, never have to touch them again, (except for level design ofc), I tried many different approaches but using the inbuilt autotiler to fit my own functions was eventually what I ended up with (my own programmed autotiling system was soooo buggy) (also if you didnt notice I created like 30 more tiles :skull:) (also I did like way more than 4 hours of work but a lot of it got scrapped so I only logged the nonscrapped stuff ;-;)

THE FIRST TIME I'VE MADE AN ART ASSET BEFORE!!! (The Ground and the background, forest theme) This honestly took way longer than I expected, the idea was to draw everything for our game but I'm not sure how possible that is :sob:

Wall Climbinggggggg - there are so many nuances to wall climbing I never thought about as a player, like how when you are on the floor and running at the wall, you would want it to only activate wall climbing after you've completed your whole jump. Also some movement fixes and smoothness
Art and animation for the boar bosssss, still a couple more animations to do for this boss but its definitely starting to come together!!
Start menu, was trying to figure out manual scene changes but then realised godot literally has a function that can do it for me and it has just been hidden in the documentation

We now have a working health bar!!!!! As well as an energy bar for an upcoming future feature (its a secret :p) This was long over due, but like with everything else we are making all the art assets ourselves so it took a while for me to get around to it. Also some bug fixes with the enemies where for some reason some of them wouldnt die when I attacked - luckily they do die now

Spent two hours debugging code from messy pull request :sob:, I don't have anything to show for other than a game that is actually playable now, sorry. Github and Godot do not mesh well, either that or my team is horrible at clean code. If you guys dont accept these two hours, thats fully understandable. :(
The boar has animation nowwwwww

camera now follows character, added acceleration to movements (super exaggerated for demonstration) and jump can be cancelled mid jump by letting go of the key for a shorter jump - also realizing for other movement options like dashing and wall jumping i may need to learn how to make a state machine ;-;

Have a door that closes on boss fight arenas now, and it re opens when you kill the boss, some enemy bug fixes with player interaction and cleaning up enemy navigation code. Also worked on improving the enemy art.
Made new art for the goose because team mate said it should be angled towards the screen slightly, also attatched it to the actual goose boss
Added attacking, can finally kill enemies. Also fixed some movement bugs -  player can actually fall off now rather than floating in the air, dashes are not stored and do not become infinite.
Set up files, linked to github and got very simple movement done

I know it looks like im not making much progress, but I promise im spending every hour working on this :sob:. As an update, I have added about 20-25 new tile variations to create more depth (including single tile platforms now) and have started working on my own auto tiler through code (the godot one isnt powerful enough to have multiple depths). The fact that I got any amount of code working in the editor is a miracle to me, I didn't even know you could add to the godot engine that way (feels like making my own game engine features)

Taking a break from tiles because i feel like progress is very slow. Instead, here is biblically accurate goose :). The enemy code for the goose has been made by one of my team mates but they haven't merged yet so for now you only get stationary biblically accurate goose.

Player animation pretty much done! added an actual idle animation which makes the player more dynamic, as well as a jump and a wall cling and a dash. Took a while because I also had to change the size of the player, meaning I had to re edit all the previous animations to fit the new size

after finishing up the big task that was the boar animation, I've decided to do some miscellaneous tasks. I did level design for the first world, splitting it up into separate rooms/scenes, I made some improvements to the player movement, like making the dash have a reload timer and only being able to activate once while in the air. As well as when attacking or dashing while wall clinging, doing the action opposite to the wall (the direction the player is going in atm) Also created a sprite for the doors that block the boss arena

Implemented an enemy placement system that makes level designing much easier and fixes some bugs the enemy had. Also worked a little bit more on animation, fixing a bug where idle attack animation would not work.
Fixed goose boss pointer problem, Player jump bug, and made enemies more modular
Health bar, and foudation for UI :)

Finally got the animation player working, was bugging out and turns out I had a node that I needed to delete. 20 minutes of testing for bugs just to realise it was a dumb mistake really does something to you

Restructured the entire player code so that it works via an enum state machine, making debugging easier and future coding much cleaner, also implemented dashing (the restructuring took like 90% of the minutes and with a finally clean code, the dashing was much quicker to implement).

reworked whole animation system to work with state machine (using animation tree) + knock back bug fixes (the player would be launched to the moon) and knock back immunity animation (the black flashing). Also found a bug with the knock back, which I will look at fixing later

Finally have room transitions!!!! we can get into proper level design and construction. Truely I had to iterate through like 5 different ways of room transitioning before I landed on this one that was smooth. Plusss I also added smooth camera movement that isnt just attached to the player but sort of follows the player.
attacks work on enemies, took longer than expected because ran into some bugs that I had to fix, also resized the screen
Made an ingame level editor using the tilemap layers system, adding collision and autotiling based on surrounding tiles

This was a long one - Biggest thing I worked on was player animation. Not only can you attack while moving now! (Implemented a separate attack state machine) But you can do it while looking original and sick, thats right, my very own art asset.  (Animation was such a pain, thats why this took so long) - Of course there was some other bug fixes, maintaining code, and changing the collision system as well.

Turned the texture I made into a tileset that can be used to auto tile. Figuring out all the configurations and combinations was so tiring and while it works, I still need to polish this through some more tile variations ;-;

Fully finished the boarrrrrr - thats with idle animation, jump spin animation, and charge up/ stomping the groud animation. Also made the camera lock into the boss arena (ngl forgot if that was this stretch of last one :skull:)
Level Design!!!!!!!!! The whole game (or at least what it will look like in juice) is designed. Now to just record the 30 min game play (after some player improvements and fixes)

Description:
Dust and Dawn

I wasn't there when my teammates started our Juice game, but I'm glad they invited me to join them. My friend, Esther, discovered Hackclub and the Juice event, and our other two friends, Peter and Layla, did the art for it. I am a huge coding beginner, and like the others who worked with me, I had never created a video game before. But as an avid gamer, I had always wanted to make one. I just didn't have the knowledge, skills, resources, or motivation to go through with it. Juice was a huge opportunity to not only start working on a game, but to actually finish it. Our game, Dust and Dawn, is a simple platformer game that follows a soot sprite. The sprite is based off a stamp collection of the susuwatari from the Studio Ghibli movies owned by Esther. It was supposed to be a story game about a soot sprite bringing light to a dark world, but based on time constraints, we decided to make a simpler version of the original idea. Now, our soot sprite travels through different levels, helping characters with various tasks. Hopefully we can continue working and change the concept of the game later, but I'm really glad with the way our Juice game turned out in the end.

Description:
Hole in One - Japanese Mini-Golf

By: Keira Pereira

Slack: @Keira Pereira

The beautiful intricate culture of Japan combined with the simple amusement of mini-golf. In my game, you navigate your way through 11 challenging courses of Japanese themed mini-golf to reach the end, where your score will be tallied up. In my game, you are able to play single-player as well as multi-player by simply adding as many players as you like in the menu. 

My mini-golf game was made to highlight Japan and all its wonders. When brainstorming for my game, I knew I wanted to make mini-golf, I just love it, but I quickly realized there are not many mini-golf games out there that are visually unique or with themes, they are all relatively the same with the same classic obstacles; fences, rocks, posts, etc. So, that is what brought me to create my Japanese-style mini-golf. A colorful, beautiful and unique landscape that changes with every level. 

The journey of making this game was so fun, I was constantly creating amazing assets like glowing lamps, boats, origami, tea, sushi, tables, cherry blossoms, etc. I really enjoyed creating these beautiful items throughout my game. With every level, a new idea/obstacle came into my head and I found this project to be an amazing creative outlet. In addition to this, the code was relatively simple for this game as well, so I just had a blast creating these visually appealing levels. 

The main difficulty I faced during this journey was navigating the Unity engine. This was my first time ever attempting to create a game, and I had no idea where to even start and how to use the Unity tools. With that being said, I kept researching and learning with videos how to navigate every aspect of Unity, and was able to create a end product that I am truly proud to share with the world. 

With this being my first attempt creating a video game, it still blows my mind I was able to put in the hours of hard work while staying dedicated to the end goal in order to have this beautiful, fully functioning video game that I have the amazing opportunity to share on Steam, the biggest gaming platform in the world.

Thank you to Hack Club for this incredible opportunity. I will never forget this amazing experience surrounded by such bright and like-minded coders.

juiceStretches.description: Created and finished the 8th course. I spent more time than I would like to admit trying to perfect the glass case that holds the katanas. Creating the glass material and getting the shape right for those took a long time, and then creating the wall composed of those cases took even longer as the proportions were off and things needed to be changed but then it would scale every individual part of each case so then I would need to go back and fix it for each one, it was a whole thing. Happy with the results though!

Modelled and created a giant cherry blossom flower that I am going to use as an obstacle in the next course. Took forever to make and I promise the video does not do it justice, it'll look better in the course.

So I was having this issue where my line renderer in my scene stopped giving different colours for each player. Originally in my player record there were a series of colours that would correspond to the number of players which was working great. For example, the line renderer on player one would be blue and for player 2, red. But, once I transferred my game to my laptop I realized this function didn't work anymore. It was only appearing grey for every player. So I spent a really long time trying to figure out the issue, but it was really difficult because it worked on my PC but not on my laptop, but the code, line renderer and player record were identical on both. Later on after lots of troubleshooting I fixed the issue which had something to do with a _Color function being _BaseColor for laptops. So that's what I did during this stretch. I know the colours are super dark in the video, I'll make them lighter later, but they do change now.

Game starts on first player, once they get in the hole successfully, game automatically cues the next player with their name displayed and a color change of the ball. Once all players have gotten in the hole, the scoreboard will console pops up (im making the scoreboard later)
Coded the movement of the ball, got the camera angle on the tee.

Made it so the scoreboard pops up after all the players have completed all the holes of the course. Made it so the putts of each individual player is added up in the scoreboard for when the game is complete to see who won

Finished 4th course, starting designing 5th course where there are grey squares (will make them look nicer) so when you touch them you are brought back to the last place you putted from, so the player has to avoid that spot.

Trouble shot code issues. Code wasn't working or being transferred to the second course, but I managed to figure out the issue after a while. Implemented the new ball style into the second map and changed up a couple of things about the second course.
Made the input for your player name where once you add the # of players and continue, you automatically get transported to the first course
Continued to design the third course of the golf game. Wanted a special glow effect to mimic Japanese lanterns which I achieved!!! Adding obstacles in next time, super happy with the progress.

Spent a lot of time refining the menu page to make it more appealing. My OMG moment is I got this really good animation type transition on the title of my game which looks really cool, and I got my placeholders/text inputs to be in the right spot and centered which is something I struggled with initally. Menu page complete

So in my 10th course of my game, I was having this weird issue where my ball would just start rolling backwards and not stop or roll immediately over to the side. I spent a very long time trying to fix it many many times by rotating the ground, tweaking the ball physics, rotating the maps, etc. Nothing worked. So I showed in my video the original course where the ball would roll funny and then to solve this issue I ended up just re-creating the entire course all over again, and it seemed to work. So at the end of the video you can see the new Level 10 course I made.

Working on the finishing touches of the first and second course, tweaked sizes and placement of obstacles as well as lighting and visual effects for the best player experience. Tweaked the size of the aimer, changed player name size, etc.
Designed and created entire second course!
Finished design of course 1 and 2, currently working on course 3!
Created flag for the hole of the courses, made it so ball does not go through obstacles, designed second course

Created and finished the 9th course. I did rearrange every course though so technically this one is actually the 4th course now, but that doesn't really matter. I heavily modified the 9th course (that used to be the 4th, which is shown at the end of the video) It was having lots of technical difficulties where you'd get stuck in the rock wall, the boat box collider wouldn't let you pass it, the invisible walls weren't placed correctly, too many obstacles in the starting section with invisible box colliders everywhere. It was kind of a mess. But I fixed it all up and it works smoothly now. Also changed what the cherry blossom trees look like

Finished the entire 7th course! I was really excited about the pipes I made that the player has to go through to get to the hole as well as the little slide type route on the way down. Took a while to create the whole map and get it to work smoothly, but it was worth it!

So I didn't really make anything new in my stretch, what I did was I went into all my scenes and tweaked small details to make my game more playable/easy. I had some people test my game and it was quite difficult. Since I tweaked something on majority of levels, I didn't record EVERYTHING because that would've been a HUGE video, but in these two videos I made it so you can go under tables in my restaurant hole (as requested from players) and I also made it so you can actually get up the hill on the third hole because it was impossible before. In other scenes I scaled and moved obstacles in practically every scene to make it easier. For example, in the pipe scene I made the pipes a lot bigger because people were having issues getting up it and in my water/bamboo scene I moved water and got rid of some bamboo because it was too difficult.
Made golf hole for ball

Worked on the menu page to make it so the letters/inputs appeared more clean and neat. Added a sound effect so when you putt the ball it makes a putt sound and when you sink the ball it also makes a noise (i'm not sure if you can hear it in the recording)

Finished the 5th course! Added bamboo obstacles as well as signs to indicate that the water is "toxic" and will kill your player and bring them back to the last place they putted from if they touch it. Also finished the scoreboard fully
Made a holder for golf ball, re-did the ball movement code, added an aimer with line renderer.

Designed the menu for my game, I was having lots of technical difficulties with the golf clubs, but I figured it out after a while. It was also hard to think of a way to show "select how many players you want" without using words.
Added power bar for aimer that allows you to hold space and choose how much power you want to shoot the ball with!

So this juice stretch was a little strange, I started off designing my 10th course but then while I was working somehow I accidentally deleted my prefab for my golf flag when I was cleaning up some folders. So I lost my golf flag on EVERY course. So I had to go design another one, which took a very long time and then I had to manually scale and place it in every course along with making new materials for the flag on the glowing courses because it has special glowing red and white colors on those courses. So I didn't really know how to prove I deleted my prefab by accident, but if you look in my video, on the left you can see the hole trigger section and within that there is the golf flag item which has the text next to it showing the prefab is missing. Under that you have the new flag I put in. Also at the very bottom of my game, you can see the flag I made. So this was pretty frustrating to have to re-do because I'm trying to focus on my courses. But that's ok, all part of the process.

Working currently on the shape of my 11th course. I made the floor so far for it, because this course is A LOT bigger than my other courses, I needed to scale my hole and the ball in order for it to appear bigger on the course once I fitted the scene camera for the course. The ball and hole was originally way too small, players wouldn't be able to see it. But, once I scaled the ball, the line renderer that helps players aim the ball did not scale with the ball and it was so small you could not see it, so I spent my juice stretch creating the floor for my course, scaling my objects and figuring out how to scale my line renderer to fit the ball, which was actually really hard and time consuming, I had to stop my stretch, research how to fix it, and try again. This is what my line renderer looks like now:
Currently working on the code to save player records and bring them into the game, trying to make the game also multiplayer

So I was having that same issue with my 11th course where my ball would randomly start rolling/falling to the side when it was supposed to stop. So I had to re-do the entire course again. So in this video at the beginning, I show the finished 11th course that I made during my stretch. It took a while to re-create the course, do the cherry blossoms and get the cherry blossom effect, but I think this turned out really nice for the time that went into it. At the end of the video I show the shape I originally had for the 11th hole.
Created the first tee for the course, going to add it into Unity and add 3D objects.
Finished the 6th course. Spent most of my time making these really nice cherry blossom trees and making the scene very nature focused, I really like how they turned out
Changed physical appearance of sushi ball. Added all the physics to ball, made it so it bounces off walls and doesn't just hit it.

Created and finished the 10th course of my golf game. Spent a surprising amount of time trying to get the shape right for the cups of green tea. I definitely didn't think it would take that long, but got it in the end!
Created the scoreboard for the game. Made it so the font size of the score grows/shrinks with the font size of the player name
Finished  the third course, adding obstacles and making it so the ball bounces off obstacles. Debugged an issue with the scoreboard in the code which took a while.

So, my game crashed and I lose the majority of my entire game, which was so frustrating and disappointing. But, I learned a new modeling technique for my course which was nice and I rebuilt all the progress I lost.
Made it so the input actually displays text, fine-tuned menu design
Designed 4th course, trying to finish it later today.

Created the 6th course! Not quite finished yet, but I have all the basic ideas down and was really excited about creating these tube things as a more challenging obstacle for players to have to get up to avoid the toxic water

In this stretch I fixed my line renderer so that the color was brighter. For some reason all the colors were rendering really dark so you couldn't really differentiate between players. Now I thought that I'd be able to just adjust manually the colors and make them lighter but turns out I had to modify and play around with a bunch of different functions of the line renderer to get the brighter color which took a bit. The second thing I did was I took one of my assets that I had not created and modelled it so I had made the asset. I did this because my game is done and I was a little bored, so in my video you can see the lamp in the middle of the two other ones is the lamp replica I had created and you can also see the line renderer (aimer) of the ball that is brighter now.

Description:
Flower Escape
This is an adventure by a witch and cat to escape to Flower Land. Started with almost zero experience, but I had many exciting first times and found many very  helpful resources while juicing.  I wouldn't say it was a great game but I had so much fun in the developing and play testing with friends ! Many thanks to juice for making this happen ! !

juiceStretches.description: 2 new level+bouncy clouds~
add second player and level switch. attempt to add a multi-target camera but it has some problems showing, I would try a split screen next time.
fixed a not workable button in pause menu. replaced a character body box with rigid body bc of errors of collision mask
2 new levels and push box function.
a slit polish to the portal. transformed to lock screen levels after attempting multi-target camera but fail to provide smooth vision. Also learned a new window trick to make it scretchable.
fixing issues found in play test: the animation of collectable water, pause menu, spite for smash level.
made main menu and upgrade pause menu, learning about how to save process. experimented with different assets(trying to figure out an overall style.

created 'fly jumping' effect, slowing down the speed of falling though changing gravity settings
learned how to increase number of jumps
used player assets from arks here for the code testing

improved jumping~ add buffer jump and coyote time, and  after many attempts to fixing error of exceeding maximum jumps I finally removed the double jump function for one longer jump which actually worked out well :) and did some modification in the levels to match that jump height =0-432`
elevator level~~

Description:
DungeonForge
We're a bunch of high schoolers who just made our first game! When we first heard of this opportunity, we couldn't believe our own eyes! 4 of us came together to make our first game! Only two of us were able to go to Shanghai. One didn't even want to go in the first place, because he wasn't ready for a trip this big. The other one wanted to go but he couldn't get the 100 hours of Juice. At the start, we had pretty big expectations and much on our minds, but we weren't able to fulfill all of them. We had lots of ups and downs. As we were coming to the end of the campaign, we ran into more problems than expected. In the very end it was a rush, but we managed to put the game together.
We have a blue-colored main character with a blue gem in his chest, which functions as a backpack. His job in this world is to explore and get to the top of the food chain by killing various enemies and bosses while also collecting cool stuff..

juiceStretches.description:
Made an equipment system, that changes your stats (the stats don't have effects yet). Made some placeholder sprites for the equipment.
Also, learned aboud unity's version control, and made a collaboration so We can work on the project together from now on
Made player movement with double jump, made some pixelart, but man, Unity IS HARD! I am thinking of buying an online course, but I still haven't decide yet.

I helped in the making of the sving system.
I drew out a map for the cave. I made 5 armors. I tried to be unique with them, but it's hard to make them unique and not overpowered at the same time. There's three basic armors with more stregth or defense or neutral, an agility armor with a slightly longer dash and there's a tank armor with invincible dash and a lot of defense. I also remodeled the EQ inventory a little bit, I think it looks better this way.

I drew some bubbles, and minor arts for some items. I made the equipment system's ability part. It was a pretty big challange, but I was able to do it on my own. After making the equipment system work, I started working on some abilities. The first one is a wink, where the MC winks, and the nearby enemies get slowed down. The second one is throwing a branch, that deals damage. The third one is throwing a blob of slime on the floor which damages the enemy. I also had to fix the look of everything. From the start my friend and I just scaled things up in unity until they looked good. Now I made everything the same pixel per unit, and I undid the scales. But because of that I had to redo the colliders and hitboxes too. We started working on the boss behaviors, but that's my teammate's main job, I just help him if he gets stuck somewhere or doesn't know how to solve something. We still have a lot to go, but I have my hopes high!!

I think I just spent way too much time learning Unity basics. But at least I understand it now!
I started watching a lot of tutorial series, but not all of them seemed good. In the end I followed Brackeys tutorial on 2D games. I really liked it. Now I just need to learn Unity on a deeper level, make some pixel art, and animations! I also experienced with pixellab.ai, but I haven't made anything, that's worth showing.

I made the tutorial boss for the game! The animations are not final, because a lot of the things will appear on the screen through unity, so I didn't bother much with the roots striking up, or with the branches falling. It was just a small showcase of what will happen in the game.

Made a third boss for the game! I may add another attack to it, but I don't know it yet. Made the airborne attacks for the main character's weapons. Also made some abilities.
The first ability is throwing a branch, but the branch itself will be put there inside unity. I feel like I am finally getting the hang of animating, but I might have to go back to programming, beccause the person who has to do it has run into some barriers. However I'm feeling pretty good about the progress I made.

I made the final boss for the game! I had to do a lot of bugfixing with the inventory, I made more armor prefabs, and I connected all the scenes. I also put down some checkpoints. I also had to do many configurations on the animations. We are building the game, tonight I probably won't have much sleep, but I think we did it!

Made the first boss's pixelart!!! I thought if I make the first boss a Slime, it would be an easy task, but oh man was I wrong! I had to redraw the boss's shape hundreds of times until it looked acceptable. The bubble blowing attack's bubbles aren't final, we hope that we can make them appear inside of unity, because I think it would be the best that way.
We are also working on a small story for the game, but nothing to show yet... The next boss is going to be a tree.
I hope I will finish it pretty fast, because we need many more to make the game last at least 30 minutes!

Learning Unity!!!
Made a basic movement "game" from a tutorial.
Added some spice to it on my own to really understand Unity, not just follow a tutorial.
Finally making some progress!

Made enemies, that hit you, gave the player a health bar, made a background asset, I finally see myself out of tutorial hell. It took me a lot of time to get here, but I think every moment was worth it! I am looking forward for my future goals too!

Made some art: 
The main character (not sure, if it's final)
Grass tile
Dirt tile
Cave floor tiles

We also mapped out the tutorial part of the game (I did it with my teammate)

We started making the maps! My friend finished the tilesets for the game. I made ruletiling in unity, so making the maps will be easier. I gave different damages for different weapons, and I had to redo the ranges on the weapons, because there was a bug with MC's hitbox and we had to change some things. I added dash for the MC's movement.
I made the Equipment system's armor part. Now if you equip something, your stats not just get updated, but now the stats matter! We have an attack, a defense, an agility, and a dash stat (the dash stat affects the length of your dash).
We also have an armor, which gives you invincible dash. Now one of my teammates just has to make some armor arts! I had to do some changes in the ability system, because when you unequipped an ability, you could still use it :/.  I used a simple formula for the defense stat: takenDam = dam/(1+(def/10).
I really hope we can finish the game by the deadline and go to Shanghai! wish us luck!

Started making the main character of the game, and made a running animation to it!!!
Animating is really hard, but I am not giving up!
I learned the fundamentals of animating, and I hope from now it it'll go much smoother.
Also made a bunch of boss concepts.

Made a basic inventory system for the game!!!
I also made some sprites, but they're just placeholders now. I also added health bars for the enemies and added a goblin enemy, which is our own art.

I made some bare hand attack animations for the main character.
We had a pretty big issue with our equipment system, so I had to fix it and it ate up a lot of time, but hopefully now we won't run into any issues! We started putting the animations into the game, and we are working on putting the weapons into the game.
Made some attack animations! I think I'm getting the hang of animating.
Made some more weapons, and weapon animations! Also made an idle and a jump animation for the main character. Started working on the story, but there's nothing to show yet...

made the second hit for the battle axe, and started working on an enemy.
I thought the slime would be good for an easy start, but this was a pain in the ass to make!
I hope that I will get better and be able to have more output, because the deadline is near!
Also made an intro for a slime boss, but it is not finished yet.

I made another animation for the reaper boss.
I started working on the equipment system, especially on the weapon part. All I have to say is that UNITY VERSION CONTROL IS TRASH!!!
Because of some committing errors, I had to remake almost the whole system and I even had to do work on some earlier files. I remade the animator to work with the equipment system. I also made some adjustments on the attack animations to fix some range issues.

Description:
I had this idea for years to make a speedrun focused 2d platformer, inspired by the precise Celeste movement and the fast paced action from ULTRAKILL, with a minimum time requirement for beating every level. That idea ended up becoming SPEEDTICKERS.

SPEEDTICKERS is a high-speed platformer that focuses on the player movement, featuring sliding and ground-smashing mechanics that push players to master momentum and precision.

I wanted for it to have a very Neon pixelart style, so i started learning using Aseprite(I really recommend it) 

The game follows Sam, an ordinary human piloting a half finished robot, commpeting for medals in almost impossible competitions. It's set in a post-cyberpunk world, the game takes place in a extreme competition that's held every five years, where thousands of contenders race in advanced robotic suits to prove their survival.

I made it in Godot 4.4, and i was very surprised by the accessibility that Godot manages. It's completely incredible trying an engine after using C++ for games.

Description:
Our idea originally came from a friend who bailed on the project without putting in any hours… It hit us (or rather, him) in the school corridor: a top-down "level select" with platformer gameplay, kinda like Cuphead. Nothing too special about it at first.
Then we thought about copying a game where you can switch between 2D and 3D, but that wasn’t exactly new. So we kept brainstorming—how could we do something similar but different? That’s when the idea of layers hit us. A magician who can switch between different layers of reality…
For the engine, we figured a 3D engine like Unity or Unreal made the most sense. We settled on Unreal, planning to write everything in C++, but the only tutorial we found was for Blueprints… so yeah, our project ended up in Blueprints.
As for the art—our artist, Leon (who’s actually a dev, but his laptop was too weak for Unreal), had never done art before. His first designs? Questionable (HORRIBLE), to say the least. And Maximilian, who had never worked with Unreal before, had to figure everything out from scratch, which led to quite a few struggles early on.
But to be fair, both of them really pulled through in the end. Leon’s art improved massively, turning into something genuinely cool, and Maxi got the hang of Unreal, making things actually work. Those last two weeks? Everything just clicked. Suddenly, the game felt like it was coming together, and we finally saw our idea take shape.
Oh, and the cutscenes? We forced a friend to do them. Just like we forced another friend to make the music. And honestly? Both turned out AWESOME.
In the end, our game was barely a third of what we originally planned. But hey, it met the requirements—so that’s something, right?

the targeting is still stupid method, but have never NEVER failed, I tryed to improve, but the "improvements" fail a lot, so I let it by the stupid version. Some times stupid things is the better thing. Today I woke up, directly sat to my computer, started Unreal Engine 5.5.3 and openend the Spell. Just at the moment, in that I saw my code of the bullet, I almost died, what did I do to this thing, did I just had 2 brain cells or why I did that like that. Well actually I really just had 2 brain cells left from coding that much. But now I did the Spell way better. Let me explain it. I have had 2 Actors, one is the Spell / bullet (if you like that better, I dont care) and one is the impact effect, just the explosion. Why I didn't did the 2 in one I still don't know, but now, it is just one. The first thing I did, was combining the 2 Actors with just the [set Flipbook] method, like that I will have the same effect, but just with 1 Actor. Then I realized, the bullet doesn't stop, after hitting sth. So I just added [change Velocity to 0] and now it is doing all perfectly. After that I fixed that the knockback the Enemy recieves at the hit is some times scuffed, because it was depending on the player rotation, that means when the player had an rotation of 180, you get a knockback in this direction and when the rotation is 0, in the other. Now it is done by the rotation of the Spell / Bullet. But then I was faceing another problem, I remove the actor, when it hits something, but the Enemy needs this reference to calculate the knockback he will receive. So, I added an delay of the [destroy actor] that has the length of the Flipbook, that means when the animation is done 1 time, destroy yourselfe from the game. So the enemy has plenty of time to calculate his knockback recieved. Exept on very very very very VERY VERY bad computers. But on these, the game wouldn't run at all, so not a big deal. Then I tryed to "aim" with the mouse. I just wanted to shoot the Spell / Bullet to the mouse location. This would do that the player can actually "aim" with the Spell. I asked ChatGPT and DeepSeek, what they would do, when they want to archieve that. They both approched it very hard, I really don't know, what they were doing with the [normalize Position]. And actually their code does not work at all. After a logically approch by me with my low amounts of brain cells, I figured it out. We just need the [mouse location] and then do [deproject screen to world]. Then get the World Direction X and Z (World Position is not needed, don't ask me, I figured it out with testing) then multipy it with the speed of the Spell and set the Velocity X and Z with the target of the Projecttile Movement Component. Then get the Actor Location and the Actor Location + the Target Location (Mouse Location) and set the Start of the [Find Look at Rotation]-build-in-function the actor location and the target of the [Find Look at Rotation]-build-in-function is the Actor Location + Mouse Location. Then You can easily set the Actor Rotation and then you are done. The next thing I did was change the Keys for Sprint and Sneak to Sprint --> Shift and Sneak --> S. What I need to do tomorrow is that when I press a mouse key, Unreal is locking the mouse position. So I can't "aim" with that. I have done, that when you press it you "aim" and release the right mouse button, you shoot. This is my task for tomorrow.

Description: Our game is a fun happy cleaning game disguised as a horror game. It was designed to lure you in with the happy design of the home while you get to sort and clean this new abandoned home and then slowly but surely everything seems a bit off... Those books are in the wrong place... you feel like somebody is staring at you... is there blood on the knife?? While we never made it that far we're hopeful you'll have seen our vision and enjoyed the very brief gameplay we did have!

Description: I wanted to share something about my recent game development journey. I started working on a game inspired by Alan Wake, focusing on atmospheric storytelling and mystery. I was really excited about the project, but due to academic commitments, I wasn’t able to complete it. Balancing studies and game development turned out to be more challenging than I expected. However, this hasn’t discouraged me—I’m still passionate about making games and look forward to creating more in the future when I can manage my time better.

Description:
Fragments of Flavor

The Story Behind the Game

"Like every good story, it all started with a friend..."

After discovering the "Arcade" Hack Club, I had the chance to participate in many projects. Then, one day, I received an email about a project called "Juice." At first, I didn't take it seriously—I saw the email as ironic and lighthearted.

However, making a game had always been something I wanted to do. I had even received a Quest 3 through Hack Club, intending to create a VR game. While my first step into game development turned out to be a 2D game, VR will definitely follow in the future.

A few days after receiving the email, a friend brought up the project again. That was the moment I decided to start. I brainstormed ideas for my game, and soon after, I had four days off. My friend and I went all in—we grinded non-stop and ended up putting in almost 50 hours of work!

But that was just the beginning. Over the following weekends, I had to push even further, dedicating countless hours to refining mechanics, fixing bugs, and adding new features. Each weekend became another deep dive into development, bringing the game closer and closer to what I had envisioned.

And so, Fragments of Flavor was born.

Game Description

Title: Fragments of Flavor

Short Description:Step into a charming yet mysterious café, where every sip of juice hides a secret. Balance running your cozy business with solving surreal desktop puzzles, uncovering strange programs, and piecing together the fragments of a forgotten digital world.

About This Game:Nestled in the middle of nowhere, your small café is more than just a place for drinks—it's the gateway to an unfolding mystery. With a broken juicer and a cursed computer, you must juggle serving customers while navigating a bizarre and glitchy desktop filled with secrets, puzzles, and unexpected challenges.

Created by a 17-year-old developer, Fragments of Flavor offers a unique blend of cozy simulation and surreal adventure. Every program on your old computer hides a new trial—quirky mini-games, mind-bending logic puzzles, and eerie digital landscapes that will test your creativity and problem-solving skills. As you collect lost data fragments, you'll unlock deeper layers of the story, revealing the truth behind your liminal world.

Key Features:

A One-of-a-Kind Gameplay Experience – Seamlessly blend the relaxing routine of running a cafe with the unpredictable adventure of exploring a surreal, glitchy desktop.

A Dreamlike Mystery to Unravel – Each corrupted file, lost program, and strange encounter leads you closer to uncovering the café’s true purpose.

Discover, Solve, Progress – Gather fragments of data to unlock new puzzles, areas, and the ultimate juicing secret.

Unpredictable and Full of Surprises – One moment you're making juice, the next you're diving into a cosmic enigma—expect the unexpected at every turn.

Cozy, Yet Chaotic – Experience the warmth of running your own café, but be prepared—the balance between customers and a malfunctioning computer is anything but easy!

Can you untangle the chaos, decode the mystery, and craft the perfect juice? There’s only one way to find out. Boot up Fragments of Flavor and start squeezing!

Description:
Trench of Shadows - Memma & Fralas

"In a parallel world, would you come to Shanghai with me?" asked Memma. And that’s how we started developing Trench of Shadows.

We spent a week figuring out the core mechanics, setting up GitHub, and configuring all the necessary tools. Each of us worked hard every single day, and after a month, the game was finally complete.

Development was a thrilling yet challenging journey. Learning Unity and exploring its features was no easy task, but it was incredibly rewarding. Throughout the process, we gained valuable skills, faced countless obstacles, and, of course, shouted a few bad words along the way.

But in the end, every effort was worth it. Trench of Shadows is not just a game—it’s the result of passion, dedication, and countless hours of hard work.

started tile mapping the cave

Crafting implementation - Item/Map asset creation
Basic inventory system (text is for debugging purposes), pickup item functions, item creations
Crafting UI Creation  / Backend crafting basics
Player is now able to buy his own house and enter it
created some sprites to create a "recipe book" in side of the game

Inventory UI Update - Finished durability system - Added "Merchant" to exchange items for money, couple of bugfixes, tree animation reworked, created assets for a few animals (sprite and animations)
Bugfix (player could cut tree without item/wood was added to chest inventory instead of playerinventory)
Changed npc animations, created new "Reserved Slots" in the inventory UI, created new armor systems to increase maximum health

Added torch lighting system to player, ai now roams close to it's spawnpoint, completed wave cave system
Added pop-up UIs to every interactable object inside of the game to allow a more user friendly approach. Added UI to Bed to show if the player can sleep

Created a demo for the main soundtrack of the game, recording, mixing and mastering. Added basic effets to the st (still a work in progress) Full st available on yt: https://youtu.be/zfVp77hKJ4s?si=QKfnx0OPWVDLv0VO

juiceStretches.description: We wanted to rework the parry system in our game such that small attacks, the enemy is knocked back and larger attacks, the player is knocked back. This was super frustrating as in the process i basically reworked the whole enemy system, giving them all a knockback state and making it so that you can be inside enemy hitboxes to make it less awkward. This also meant a rework of how the damage is done, now enemies constantly damage you if youre in them. There were also frustraing bugs with trying to knock the enemies back in the player code etc.

I fine tuned a lot of the details for my dashing enemy. It now:
- Is affected by gravity
- Turns when it hits a wall/ledge
- Only detects the player if theyre on roughly the same y level
- Stops charging if player goes out of view/detection range
- Because of ^, is balanced to have a much shorter chargeup time but a slower dash
- Stops dashing when player goes out of view
- After dashing, goes into a recovery before returning to patrol.
I made a new enemy that charges at you. If it detects you, it "winds up" by stopping for a bit, before charging at you. (there are still some edge cases i need to work out)

Description:
I’ve always been a fan of the John Wick series. In the series, there’s a character named Caine who is blind but the only assassin in the world capable of matching Jon Wick. He detects enemies solely through sound, sometimes even creating his own to lure them. This is where the idea for EchoEcho came from.

Working on EchoEcho was not an easy task, requiring many sleepless nights. In the end however, I am proud of the result.

Description:
DEV TALKS
Thinking Behind the Game

We are huge fans of Dark Souls and its art style. Initially, we planned a shooter, but later shifted to a multiplayer Dark Souls-inspired PvP game.

Concept
The game will be PvP with different modes like 1v1, 2v2, and more coming soon. It will be a platformer in the Dark Souls theme.

Launch Date
The game is scheduled for release on March 31, 2025. Future updates will come, but no DLCs. However, a Dark Souls Campaign game is planned!

When I was a freshman, I started dreaming about making my own indie game. I had dabbled in Unity, Godot, and Pygame, developed my pixel art skills, and studied the game and level design principles behind some of my favorite games. From organizing programs and events like Hackapet! and Counterspell Giza at Hack Club to creating chaotic levels in Super Mario Maker 2, I’ve always been passionate about Game Development.

I started small, collaborating with friends on projects, hoping to one day publish a full game. But with school taking up so much time, I often felt like I was just spinning my wheels. Then I got the email about Juice, and suddenly, I had the perfect excuse to finally build a complete game—with my own assets, my own ideas. It was now or never.

So, I created a concept about a pigeon that falls from the sky and must find its way home—a platformer inspired by everything from indie classics like Celeste, Shantae, Undertale, and Hollow Knight to retro favorites like Mario, Kirby, and Mega Man.

Now, as a senior, it feels surreal that I actually got to do this before finishing high school. Looking back, I would have never imagined that I’d be here, creating my own game and sharing it with others. But making the game ended up not even being the best part of Juice—it was the people I met and the incredible community I found on Slack. That’s what made the experience truly unforgettable. Now, I can’t wait to meet everyone in person in Shanghai. I just hope my visa gets accepted!

Description:
Shoot Out was the first game I ever tried to make. I had the idea after I played an older version of Call of Duty. The pretense of the game was a robot fighting against magical creatures. Suffice it to say, the project wasn't something that could be conjured without thought. But I was determined... until I wasn't. It got boring and hard quickly.

I then drifted through grosses of game prototypes, but I never really made anything.

Enter Feb 1—an event called Juice is announced, and I immediately sprint to get the specifics. I impatiently waited for the website to load, and while I did that, I analyzed the email. As soon as I was done reading the email, I ran to one of my teachers (I learn in a boarding school) to tell them.

I asked not to have sports or service and for them to loan me/my club laptops. They ecstatically said yes, and I submitted a formal document with all the correct information.

A month and a half passed as my friends and I worked away. Then all of a sudden, we were sent our invitation letters, and we were obviously overjoyed.

Two days passed, and suddenly a teacher (SHORT) pulled me out of physics class. They said to me, “WHO SAID YOU ARE GOING TO SHANGHAI?” with a stern voice.

I gave them a steadfast response:
“Our club has been working on this for a whole month and a half! We included it in our request too! Ask (let's call them BALD), he’s the one we talked to.”

He sighed and said, “Go back to class.”

I went in, and just next period, BALD came to me and started to interrogate me. He was ruthless and restless, but I stood my ground. He told me I’d have to explain myself to my school’s admins—SHORT included—and I accepted.

Later after class, I was waiting for BALD and SHORT to take me to the meeting. But for some reason, they were nowhere to be found. Another peculiar thing: these kids called me. I hesitantly answered, and they told me BALD and SHORT had called a meeting without me.

I ran toward the meeting to keep them in check. When I got in, BALD left. I stood, listening to the absolute farce SHORT had been spouting. He said they would get killed and that there was no point. I continuously countered SHORT, but then he said to my club that they wouldn’t get support from the school for college.

SHORT had all of them state whether they were planning to go, and all of them forfeited.
It was me and one friend of mine who were planning to go. But after a while, he gave up. And then it was only me.

I worked on my game. Finished it. And got the flight grant.

Description:
I first heard about it on the Hackaclub Slack. Initially I treated it like just another HighSea event, but after reading the full description, I realized it was pretty cool. In Shanghai, I can speak Chinese generally while practicing English with Hackclubbers!

The first 100 hours were a painful time. I tried making Bevy ECS work with Godot using GDExtension, but I wasn't familiar with Godot's object/memory management. I was basically throwing `.clone()` everywhere in my Rust code like I was running a cloning facility! Eventually, I decided to switch back to C#.

I must say Claude was the MVP during development. I asked it to create an implementation plan, then adjusted some details, before having it write the code. While copy-pasting between editor and chat window was annoying (but manageable), what truly broke my spirit (and briefly sent me into a burnout dimension) was that Claude couldn't access my entire codebase!!! Since I was working on some essential components, this meant REFACTORING... AGAIN. _cue dramatic music_

The second refactor started on 03/19 and ended on 03/27, leaving almost no time to create the rest of the content. But then, CODEMCP was released! Claude could finally access my codebase! 🥳🥳🥳🥳 I quickly built a framework and told Claude to implement these parts. It worked like magic!

During the refactor, I kept pestering my artist friend: "Draw another mob!!" "Where's the animation??? You didn't draw it??? DRAW IT NOW!!!" Occasionally I'd crack and suggest, "Want to play Minecraft?" or "Play Euro Truck Simulator 2 with me!" – anything to escape the refactoring abyss.

I'm sorry your drawn assets aren't used in the game. ("What do you mean 'not used'? They're just 'not yet implemented'!" OK?)

Description:
Gobs&Clanks 

It started with a very intriguing Instagram reel. HackClub's Juice. I saw it and something just clicked. I'd always been a gamer, loved those quirky indie titles, and suddenly, I wanted to make one. I knew nothing about game dev. Nothing. But I downloaded Godot, because it sounded cool, and started watching tutorials.

Man, those first few weeks were rough. Gdscript? It was like trying to speak alien. I'd spend hours trying to make a pixel move, and it would just… not. But I kept at it. "Gobs&Clanks" was born. Simple concept: knight, towers, goblins. Protect the towers, survive the waves.

Movement was a nightmare. My knight was like a drunken robot, stumbling around the screen. I spent days, days, trying to fix it. Finally, after what felt like a million lines of code, it worked. Victory.

Then came the lightning. I wanted this epic chain attack, zapping goblins left and right. I even made the textures myself, which, let's be honest, looked like a toddler drew them. But the lightning? It was a mess. Flickering, weak. After countless hours of debugging, it turned into a thunder strike, a single, powerful zap. Spectacular and effective.

Sound design? Surprisingly fun. Me, who barely knew how to play guitar, was messing around with sound effects, making goblin grunts and tower clanks. It was weirdly satisfying.

And then, the gut punch. Shanghai. Juice. Everyone was booking flights, getting visas. Me? I had school, family stuff. I couldn't go. I watched my friends' stories, all those excited faces, and just felt… empty. It was like watching a party I wasn't invited to.

I could have quit. Thrown in the towel. But something in me wouldn't let me. I had that 100-hour challenge. I was going to finish it. I spent even more time on the game, fueled by a weird mix of frustration and determination.

And then, it was done. "Gobs&Clanks." My game. It wasn't perfect, but it was mine. I'd made it.

What am I doing now? I don't know. Maybe I'm writing an article for that Juice magazine, telling my story. Maybe I'm tweaking the game, getting it ready for release. Or maybe I'm just… breathing. Taking a moment to appreciate what I did. I made a game. And that, after all that, feels pretty damn good.

Description:
Limerence
A music-based platformer inspired by the game Gris and a Youtube video titled Beat Totems. I stumbled upon the video one day and it was super cool how the blocks changed to the music :) I also love how the Gris character was super flowy and took inspiration from an anime character for the main character design.
I originally intended it to have 5 different areas, but ended up just making 2 areas — it definitely has lots of areas for improvement!!

Description:
You awaken in a strange, unfamiliar room—cold, sterile, and eerily quiet. There’s no memory of how you got there, What starts as a simple puzzle soon unravels into a series of increasingly twisted challenges, each more dangerous than the last.
As you delve deeper, you realize you’re not alone. The environment shifts with every completed task, revealing darker secrets, hidden threats, and cryptic clues about the real reason you're here. To escape, you must survive not only the puzzles and the lurking dangers, but your own dwindling resources.
Every room conquered earns you points—rewards for your cleverness and courage. But they’re more than just score; they’re your lifeline. Spend them wisely on food, water, and healing, or gamble everything on your next move. Time is ticking, and the deeper you go, the less forgiving the world becomes.
Only those who master both mind and instinct can survive long enough to return to the real world. The question is—how much are you willing to risk to escape?

I’ve been trying to figure out where the issue is, but I haven’t been able to pinpoint it yet.

-Implemented a game restart function that triggers when energy or health reaches 0.

-Fixed several bugs within the restart function for smoother gameplay.

-Added a "Use" button that, when clicked, increases the player’s energy or health.

-Created a "Drop" button that removes an item from the inventory when clicked.

-Added a "Resell" button, which removes an item from the inventory and adds its value to the player’s points.

-Implemented a resell shop feature. When the player overlaps with it, the resell button is enabled, allowing them to sell items.

-Fixed numerous errors in the code to improve overall performance and stability.

I was able to solve the issue:- "When I click on the first item and hit "Buy," everything works as expected, even if I click it multiple times. However, after selecting a second or different item, it ends up adding both the first and second items to the inventory and accumulating the points for both." It took me 4-5 hours to figure out the issue and the solution, but after solving that, I got another error like when I click the item but do not click the "buy" or yellow button, and close the widget and click another item and click the "buy" button; it's again adding both the previous item and the current item to the inventory and deducting the sum of both items. So it took approximately one hour to solve this issue, and now everything works fine.

Description:
Castle Hardcore 
You are a exiled barbarian who is always looking for thrill. While being adrenaline deficient, you stumble upon an ominous looking castle. Your eyes glisten with blood pumping throughout your body. You are ready to take on this adventure. Go on, pickup your sword and fight those monsters to pump up your heart's desire.
Our team has had our greatest learning experience in this event. We learned about state machines and how to write better code Revised and beautified our code multiple times. We had one goal in mind, to make it difficult. And we think we delivered on it. Though there were some burnout days and annoying bugs, in the end  we had a satisfactory product which we built together

Description: Killer Instincts, a survival game with evolving instincts as you adapt to the environment. Although we formed into groups, some of the team members just quit midway as we can't go to Shanghai, China due to visa and passport or not allowed to go—which sadly demotivates everyone. However, I'm looking forward to bring improvements and try to complete the game in the future :D

juiceStretches.description: Completed display options on settings :)

Description: Our game is inspired by the Tom Hanks movie, "Captain Phillips", in which he must fight off pirates from his cargo ship. We thought this same idea would be interesting to implement in VR, so we decided to make Modern Day Pirates, an immersive VR experience in which you must take up arms, and fifth back to protect your cargo as you sail across the world!

juiceStretches.description:
spent time linking the 1st song with our beta demo of stage 1. experimented and implemented action based music / sound execution:
- fade in for music at the start of the level
- music trigger in the middle of the stage to be more intense
- close shop trigger combined with nearing the end of stage
next steps here are to work on song 3 & begin foley (making my own sound effects / finding free to use databases). 
additionally, added a bit more to this stage 1 music by adjusting levels and parametric EQ.

spent a couple days recording and producing a lobby / afk idle music for the user. instruments recorded (IRL): electric keyboard patches (drums, hihats, vibraphone, rhodes). next steps are to create "egypt," the stage 2 soundtrack & test integrating music into the gameplay. *note that i can't upload the full audio in its entirety here but message me if you'd like to learn more!

in this juice session, i worked locally and digitally only to create the soundtrack for the japanese scene in the game, the 4th / 5th level. this beat is purposely highly vamp-able (sections are repeatable) and energetic since it is one of the closing scenes. spent lots of time attempting to produce an east-asian vibe without the base instrumentation being overwhelming. additionally, experimented some more with tuning vocals that will be improved later on and serve as transitions between songs and thus levels. finally, spent a lot of time fine tuning special effects like EQ, reverb, and tone / pitch fade / bends. 25/30 minutes mark in the game, super excited to finish this one out. please message me for more about the song!

produced a full song that will play at the first tutorialy / introductionary part of the game. spent a lot of time playing around with sound packs and even recorded a violin IRL to go into the music. within the song, there are multiple sections that can serve as repeated vamps throughout the game. next steps: mastering the audio and creating the music for main gameplay.

experimented irl with various instruments, including the chimes and bongos shown in the video but also including gong, cymbals, and vibraphone. finished production of the second song, "egypt" as a continuation of the first in the soundtrack. this took multiple days to test and record all the audio then produce it. also tested out using Garage Band on MacOS as an alternative to FL Studio in this juice stretch, shown in the video. This marks the ~10 minute music mark, 1/3 of the needed 30 mins. will be working on lobby / idle music next. *note that i can't upload the full audio in its entirety here but message me if you'd like to learn more!

in this session, I transitioned from using Garage Band on Mac to Garage Band on iOS 18. the main reason for this shift was for the ease of recording and sampling vocals, which is shown in the video. there are two major changes that required a lot of time: (1) finding plugins that fit iOS 18 & effectively conveyed what I wanted to do; (2) learning to record, clean, and tune vocals. I spent a ton of time back and forth, recording vocals, picking out effects and tuning, and re-recording the vocals. furthermore, this was created as the end / credits scene, so I took the creative liberty to sample a song instead of crafting a beat from the ground up. at this point, there are only 3 stages of gameplay left music production wise. will need to master all the audio in these sessions before they make it to the game too. wanted to show a bit more of the behind the scenes process for music, and the BTS is much more complicated for the other juice sessions I uploaded. please reach out to me for a detailed breakdown of how I spent my time on this (and previous) song(s).

spent time over 2 days to get fl studio and begin testing the program. got used to using plugins and played around with the mixer and piano roll. created a few beats to work with as base vamps laid out my next steps regarding soundtrack production. the one i attached is a beat using their original instruments. this serves as the starting point for audio production (soundtracks, sound effects, and etc) for our game.

in this juice session, i worked with a friends to record a 4-5 minute LOOPABLE (!!) latin inspired beat with multiple layers of piano, latin drums, and a drum pad. i also experimented with implementing a flute and brass highlighting part. a lot of the time spent on this session was in person with friends, all on garage band and cranking out potential melodies and rhythms. furthermore, when adding the flute and brass, i called woodwind players and "forced" (politely asked) them to play some potential lines. we then jammed out a bit and workshopped the rest of the beat. some time was also spent on levels, EQ, effects, and minor adjustment / layering refinements. marks 20/30 minutes of music ready for the game's levels. message me if you'd like to learn more about the creation process & the audio files.

in this stretch:
produced the last song "Australia" correlating to the final layer in our game (30/30 minutes!!)
started this project figuring basic rhythms prior to weekend, (2 hours), and spent majority of weekend at IRL juicathon (~7 hours) with Sebastian (see slack for image). we worked out the rhythms and finalized the production style.
today, i added more mastering & sfx for the sections (~2 hours). the general vibe of the song is moments of seriousness popping through (with the metro 808s and chime hits) while being juxtaposed by the sillyness of the piano texture. 
next steps are to implement everything!

okay this one was insane (see video). recorded my own sound effects IRL using my mac & a simple mic, then processed sound effects in FL Studio with compressors, EQ, gain, fruity filters, distortion, and other plugins. spent a lot of time getting the perfect take & actually making it sound good. (not included in juicing time) but did a lot of research into foley and professional audio design. recorded sfx like walking, gunshot, reloading, chambering, container walking, container latching, etc. apologies to the mod grading this & dm me if more info needed

in this session:
spent time finding open source sound databases to use in ADDITION to the sound effects that i have already created:
researched licenses and how they would work in my game, including physically implementing the licenses into the repo / credits (~6 hours, finding free databases takes long time)
downloading & going through ~100 gb of audio sfx from sonniss's patch releases & deciding which ones to keep (~4 hours)
based on the ones to keep, adjusted audio for some sound effects (as demonstrated in the video, with distortion, compression, gain, and other sound effects) (~2 hours)

spent ~1.5-2 hours per song, (6 songs, shown in video), mastering & finalizing sound effects. this includes equalizers, periodic low/high passes, audio normalization, and fine tuning several instrument layers. removed as well as added various segments in the songs, but now theyre all finalized! (30/30 songs). next step is to fully implement these into the game, as well as finalize sound effects.

(as shown in video) experimented with integrating lobby music into the actual lobby. lobby is rough and not finalized but just got used to actually placing the music in. short session just to test integrating the game and audio

spent 2 days IRL and on garage band producing this song, ~5 minutes and spans the more extensive levels in the second half of the game. egyptian inspired with a hint of crazy guitars and european piano intro / outro. this was made with 30 layers in garage band, with 4 recorded layers and 26 of garage band's electric instruments. this marks the ~15  minute mark of our game, and after this, there are about 3 more levels of music to make. definitely spent a lot of time experimenting in this juice session, hence the length, but very proud of the outcome here. *note that i can't upload the full audio in its entirety here but message me if you'd like to learn more (especially about the creation process)!

Description:
Junkpunk Rats 
My story of making this game started with some email I got from hackclub one day. It was advertising some silly little event about game development and the more I read, the more interested I got. I messaged a good friend of mine, Louis, to see if he would be down, and since we wanted to make a game for quite some time, we signed up. What followed was an unforgettable and very time consuming several weeks during which we worked out and put into fruition our adorable little game about a rat with a gun strapped to its back. I'm sure the game could have been made better, and I'm sure that I could have worked harder, but after all is said and done maybe the real rat was the junk we punked along the way.

Description: Learning to juice with unity was a twisted as the next person, full of bugs and annoyances. As a noob game builder, my experiance was particularly painful. After a basic outline of my 2d platformer, I noticed some glaring holes in my game plan (get it?), I could not draw, nor get an artist halfway into juice. So alas, I had to discard my game theme, an origami platformer, and switch to an dark fantasy pixel art graphic set I found online. After many hard hours on Unity, I finished the game and pack it off to juice, just in time to pack my baggage for Shanghai! Glad to be in juice :D
