Description:
Snake Master

Growing up as one of the few women in my family pursuing STEM, I was often confounded by the challenges of breaking into the field of technology. In my heart, I was determined to make a difference, but financial and geographic constraints made it difficult to contribute meaningfully without bounds. However, that never stopped me from stepping beyond my limit to reach my goals. Snake Master is the first game I have created that supports macOS, Windows, and Linux, which is an achievement from my previous attempts at globalizing my code. With this, I am immensely proud to say that I have taken a step forward in making games and tools that are not only open-source but also accessible to everyone. 

Snake Master is a simple yet engaging game where players control a snake using the WASD keys to collect delicious apples. While the game is still significantly in development, I aspire to add special levels to make the experience even more personalized and dynamic. To those who are questioning themselves in any way, I want to dedicate this message to you:

Never give up.
Never stop dreaming.
Keep on coding.

Whether you are working on a simple game or developing the most intricate world you can imagine, keep pushing forward – your progress and efforts will be recognized. Snake Master is proof that focusing on a goal can lead to a playable and tangible result.

Thank you, Juice and the Juice community, for making learning so accessible and enjoyable. If you are interested in collaborating with me or simply would like support, feel free to reach out to me – I am always here to help and support the open-source community! I hope you will take a moment to play my game, and I look forward to creating even more exciting and complex experiences in the future.

Happy coding!

RiftStrike

Fight against hordes of enemies and see just how long you can survive the continuous onslaught!

This was very fun making! It was also cool to see how the speed of development increased over time of using Godot. The best thing however, was that I didn't just build my game all by myself, but I was part of a community that encouraged and enabled all of this in the first place.

The hardest part from a development perspective was definitely getting the unit selection and movement system up in the beginning. From there on I just iterated on what I had.

I think the most valuable thing I learned is that there is no one single 'pattern' or a fundamental 'best' paradigm for anything in programming. It's not 'always composition', 'always inheritance', or 'use singletons everywhere.' I actually use all of those patterns, but just when it's actually the right use case. (Please always try to avoid singletons though! They make testing impossible and debugging a nightmare; I learned that the hard way)

juiceStretches.description:
Unit selection working again with .NET / C#
A lot cleaner than GDScript (in terms of types)

Unit state now persists across waves
Waves get longer by 10 seconds each
(still have a bug where the units duplicate on every run... couldn't fix it yet; probably gotta reset state at game start somewhere)
Improved the reroll levelups button icon and animated it as a dice (show some sides of a dice in a row and then show new upgrades after *rolling the dice*)

Refactored code and made some global state objects; simpler for my use cases
removed some of the more weird bugs (i.e. unit vanishing permanently after wave end occasionally)
Remade the artwork for the "shock trooper"
Made a new sprite for the small enemy. Made it also behave differently (fixed jittering bug; applied push force to prevent overlap; made it overshoot the target position when attacking)

Had an issue when trying to release to itch.io.
The way I loaded the uprades was directly from the file system but that does not work the same in release as in development. (see https://forum.godotengine.org/t/error-loading-resource-files-in-game-build-in-godot-4/1392)
Now I have made it so it loads via a global instance that has the resources as a property instead of getting them from the file system. I also made an editor script to update those uprades. The script loads all the upgrades from filesystem and updates the exported property. (So I don't have to manually add all those upgrades. It works in development after all; it's an EditorScript)
Try it at https://johannfh.itch.io/riftstrike (v0.4.0 currently)

Drew the sprites for the rift shards (small, medium, large)
Rift shards will be the material used for rerolling levelups as well as purchasing stuff in the item shop (item shop is the next big feature WlP)
Worked on smaller details

Completely overhauled the way I process Inputs and made it so command components now dispatch events (signal based) so that units encapsulating those command components can pull in those commands and handle them each on their own
Fixed a bug where the path finding would be weirdly recalculated resulting in unit movement jittering and computational overhead
Modular unit upgrade system (with double speed upgrade as an example)

Finally making some good progress! got the shock trooper attacking the enemies now and both have hp and can die
can now fight enemies basically

Got my modular upgrade system working! you now get (even tho you cannot really see it) a random upgrade on every levelup that can for example increase regeneration, damage, or health!
Next thing will be loading the game from a "Config" so the player can select units they want for the next run (e.g. sniper, damage dealer, tanks, etc. for more variety).

Managed to get lots of things to work:
- Loading and switching between Scenes
- An enemy can now attack the player
- Added some placeholder sprites (kinda learning Aseprite rn; awesome program, would recommend)
- The units now switch sprite on death
(+ optimized suboptimal code)
Got random unit across map spawning working

Managed to get C# to work properly with Godot.
(Started rewrite because project got to large for GDScript; hope this works better, looking promising)
Added level up functions and display above unit

# "Patch Notes"

## Fixed bugs

- Camera zoom now clamped correctly
- Units now no longer get blocked by Enemies and vice versa

## Implemented State machine based mechanics on enemy

- **attacking**: follow the closest unit
- **Idle**: currently just standing around, wandering later

began work on the shop page (all graphics are placeholders rn)
First page allows you to choose between four upgrades per levelup. I want to add the ability to reroll with an ingame currency/material you get from the enemies called "Rift Shard" (you can see the counter in the top left already, but it is not used atm)
Made graphics for the levelup upgrades, also improved the animations and added a label to the upgrades so the player can see the effect (for example "+15%" below a damage upgrade)
Moving the camera (smooth reactions) and zooming with mouse wheel
Implement unit health and death with progress bar
Made a small projectile animation for the shock bullets
Got experience collection working
Units can nowshoot projectiles (with bullet animation playing on repeat)

Implemented multiple upgrade rarities (but they are equally "rare" in % currently... that's missing)
Upgrades/Items exist in common, uncommon, rare, epic, and legendary qualities. Levelups generally follow the stats schema where common is x1 multiplier on the stats, uncommon is x2 (so twice as good as common), rare is x3 (so three times as good as common but only 1.5 times as good as uncommon), epic is x4, and legendary is x5.
For example: A common damage upgrade is +5% damage, a rare one is +15% and legendary is +25% damage (meaning, when you had 100% before and did 20 damage, you now do 125% of that damage or 25 damage flat (after getting the legendary upgrade)). Other upgrades include health (max hp), vitality (hp regeneration) and rift energy (currently useless but will be useful for some unit types later)
Path finding using the native NavigationAgent2D in Godot combined with a NavigationRegion2D.

- unit visuals
    - unit sprite flipping horizontally
    - visual feedback on selected and hovered units
- cursor visuals
    - custom cursors (arrow, pointer, select)
    - visual feedback on mouse when hovering units
changed floor to 1/1 aspect ration from 3/4 and changed color of placeholder to resemble actual color of art later

increased performance for units as well as enemies so it works kind of stable now
cleaned up the code (removed some old debug print statements etc. which also helped perf a little)
#riftstrike
Regeneration working too now

I used the animation player for the first time to animate the appearance of the upgrades in the menu between waves. (Also, you can now use the keyboard keys to move between the buttons (Tab & arrow keys))
Make XP spawn on enemy death; Also improved performance for spawns (the game slowed down when a unit died before); Reduced map size to 70x70 from 100x100 tiles

Features:
- Added mouse based unit selection capabilities

Internal Changes: Refactored out inheritance logic for composition approach
Unit input and selection now working in even less complexity, also clicking vs dragging differentiation (based on pixels moved between mouse down and mouse up) and I can group select with LShift
Area Selection Box

Made a new Unit (cannot attack yet but is compatible with all of the interfaces needed (HP, Levels, etc)
Missing: Sprite (will do later)

I completely refactored my unit selection code and decoupled pretty much all of the important stuff now from one another.

Now I can focus on creating the command/input system next
isometric map style with aseprite and tilemaps
Fixed a bug where units would stop processing the move queue when the next target position in queue is unreachable (use .GetFinalPosition instead of .IsTargetReached (navagent2d))
Directional Lighting on tile map cells with occlusion layers

Implemented unit selection screen before starting a game.
This is really important soon, because I want to have the player select 4 out of N units from this screen for the game. There will be multiple unit types available but the player can only pick a maximum of 4 of them.
I also remade some of the sprites and made new ones; for example the icon of the shock trooper that is visible in the unit selection/game setup screen as well as the upgrade selection screen (top right).
Next I want to visualize the upgrades for the current unit in the upgrade screen so you can see what upgrades the unit has OR I will show the stats of the unit...
After that I want to make more unit types for the player (like continuing the work on the sniper I began developing a while a go)
Refactored a lot of code and reorganized the folder structure. Also fixed a few bugs in the upgrade system. No new features but now I can add some again :)

Enemies now drop rift shards.
Rift shards are used as a currency/material for rerolling upgrades between waves
Enemies no longer drop experience so units gain the xp on kill
Reworked how unit drops are collected (now the drops accelerate instead of having a constant speed)
Select Units with keys 1-4 and all units with F2. Display selected units in UI on screen
Learned to use aseprite a little, made some sprites and a launch screen; also made some small circles appear below selected units

Got units working finnally with controls and also got smooth camera movement (It moves with Arrows and mouse wheel dragging; Zooming with scroll)
Code is clean and now I think I can get going after "learning the domain" (failing over and over again lol) for 50 hours or so
(Point and Click) pathfinding inside of a TilemapLayer2D
Made an enemy, made it follow the player, made a small sprite for it and made that animate
Camera Movement with WASD and Arrows
Move unit with rmb (right mouse button). Queue moves with shift+rmb. Camera is WASD and arrow keys.
Refactored some of the code and fixed and issue with enemy collision (they were not pushing each other away as intended)

# Released as v0.8.0

**In this stretch:**

- Refactored code in preparation for stats rendering in the upgrade screen (i.e. put base stats into the unit data object so they're accessible from the GlobalState object when in the wave shop scene)
- Changed some of the UI sizes
- Released as v0.8.0 on https://johannfh.itch.io/riftstrike and https://github.com/johannfh/RiftStrike/releases/tag/v0.8.0 (now contains the unit selection logic; even tho it's work in progress)

Commit(s) that went into this OMG Moment: https://github.com/johannfh/RiftStrike/commit/7636fa4415d504ccfd96b23a310d91bfccef19e0

Commit(s) that went into v0.8.0: https://github.com/johannfh/RiftStrike/compare/v0.7.0...v0.8.0

Animated more the UI using tweens and added some icons to begin replacing the text (cause that's language and we don't want that later)

Also: 100 HOURS!
Made a small concept art for one of my units

More UI/UX improvements (like UI interactions having visual feedback (i.e. shrink buttons on mouse down, grow when hovered); also added more icons so it is now fully languageless again (there were some placeholders before; now they're removed :3)

Release v0.6.0 is out now at https://johannfh.itch.io/riftstrike
(Try it now before it gets replaced by v0.7 and v0.8)
Rework logic for enemy spawns (simplify code and optimize; less laggy on large map size; now works fine even at 100x100 tiles)

Main Menu/Title Screen so you can restart the game without relaunching the application etc
Also fixed multiple bux (enemies had 1hp for some reason)
Rebalanced the Shock Troopers base damage: 50 -> 20
Got unit selection in .NET / C# working again like in GDScript

added: Waves! (currently lasting 10 secs for debugging)
Every Wave the units are spawned dynamically from defined data. This enables me to implement persisting unit state across waves and adding unit selection per run after that.
increase icon sizes in UI and add play icon for the "Play" placeholder button (so now languageless again)

Description:
DuctTape
This game was the product of an idea I've had since I first started playing games, along with two months of game development balanced with a heavy school workload. I expected to have way more time than I ended up with, and I started by trying to build a game engine. I quickly learned that was out of this project's scope and started over using Godot and Rust to form a game development stack I could be happy with. DuctTape is a puzzle cave dweller where players resourcefully craft items from whatever resources they have to navigate the environment in many ways. You are a humble caveman tasked to dwell in the many caves in the world ahead of you. There doesn't appear to be much down there, until one day you find a magical roll of Duct Tape from the future. You may not be as advanced as future societies, but you can reason enough to put a few things together, building an assortment of tools that allow you to navigate further and further into the depths of the world.

Description:
Our team went with a 3d game in hopes of trying something new and creating something different. It was a hard journey, both in programming and graphics. I planned on joining this project in hopes of getting more programming experience and immersing myself further into game development, but as an art kid I always seem to come back to arts and design related work. The graphics aren't gorgeous in this game, but what would one expect out of a completely new blender user? I learned a lot in this process, and my respect for 3d game artists have been taken to a new level. With school and extracurriculars, and 100 hours to go, it was definitely a time crunch (my hyperactivity did not help). I was really regretting suggesting a 3d game, as 2d game would have been so much easier to create. 3d modeling is too technical, 2d art is more my expertise. 

Definitely a lot of work, thank you very much my team, carrying the whole programming process. I do apologize lagging behind in graphics but the amount of times blender has made me rage quit might compare to the amount of times I rage quit in video games. The entire process was very nurturing and I am so glad I was able to join this project--which is likely my last ever Hack club event as I am a senior, but I'm glad to leave after such a spectacular event, and certainly as one would say, with a bang.

Description:
PlatformLands
When I received an email from Thomas inviting me to participate in Juice, it felt almost unreal. I had never worked with a game engine before, I couldn’t create pixel art, and I had no idea where to start. On top of that, the location—China—was fascinating but also distant and completely unfamiliar. I had many doubts: Would I be able to finish on time? Could I really create my own game?

Despite everything, I decided to give it a shot. It was a challenging process—countless hours spent learning the engine, designing graphics, debugging—but in the end, it was all worth it. And now, thanks to all that hard work, my character is on the cover of this magazine!

My game, PlatformLands, is a relatively simple platformer in terms of mechanics. For now, it features two biomes: Jungle and Fire. Some areas require a bit of thinking, while others test your agility. I hope you have a great time playing it!

juiceStretches.description: I've made an animated parrot!
I've finally managed to add dash/roll. I tried different ways to do that but it wasn't working like I wanted. I think I'm starting to understand more about Godot!!!!
I've made an explorer!!!!!!

I decided that I wanted to work a little more professionally on the graphics, so I downloaded and set up Aseprite (if that doesn't count deduct me 15 mins) I worked on details such as the joints between the grids, etc. now the graphics look better and smoother. I added the totem and the mechanics associated with it. I set the position smooothing, checked and set the appropriate custom data everywhere (mostly related to walljump) I connected all the scenes as they should look, blocked the transitions to levels that are not finished. I set the appropriate physic layers everywhere. There was a bug with not showing hearts in the mountain scene, so I fixed it. And then I found the bug I spent the most time on. The player, after exiting the mountain, instead of leaving at the place where he entered it, was leaving at the beginning of the scene. It used to work, but in the meantime I added chceckpoints, which used the player's last pose, and I think I broke something, but after a long time I managed to fix it. In the tutorial, I added the part about the touchdown and the gate. I also spent a lot of time testing the jumps, I changed a few settings such as the player's speed and had to make sure everything was doable. Finally, I published a new version of the game on itch and completed the description a bit.
https://supertik.itch.io/platformlands

I created an account on https://www.soundtrap.com. I added background music to the game, damage, death and pickup sounds. I had some trouble getting the two to play before the dash disappears, but I put it in the player script and with the help of global variables it was ok.
I've smoothed the slide move and added moving on the liane (but in a different way than ladder mechanic before, now it works better)

Okay, this was a long session, but I’ve added a core feature – the player’s health. I had trouble passing the health variable to other scenes so that the hearts wouldn’t reset every time. Once I figured that out, I started working on the bounce effect after touching the Golem or spikes. It was really hard to make the player bounce properly—I had issues when the player was on the left side of the enemy. I made some changes to my code, like changing the direction variable from a vector to a float. Then, I had to adjust the parameters so the player wouldn’t fly off uncontrollably. Right now, it works! Maybe it’s not perfect, but I’m proud of it.

I worked a little bit on level design, implementing the release of the tiger, and adding graphics that appear when an animal is freed. I also fixed some bugs (most of the time). I fixed a bug that prevented dashing while moving (or caused the player to move backward when dashing to the left). Additionally, I fixed a bug where the panda and tiger could kill the player. Finally, I added a new mechanic: now, you need to collect two keys to release the tiger.
I've added player animations!!!! and score!
I've added wall jump and wall slide!!!! It looks so cool. I also changed some small things (such as player collison shape)

I rebuilt the Jungle ceiling, reduced the parrot size, added corners to the slide, added a dash to the tutorial and placed them around the map, added chain ends, decorated all levels (flowers, stones, plants), added a background in all levels, fixed a bug with the frame closing again after entering the jungle cave, added a background in the frames, fixed a bug with the golem, reworked main_menu and pause_menu to be textless (I spent a lot of time here because I couldn't press Texture_buttons, it turned out that control didn't have process always enabled and when pausing the game the buttons were also paused, and I thought about it so much :(  )

I changed the color in the jungle (so I had to do everything from scratch (changing tiles)). I made graphics for the panda and stripes. I added a mechanic to free the panda from the cage. And finally the worst bug I've had so far - the moving panda (I added a recording of the bug at the end of the video). I spent almost 3 hours trying to fix it by changing the flip() function. It turned out to be a RayCast range problem. I also did a little bit of a level design but I'll make it in next session probably.
I finished mechanic for the maze! (buttons and gates)
I've added slide animation. For now i've used question mark blocks but i will change it later (my Tileset doesn't have a ramp)

Long session but it was so productive. I've made the whole tutorial level. I've made special graphic, like buttons etc. I've added a parrarelBackground which took me soo long. I've tried many times with different resolutions, mirroring, scale. Nothing worekd. Finally it looks fine. I've designed the level and now it's ready to go.
I've made a run and jump animation. Tried like 10 different combinations and this one is the best I can do right now
I've added coins mechanic, platform, background and more platforms!!! It starts to look amazing. I'm so excited!!!!!

I've fixed bug "Attempt to call function 'setMaxHearts' in base 'null instance' on a null instance." which was blocking displaying hearts. I also added a connection betweent tutorial and game (as always at first I mistook the collison layer)
I've added a music and a pickup sound

I've made the whole new level (additional level). I did the level design, little bit of art (everything is shown in the video), I made buttons mechanic and gates. I also likned it to the jungle biome. Additonally I improved dash movement so now you can dash when you are moving. It was very hard to plan the level so it's doable and pretty hard, so i took a lot of tries.

I added new thing to the tutorial (buttons and gate), fixed a few bugs (walking backwards during attack, walljump (wrong layer was checked) in jungle biome, and slide (also wrong layer) in tutorial scene). I also added checkpoints mechanic and design a new part of the level with it. (it's possible to do I've checked it, just didn't want to waste your time watching me trying to complete my own game)
I made art for a secret level in fire biome and designed the level. I tried to make it as hard as possible so I spent a lot of time testing jumps and adding new possible ways to pass the level.
I've added fight animation! It's time to start working on my own assets because the one from the internet doesn't have the animations I need.
I've published my game to itch

I've done several things. Added player graphic, new graphics, changed camera and build the main room in the game!!! (I also want to mention that in my last 2 omg moments I've shown only the pixel art not the inmplementation. I was trying to prepare a few graphics and then add them all at once. After the kickoff call i know I have to show the implementation in the game. I'm gonna use all the graphic that I made for sure, I hope that's not a problem. From now I'll try to show the graphic in game every time!
I've added an enemy - slimeeeee. Now player can die by touching the slime, then he falls offff.

Okayy, it was a very long session but I'm satisfied with the results. As a main thing I've added golems. You can kill them or get killed (managing these 2 took me most of this time. There were several problems like kiliing all golems at once [problem with global variables] or not killing anyone at all. Later there was a problem with my player animation getting blocked by other animations. There was a lot of work with attack area, adjusting parameters so the player wouldn't die during attack dash etc.) I've also worked on animations (during implementation my graphics size changed and I had to fix that) and graphic (golem). You can now use chain like a ladder. At the end I change Golems movement so they can bounce off the wall.
I've added the main menu! Like always there was a problem (after choosing full rect option my background kept disapearing) but I figured it out !!!
Finallyyyyy it works. I've spent way to much time on this ladder mechanic but it works now. I'm so proud
I've added more details to my Tileset such as various overgrown floors and a puddle.

I added checkpoints. This was very hard to do without messing up the checkpoints in the jungle biome. It finally works somehow. I also built a maze, I'll work on the mechanics of it in the next session.

This is my first time using Godot so I managed to lear how to use simple movement, tileMap and another essentials. I am using graphic from the Internet but later i will change that, I just want to lear the basics now. :)
I've made a new level (first part of it) (fire biome). I worked on graphic, level design and implementing core mechanics. I've made empty platform, becouse now I'm gonna work on enemies.
I've added double jump and adjusted it

I've added kind of a playground where I'll be testing new mechanics. I added new platforms and tested my idea for one level (with those platforms). And finally I figured out adding platforms without any problems (there was a lot)

During this session I've been working on overall level development. I've made a bunch of graphics (I'm gonna use tiger one's in the next session) like door, icons, dirt stones. I improved releasing panda animation [like always I had mistook layers and tried to figure out what was wrong]. I worked on level design and after a few different ideas I know what will be the best in game. I also changed the look of main scene in cave.

I've made an actuall level! I was working on level design, grpahic, slide move (it finally works perfectly), parrot, vackground, killzone, platform. There were many problems (I had to make a new scene and then build the level) but I figured out everything!
I've started working on temple and it's cave. I've made an entrance to the temple, mushroom and cave tiles

I added disappearing platfroms. I also wanted to switch on the ability to walljump on those so I had to change conditions of it (since disappearing platforms are not in th Tileset). Finally everythings works perfect!

Added transitions between biomes, a mechanism for getting up after killing golems, finished the level design, made a fire totem and its mechanics, added keys and hearts to each scene, limited dash and its mechanics
I added a key count on the screen :)
I've added spikes! (for now mushrooms). It was so hard, firstly the player couldn't die on die left side, then on the right side and lastly when he was on top, so there was a lot of debugging
I've added pause menu. (text is only for tests i will get rid of it)
I've made a Tileset for my jungle biom!!! It took so long but I'm happy with the results :)

Description:
**My Journey of Building Luminaze for Juice**  

**Luminaze** is a maze game I built, but with a unique twist—you solve the maze using the power of light.

Hack Club has always been a game-changer in my life. After attending my first event, **Epoch**, I was eager for the next one—which eventually turned out to be **Juice!** The moment I heard about it, I knew I had to be there in person.  

Game development was never really my field, but for a Hack Club event, I was always ready to dive into something new. So, I started learning game development, and it turned out to be an **amazing experience.** From **February 15 to April 2**, I barely got any proper sleep because I had set a strict goal—**200 hours of juicing** to attend the Juice event. Managing this alongside my **classes and exams** was one of the biggest challenges I’ve faced, but I pulled it off.  

I still remember the moment I hit **100 hours** and confirmed my spot at Juice. The first thing I did was tell my **teachers and parents**, and seeing them proud of me made all the effort worth it. Of course, building a game from scratch isn’t easy—I’ve **been through it all**. Sleepless nights spent sketching and thinking of **maze designs**, getting stuck on **tiny errors** that ate up hours of troubleshooting—at the time, it was frustrating, but looking back, it was all **fun**.  

Now, **Luminaze** is complete, and I’m all set to attend Juice! The excitement of meeting my **Hack Club family in Shanghai** is unreal. This journey has been one of the toughest but also the most rewarding experiences of my life. Can’t wait to share my game and my story with everyone!

juiceStretches.description: I’ve completed the second basic level of my game. While it remains easy to win, it introduces a few additional challenges. I built the base outline, designed the map, and added Box Collider 2D components to restrict movement. The key new feature in this level is the change in the movement pattern of the monster. Previously, it moved along the X and Y axes, but now I’ve implemented circular movement using Mathf.Sin and Mathf.Cos. The coding part was a bit tricky, but I managed to get it working!

In my game, I added a narrow path that the ball cannot pass through at its original size. To solve this, I implemented two resize boxes. When the ball touches the small resize box, it shrinks, allowing it to pass through the narrow path. After exiting, the ball touches a big resize box, which restores it to its original size. The code part was difficult and confusing.

I've successfully built another moderate-level in my game. While it's a tricky level, players can figure it out with some effort. I added a basic level script to control monster movements. In this level, obstacle monsters block the player's movement, and players must find the corresponding box to move each monster. The ultimate goal is to obtain the key and unlock the door.

I successfully completed the new level with all features fully integrated. I started by sketching a rough map of the maze in a notebook. After numerous trials and adjustments, I finalized the maze layout, carefully placing obstacles, monsters, and guiding the player’s path. The level now includes teleportation, moving monsters, a ball resizing mechanic for navigating narrow passages, animated doors and various interactive elements to enhance gameplay.

h basic level of my game is moderately easy to complete but introduces new challenges. I built the base outline, designed the map, and added Box Collider 2D components to restrict movement. A key new feature is the addition of multiple obstacles, enhancing the game's visual appeal and filling empty spaces. Additionally, I placed an obstacle key above these newly implemented obstacles, requiring players to interact with them to progress.

I’ve completed building another new level base and the construction of the maze. I made sure this maze is challenging and frustrating for the player to complete—lol. I also added separate barriers to the level, each with unique shapes, which was hard and time-consuming to design.

YEAYYY!! I just created a new level for my game! This one is a moderate difficulty level. First, I built the base layout, then added objects on top to serve as box colliders to restrict the ball’s movement. In some areas, I directly placed box colliders to block the path. After that, I planned ways to make the level more challenging. Then, I implemented moving circle monsters, door animation, a door key, and obstacle monsters with their movement mechanics. Finally, I wrote the necessary scripts to bring everything to life!

This stage was the most challenging for me to build—every small error cost me time and sleep. First, I created the **Main Menu**, designing the UI and importing a **Canvas** into the scene. I set a background and added a **Play button**, which directs players to the **Level Selection** screen.  

In the **Level Selection** screen, all levels are displayed, but only the **first level is unlocked by default**. Clicking on it takes the player to **Level 1**, with a smooth transition effect. When the player touches the **win element**, they are redirected back to the **Level Selection** screen, and the **next level is unlocked**, allowing them to continue progressing through the game.

I created a new animation and added a button feature to restart the game when the player fails by touching the monster. The code was quite challenging, and it took me hours to figure it out. Animations can be confusing! Now, when I fail, I have to manually click the restart button to restart the game.

Edited Monster Voice Effects:
Created and edited unique voice effects for the monster using Audacity. Added distinct sounds for when the monster moves and when it returns to its original position.

Customized Code for Each Monster:
Modified the code for every single monster in the game to incorporate the new voice effects. Ensured each monster has its own unique behavior and sound.

Added Tasks and Features to the New Level:
Designed and implemented various challenges and features for the new level, including:

Obstacle monsters.
Moving monsters.
Door animations.
Restart level functionality.
Barriers and other level-specific challenges.
Completed the New Level:
Fully built and polished the new level, integrating all the features and ensuring everything works seamlessly together.

I’ve mostly finished working on the soundtracks for three in-game features:  

- **Ball Size Changer:** Made two sounds—one for expanding and one for shrinking. At first, the sound kept playing repeatedly whenever the ball touched the box, so I added a flag variable to make sure it plays only once per touch.  
- **Door Opening Sound:** Recorded a door-opening sound and edited it to fit the game. Then, I linked it to the key animation so the sound plays when the player picks up the key and the door opens.  
- **Obstacle Monster Movement:** Set up a sound effect for when the monster moves. When the player activates the box, the movement sound plays, and when they trigger it again, a reversed version of the sound plays as the monster returns to its original spot.

I created and assigned a sound effect for the teleportation effect, but after assigning the sound, I encountered a bug where teleportation was happening twice, causing the sound to play twice as well. To fix this, I made several major changes to the code:

Added a bool isTeleporting variable.
Set isTeleporting to true when teleportation starts and reset it after completion.
Prevented the TeleportPlayer() coroutine from starting if isTeleporting is already true.
Ensured TeleportPlayer() is called only once by properly using the isTeleporting flag.
Stopped all existing teleport coroutines before starting a new one.
Prevented multiple OnTriggerEnter2D calls from stacking up teleportations.
After implementing these changes, I successfully fixed the error.

In this project, I designed a completely new maze level from scratch, creating and editing each component to fit the game's requirements. After finalizing the maze structure, I began developing the game by adding a 2D box collider to every component. This was essential to restrict the movement of the ball and ensure it stayed within the boundaries of the maze, allowing the player to complete the level successfully.

Once the maze was fully set up with colliders, I integrated the ball's movement mechanics into the game. This included scripting the ball's physics and controls to ensure smooth and responsive gameplay. Additionally, I added global lighting and configured the main camera to provide a clear and visually appealing view of the maze level.

I’ve completed designing an icon for my game, *Luminaze*. I created the entire icon in Figma using only single pixels, without incorporating any images. The most challenging part was constructing the entire poster pixel by pixel. Additionally, I designed a custom font for the game's name, also built from single pixels, merging them together to create a unique and distinctive look.
last time forgot to add the door opening sound in the key when the player touches and activates it. now successfully added and tested.

I created a new animation for the final win door opening, featuring a rotating key. I also added scripts to the door to trigger its opening when the player collides with the key. Additionally, I implemented a feature that changes the ball's color upon activation, indicating that the key has been used and the door is now open for the player to win.

I just built a brutally tough level—so confusing that I’m not even sure if players will be able to complete it! 😂 The maze design is meant to deliver both thrill and frustration, making the challenge fun. I put a huge amount of effort into completing this maze due to its complexity, with my main focus being level aesthetics and design, which took most of my time.
I'm sure players will struggle to win because of the intentionally confusing layout. After designing the map, I integrated:
Monsters and moving walls


Monster-controlled doors


Movable boxes to manipulate obstacles


Dynamic lighting effects
Moving balls


Barriers to restrict ball movement

I successfully built the UI for my game, creating two key screens:  
1. **Main Screen UI** – The first screen players see, featuring a play button.  
2. **Level Selection UI** – Includes individually designed assets that allow players to click and navigate to respective levels.  

The biggest challenge was designing all assets from scratch using small pixels instead of using images from the internet. This process took a lot of time but resulted in a visually cohesive UI that maintains the dungeon-style theme of my game.
I have successfully added a teleportation feature to my game, complete with transition fades and integrated voice when teleportation transition happening.
Lol, I just realized that when animating the fail screen last time, I added text, which isn't allowed by our rules. I replaced it with new icons instead.
I have completed the fail sound. Now, when the player touches the monster, the level restarts, and the fail sound plays. I also edited and adjusted the fail sound using Audacity.

I successfully built another moderate-level map for my game! This level is somewhat confusing, but players can complete it without too much effort. The main new feature introduced is teleportation, allowing the player to teleport to a locked region, unlock a door from there, return, and open the door. After that, they must escape from a moving monster to win the game.

I designed a new level for my game using a trial-and-error approach to create the best tricky maze layout. To ensure the ball stays inside the maze, I added Box Collider 2D components along the maze’s shape, forming a complete boundary that restricts movement and prevents the ball from escaping. Additionally, I implemented the ball, main camera movement, and global light to enable basic ball movement within the maze.

In the Luminaze game, which I built from scratch, I created two fully functional levels with reusable prefabs like the player, monsters, fire objects, doors, and keys, along with custom C# scripts for player movement, monster behavior, collision detection, lighting effects, and level management; the scene design features a maze-like environment with walls, pathways, dynamic lighting, and interactive objects, while animations and an animation controller bring the game to life with player movements, monster patrols, flickering fire, and door interactions; the gameplay in Level 2 focuses on navigating from point A to B, avoiding monsters, collecting keys, and solving puzzles, with smooth transitions like fade-in/fade-out effects enhancing the experience, and the core mechanics, visuals, and engagement all work seamlessly to create an immersive and challenging maze game.

I’ve completed the starting basic level of my game, which is the first level the player experiences. This level is designed to be very easy to win. I built the base outline, created the map, and added Box Collider 2D components to restrict the ball’s movement. Then, I integrated the ball and light effects into the game. The only feature I added here is the door and its key—players can simply collect the key and open the door to win easily.

Description: It's another beautiful day in New Philsberg, home of Phil and friends - but something has gone tragically wrong. The bus manager is missing! Now it's up to you to make sure that all the trains run on time, and that everyone can get where they need to go on time. You can do it - Phil is depending on you!!!

juiceStretches.description:
buses can pick up people!

Added towers, assets for towers, collect all towers in global script, accidentally added gravity to people

Now can buy new routes and stations, and it shows the cost (increases per purchase). Improved design that shows how many are left (instead of showing amount out of max, it now shows how many are left).

Fixed issue where buses would "bounce off" stations in some situtations

seriously these bugs just keep getting harder, and with each one goes a bit of my sanity. I've bene working for literal hours and can't get it fixed, even after reworking the code multiple times, and I know where in the code the bug occurs (have known for like 2 hours) but can't fix it, and this session is getting too long. I also centered the game over popup on larger screens
fixed an issue with circular routes (was choosing an incorrect node for comparison), new color for each route
live preview of the route being placed
fixed issue where buses were not stopping at stations when the route has points without a station
Add towers to global array, have godots move toward the nearest tower
General improvements to movement, balancing of speed, improvements to station placement. Improvements in many places that make the game smoother and more performant

allow zooming out further, made scaling more consistent, fixed issue where coins amount would end up with something like x.00000001, fixed issue with sprite orientation, fixed issues where people  only show default sprite when being recreated

FINALLY. Finally. finally. this bug has sucked all the joy out of this project, but after hours upon hours of debugging it now works. Buses now pass through station centers (instead of stopping) unless they actually need to stop; this was done by ensuring target stations are only set when needed. Solving this created other problems, but those are other problems, to be dealt with later. I'd like to thank my friends Sai and Kai for finally giving me the motivation today to face this absolutely terrible code and solve the issue; without them it would probably be a long time before I gathered the courage to do so. This is actually a very emotional moment. The video looks simple, but this was so so so so hard to get working. I will try to keep sessions much shorter in the future.
*click to create new stations*, improved performance by removing people at station, other various fixes/improvements
Pause after win, made win more difficult (increased resource costs, winning score), reset coins, resource costs, and their displays when replaying.

Fixed evasive bug which would randomly cause game to crash, something to do with people selecting dream stations. It was difficult to replicate, and it's also fixed now, so the video is just of everything working correctly.
Fixes with moving route points - improvements when dragging in/out of station ranges (recognizes station, updates points). Some issues still exist with buses crossing points while moving
buses bounce back, if track is closed. so many booleans getting passed around

fix every issue related to bus arrival at stations, as well as the issue where it would pass the station by going to fast and completely break. buses no longer slide into stations, they stop suddenly (will fix later)
fixed issue where vertical routes would glitch bus (also solved another issue with being unable to place points above/below each other), reworked turning to be more consistent

scrapped edit mode, instead opting for moving points while paused
controls stay in bottom left when window is resized, shows option for mac users in tutorial, added game win screen when enough people are delivered (3000, less is shown in video to save time)
fix sizing, styling, improved zoom, shift + left click to pan, double-click to add station

It's finally generating the new "people" (currently just the godot logo) in the desired area, which in unfortunately currently selected in a janky way.
cancel route creation with a button next to the indicator
going a bit crazy because it's incorrectly positioned, but routes can be created with alt + left click, and buses will be created along the routes
improved game over screen by showing amount over, fixed a few issues with route creation by tweaking values
coins are now added, based on distance travelled by the person (using inverse proportional decay)
add play/pause button
users now have a target location instead of target station, and head for target location after arriving at the final station. also fixed issue with creation of users
each person has a dream station, which is added to the nearest station when they reach it

moved people creation to a global script with access to all areas (creating a consistent amount of people at each interval), which will make it possible to set position goals with any existing area (next step)
routes and buses now appear in the correct positions

new bus asset flips when changing direction, people now have 2 different assets (with animations) that are chosen from randomly, and they face the y-axis of the station. no time was spent developing assets
Fix slowing to a stop at stations when there are no extra points in range.
Dynamically generate tiles that create people, with some 2d array handling that would make my CSA teacher proud. Video is sped up to save your time.
Camera movement (arrow keys, scroll to zoom, panning) works!
godots move at constant speed, stop once at station. stations now count occupants
web export of game
fixing regression that made buses skip stations and not pick up people
Implement janky partial pausing (no ui), implement and show score, game start, end screens

partially fixed bus in range after movement:
- updates station statuses of buses after moving route points
- checks point is next on line before setting it to last, solving some issues with points on routes being moved
- stops at first station (fixes bug where bus would not stop at second station sometimes)
- bus keeps progress ratio (not position) when route is moved, solving issues like being pulled away from end stations
there may be some difficult hidden bugs, but without being able to consistently recreate them I'm unable to attempt a fix
add multiple population areas, improve assets
Designed a beautiful cover screen, took way to long figuring out how richtextlabels and custom fonts work, and changed the way page covers are hidden/shown
add visual indicator of max stations and routes, as well as how many are currently held
it works. IT WORKS!!! fixed issue where a bus stops at station if it runs through inner even if there is are points on outside the range before finishing
fixed issues when station areas overlap, now stations can be much closer together; added a small minimum distance between stations
Picks up people at station after arrival, fix issue where some people were not picked up, but only sometimes
created draggable element (it preserves offset) to write the code needed for moving route points

completely remade the bus + route system, *again*, fixing an issue when a station passes through the area of a station on it's route without arriving at the station (would get stuck before), also lays the groundwork for the other major bus/route issue
fixed that you can't make stations after creating a route

Description: We started our game in Febuary, looking to make a game similar to Hollow Knight (and quickly pivoted because it was not going well LMAO). The game had a lot of bugs and overall looked real scuffed, so we quickly pivoted towards a smaller, more cuphead-like game style. Our protagonist was originally a biped robot with a broken arm, and would've run around with a one-handed stick, but this was eventually turned into the rat we know and love. Music for the game was written by me and was inspired by the video game ULTRAKILL, as well as music from my high school's Marching Band Show (which both me and my partner were a part of). I'm extremely proud of where we've come as a team, and I'm very excited for the future of game development.

Description: The game started off completely different from what it currently looks like. Instead of being a tower defense game, it was originally intended to be a sort of atmospheric puzzle game with horror elements. However, given the high amount of art required for a game like this and the lack of an artist on our team, we decided to change ideas. We ended up switching to a resource management / tower defense game, with the pitch that the game would only use a single resource—we could instead control the use of that single resource to provide unlocks, supply different towers, and so on. Development on this continued, to where it is today!

juiceStretches.description: Movement spin glitch fixed (originally moving spun the player object which caused synchronization issues with the progress bar transform rotation). Looking into how to disable collider-caused rotations next.

Switched to a vfx package-based particle fog system, resulting in much smoother/optimized fog. Added render bounds so fog doesn't generate infinitely (huge performance boost!) Note how fog has virtually no lag now.
enemy spawning / health / kb, bullet damage + targeting, tower spawning

Fixed bug with bullet movement and collision detection, tuned enemy movement logic (momentum vs acceleration). Modular addition of new towers (ft. byteatatime). Some minor optimizations to bullet and enemy pooling mechanic.
item despawning, death respawn cycle and animation (i think this text is allowed since it's not important at all, merely aesthetic. same effect will be achieved if i replace it with gibberish).

tied everything together. upgraded resources now perform different effects, updated bullet pooling optimization to fit different attacks. smart attack choice priority option. routing updated to target basic upgrader first then advanced upgraders -- looking for a balance between upgrading bullets further or keeping basic bullets.

improved energy sharing (resource distribution is now equal instead of greedy), more optimized connection cache system. connections are still invisible (will try to actually visualize them next update!). drops with byteatatime
Basic progression system, previous sandbox-like program is now a game! Progress bar added (you will not believe the amount of code that took, unity sucks for anything with UI)
Turrets now require orbs to fire, drone module successfully integrated with transport backend logic system.

Changed game idea! Implemented a bullet-hell style bullet entity pooling system to help with memory and performance later on. Modified camera damping from earlier platform framework, set up basic colliders and particle triggers.

Completely revamped resource transfer, is now no longer direct (indirect transfer, decentralized onto resource prefabs). Decentralized resource transfer animation with some centralized control. Backend dijkstra's pruning for efficient bfs targeting of resource delivery. Connections seem to be broken, however, which is why resource isn't going into the smaller tower. Fixed a bug where modules try to connect to placement indicator due to certain constraints being satisfied. Will be extending bfs for better targeting next stretch.
Previous movement/camera/mirroring mechanics (will become apparent later), switched to some assets (spent a couple of hours just labeling the tilemap TT)
added fog system, among other small changes (also added an energy & resource system with bytetime)
new module, experimenting with particle effect for orb transmutation
added lightning attack. worked with shadergraphs to create glow texture, fixed render settings for lighting adjustments (two moments merged into one since the last one didn't ship correctly).
Grenade / explosive bullet + explosion logic. Burst attack logic.
new weapon (blue orb): ball, goes through enemies, slowing down to a stop, then disappearing. fixed correct scaling / cropping when resizing game window (previous version crashes rangecheck)
smart routing achieved! routing bfs logic now targets an upgrader first (since only upgraded xp into orbs can be used) before routing to a turret.
new physics-based pulser, momentum/velocity calculations. tweaked progression, de-prefabricated and hardcoded some custom low-health/movement/location/etc enemies to further ease progression
dynamic cache-based TOI generation (not seed generation!) around map. world tilemap is now tracked in GameManager. Small drone and routing improvements (both visual and logical).
better distribution logic, drone style updates. backend routing simulation for 1 minute of future gameplay
Generalized movement logic framework from previous personally developed game [>_TER]RAFORM. Optimized camera effects, damping, and player interpreter for better framerate.
tied together elements. transmutation logic finished.
upgrade logic and animation implemented. xp and resource system rework.

Improved connection logic (turrets now don't connect to other turrets, will only connect to generators/hubs) and added visualization for connectors. Added postprocessing and damage effects. Improved enemy acceleration/momentum system, centralized knockback calculation onto player to avoid duplicate knockbacks in the same frame.
Fixed bug where collider detected too late, fixed by using an averager / normal vector calculation to enemy surface. 236 lines of pure math calculation TwT
Added nodes with distinct connection logic, decreased enemy knockback stun time. Fixed player isTrigger for energy transfer.
tuned tower visuals and energy system. added backend connection system (not visible atm, but maintains cache of connected modules) and basic energy sharing.

transfer to locations with greater than 1 depth now works, bfs now correctly identifies least energy tower. added to decentralized transfer logic, incrementing when reaching destination. in the process of adding an experimental jump / speedup at intersections to make the period where nothing happens in a node (since its covering the resources) less obvious.
finished tileset system, added wall connector logic (i.e. corners, bends, connectors, etc). Set up uvcs repository so teammates can not access the repo.
Enemy hit vfx and knockback logic added. Finally fixed player rigidbody conflicting with tower rigidbody. Some improved collection and energy transfer logic (player collected orbs power turret.)

Added hexagonal module locking (rectangular locking looked a bit weird, but we might add it as a changeable setting) and grid preview. Connector logic now checks range and tower data. Better targeting logic for grenades, with addition of tower attack range (one closest, two random enemies). Optimized fog (at the cost of some fog graphics, might not be noticeable in recording). Fog now clears in a location damped between camera and player instead of player---meaning player can now actually enter the fog.

Description:
Racing Town

This is a racing game centered around your player's racing career. As a kid with a dream of being a world champion, you move to Racing Town to get your start. Racing Town is filled with other racers (find them strolling about and in various shops and garages) and a nearby track.

As a meager newbie, you start out with a slow car. If you're up to it, you can go up to other racers in Racing Town and challenge them. If you show promise on the track, you gain trophies and unlock faster cars (and better opponents). Win enough races, and you can become a world champion!

Because this was my first game, I encountered a lot of challenges. I even almost quit on the first day because I couldn't draw my tilemap (it turned out I accidentally had the eraser icon selected the whole time). I'm really glad I stuck with it though. My game also went through several transformations. I initially started making a puzzle game, but then I landed on the idea of interacting with NPCs, which I really wanted to try and program. I initially approached this as a survival trading game, where you had 10 days to try to trade with NPCs and various shopowners and gain enough coins to leave an island you were stranded on. Midway through, I realized that a game couldn't be fun with just NPC interactions, it also had to have an action component (e.g. a similar game called Duck Life has both NPC interaction and obstacle courses, etc.) So, I added a new section to my game (the racetrack) and made new tilemaps to turn my NPC world into Racing Town! 

Juice has been a really crazy, rewarding journey, and I've learned so much from it.

juiceStretches.description: I HAVE NPCS IN MY GAME NOW LETS GOOOOOO. Three unique NPCs: "the financier", "the survivalist", and "the skater", each skin custom made by me. they roam around and can navigate up and down obstacles, while not falling off the map (this was so hard to implement). also players now flip based on which arrow key is pressed so they are facing in direction of motion.

various improvements
- game speed is a thing now and time of day has actual effects
- at night, the npcs roaming around the main map go into the shops
- if you exit the shops, the npcs that were originally there also are near there too, adding consistency
- resources UI actually works now, and initial values are set without needing a trade to trigger it
improved UI, fixed bugs with hearts, added "retry" button that appears if all hearts exhausted, allowing the user to restart the puzzle/level. i think i'm getting the hang of this game dev stuff.

scene teleportation with input key!!!! e key popup appears when player gets near a door. pressing that takes them to my new setting, the cafe/shop! there is a new NPC, the shopkeeper, that i designed the art for myself, and the setting is extra cool because there is brand new tilemap with furniture -- stairs, lighting, doors, a shop stand, and tables. if the player wants to leave, they can go back to the doors and press e again!

tldr: car leveling and win scren now work.
for the video, i set it so that after every win the car leveled up. visually, this meant that the player skin changes with each level, and the car skin also changes to be more aerodynamic. the car settings also change, they become much faster and accelerate quicker. quicker cars meant that deceleration after finish line didn't always work fast enough, so i added a barrier after the finish line too so nobody ran off the map. after the player accumulates a set # of trophies, the player is transported to a win screen i made, with a gold medal on their character. bc this is the last session, i also worked on polishing the game such as fixing miscellaneous bugs with npcs, and improving the performance of the game by removing redundant skin loading which was making the racing jitter. what a journey it's been!

npcs are now interactable!!! this was very tedious to do, and there were so many edge cases. npcs have a special interaction area to sense when a player is near. if a player is near, the speed of the npc is dramatically reduced and jumping is disabled so the player has time to interact. when in range of npc, an interaction popup appears, and when E is pressed the trading offer for that specific npc pops up, pulled from a global script. so tldr, npc interaction mechanics are done!
fisherman's hut up and running. fisherman npc found inside, with his little fishing pole and bucket. fisherman's hut building exterior is also on the base screen right next to the dock.

global coin economy! trading now works! trading options menu! previously i got working the trade offer menu, but the actual exchange was not there. i added a trading options menu, with press 1 to accept the npc's trade and press 2 to deny the npc's trade. pressing 1 updates global variables representing the coin/fish economy, which then updates the global coin counter! this is very cool, because now i have the building blocks for more goods for the blacksmith, and also trading goods for coins with the shopkeeper. lets goooo

blacksmith's workshop is online, complete with blacksmith-themed building on main island, custom-made blacksmith character, new blacksmith theme tilemap, blacksmith tools on the walls, and got a generalized teleport system working paving the way for the fisherman's hut and more.

game refactor complete! trading town is now racing town! brand new racing tilemap, and all the npcs now have racing driver pixel art skins, and all the buildings are racing themed. the garage allows you to buy a new model of racecar, while the gas station (peep the gas pump pixel art) and agent's office are places you can find other npcs hanging out. some other improvements include when exiting shops, the player now spawns outside the building they just entered instead of just spawning in the middle of the map. also, there are now invisible barriers on the sides that prevent players from running off the map. next up is the racetrack and the racing mechanic!

We back to juicinnnn. Lots of behind the scenes changes to the economy to make sure the math is mathin. Lots of edge cases here, but now things make sense such as negative trades being blocked (as demonstrated with the dockkeeper / moustache man).

Core mechanic of puzzle game is almost done. Added "lives" functionality, a nicer background, a "run" function allowing the user to plan their response, and a full three layers of the multilayer perceptron, in addition to the logic of computing the end node state.

implemented a day/night system, with a sun and moon icon that change based on which stage using modulated canvas layer and a script that was sooo hard to get right. also added a custom player character and a dock with a ship sprite (win condition). game is coming together :D

fish and ore trades work! + certain npcs can be programmed to only offer certain trades. next up is allowing multiple trade offers from npcs, and preventing trades that allow you to go to negative values.

complete newbie to game dev or godot, but i finally got one of the core building blocks working! it's a puzzle solving game, where the user has a set number of tries to guess the correct combination of colors to pass the level.

I. need. sleep. I thought I would finish the game in chunks, but then I was like screw it, I'm skipping school, and I just did it all in one go lmao. Sorry it was such a long session, but I'll give a detailed breakdown of what I accomplished to make it easy for the brave soul that is my reviewer:
-- Learned proper Godot UI, now all UI elements are anchored instead of hardcoded positions, meaning the game works with all screen sizes now.
-- Fonts changed to Pixel Arial
-- In racing town, the signpost now leads to the racing track.
-- Day counter (allows replayability if player wants to beat their previous day record)
-- Trophy counter
-- Made a brand new racing track tilemap, complete with barriers and spectators in the stands, as well as the actual track. The spectators took soo long, I made them way too complex lolz.
-- Programmed collision object that acts as finish line, keeps tracks of the car's final times.
-- Added logic to randomize which team the player is playing against (green, yellow, or pink racing clubs that match with a specific car wrap in the same color)
-- Programmed the player car, which is controlled by top speed and acceleration parameters. These parameters are set by what level of car the player has, and then to make it interesting, they're multiplied by a random value between 0.9 and 1.1 so that each race you  can have a different opponent, but they are still in your same "tier". This also allows for really interesting races, such as a slow acceleration but faster top speed leads to some pretty close finishes.
-- Programmed an npc car, which has similar logic but acts independently of the player car, and starts acceleration once the player first presses space.
-- Added UI timer that starts when the player starts the race by pressing space
-- Added logic that a) determines when the race has started, b) what the player final time is c) what the npc final time is d) who won and e) updates the UI timer with a final post-race scoreboard of the times. The logic for this took so so long, as there's a lot of edge cases and messing with global variables caused a lot of bugs i kept having to fix.
-- Implemented logic to auto slow down the player and npc cars once they cross finish line so they don't run off the map.
-- After 5 seconds of the race ending, the player is sent back to racing town, and if they won the race, their trophy counter increases by 1.
-- all the roofs in racing town are now consistent and don't block the player jumping on them
Only thing left is now sound effects and changing car levels once the player hits 5 and 10 trophies! Shanghai here i come!!!

added base scene with a cool world the user can run and jump around. the user can go around to different houses -- these are the levels. when the player gets near a door a callout to press E appears, transporting them to the puzzle level. this took a long time to get right with area2d scripts. additionally, the user can go back and forth from the puzzle screen using a back button i added. game is coming together!

pivoted my game from trading game with npcs, to racing game against npcs. i was unhappy with my game previously, as there wasn't enough playable content. i realized that purely interaction with npcs can't be the meat of the game, it has to center around a main action. e.g. games like ducklife you complete challenges, and then interact with npcs on the side. after a lot of bashing my head against a wall i had an idea for a racing game so I'm going with it! good news is i have all of the infrastructure done (interacting with npcs, entering buildings, movement, etc.), so it's just a matter of changing the artwork a little, adding cars, and sound effects. today i worked on the artwork for both the players and cars and designed the "racing town" scene and the actual track scene. there are 4 racing orgs, each with their own color scheme. there are three tiers (levels) that this game will progress through, each with their own locations. each new location the racer kit and the car gets a little more advanced (e.g. going from NASCAR to formula 1. i made different versions of the artwork to reflect that.

Description:
I was just scrolling the announcements channel when I found this. At first I was lowk doubtful but soon realized that they ain't capping. I've always fw game dev in general but hadn't done it for quite some time. So this seemed like a perfect opportunity. One thing tho that I already knew wasn't gonna be good was the fact that I'm TERRIBLE at sticking with ideas. Like gng I changed my idea 6 times and no, it wasn't just the idea that I changed; I worked on every idea and THEN I scraped them. For a better visualisation of how dumb I am, I worked around 150 hours on stuff that I scraped later lmao. I still did figure out one idea that I li ked enough to stick with. Tho the game wasn't really anything special, the process of making something from ground up to the finished product is always close, very close to my heart. It was just a two player game where you fight each other and stuff (you think ik what im working on gng 😭😭).

Anyway, I'm writing this in Shanghai and lemme tell you, ts is GOATED ASF gng. Like I've never experienced anything even close to this before and lowk I doubt I ever will. The people I've met here are some of the most talented and most awesome people I've ever known and maybe ever will. For example, Neha's the best person I've met on this platform (I've got a gun pointed on my head rn). This was my first HackClub IRL event and I'm so glad that I didn't procrastinate on ts one.

Aight gng, that's all I have to say. Everyone who worked on ts is goated asf, y'all remember that.
OK BYEEEE!! <3

This game is a mess of disorganisation, passion, and tears. Initially, my partner and I decided upon a concept that we thought would be fun and interesting: a dungeon crawler puzzle game with Balatro-like mechanics. We worked on this game pretty liberally at first, I wanted to put basically all of my time into it because it was a thing I enjoyed. However, later on I got busy with exams and so did my partner, so we sorta had to stop doing as much work. I still tried my best to get the hours done but it was generally done very late. Come to about 15 days before I had to leave for Shanghai, I have about 40 hours left to do. I still had assignments to do, so I start staying up extremely late: about 3 AM every night, pulling 4 hour sessions of game dev debugging and attempting to implement features which ultimately had to be cut for time and bugs. In the end I ended up fixing a major bug in shanghai and was able to be proud of my game for the first time in nearly a week.

Description:
biofuel

So, this is my little game! Biofuel is a roguelike/farming style game where you defend your farm from a bunch of bugs. Unfortunately, I'm not very good at game development so it looks pretty bad. I started this about 2 months ago when I first heard about Juice, got super excited and then started grinding immediately. I drew all of the sprites by hand on paper and scanned/edited them into my game for a nice little aesthetic, then smashed my keyboard until something resembling code appeared on my screen. Slapping all of that together with a bit of burnout and stress and you get Biofuel! 
I think it's appropriately named. Besides all of the story reasons behind the name, I did literally put so much passion into my game that it's the only thing fueling it and making it run.

finalized the dynamic crop system!!! rn there's a bug where the texture isn't really showing up properly but it works ig. also, i need to further optimize the loading because it does freeze for a short moment :P so i would probably need to just fetch data and preload instead of loading the data every time if that makes any sense

Description:
DEADBEAT
DEADBEAT is a fast-paced top-down arena shooter with a rhythm twist. It's loud, flashy, and colorful, and it requires quick reflexes & strong focus. Timing your shots to the beat of a song turns a traditionally button-mashy genre into a technical challenge with a surprising amount of depth. DEADBEAT started as a simple idea: "What if our roguelike was a rhythm game?" However, after building a prototype we quickly realized how fun the mechanic was and jumped headfirst into development. As novice developers we ran into a slew of basic problems that we had to work through one by one, including the fact that we didn't have a clear vision for the game until the very end. As time progressed, though, DEADBEAT coalesced into the single final product it is now.

Description:
DimensionShift
I first got the idea for this game when I was playing through a game called Titanfall 2, and I came across this level where you could free "time travel" at any point to switch between two different time periods, while still maintaining your exact position in the map. In one time period you were in a futuristic factory building but in the other the factory had completely burned down. This was one of the coolest gaming experiences I had ever played and I thought it was too good of a mechanic to only be used in one level of one game, so for juice I decided to make a full game with this mechanic. I ended up making a linear, top-down shooter in GameMaker where you switch between a dungeon map and a swamp/forest map. I also layered some other mechanics in utilizing dimension switching to make it a little more interesting. Although this isn't my first video game, this is my first time making a video game at this scale and I am really thankful for this opportunity for pushing me to make something bigger than anything I have made before. Most of the art comes from https://itch.io/c/1507436/fantasy-but I did make some of it, and I made all of the music/sound effects in the game. Thank you so much to all the juice organizers and participants for helping make this once in a lifetime experience!

Description:
Ironshift

It all started one day, I got an email from GitHub Education. It was about an event called "High Seas". I decided to take a look at it and give it a try. And so I became a part of Hack Club.

After High Seas ended, they announced Juice. I've always wanted to create a game, and ship it to a store like Steam! This was a perfect opportunity! So I signed up and made a bit every day, instead of playing Factorio. It looked awesome at the start!

This was my first Hack Club event, where I could fly somewhere, so I told my parents: "Hi, I could go to China at the beginning of April for free!". My parents were like: "Ehmmm... what?! What kind of scam is this?". So I spent the next 2 hours of my life explaining what Hack Club is and all of this stuff.

I did really well, I was a bit late, but it was very fun. I had a lot of problems and bugs, but I always found a way to fix them. I'm not a good artist everything and I tried to draw looked awful, so I decided to buy some assets on itch.io

Just one day before the deadline, I had all the 100 required hours, no words in my game, but still only 15 minutes of playable content.

The next day I was programming the whole day and made the required 30 minutes of playable content. Sadly, I didn't make it to China, but it was still very fun, and I'm proud of my self that I finished the game.

juiceStretches.description: The axe finally does something!

1. Implemented the new tileset system into the actual game.
2. Optimised the chunk loading system.
3. Fixed the bug where the player had to jump before moving.
4. Fixed the bug where the game crashed when opened inventory after an axe broke.

1. Created an iron ore, that spawns randomly around the world.
2. Made a new item type that can be placed into the world.
3. Made a furnace that for now can only be placed and mined.

Reworked the system that places the tiles to look connected.

Before:
1. It took like a minute to load the game because it duplicated the tileset a lot of times. This was needed for the player to be able to jump between the layers (I needed the ability to set the physics layer for each terrain layer).
2. It was incredibly painful to modify the tileset.
3. The tilemap didn't work in the editor because i needed to set the tiles in a script based on the surrounding tiles.

After:
1. It should load faster because the tilesets are a lot smaller.
2. The tileset is just 7x7, so it is easy to modify.
3. It works in the editor too!
Now it works by overlaying the center tile (in the tileset) with the tiles around (red is a sign to not to overlay that pixel).

Description:
It's the year 2027, AI has finally matched human intelligence. After 2 years of faithful employment at Tetsu Incorporated, Coby-SP is finally thrown away and considered, “obsolete.” But Coby also happens to be the first of his kind: persistent. Now he must escape the bowels of his old workplace and make some friends along the way, too. Your job is to navigate the maze-like facility and keep Coby out of trouble, because it isn’t going to be easy. In Club Robot’s development, I had to essentially learn everything from the beginning. See, up to this point, I had like no experience working with a real game engine, and I was stuck on little web games with limited gameplay. My buddy GB actually started out and asked me to join Juice with him, because we kinda completed each other's skillset, and I was lead game design from then on. I came up with the whole idea for a story and game, then we got to work. 100 hours of back and forth game development later, we ended up creating a project that, at least I think, is something to be proud of; and I’m very thankful to Hack Club for the opportunity. - Boxthings

Making this game wasn't always fun. In a way, my partner and I were like the character in the game, trying on things we'd never tried before (Godot and GDScript), with no one to help us at all. We gathered with three other people to create this game, but they sadly left due to circumstances early in development, leaving just two people to carry on the dream.
It almost felt crazy, setback after setback after setback and deadline after deadline after deadline, with all these what ifs and will we make it…? Boxthings and I grinded the final push to make it all the way to the top, collecting achievements, making progress... (just like Coby.)
I programmed nearly everything, with Boxthings sending art left and right. We didn't think about what could happen, we thought about what WILL happen.
And at last sweet victory came. We finally drank all 100 hours worth of juice. - GB

Description: Due to my lack of experience in game development and limited time, I have chosen a game genre that is less difficult for me to develop. I did not use the well-known game development engine in this game, but instead used Electron, which to some extent simplifies the details of game development without having to consider more complex designs.

juiceStretches.description: Found errors in the first 4 files and related configurations, updated the location of some clues based on player feedback, and fixed some errors. Due to ongoing defects, Github has not been uploaded yet.
