The prototype version of the project has been produced.

Description:
Undead Courier

I never thought I’d actually make a game, but I had an idea: Undead Courier, a game about delivering packages in a zombie-infested world. At 13, I didn’t have much experience beyond messing with game engines, but I dove in anyway. I first tried making it in 2D with Godot, but it looked awful. Frustrated, I switched to Unity and restarted in 3D, but balancing everything—movement, enemy AI, and level design—was brutal. Every fix seemed to break something else, and I nearly gave up more times than I can count.

I spent late nights debugging, learning from online communities, and reworking mechanics over and over. Eventually, things started clicking. When people finally played Undead Courier and actually had fun, I knew all the struggles were worth it.

Description:
Hera Kleos follows the legendary story of Heracles and his 12 labours.
In this action-packed 2-player 2D platformer, you and a friend will work together to overcome challenges. One player controls Heracles using the keyboard, while the other plays as Hera using the mouse—assisting with divine movement, strategy, and godly powers to help Heracles through his trials.

It all started when I received an email from Juice—at the perfect moment. I had just been discussing the possibility of making a game with Allie. At the same time, I recalled a game mechanic that Jafar had come up with and shared last summer. That’s when I brought all of us together. After explaining the opportunity, it felt like the stars had aligned, and JUAce Games was formed. (As in Juice! Get it? Get it?) Later, when another crew member joined our team, we renamed it to Jaunty Games.
From the start, we brainstormed countless ideas—exploring different mechanics, genres, and art styles. But when the idea for Hera Kleos took shape, we knew: this was the game we had to make.
I’d love to say the development process went smoothly, but balancing school, sleep, and the juice was tough. Despite the hardships, we had a blast creating this game, and each of us poured a part of our soul into it.

Meet the Crew:
👾 Umarbek (me) – Let’s just imagine I’ve written something insightful about myself here.
💫 Allie – An incredible artist and writer. Sometimes you have to wonder if she’s even human when she starts reciting The Iliad word for word. The greatest history nerd on the planet, she single-handedly drew and animated all the visuals for the game!
🧑🏻‍💻 Jafar – With a passion for overly complex deathless speedruns, he was the perfect choice for level design. He loves mathematics and programming, which explains why he insisted that the donation suggestion be $3.14—as in, π (pi). Just don’t ask him how many times he made us redo pixel-perfect levels with inhuman timing.
🎸 Nay – There’s only one way to describe him: he’s Nay. A disciplined and mature mind, skilled in various sports, and a solid musician. Every track in the game? Composed, played, and recorded by him.

For anything, feel free to contact me at umariktokyo@gmail.com.

juiceStretches.description: Hera's tile mechanic works. I've worked on managing multiple abilities and hotboxes in order to do various actions depending on the chosen abilities and if its touching the Heracles.
I've improved on the animations of Heracles and added the ability to punch.

- Added basic functional user interface
- Updated the data-manager for support of multiple slots of the game
- Added a timer for recording playtime.
There was a major bug with everything going black after a scene was completed. (video) I've fixed the error; turns out the camera was under some node, and moving it moved everything in the scene 🤦‍♂️

I fixed the menu bar, now all the buttons are working and displaying correctly, and are now moving around whenever some of them are clicked. I've tried to come up with clever solution but then gave up and brute forced the method... There are two layers of UI, and whether the ability is available or not, the image gets dark.
I've resolved the GitHub merge conflicts and reconstructed the lost progress with the levels I've worked on.

I rewrote the collision logic in Godot as it was made in a completely wrong way and started working with resources to create reusable objects. It's taking a lot of time to understand the working of the Godot and rewriting the "badly organized" scripts and structures.

- Now Heracle can die in the levels
- Started designing levels for Heracle and Hera to platform together with the tile ability.
- Added the new Damage colliders as 
- Fixed the window resizing functionality. 
- Added the save-points functionality for Heracles. Now we can kill both characters without restarting the level from the first scene.
I've implemented the hearts (on the top-left corner, sprites for them will be added soon), and the mechanic for the health and damage for Lion and Heracles.

Wrote out the README file for github and agreed on some aspects of the game with the team. We've come up with the 2nd player - cursor mechanic and how we could incorporate it into a game as well as the ways we could create every level in unique style.
I've figured out a way how to setup the singleton structure in Godot and change levels from one to another. It took quite some debugging and refactoring the code into better hierarchical structure.

Now all the characters stop when the game is paused. Additionally, I've fixed the bug with the menu_bar being pressed whenever space is pressed. Turns out the same issue was occurring with the rest of the buttons in the game; fixed them as well.

I've worked on the updated structure for the code of the menu bar as well as importing the assets and making them feel good. It's my first time designing the UI in Godot so it took quite a lot of trial and error.
Now the summoning circles rotate when Hera is on them!

I have implemented various types of hotboxes, each with own purpose and started working on the level 1 puzzles/platforming. Yellow means Hera can't pass it, blue means Heracles can't pass it and Purple blocks both characters from passing.

Today I've worked with Resources and collisions and have created gates for the castle room. I've implemented functionality of Area2D's in Godot for the first time, encountering many obstacles on the way which I've successfully passed and got this beautiful prototype of Heracle's hotbox entering levels depending on the gate. Next I will work on adding the ray collider to the main character which will keep track of all the objects he's coming close to (to play the king's task animations and picking up objects?) and will start creating actual weapon systems (arrows, hitting and so on.)
Brainstormed and developed a mechanic which in theory should solve the issue of second player - cursor's finding purpose.

I have fixed Heracle's rotation; now all the hitboxes are aligned and work properly. Additionally I've added the animations and code for punching. I've worked more on anti-cheating systems for Hera (so she doesn't leave the screen and re-enter from the other side, but is still able to close the window or leave it) but I think the currently used method is not good enough. Still searching for a better solution for that part.
Studied more about GOScript and the signal system used within the engine. Decided on the art styles and cursor mechanics with the team.
I have fixed the rotation of the main collider (body) for the Heracles. Turns out the same methods don't work for the Area2D and CollisionShapes..
Created more detailed map for the home-chapter, chapter 1.
I've learned the basics of GDScript, and have implemented various buttons, sliders, labels, and worked with inputs. Video has one of the tests I've created while learning

I've worked on the menu, now locked abilities are half-transparent. Additionally, I've made so Hera Can't leave the scene (it was easy to cheat before as hera / mouse could easily leave the screen from one side and re-enter from the other side)
Hera now rotates according to the mouse's position!

Now Hera's obstacle functions work properly, I've been trying to implement the mechanic of having certain blocks Hera can't pass but it was a little too hard to implement... Anyway, I've made so the level restarts when she dies, same as for Heracles
I've started importing and adding assets to the scenes. I've also created the "summoning-circle" for hera. The adding of sprites is still ongoing.
The basic player now moves and jumps!
I made movable platforms, with adjustable speed, distance and style of movement.
I've created working health in the game for Heracles. (I don't have any other objects other than gates so I demonstrated using it.)
I've fixed the gate. It was very buggy; in general its taking a lot of time to fix these errors... hope I will be able to finish it in time.

Set up the basic workflow for the Lion Boss. Defined all the animations and the correlation as well as the progression of the boss battle. Next, I'll have to create the animations, and program the lion.

I've played more with the states of the main characters; now depending on the selected abilities, Hera can and cannot enter the Heracle and arrows either do or not follow the Hera. (Hera can navigate the arrows.)

There was an issue with the lion's node being stuck in a single location, I've tried to debug it but nothing worked.. at the end I've re-did all the animations fast and set up a basic environment for the boss battle to happen at.

The issue was, Hera could just stay in one place while Heracles went to next level. Now I've added the new colliders / elements where Hera must stand for Heracles to be able to leave the scene and camera to move.
I have fixed bugs with some previous things I've developed and additionally started working no the lion boss and his attacks. You can see the "Moon-Walking" bug on the video 😅.

Turns out we've neglected adding ready timers into the playable scenes. I've quickly fixed that issue by adding our modular timer element into all playable scenes developed so far.
Additionally, I've now made the death counter functional. It records the new death every time Heracles Dies. (idk what should I do with Hera's deaths, perhaps implement another separate counter or just add it already existing counter?)
Animated the Heracle's character!
I have figured out how to make the background repeatable. Additionally, I've added the camera limits so characters don't leave the playable area.

I've made smart camera system, which stays static during the solving of the level but moves when character reaches the end of the screen. Additionally, now Hera has resting location where she respawns and moves the mouse towards that location when spawns, which illuminates the bug with her flying into other side of the screen every time the level starts.

Started importing assets into the game; using custom software I've made, I've been cutting extra parts from the sprites, importing them into the game, organising the file structure and filtering the background layers to make the foreground more visible.
Updated the design of the menu-bar; imported some of the assets and added basic functionality.(WIP)
I have been importing sprites and assets for the level1.0. This is only 1/6th of all the screens... 🥲

To automate the process of importing the assets drawn on large canvases to Godot from our artist, I've created a solution to strip all the extra png space on the images using image processing library. The previous code had a crucial bug in it because of which only some of the images were updated; now that bug is cleaned.
I've created the functioning lava-fall. This element will be used for the third part of level 1 - lion, in the cave.
I've integrated Hera's animations and some of the background assets.
I've cleaned up the menu screen by aligning all the colliders to the grid system, minimising amount of elements and cleaning up the hierarchy of the nodes.
Implemented Hera's death animation!
I have optimised the lava_rain object, (falling lava) by spawning the lava particles only if the source is visible on the screen.
I've updated the structure of the whole project. We had a lot of scenes with objects floating around randomly. Now it's all organised and clean 🫧

I've worked on:
- Created a python code which can strap the empty free space in PNG's so assets take up less space.
- Added few assets to the scene
- Added Parallax effect to the background and foreground elements.
- We can now show and hide the menu bar.
I have cleaned up the levels for the level1.1, there were some uncleaned levels; I've aligned them to the grid we've made and ensured it's playable.

I've made Hera's deaths count as well and have separated their deaths into two separate counters. Had to fix the death counter throughout the entirety of the project. There was also an issue with the multiple deaths being recorded at once for Hera (seen in the video), which I've debugged and fixed eventually. I've also added the timeout for Heracles, so he doesn't immediately move and die when respawning.

This was a long session.. I've added some "beauty" and structure to the previously only-functional UI. Now all the elements are structured accordingly and look relatively neat. We'll just have to draw and add couple sprites for various buttons or icons and we can consider the starter menu finished. Additionally, I've edited the logic with the mouse being hidden. Now it's not just hidden by default but rather is hidden when the game is played and is displayed when the game is paused.
Worked on Hera's logic as well as her main mechanic (being a mouse-controlled platformer character)

I fixed all the mistakes and bugs with the two characters. Firstly, every time Hera dies, the whole level used to restart, now she just goes into her start position. Secondly, Heracle's colliders used to flip in a wrong way, now everything works fine. Thirdly, there were issues with exiting the game, now they're less of them. Lastly, I've fixed the issues with Godot timers which came out after merge conflicts when cooperating with my teammate on GitHub.

Understood how the inheritance of the classes and collections in Godot works. Learned about some nodes and their work, created this basic jumping character. Soon will start working on the first level of the game.

Updated the management of data
- Combined enums.gd into data_manager.gd for easier usage.
- Fixed the bug with the Godot 4's new JSON parser.
- Moved all the functions responsible for the global data management into data_manager.gd.

- Created basic caste scene with the floor and parallax effect. 
- Added the camera and made it follow Heracle.

After so much work, I've solved two major issues with our mechanic. Firstly, I've solved the issue with Hera's cheating by leaving the screen by making her un-active when she presses the menu. I've moved the menu to the left side of the screen so she can press it at the beginning of the level. Additionally, when you were replaying a level, the camera's following logic was making it stay on the last level you were at, while characters were still on the first part of the level. It took quite some debugging and coding but now it all works; camera is always with the player.
I've added the arrow to the game! Now I know how to initiate objects alike and delete them when they leave the scene.
Fixed the visibility of mouse with Hera, fixed her death counter and made better anti-cheating system.
I've made a basic template and guidelines for the designing platforming sections of the game, so my teammates can design them as well.

I've created a logging system which saves the game data into systems and let's you load / update the critical information. I also started developing the movements and mechanics for the Hera character.
I have cleaned up the entirety of the first third of the level. Everything is now aligned with the grid and of similar thickness. The art is ready to be drawn.
Turns out I've introduced a major flow to Hera when implemented her death animation. It took quite a lot of effort to fix it.
I've added more functionality to UI, now you can name your slots! Additionally, before every slot was pre-created by me but now you can create and delete them in the game.

I've uploaded the game to itch.io! Turns out there were some bugs to be resolved and things to update before exporting the game. (our assets are not ready and we were using the collider shapes only to experiment with mechanics, so I had to ensure all the sprites are portrayed in the actual visual mode and change the sprites when changing the abilities. Furthermore, some issues with exporting were encountered, which got resolved with re-installing the Godot engine.)

Our artist have finished creating a bottom menubar for Hera as well as I've finally figured out what to do with stopping Hera from cheating but not restricting mouse to the screen all the time. Finally, the game now can be paused. (all characters and animations stop moving!)
Designed more levels, and fixed the hierarchy of the elements in the scene.
I've set up the exporting settings for our game and figured out the system requirements in Windows, MacOS and Linux. (just realised linux is not in the screen recording, I've added it afterwards.)
With the team, we've brainstormed what could our game look like and thought out the basics of it.
I made more customisable lava, now there are various thicknesses of it.
I've imported the sprites, and cleaned up the slots screen, now it looks beautiful ✨.
Created a plan out for the first chapter of the game - Intro / tutorial.
Imported the lion animations, and started designing the lion boss battle

I've finally figured out a way how to limit the speed of the mouse for hera! now she can't just go through the walls by moving the mouse really fast. I've tried few solutions out and decided on choosing to making a separate entity tracking the mouse and its speed and resetting hera back to initial position if it's too fast. 🏎️ (I've also fixed the error with the screen exiting which I've noticed occurs on the recorded video)

I've added customisable movable platforms. Now they can move in two directions (horizontally and vertically), in two different styles (linear and sine), be of three different shapes (brick, stick and brick with supports), damage Heracles or Hera depending on your choosing, change speed, and distance over which they work.
Continued working on the importing of the sprites. We're running out of assets so I've done everything I could so far.

Description: "Shake it!" is a game where you get to run your own bubble tea cafe! My 2 favorite things in life are bubble tea and cats so I had to make a game related to them. You start off as a brand new shop owner serving bubble tea to a small select amount of customers. Upgrade your restaurant and find new customers to serve as you grow a monopoly on the bubble tea market. I wanted to make it fun and interesting to play, so preparing the bubble tea is done by fun minigames and it's overall a really cool and relaxing game to play!
