Description:
Flourish

Making flourish has been a wild ride - days of equal excitement, frustration and sometimes tears in my eyes after hours of juicing with no success T-T. When I first started, I had a simple idea: create a game with many worlds involving fighting and gathering resources, and use my inspiration from other similar genres like Terraria, Minecraft, and Stardew Valley (of which the early prototype of the game was given the name "Temu Valley" by my friends). What I didn't expect was just how much this game would evolve and enlighten my views on game development.

In the beginning, everything was about setting up the basics. I had never touched Godot before, though the Pythonic-looking GDScript syntax lured me in, and from there I laid the foundations: Tilemaps, enemy AI, combat - your standard top-down action game stuff. My humble start with the first enemy, a blue slime, was built with hours of confusion, and yet my selection grew to be more than slimes. My initial system of handling the important mechanics weren't as scalable as I needed them to be, and every bug I patched felt like a bandaid solution - things started to feel like they were being held together by duct tape.

One of the biggest turning points was when I realised my harvestable resource system (trees, rocks, crops, etc.) was becoming a mess. At first, I use d a simple inheritance-based system, but tweaking each resource felt clunky. That's when I started exploring Godot's Resource system (not to be confused with my in-game resources :P). I flip-flopped a few times and eventually landed on a structured OOP-based system - now the volume of tears produced every day was reduced!

Every little detail mattered in my game, and I wanted it to be satisfying to play my game: hit effects, knockback, sound effects - these small details really brought Flourish to life. There was a moment where I realised: "wow, this actually feels good to play now!" - that was a huge milestone for me :3

I would like to thank everyone who has supported me in this journey - Hack Clubbers and parents included! This game has been a learning experience in every way, and now seeing it come together and getting a chance to share it with strangers in Shanghai and other juicers who shared the same journey as me? That's beyond anything I imagined, and I am thankful to be a part of this big journey - and my first big journey at Hack Club! There's still a lot of work to do, and Flourish will continue to... flourish. But this journey has taught me so much, and in life, we are always learning.

Made with <3 by Junya.

juiceStretches.description: added some form of respawn system (will be reworked) - this is what i have for now :P
updated the cue system of my harvestables, shows a little dotted rectangular outline of a harvestable. also patched a bug where you could get double the loot :skull: and keep harvesting.

been juicing for a while to add a base class for passive entities in my game, as im handling them differently to enemies. this pig inherits from that, and so i have made it roam around randomly (horizontal directions only so far) or idle. tried to get other actions like pig sleeping going but it didn't really work out, but i shall add more entities like cows, cats, dogs, etc to flourish!
player takes damage (kinda)
i should never ever make text through 2d tilemaps again 💀💀

OMG "IT" WORKS, "IT" being my system that shows the controls in the bottom right corner. my idea taken from the console versions of games like minecraft and terraria is a list of controls / keybinds sorta thing that displays what you can do on the bottom of your screen, and they're dynamically updating. so if you move near a resource you're in range to gather, the gather keybind shows up in the bottom right corner! same with other actions like dash, etc, etc!
added more varieties of harvestables (autumn + winter variants!!). fixed the bug where you can attack rocks after they've been harvsted, and tweaked the rock destroy sound to sound more natural :3
rewriting player character script so its less spaghetti code T-T
slightly tweaked the dash velocity interpolation so it doesnt look like the player is propelled by a force; added attack icon indicator and fixed first time attack detection
added a custom cursor icon to my game, thinking about adding different types possibly...
finished with basic collisions for my objects, as well as y sorting :yawning:

healthbar ui with hearts is functional (not with shields yet though...) - the hearts go in an anticlockwise manner when displaying how much hp you have so 87 hp for example roughly translates to 4 full hearts, and a quarter heart, so people can gauge how much hp they have left!!
added the rest of my status effects (maybe more in the future O.O) - the player teleporting back is my temporary respawn mechanic :P. there arent just debuffs as well, hoping to add buffs maybe...
(new enemy) scary skelebones chasing you :OOOO

made some additional changes to resource gathering this one tree! i forgot to properly show it in my OMG moment, but notice how the tree becomes a little bit brighter as you approach it? that's your cue to harvest it (or well, you CAN harvest it). tree shakes and gets tinted a darker, yellowish colour as you harvest it to indicate damage and then its harvested :)
reworked my effects system to be class-based in godot, which means they arent hardcoded anymore and theoretically can be applied to other entities, not just the player!
added a stamina depletion system so actions like sprinting, dashing, attacking, etc deplete stamina (so far its done internally, will add a stamina bar to indicate progress).

i converted my resource gathering system to an inheritance based system similar to how i did it at first. the system i had before was just "one script for each resource" which copy pastes all methods, code etc which obviously isnt a good idea as refactoring and restructuring will be an absolute pain in the future. i also attached the script to the static body, instead of the root node of each resource's scene the Node2D, which is in general a bad practice in godot. i had to delete what i had (thankfully i didnt really have a lot of resources) and convert it into an inheritance based system where i can override methods and variables. as you can in the video, everything looks SOOOO much cleaner now and less spaghetti code. so far i've got it working for just one tree, but that means it'll be so much easier to make new resources in flourish, and im glad i did this!! :D

rewrote player script (again.. for the better :P) but i've gotten rid of diagonal movement (because it feels retro on a 2d top-down game) and added (drumroll...) acceleration movement so it feels smoother.

rewrote my shield system so its no longer like a second health bar and more of a damage reduction system. also added the ui for it with updating text. now when taking damage (that doesnt bypass the shield if given that parameter), i used a short logarithmic formula to calculate the actual damage taken from the damage reduction, and it's pretty neat and balanced :D
first time using godot, basic 2d platformer controls!! yay :DDD

wow! that was an amazing journey by finally adding sounds. had to fix a couple of issues with my sound manager script, but all is well and so ive downloaded creative commons sounds off freesound.org (you may recognise these sounds from other games as well :P), edited them in Audacity and imported them into godot, which is currently used in my resources and passive entities. timings, etc is a bit dodgy but they work, fit in nicely and sound so good!!

spent a while looking at audiostreamplayers in godot, wrote my own custom sound manager for handling music, global and spatial sfx which works pretty well. demoing spatial sfx, and a soundtrack (faint cuz im not at home but you can barely hear it).

finally got item textures to show up properly (after some edge case scenarios i hadnt accounted for like when stripping ".png" from oak_log.png turned it into oak_lo... or other weird wacky things with loading assets in godot). my demo here is just me binding the open inventory to add a random item with a random amount to my inventory (and if it tries to add more than what is populated i.e. the inventory is full, then it refuses and wont bug out).

refactored all of my passive entities so their scenes' root node is the characterbody2d instead of a redundant node2d. im not mistaking this mistake again, but hopefully scripting will be less vague and more consistent with everything.

blue slime is able to take damage (and is able to begin attacking the player within range, not attack once when the player enters the range) under new system. trying to fix knockback - vectors are too confusing T-T but the slime is noticeably nudged back when attacked.
made the damage tint of the resource (tree in this case) be based on how much damage it received by lerping the colours. more damage = more reddish darker tint, less damage = less reddish tint.
fixed the combat system - enemy death animation works <3
improved enemy aggro; worked a hard ton on the collisions (wish i could show them all :sob:)
added player movement abilities like dash, sprint, etc. also (not demonstrated in video) added player flashing red when taking damage!!
entities have loot tables now (drop items on death). my pig drops seeds.. :3

been working on tweaking a couple of things in the player script along with a new addition - status effects! demonstrated is poison but im gonna have more status effects like burning, freezing, bleeding, etc!! :yay:

so ive been spending a lot of time debugging errors with my player's code (e.g., resources dont detect attack on first attack). i decided screw it, i'm rewriting the whole thing more organised and follow better practices with gdscript - spaghetti begone :P

(attempted to) fix issue with being able to hit tree stump after it has been harvested; fixed the tweens of harvestables being sequential instead of parallel, and now rock destruction sounds more natural (in sync).
i finally got y sort working again.. it was an issue with how i handled sprite offsets and origin positioning with the static bodies (since i handle y sorting on resources and tilemaps separately) 💀💀
messing with ui in godot for the first time and managed to tinker with textureprogressbars. they arent functional yet but they look pretty neat with the sprites i made! :D
collisions and y-sorting finally readded for the objects (this time they're more accurate, because i did it by pixel instead of freely drawing the collision box by eye)

- adjusted my crop system so red outline shows if not ready, green outline for ready for harvest, and demonstration of what happens when the crop needs to be watered (still need to work on the watering system :P)
- worked on my hotbar system - the set of tools available are just an example and player wont have full access initially but these tools now limit what you can do - so pickaxe for rocks, axe for trees, sword for attacking etc. - added controller support for the cycling as well (and scroll wheel) but its currently extremely dodgy and sometimes "double" scrolls as u saw a lot in this video. may consider changing the sprite as this one only has sword animations :3

omg i cant believe it took me 2 hours of juicing to get some sort of inventory system working :sob: :sob: :sob:. anyways i've got my inventory ui setup that can get populated with items, and yes there is an internal inventory - the ui just displays the items that are in the internal inventory with the texture. tried to add item dragging but struggled a bit, so now im gonna see if i can actually get items displaying here.
added a hp regeneration system for the player; the player regenerates x amount of hp every y seconds, but only if the time since they were last attacked exceeds z amount of time.
learning to play sounds in my game with godot's AudioStreamPlayer2D - poor cow...
modified my iframes indicator code (instead of turning the player momentarily invisible, i modulate the sprite colour to red) - also experimenting with knockback when taking damage :3
added healthbars; kind of fixed the attacking mechanic (still need to work on that one :P)
facepalming very hard right now as i discovered autotiling terrain generation in godot saves so much time

had to add a new method to my inventory system to actually update existing items and sync the internal system to the ui (you can see as soon as i chop the tree that i get the drops instantly). anyways this is basically my first attempt at making the resource gathering system in flourish. the tree is my starter, and it OMG MOMENT works (sorta, i need to make the code better and not dodgy). spent so much unncessary time trying to debug an issue i had with my player's hitbox not detecting the tree thanks to an unresolved godot bug (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/66468) 💀 so there's that... resource gathering system has things like loot tables as well to manipulate drop chances, quantity etc!! im so happy how nicely everything's coming together :DDD

finished doing the rest of my trees and rocks with the new inheritance system - y sorting is a but dodgy but i think i can fix it easily :P. anyways im gonna add more resource objects like this, 4 different trees and 3 rocks aren't going to do.
convert my 2d platformer to a sort of near top down view idk - it works in 3d now!!

- worked on a helper class for constructing parameters for making entities take damage, because the line for the parameters in the method was getting very long
- mostly rewritten hostile entities, blue slime is redone with roaming like the animals and also chases the player and attacks player. took a very long time of debugging on why the chase wasn't working until i decided on a bandaid solution, where i will rewrite the chase system next juice session T-T
first (real) animated 2D sprite with movement :P

currently in the process of refactoring and restructuring my player + entities root nodes. got pathfinding + roaming working on the slime so now the slime chases me, or roams randomly when not chasing T-T
fixed healthbar on passive entities not displaying correct value; added new animals (sheep, chickens, cows) - going to change their pathfinding and intelligence maybe..

OOOF where do i even start? :skull:. i've added these little tool icons inside the dotted rectangular outline of the cue that visually shows what tool you harvest them with. i've also overhauled my entire items system; previously i would use the name of each image tile PNG as a way to see if an item is valid or not; now i have a proper database. adding the items i needed to my "registry" took a LOOONGGG time, because i'm no longer handling their textures through normal textures, im using atlas textures where i trim down a tile region for the item texture so i had to manually type in the atlas region for each item, as well as the atlas texture it was in - very fun isnt it (no, it really isnt..). in addition, ive overhauled my harvestable system AGAIN, but for the better as i now have proper loot tables with each "stage".

added items on the ground you can pick up like swords, etc which will get added to your hotbar, and now if you try and use something whilst nothing is selected in the hotbar, the game wont crash anymore :DD
added a shield system for the player!!
revamped enemy system to be class inheritance based. now i can easily create new enemies without rescripting everything (attack ing enemies is unfortunately broken at the moment :sob:)

kind of back to square one when i first started out with tilemaps, but now with terrains for better efficiency and new godot knowlegde - hopefully it wont take me a long time to redo all the collisions as a result of the massive restructuring of my tilesets :P

a true OMG IT WORKS moment i finally made y sorting work on this stupid thing (previously it would look as if the player was above the tree's leaves), now the sprite properly renders to make it look normal so the player can be "behind the tree" or in front of the tree's trunk. thanks godot for making y sorting even more confusing in godot 4 :/, anyways i also show that cue i was talking about last moment :3
building on autotiling with terrains in godot woohoo (i wished i discovered this sooner :sob:) - hopefully speeds up tilemap making in the future...

improving my "harvestables" system (previously called resources, changed the name cause theres already something in godot called Resource :skull:). with the new asset pack, i have a berry tree split into 3 stages where you harvest the berries, then the main tree trunk, then the remaining stump!!
slightly reworking inventory ui design, started designing hotbar slots ui and experimenting with the slot textures and bg textures in godot which was a pain :skull_ios:.
locked in and revamped my entire tilemap layer system - built a small map for the first world and just discovered scatting in godot for my decoration 😭😭
refactored my resources, removed unnecessary root node2d and because i am a goofball, i did NOT inherit the scenes for most of my resources by mistake so i had to sort that out 💀

whoever is reviewing this im so sorry :sob:. i revamped my tilemap system and started designing my first world. i am using a new sprite pack as i didn't really like the style of the old one, and was hoping to combine this beautiful pack with some 2d godot shaders to make the tilemap look stunning. it took a while to set everything up as i had to import all the tiles (images), setup terrains for each 4 season's land, pathway, farmland, cliffs, etc (took a very long time to figure out because godot terrains is quite limited and not exactly intelligent). i had to setup collisions for any collidable objects in my tilemap which was also annoying, as i wanted my collisions to be pixel perfect, so i setup collisions using good ol' click to place vertices. next i had many issues with y sorting due to the amount of layers i had, and also had to deal with collisions issues because at one point i was able to push my animals like they weighed 0g and the player weighed 100 tonnes. my first world is where a player starts on an island (their house) but ventures into a forest (about to design), but i might rework my resource system first - feel free to msg me if u have any questions cuz this was a headache to deal with esp since godot crashed alot.
working on pixel art assets for my game - buff / debuff images which took a bit longer than i expected to make it look original - burning debuff is my favourite :D
finish flourish's game logo and itch.io banner (this took me a really long time to make :( )

spent AGES trying to create a bounce effect on the slime (by rewriting the entire enemy script from scratch to account for new structural changes in my game's node tree) and only just made progress on something that works.... except the slime is scared of me instead of it being the other way round T-T.

also added dynamic sprite frame fps changes, so the player animation actually looks realistic when they're sprinting. made attack animation's fps change depending on the attack speed (not really noticeable but it kind of looks smoother now).

adding basic controller support and attempted to make controller movement as fluid as possible, but kinda hard when you're testing with a controller that has horrendous stick drift T-T. probably leaving controller support here, but im looking into adding steam deck support for my game when its mostly done O.O (the game is still natively supported with keyboard and mouse)

expanded on + reworked passive entities, and built upon my pig's mechanics. now it can roam randomly, perform natural actions and respond accordingly to threat (run around in panic when attacked for example :P)
smoother camera movement :3

added more harvestables like cherry trees, trees with vines, and adding destroy sounds for the rocks (need to be fixed so they dont play more than once :P). reduced cue range as well, maybe ill put an axe icon with them..

added crops into my game and began writing the (painfully complex) system. with this demo here, i've got a (already planted) wheat crop thats growing and has different stages. depending on the stage you harvest it, it will give different loot based on the loot table (similar to minecraft where harvesting plants too early only gives the seeds). also had to rewrite / expand onto my itemdatabase system to include sprites which arent necessarily items. each stage of the crop can have different growth times, and may need watering as well - working on tools / some form of hotbar!! :P

fixed the scaling / spacing issues with the controls layout like i mentioned in the previous omg moment, it was a pretty simple fix which im very glad as ui in godot has given me enough headaches already T-T
y sorting works less goooooo
diagonal movement yay

added variants of rocks as harvestable resources, took a while due to variable renaming and structural changes (i named the variables as if the only resource were trees :skull:). hey - that's my friend in call with me lol! also, you can mine multiple resources at once (unintended feature? keeping it for now :P).
combat animations - yay! (except it kind of doesn't work and i need to clean my code 😭)
doing more tilemap structures - also added camera limits to stop the playing from seeing more than what is there to be seen 👀
changed a bit of the player movement parameters as it felt like you were walking on ice (its still weird, but much smoother) - also made it so you cant move whilst attacking (may change in future :P)
slowly getting there with the rewritten code of getting a slime to follow and attack the player properly (which you can see from the red flash :3) yet my knockback still isnt working :sob:

added in a couple more resources like tree stumps, bushes, logs, etc (and yes the sapling having no loot table therefore not dropping anything is intentional - save the trees guys!!). took a bit longer as im still scratching my head on what was wrong with the rock's y sorting and working out how positioning relative to the origin works in godot.

made more sprites myself - the actual player sprite was from itch.io, but i drew the cute minified versions of the player character for the sprint and dash icons :3 - with addition to stamina, and the heart sprites.

added player to globals to make my life easier in scripting; but more importantly, status effects in  the ui now! temporarily ive assigned the dash key to give me burning for 10 secs lol but any status effect the player has is shown in the ui, with the timer and amplification and progressbar!! (this took me so long to troubleshoot any errors i had :heavysob:)

fixed issue with player body getting "attached" to other collidable bodies (godot issue apparently). added more varieties of pigs, attempted to modify entity intelligence, also modified movement limits of the entities.

added dash and sprint icons. had issues with hboxcontains and restraints in godot ui for a while due to the inconsistent sizes with the hearts and sprint/dash textures, but i made it work :DD. sprint only shows when you're sprinting, dash only shows when you're on cooldown (it disappears to let you know you're ready to dash again!)
2D sprite collisions!!

added multiple variants of the tree resource that can also drop other things (you got a small peek at the loot table in beginning of video O.o). had some issues with godot copying the @export variables which i didnt realise after figuring out why all my tree variants looked like the same tree sprites...

Description:
So hello, I am the indie dev behind "Do you like trains?" , I have always been intrigued by trains... Mainly japanese ones, with those well crafted stations. Even though I love fast paced action games, slow and cozy ones were also my taste.
I then started crafting my game with those ideas in mind, and then SIKE, who said cozy games were fun, I went with a rapidly increasing difficulty game where your goal is to beat your highscore with ever more stations and fewer time to get to them, while you drown in despair as your money gets lower and lower, reaching the inevitable ... You went bankrupt..
I mainly wanted to focus on small details, water reflections, more smoke when you go faster, some particles when you slow down, an original menu, small animations here and there...
I was also really inspired by alice, who was also making a managing game, that's why i decided to try to be a bit original for once. 
It was a real challenge because I had never used Godot before, so I had to learn on the fly, while managing with my graduation.
I am forever thankful to hack club and all it's people who were always nice to me and motivated me to always push further.
To every readers, have a nice day!

juiceStretches.description: The train and wagon now follow each others and the train tracks can direct the train, there are also station that can give you passengers (will then bring you money

I fixed 3 main issues (lots of debugging today lol) :
- z sorting issues (with tracks being above certain stations
- an issue i had with clicking on the uis (turns out it was due to some control nodes which were overlapping)
- and the biggest issues : disseapering tracks (they were showing on screen but the dictionary lost them => it was due to the fact that i was handling the inputs wrong

I made all the upgrades : speed, coal level, nb of wagons and more money per people (taxes lol)
Also fixed a bug where a wagon kept going out of track
And lastly the number of people per wagon now updates on the top right part of the screen.

I worked on adding a shader effect, the distortion one, which also updates to the camera position and zoom.

Small change with the lokomotiv too, it has two lives
I adde music to the game, with some sound effects that i got from internet and modifies in audacity and the music was made with soundtrap (also coded all sound calls)
train movement and script control -1h30
You can now add wagons to your train and they will set up correctly and follow the previous wagon

I added a main menu, where you can leave the game, launch it, or change parameters such as optimisation or master volume
it is all connected now and i have the sounds option and set up already prepared for when i will add them
I added shaders to the speed screen to make it look better and i also improved the speed control, there was someting (the values between -1 and 1 were unnecessary) now it's etween 0 and 1

I added 2 types of trees and fixed an issue with the spawning system (it was taking a random number between 0 and 360, but with sin and cos i needed to switch to a number between -180 and 180 also added colision to trees
You could loose your wagon before but now, there is an explosion if you hit it (will add tamage to the locomotiv later on)
I have added new tracks and also they are now properly working (had a bug with rotating the train in certain conditions)

I worked on the first train anim from the side!
also learned some godot
Lots of new drawings, i was setting up the tilemaps

So there is no big change, I just control the vfx differently:
before i had a system that only worked when there was the effect in the scene (it just had a reference to it)
but the problem was that it wouldn't exactly work when multiple obj were using it (so it would work 1/2 of the time => in the last video yesterday you can also see the problem with the explosion vfx not working)
NOW I instnciate them based on my need and destroy them through script after some time for optimistation purpuses.
I added a coal system (it goes down faster if you are going faster) with some fire and smoke to the art

I added rotation to the weels based on speed, fixed a big issue (when the sprite was rotating the windows and weels weren't (now i inverse their position)
I added a shader to the glass, I also made the spawn of new station fully functionable and fixed a bug with it.
And fixed a weird bug where the number of people became negative (it was because of a dictionary check that wasn't properly working)

and lastly, the new wagons (2 of them) -1h
(thank u cosmin!)
I completly fixed the problem where the wagon went faster than the train, now if they loose the train/ wagon in front of them they stop (will cause accident later on)
I added functionnal explosion (when you get out of tracks you now get thrown away and there is an explosion), also fixed some issues when the lokomotiv dissapeared
I made some new ui (with a system that should scale correctly) and tried to add bloom effect to the text on the side

I added a system to create new tracks and delete one.
With a selector and all you can easily change your track now, also a tab system.
6h in a day :skull:

I made some new sprite for all the stations (coal, big, small...) and tweaked some of the values for the time and number of people.
I also improved the coal chimney and added fire to the coal station.

I firstly fixed a very weird bug : the lists for direction were shared for the tracks so some of them ddin't work properly (fixed with a class independant)
Made some improvement to the code that generates people (you can now pick them up and they will drop where they want to go at this point you will gain money, if you are late you will loose money).
The people choose where to go based on the station size and where they come from (the station)

I have mainly worked on the camera system and it now works well, with zooming (I also fixed some control nodes that where interfering with the drag system)
I also improved the speed buildup (now slower) and the system to changing sprite when the station levels up. lasly I worked on the system to spawn new station with for now placeholder art (it's why it looks weird, but the code is actually genius (I used imaginary number trigonometry))
I improve the speed building system (it slowly ramps up and started working on some smoke with the train also some art done
I tried many different ways to imprrove the water shader the problem was the offscreen part, it would give a weird effect, but I am ok with the new fixe I brought, also ...screw viewport...

I added new sprite for the track system (there was a scaling issue)
and also now there is a button to change it
-> updates with animation 2 of them
And lastly some bug fixes due to the train movement system
smoke art and also code implementation (the faster = more smoke) - 2h30
I improved the main menu a bit with some vsual, also shader thinggy XD, and mostly worked on a bug number at the top of the screen it represents the time before another station spaws!

Made new art for the background new tiles for grass (8x) and water and also added the water tiles in the new station spawning script => so that it doesn't spawn in water, I also fixed multiple issues with this script (i didn't see but it wasn't working at all)

I finalized the last (i think for now at least) way of getting out of track (going too fast with a sharp turn) => sparkles tell you that you are going to fast and when you screen is trembling, you should definitly slow down before a sharp turn)
I started with the godot project and made multiple sqpritesheets for the wagons too, also the train now has code to move (still barebone, but a good start with GDscript)
I have implemented some ui for the speed controls and also some new sprite for it
I mainly worked on the devloppement of new station with a construction animation (which went through 2 iteration) and lastly i fixed some collision issues and bugs with positions
I made a water shader with reflections and movement but it works weirdly so I might not keep it, not sure yet
I made the sprite way brighter listening to everyone's recommendation and now i am more familiar with libresprite!
I made some new art for the station, also added a timer to pick up the people and they are now different for all stations (nb people +timer) som ui animation too and the money ui...
small art with some wheels and also the uncomplete train speed controller - 1h

Description:
Dust and Dawn
A soot sprite brings life to a dusty world.
I had been wanting to make a game for a while, so when I found out about juice, it made sense to try. Plus, for the rewards at the end, it wasn't a lottery or anything. If you completed the 100 hours and had 30+ min of gameplay, you went. In the beginning, I toyed with the idea of doing it as a solo project, but in the end, I couldn't help but invite my friends to join.
Our Team:
Esther - Me! Coder, robotics kid, artist & violinist, crocheter, swimmer, pottery enthusiast etc. Needs constant alone time, and lives half of life wearing headphones & listening to music! Loves the outdoors
Layla - Twin #1. Graphic designer, animator & composer | Hates sports but rows competitively, 24/7 music listener, enjoyer of old books and orange juice in green mugs (specifically green mugs)
Luca - Twin #2. Co-coder, quest giver | violin virtuoso & composer; amateur photographer;  tea addict and acrobatic extraordinaire (will run off and join the circus when you aren’t looking)
Peter - Graphic designer, wannabe blacksmith (be careful with the battle hammer in the shed), track star (?), and has a trampoline in backyard (therefore, ideal to host meetings)
In the end, only Luca and I made it to 100 hours and went to Shanghai, but we all had a great time and became better friends.

The idea for our game came from a little Totoro stamp set I had. Right before I found out about juice, I had been stamping little soot sprites in my journal and drawing accessories on them using gel pens. The idea kind of went from there.
We initially wanted to make a story game, but quickly realized how hard that would be if we couldn't use language so we didn't put the story into the game. After juice we hope to pivot with the game into more of the story we wanted at the start. 

The biggest impact of Juice for me was firstly being committed to a big project and succeeding which was a huge boost in confidence to prove to myself that I am capable of doing really cool and difficult things. Secondly, but more importantly, Juice has helped me and my team become better friends. Shared commitment, collaboration, excitement, experience, and a reason to meet up outside of school all kind of stemmed out of Juice. As someone who just moved to a new school and has trouble making friends, this means a lot to me. 

I want to say thank you to my team, who put in countless hours to help make Dust and Dawn a reality. I also want to say thank you to my parents. You supported this project and were always an encouragement when I felt overwhelmed by all the things I was juggling. Lastly, thank you to the Juice team and community. This challenge would not have existed without you, and I look forward to meeting some of you in Shanghai!

Best Regards,
Esther

juiceStretches.description: Smog and new plants!

Fixed some merge issues. Edited item scripts so they could not be multi collected by removing them from the scene instead of just hiding them. (used queue_free()). Made minor changes to the map to make jumps easier, and added more mushrooms
Finally was able to merge animation branch with master!!!! It took me 3+ tries, but now it works!
Made lantern that follows character around
Tried to change the size of the array responsible for inventory. Failed, of course. Tomorrow though, I might succeed.
First Platform!
items can now be removed from the inventory
Inventory works!!!! Multiple items too!
Backpack Quest fully completed! Just need to make it harder...
new quest: backpack quest. Also merged some stuff.

-key required to switch to next level from lantern lighting level to cave level
- if you go back to lantern scene after going to the caves, the lanterns stay lit and the light collectables do not respawn as long as you have the key.
- The item sprites are now accurate size (12 x 12 instead of 1200 x 1200)
- merged teammates code and it broke everything :(
- spent ages finagling git and godot till everything works (edit, not everything works: the jumpy mushrooms no longer jumpy)
Inventory now changes size depending on whether or not you have a backpack. Has a size of 3 w/out, size of 12 with. Need to fix bug that causes it to reset if you change scenes.
Started to implement new tileset for decorations/plants

New sign post to show you how to open your inventory. Camera switches so it is zoomed in on sign. That was a lot of work.
Redid lv 2 map, and added lantern quest to it. fixed most of remaining merge bugs that effected lantern quest. Sound is implemented.
Inventory slots now clear when their value is 0
tried to help teammate fix animation bugs - mostly succeeded. Tried to merge animation branch with main branch -- failed badly.

Well, trying to implement a level switching thing, where when you exit the left side of one level, you enter in on the right for the other level, but global variables are confusing, so it doesn't work YET - maybe tomorrow, I'm tired

Made a door that only appears in the caves if you have completed the quest -> the golem now gives you a glowing crystal if you give it 10 normal crystals. If the player has a glow crystal, the door will appear.
also edited the crystal sprite to be glowy
Main Menu! This took too long b/c I had to restart after finishing it the first time due to a bug that had popped up elsewhere

Added another lantern with different texture. Uses the same script as the first, so there was a little finagling to make that work code wise. Tileset edits: More light collectables, new mountain/cave. Will add more mountains and taller ones in future. Had my sister playtest and give feedback.
Started working on making a bat character that knocks into the character to knock them off the platforms - currently a godot icon. Also, the knockback does not work yet.  :(
Fixed mass bug attack, changed texture of tiles. The game does not crash, but inventory still does not work :( At least it doesn't crash though!
Inventory shows items! also, items are sized to fit in inventory slots

Final Level Completed!!!
Merged teammate's quest giver/npc
finalized tilemap
tested all parkour to make sure it's possible but also hard
placed water droplets and plants that need to be watered.
scene switching! If you leave from right side, you enter the next scene from the left, like it's all strung together. Not the most optimal way to do it, but it works!
Lantern now (almost) can correctly light or not light based on whether or not there is sufficient light in the inventory. Just need to make inventory slots clear if their item count reaches 0
Lantern lights regardless of whether or not there is sufficient light to light it :( Will probably fix tmrw. I'm tired
Semi working level switch - currently triggered with a keyboard press, later will be by colliding with a side border

Merging many many branches. (most of which were my partner's) Bouncy mushrooms, sound effects, bug fixes, wall climbing (which did not work...) Will fix merge issues tomorrow b/c it's late. Thankfully very few, but still some.
Character (Soot Sprite) now moves around the screen. Have not yet implemented gravity though.
Combined multiple sprite animation sheets for other coder, updated itch.io website
Made a new mountain! Still need to add light collectables and test out the jumps, but so far it's pretty good!

Updated the quest screens to be more intuitive and understandable. Added a second lantern to the lantern quest, added another light collectable. Made it so the walking sound only plays if you are on the floor, not jumping. Updated the itch.io with new bug fixes

made it so you can only move scenes if you have that scenes completion item (backpack, cave key, glow crystal)
Made it so you spawn on the correct side depending on which scene you just came from (using the inventory temporarily b/c it for whatever reason does not reload when you switch scenes)
Working parallaxing! Thanks Olive for the help!
Finalized the second level and made it so you can only go to it after you have finished the previous one.

Organized scene slightly (nodes were children of nodes they shouldn't have been children of)
Made it so the crystals don't respawn if you come back into the scene with a glow crystal in your inventory.
Camera follows player and I implemented tilemaps!
First quest! Need to make it languageless, but YAY!

Drew a door. Put the door in a new level (hopefully the last!). made it so that when you press space in it's area, it switches the scene to the caves. This code is controlled by the scene's master script. The space popup when you are in it's area is controlled by it's own script -> making it repeatable so each scene it's used in doesn't have to have a new door script.
Sprite now only jumps when on the ground, except for double jumps, which have less strength

Full level 2 finished. All jumps can be made without double jump b/c we are removing it. There are now three lanterns to light, and the npc script reflects that - you cannot finish the level without lighting all three. Made some edits to the quest screen to *try* and make it more intuitive.

Fixed some uncaught merge errors:
Soot Sprite no longer slides on celings
Mushrooms bounce again
Bats send you back to start again.
Inventory popup - without actual inventory, and camera changes position so you can see the whole inventory page.
I can now change the number of slots in the inventory! However there is a new bug b/c I probably messed something up while I was experimenting... a problem for tmrw

I made it so that when you were in the door's area and pressed space, the scene changed to the next level (yet to be fully developed). All done through the main scene script instead of the door script because the door is a linked scene that is in other scenes so couldn't always teleport to one level. This took such a ridiculously long amount of time... because I couldn't do it manually. This was because the node was not in the scene unless a specific circumstance was achieved (collecting a glow crystal). Therefore, all the setup and signal connection had to be done through a script. At least, I tried to do a signal connection for goodness knows how long, but eventually had to go with a variable because it didn't seem to want to work :(
Tried to implement parallax scrolling, to no avail. It's just stuck on the screen...
Project up on itch.io! Also fixed pixel sizing

Plant node that you can water and will grow through different stages.
Finished tilemap base for caves under mountain.
Added gravity, but now, the left arrow key causes the soot sprite to jump to the left hand side of the screen, and I can't figure out WHY!?!
Added two new items and began adding a new quest.
Added connection to next scene from 2nd scene. Made it so you need a key (from completing the lantern quest) to access it. Now teleports you to the caves!

Started outlining what I wanted the level to look like
Switched the tileset which was complicated because the origional tileset was scaled up whereas the new one was actual size so it kept not assigning the tilesizes well, and being way out of porportion (tiny!) I then had to basically redraw the tilemap b/c the tiles didn't line up with what it was repacing (eg: the top tile in the origional was a corner tile in the new one)

knockback works! The texture of the bat (currently a godot logo) will be changed later. It currently dashes at the player, and if it hits, it will push it around. When it has dashed to the end of it's area, it teleports back to it's start and dashes again.
omg it DOES NOT WORK! I have spent soo long trying to figure out bug after bug! Maybe I should sleep and look at it in the morning :(

Made a few more tweaks to the inventory. Made a massive revamp to the world map: extended the size of each map by 2x, built out that side w/ a cave system, made the jumps harder on the existing side of the map. Tweaked camera settings.
Jumping and gravity now (mostly) work! Just need to add code to make sure the soot sprite can't jump on air
Tried to merge teammate's work (new parallax background) but failed so redid it :( Also updated itch.io

Description: When I first heard of Juice i tought "OMG my dream is gonna come true" (travelling to China), but as the time went, I realised, that the first month is gone, and now I have to push myself and put away things a bit and only focus to this. Compared to the first idea of the game, it became more complex and a bit different one. Making this game was a great chance to try and learn new things.

juiceStretches.description: I worked on the slime enemy to look more topdown view

I started thinking on a landing kind of art (featuring the main playable characters and some enemies) for the itch.io page as it's a bit blank right now. I also tried to do something with the characters' movement as it just looked so ugly but it somehow came out that I made a dancing stickman.

I continued making the 8 angle design for the priestess character in the game. Now she has all the 8 angles players can navigate her to, also it looks like she is turning around if you switch the images fast (as shown on the video)
I tried Godot once again, but moved onto real work. I made the tileset for the floating island's side- I made more of it so it can alternate. I also continued working on the trees.
I corrected the shading of the flying rocks (the video has the before pictures too)
I finalized the tank's attack swish, but I still need to correct some things on it
I corrected some mistakes on the logo, and animated the grass texture and some flowers
I changed the color of the trees as they didn't fit the game and made them more top down view. I also made a cloud for the background, and gave another chance to shaders in Godot
I started making the priestess's walk animation, so now she can walk!!!
I made some walk animations for the rouge, but it was a bit hard because of the complex design of the character
I continued my studies on shaders, both animation shaders and color changing ones. I also did some research how to make them, and tried to make them fit the game.

I made a chest, from both front and side view, continued the eye enemy's and the seaworm's animation, made a groundslam for the tank character, and started the attack aniamtion of the tank, also a ghost for fallen characters, and a button for the tutorial stage (E).
I made the 8 angle turning animation of one of the enemies in the game
I made a door for the second part of the tutorial and animated it in a front and a side view
I finalized the attack animation of the tank character. I made two ship designs for the game's story and made the only face icon for the rouge and the priestess

The ground tileset is still not working so I had to come up with something and I did some research on tilesets (in the video attachment I'm only showing the latest solution). I also finished the resume button. Moreover I strated thinking on how we can solve the bugs and problematic parts of the game which came up while testing it under Linux.
I made a dirt tileset and some tees
I made an animation for the seaworm enemy
I did some refinements on the orbs
I continued working on the music and tried to come up with a melody that can be played during a fight scene but all of them turned out to be a bit too soft

I design the graphics of our game, now I started the background. I made multiple pieces, so we can decide which angle fits the best to the game. Also, I made two chests, one opened and one closed. Anyways our project's artstyle follows pixel artstyle, so I made both the backgrounds and the chests. In the video I'm showing the done backgrounds and chests in photoshop before exporting them to import them in the game (I'm using photoshop to draw)
I worked on the door
As the settings and the resume buttons were imported to the game I noticed that they look horrible next to each other as the settings button look so big
I removed the coind from the chests, changed the attack to be 24 frames, made orbs and a soul icon for a characters ability, and started designing the logo
I made a white and a black overlay layer to the resume and the settings button. I also made some bushes

I made the opened version of the chests, continued the design of the ghost of fallen characters and finalized it, and redesigned the rouge character(and made the 8 angle spritesheet). Also I continued the attack spritesheet of the tank.

I made some refinements on the ground tileset and resized the petals for the flowers' wind animation. I also did some changes on the attack animation to make it look smoother. Also I started working on the settings menu (tried to figure out how it would look good), and ended up using the logos colours and styles. I also tested the itch.io linux link to our game and looked for mistakes. Moreover I started the resume button too (now it's only half-done T-T)

Today I designed a layout of the map for the first level of the game. Also, I made a new enemy, which is like a octopus kind of monster with a glowing orb in the middle of it, and it attacks with the orb. Furthermore, I started animating the enemies I designed the previous week (that's why I'm showing them multiple times, so you can see the difference).
I made a new enemy, a mandrake, which will be both a trap and an enemy

I made the slime a bit taller and finished the worm's walk animation and made an attack animation for it too (when it comes out of the ground) and made the grey and the pink flowers bigger. I also made a pillar with on orb on top which will break slowly when getting hit by the characters.
I continued working on the door and also practiced the melodies I wrote and choosed the ones that fit the game the most. I also made a mud thing for the worm enemy.
I made a wall tileset kind of thing based on another one made by my teammates
I made some refinements on the background of the portal gate. I also made a spawn animation for the slime enemy

I started the butterfly which the players will have to follow in the tutorial. It was a bit hard as we already have similar seelies. Also I was thinking how we could make a background that would fit the game's aesthetic and would take much attention from the actual "playfield", so I made new clouds similar to the one I made earlier.
I animated the flying training dummies and made some flowers for the puzzles. I also made a slime with a bouncing animation.

I continued working on the flowers and made some stones and sticks so the game area won't be that boring. I tried to import them to the game but somehow it just didn't worked and the flowers were too big compared to the others, so I guess I will have to make shaders for them. I also tried to connect my vsc editor to github so it would be easier for both me and my teammates to keep an eye on the work we are doing. (I know it's not a game development related thing but I think it's still impotant to have). Moreover I made a chibi face for the rouge and the priestess as there will be a small animation between the levels in a chibi like animation style. Also I had some trouble with the stones and the stick imported to the game as they had too much detail, so I had to put a pixelating mask on them. I also started the flying magical rocks players will have to pass through by solving puzzles or defeating enemies. Also I made a white and black overlay for the back to menu button
I made a few buttons for the tutorial stage. Now it's only the controls (W, A, S, D) and the character switches. (1, 2, 3)
I made a background to the logo, animated the orbs and made an explosion for them.

Today I started drawing some simple icons. As I show on the video I drew both a coffin and a skull to simbolize the dead player (it turned out that we are going to use the skull for now), and just like yesterday, I tried different angles to figure out which one fits the best. Also, I started the health bar of the player, and I did two color combinations for it. In fact, I did two buttons, one for replaying (if the player dies) and one for returning to main menu.
I changed the spikes to be more sharp and the gradient at the bottom of the tiles so the shadow the walls drop will be more visible
I corrected the spots on the mushroom's hat and finished working on the slime's 8 direction animation
I continued working on the priestess's walk animation and finished it
I corrected some mistakes in the attack sprite, and created lightning sprite for a attack animation
I made a bigger boreder to the logo, and made some small changes on the attack animation too
I continued working on the ground tileset to fit the grass tileset and tried to import it to Godot to see how it fits the game
I made some more angles for the mushroom enemy and started them for the slime one.

I redraw the flowers as the had too much detail.  I made a bigger rock, that will block the path of players and will fall apart when the guiding butterfly approaches it. This was a harder task as the game has a topdown view, so I had to make the rocks in the same view (I also made more so they can alternate). I made charms for the characters' abilities, but at first I wasn't sure how to make them obvious so players will know which ability's power it increases, so I needed to think about it as the charms are relatively small so the pictures on them can't be that big (all my tryings looked like either bugs or trees T-T). Moreover I made a loading icon which will appear between the scenes loading after each other. I also made a dirt patch to go with the grass.
I made a stone tileset for the ground both with traps (spike and fire) and without them.
I made an animation for the explosion, and made icons to the GUI of the game (damage, max damage, heal, walking speed)

I made a back to menu button in the style of the previous buttons, so now the pause menu is ready, and all the buttons are done for it. Also, I experimented a bit with the butterfly thing as it wasn't looking good with the grass, so in first round I was thinking of making a fog like thing, but ended up with a flower like particle which moves with the butterfly. Moreover I made more flowers so the gaming area will be more interesting.

I only worked on graphics before using photoshop, but I decided to use Godot for shaders, so I went ahead and gave it a try and downloaded Godot, but I didn't liked the platform so I decided to continue using photoshop instead.
I continued the tentacle enemy's 8 angle animation, so now he can move!!
I did the shading on the flying rocks and corrected some things on the fire trap tileset
I made a skip button for the tutorial.
I started writing the sheet music for the game (it sounds a bit like a minuet but it didn't meant to)
I made a new flower and some petals and a leaf for the wind animation
I made small rocks, they are gonna form the bridge players will be able to cross to the next flying platforms (also the reason I made more is that they can alternate).

I started thinking on the puzzles and made some sketches. I also made a flying dummy with two designs. I did the walk animations a while ago but I started to redo them as they looked kinda weird without the frames that make the transitions smooth.
I worked on the stone bridge and made them to a tileset kind of thing so that it will be easier to alternate them.

I made some clouds based on the ones that are already in the tutorial, but these are gonna go for the nightmare sequence of the tutorial (right now it only exists in our head so there's no code for it yet)
I made a teleport gate that will transfer players between levels.
I made a dash icon for a charm and refined the spike tileset
I think there's something wrong with the video on the previous stretch so I'm uploading it again (I mean I can't watch it so yeah)

Today I designed a new playable character, a priestess. I started drawing the angles instead of the animation this time. Also, I was thinking of a healing field for the characters, so I only draw the idea of it for now.
I made an angry mushroom and a sandworm enemy (they are gonna be weaker enemies so they'll be easier to defeat)

I retried Godot once again, and I managed to make a tree swing!!! It looks a bit weird but it's my first try, and it might not be a big thing for those who can use Godot, but I still like it and it makes me happy that I could make something new.

I continued making the boost charms, priestess's attack animation (she lifts her staff), the tentacle thing's attack animation (I'm new to animating so it looks bad rn T-T), and the enemy full of eyes has attack animation too (I forgot to record that T-T), also I made a ghost for fallen characters. Moreover I stared to animate the seaworm enemy (which I also forgot to record)
I made a reset button
I corrected the priestess's walk animation and added some leaf things to the trees
I continued working on the itch.io landing art, and uploaded it, but it still needs some finishing touches.
I made the designs of the charms players can get from specials chests. Also they'll give some specieal powers/boosts, as shown on the small shoe icon

Today I started designing some of the enemies to our game. One is the "eye" monster, who is basically just a bunch of eyes, and attacks with his eyes. The next one is a seaworm kind of thing, but it doesn't have any kind of special power yet. Last but not least, a humanoid cthulhu.
I continued working on the music of the game and came up with some chord chains that would fit for a cozy exploring gameplay and a fight scene.
I made one more cloud, and made some nightmare trees (I couldn't decide which kind of pixel filter to use so I made more)

Description:
Selenia
As an astronaut-cat who crash landed their spaceship on an alien planet, complete minigames and navigate an unfamilar world to rebuild your spaceship and go home.

I am still amazed by how Selenia--and so many other games--have taken shape over the past two months. With Selenia, I wanted to create a game that would fit the atmosphere of the in-person cafe. Relaxing, exploration-based, and languageless. I had so much fun shipping all the game features, and the languageless requirement forced me to be creative with conveying information to the player.

A fun fact about Selenia is that it can be played with one hand -- leaving the other hand free to enjoy some freshly squeezed juice :)

juiceStretches.description: designed and implemented basic sign sprites to distinguish portals
first juice! established basic character/npc/map functionality using existing asset pack (will change drastically in the future)

island 4 maze done, and each component seems to work as intended. player might get lost here (i certainly did while playtesting) but that's partially the intention. to finish up this part of the quest, plan to implement questbar + design island 5, which is the hardest of the 3 mazes to navigate

It's been quite the journey. Playtested the entire game, fixed bugs, pre-loaded everything in the beginning to improve latency, added portal transitions for continuity. full game is now available on itch & submitted v1, only thing left is get hours reviewed & ship to steam :D

yet another generational juice session (at the cost of sleep schedule). new itch game demo available @ https://btng.itch.io/seleniav1. Main contributions:
- finished miner minigame (random ore generation, gui improvements, shaders, cooldown)
- added NPC trader that can be customizable to exchange one resource for another
- finished second quest mechanic and patched various visual inventory glitches
- published draft to itch and did a preliminary gametest. right now if I speedrun all current gameplay it takes ~5 min. Thank you for listening to my TED talk.
full map & portals working... todo: signs for each of the portals showing where it goes, and the actual island design itself

not sure how to show, but music soundtrack has been implemented thanks to suno. other changes include adding a portal activation animation and allowing the NPC trader to wander every now and then. next steps would be implementing main menu of sorts and fixing a weird hitbox glitch that's happening with the mining game & with trader npc (if you know how to fix, please lmk!) which would be enough for a new itch release

much longer than intended, but outro scene finally works, and spaceship component of spawn island also works (so 98% of the game is comlpete). i think i want to revamp the intro scene now that the outro scene is done, will be playtesting the full game later today
back to juicing, designed mining minigame gui and sprites for ores (surprisingly time consuming). shoutout godot debugger, next task is getting the mining game mechanics working

designed island6 and npc/exploration/sprite part of solar panel quest, tilemap building for this level took a lot longer than I expected. v1 quest done soon, but still have to implement the questbar and minigame aspect of the solar panel quest and the spaceship so the cat can actually go home

island 1&2 redesign to encourage more exploration and drive player engagement

next features will be main menu, opening cutscene (maybe?), and allowing blacksmith npc to roam
designed portal sprite & implemented on spawn island (still a minor visual resource bug to be sorted out)

tornado warning came on for like 30 min during this juice session, had to go find shelter. 

but I did finish island 3 map design and mechanics with the "maze-like" puzzle where you have to explore the map for islandfruits and enginescrap and find the NPC to trade to unlock the next island (coming soon in the next juice stretch). also since both island3 and island4 are activated by blueportalkeys the player can choose which one they want to explore first. already explored scrap/fruits don't show up when you load back in to prevent reward hacking of sorts
UI/global variables for solarpanel minigame done (up to no good), TODO functionality

implemented solar panel quest on questbar/alien npc, spent time playtesting/bugfixing on dev mode, everything up to the last minigame works. still need spaceship and last minigame but after that will be ready to ship

All functional gameplay is now languageless! 
In other words, this juice session I:
- updated Player/NPC sprites to replace placeholders
- added functional "trade" graphic schema for npc trader, and quest "icon" schema for npc alien
- playtested a bunch more to make sure the game was running as intended
- shipped new version of game to itch : https://btng.itch.io/seleniav1. check it out & lmk how long it takes you to get through the game!

next up: add a main menu gui, make the trader npc on island 1 wander around (so its harder to find), and create the basic map layout for island 2 (unbuilt as of now)

(also considering replacing main character sprite from astronaut to cat again bc it looks cooler... thoughts?)

we're back, 12 hours behind schedule but generational juice session incoming...

implemented core progress bar functionality that shows progress on current quest (and components of said quest) to aid players while adhering to languageless theme. next step is to implement a similar feature with the NPC alien and build main quest on island 2. feeling optimistic that I can finish w/ spring break coming up

when i start juicing it's very hard to stop... added QoL improvements for key animations, revamped first island map, implemented hitboxes and created the mvp with working mechanics for the mining minigame. next up (for mining) would be to add shaders, random map generation, and an NPC to convert metal ore into metal scrap

finished building fuel tank minigame (& integrated with the whole rest of the game), which finishes work for island 2. getting a lot closer to the 30 minute gameplay mark. new itch release @ https://btng.itch.io/selenia (now v2). next up is building "maze-like" exploration puzzles for each of the islands and building out the engine parts quest up next. planning to go from 60h -> 100 over spring break :)

after much debugging & code tracing, excited to announce that the first part of selenia is finally working w/ full adherence to the languageless theme (minus NPC trader).

Added Dev Mode for game speedrunning (don't watch video if you don't want spoilers)
Added quest bar w/ custom gradient to show current progress/hints towards next steps
Added icon-based quest prompts on cow NPC instead of text
Fixed Portal/Visibility bugs that ran deeper than I expected
next step is to fix trader npc, build out main island & next quest to further drive player engagement (w/ more minigames)

also important todo items in the near future: replacing placeholder sprites, creating game theme music, and adding sfx

spent today reworking the first part of the game and building out the main island. added 2 npcs on island 2 + scavenger hunt mechanic, created fuel tank sprites and fuel tank quest, added lights to NPCs so you can find them easier, and re-generated music to be more synth/lounge like rather than pure piano. almost 2/3 of the way

designed title screen, reverted character sprite to cat (seems more fun), fixed mining bug where the raycast2d would land on something rendered on the main island and prevent cat from mining ore (solution: adjusting collision layers & masks)
think i'm finally ready to build out the main island gameplay
lots of progress :D fixed dupe glitch, added basic ground/water tilemap, added basic shaders based on day/night cycle, remade spawn island

quick juice session before itinerary call, designed island5 & made it functional. trying to implement something new with canvasmodulate to make the maze harder to navigate per island, and still have to add the quest into the system
basic inventory mechanic working :O thought i broke everything but realized it was because i renamed a folder and didn't update the dependencies

revamped starting screen and made it so you cna go from end screen back to starting screen to play again. I believe I have 1-2 hr of juice remaining so I'll likely spend it playtesting, refactoring dependencies, and shipping to itch.
also added zoom functionality to make the maze parts easier.

TODO: fix a couple rendering bugs to make game run smoother, & potentially add signs to questbar/ui to indicate which island the player is currently on
2nd juice session, npc dialogue working! (quest/inventory mechanic tbd)
first quest working (although resource dupe possible) + crude version of game published to itch.io

the most atrocious code i've written in a while, but the solar panel minigame is finally functional instead of just a ui element :) , unfortunately this minigame will make you brain work to bring the astronaut cat home...

will probably spend tomorrow finishing up the rest of juice with QoL changes (e.g. arrows indicating distance to unlocked portals, cutscenes?), playtesting, and implementing the spaceship building process to beat the game. so if all goes well tomorrow i will both have my 100h + full game + v1 itch upload challenge complete

scene transition works (barebones, and took way too long, but it works!), and allows for nonlinear scene transitions too. in a more polished draft there'll probably be a transition animation instead of the abrupt skip

fully implemented island maze quest with questbar, responsiveness with rest of game, and fixing various teleporting/shader bugs. spent a large amount of time playtesting (i think it's above 30min now) and fixing bugs which is hard to show in a video. toned down the difficulty of island 5 bc I got very lost, considering adding a light "trail" to where the player has been already (not sure how to implement, assuming path2d?). also implemented mute functionality at the game starting screen so the user can choose whether to play with sound or not

Description:
Ossatura
Ossatura is a Rhythm Game RPG made by a small team of high schoolers from Southern California. 
We started making Ossatura with inspiration from indie RPGs such as Undertale, Deltarune, Omori and Oneshot, and combined that influence with our collective love of music!
In our game, you play as a skeleton navigating the afterlife after a tragic accident to find his former band members and friends.
However, to find them, you must fight in music-inspired battles with a variety of enemies, ranging from a duck with a violin to a crocodile with a harp!
Making our game was an incredible adventure, and while very stressful at times, was 100% worth the effort, both in terms of how our game turned out and the memories we made together making it.
It's incredible how two months can change a person, and we all feel like we've truely accomplished something incredible working together.
We hope players enjoy our original, made in-house soundtrack, our fun, rhythm-based battle system, and our (still under development) world and story.

juiceStretches.description:
-New Shield Sprite
-Improved Shield animation to move forward for blocking notes
-Increased particles for Healing sprite
-Implemented victory yippie noise
-TOOK SO LONG TO IMPLEMENT PARTICLES. I spent 2HRS fixing a bug where the confetti didn't spawn in and the solution was because the spawner WAS OFF THE CAMEARAAAA AAAAAAA. Anyways it works.
New sprites for notes, changed icon to purple for readibility. Added shake animation to text when >15. Fixed combo system, made it consistently hide and set to 0 on misses.
Overworld movement! and tilemap

Fixed a bug where the dice roll button would be transparent after initiating the animation since it was tied to the button. I added another sprite2d ontop of the button and manually copied the texture timings so it would match with the sound effects on the animationplayer. Spent a long time trying to make the button run icon not display when the animation played but ultimately couldn't, so I'll fix it later while I work on more important things for the game.

-Added new enemy: goat
-Added new player attack prep and attack animation
-took a bit to transcribe a melody track, meaning manually going through a song in audacity and noting where notes played in miliseconds for use in the attacks. Handed it off to my teammate for him to do the pathing, should have the melody for next juice season

-implemented new heathbars and added flashing effects
-reworked healthbar animations using tweens instead of very jank hp * Delta code
-sampled and editted marching band song from jackson state's sticky cover as a perfect attack lol
-assigned new sound effect per level of attack dealt
-sampled a jazzy track from homestuck to be used as a transition between overworld and combat in the next build

FINALLY GOT COMBO COUNTER TO WORK! Uses a series of signals to get the note value from the target node and raises the combo if the note value is not a miss. Three stages of wave for text, 0-5, 6-10, and 10-inf. At 10-inf an animated sprite used as a explosion is used. Also coded the interaction key using raytraces and interact groups. it will be the ground work for save points and interactions in the game.

I lied oops, long session, sorry oopa or rrr :<:
-Made buttons fancy using themes, playtested the game with several people at school to gather their feedback on the button styles and gameplay, still not satisfied just yet
-minor bug fixes with healing animation playing during the attack
-I learned and implemented shaders into the game, starting with particles effects, I eventually plan on creating a cool scrolling effect for the focused buttons in the game. It took me a while to figure out shader code, its kinda complicated for my not so great programmer brain (my teammate Mathew usually does the backend coding) I started with the heal sprite where I figured out I needed to convert all the textures for the particles into grayscale for them to be made dissolvable. Now all the particles in the game use shaders to have a cool dissolve effect instead of just fading out of existance. Took me a while to figure out the grayscaling and I had to figure out my teammates work for generating the particles since it created the particle effects via code instead of the inspector node but after some thinking I made it work by making preset shader files and gradients for each individual particle color and type.

-Enemy healthbar changed to different color
-Enemy now has hurt animation
-Healthbars now have animation when they go down
-made the entire game completely playable without mouse inputs
-made attack animation which is also the same as enemy hurt. Used audio in animationplayer.
-Created fade transitions for main menu, exit and entering overworld
-Created title animation for too long, duplicated sprite to add a background shadow, used animationplayer to move it up and down and used curves to make it have a sense of gravity. -Used the tombstone and skeleton sprite as a separate sprite to overlay ontop of the title screen to make a 3D-ish effect
-Suffered with merging into main :sob:
-fixed fps difference between player and witch

-Created a run away animation and fade out for combat
-Created post combat system, now it doesn't just kill the enemy after each encounter, if you run or don't run.
-Added a enemy "cool down" so you are given 2 seconds to run away from the enemy and used modulate to darken the enemy and show this
-Suffered with github merging into main :sob:
Animated moving enemies, tweaked particles for hits, added variable hurt animation and sound.

-Added zoom effect when correctly hitting notes
-Added scaling up effect when successfully hitting notes
-took SOOOOOO LONG to make battle transition. I was trying to go for something out of deltarune, where the overworld enemies and player moves into place into a battle sequence and the battle background items fade in, however, because the battle sequence in the game is made in a separate scene, I couldn't just move the sprites to the battle positions when they collided, I had to calculate the position of the enemy relative to the player, then pass the coordinates to the combat scene where it would start the player and enemy at the overworld scale and position, then move the enemy and player into place. I had to figure out how to export the keyframe from the animationplayer so I could change the starting position of the transition using variables which was kinda hard to do understand. I think it turned out pretty ok.

tl;dr: Jank code made making cool transitions really hard

-Implemented lake backgrounds for lake enemies
-added a small input lock delay after finishing an rhythm attack to prevent accidental presses

-Implemented attack sprites for enemy attacks

-FINISHED THE TUTORIAL AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA. I had to figure out how to pause the notes on command but still allow button inputs and show the interface icons through the icon add-on WHICH ALSO DIDN'T WORK AND I HAD TO FIX IT MYSELF. After figuring out how to pause the rhythm game, attack bar, background music, and melody music I ran into issues with timing the pause in the rhythm game, it would vary by tenths of a second but was enough to throw off the pause. I fixed that by making it send a signal when the note got to the perfect zone, Then I had problems actually making the player hit the note after the prompt since the note kill was attached to the same node as the one I had to pause to hit the note which I fixed with a microdelay after the attack is unpaused kinda scuffed but oh well. THEN THE BACKEND FOR THE RHYTHM ATTACK GOT REWORKED and I had to MANUALLY COPY THE CHANGES AND FIGURE OUT HOW THE NEW SYSTEM WORKED, then I ran into a very strange issue where the the attack never ended on the tutorial scene but ended on the combat scene which took me so many hours to figure out because the code was the EXACT SAME and after many hours I figured out THE STUPID SIGNAL WAS OUTPUTTING TO COMBAT_MAIN INSTEAD OF THE TUTORIAL AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA. Anyways tutorial works :3

Description:
Prism Maze! A Maze and Platformer in one, played in both 2D and 3D! A mashup game of a mashup of games. I based this game from a little project I made back then for Sprig. You play through a set of levels, from mazes to platformers, unique every gameplay. And I suggest not dying, or else you'll start back at zero (And maybe don't quit too). You play as Prio (I call them a prism-like), the plot is thin here but they we're supposed to be an "agent" that aims to beat the levels it gets thrown with and basically train as part of a "machine learning model".

I was stumped on what to make that adds a twist on top of the somewhat okay formula. And in one way or another I decided to go 3D, despite me not knowing how to even use Godot for 2D yet. And in a bit I was able to nail the 2D game to something I would say is awesome enough. And then it hit me that I had to do the daunting 3D game in one way or another. A good ponder and UI glow-up later, I was able to start making the 3D Levels.

A few levels later, we got a snappy 2D game with generated mazes, interactive mazes and swift platform levels, and a vast 3D game ranging from petite levels to broad towers. I plan to add a few more touches but this is the game I made and I hope many people can enjoy it!

juiceStretches.description: On-demand level spawns! Should be more performant and make infinite levels easier (Also added level culling as seen in the video, also closing the doors to older levels!). Also fixed the wall jump bug (infinite jump from bouncing off the same wall), and wall jump height, should be consistent with normal jump now. New 2 levels too I guess.

Added a tutorial level for the 3D Game! With a screen overlay for guiding controls. Some minor changes like 2D flags healing you and a wider hitbox, and a certain 2D level difficulty balancing.

Created a new parallax background (Had a few issues at first, but it works now!) Also fixed some minor stuff on the code side of things. (Level randomization code and other things). Also improved character collision to account for the animation and to be easier to platform with.

(Also hid the flag for the first second of the level to avoid seeing it when the player teleports to 0, 0 on start of each level)

- Changed 2D Killzones into boxes that kill you when you exit (Should mitigate bypassing death in some cases)

Added conveyors! (Never too late to add blocks i guess)

No mouse capture for the 3D game when started from the main menu though. Also minor tweaks to the main menu to accommodate the new buttons and added padding to each buttons.

2 new 3D Levels! Seen as the first 2 levels in the video after the starting level.

And the following:

- Fixed virtual controller (Handle the Xogot-exclusive Input function to "work" with Godot by handling undefined functions)
