Description:
Spadooshka
This is a fast paced 1v1 shooter where players can find items in loot boxes around the map that can be utilized as weapons, or give buffs to players. These items include speed boosts, grenades, health burgers, and more! 
At the time of writing this, the game is still deep in development. In fact, I'm currently inside our game office (my older brother's old bedroom) with the team working late at night. Our game doesn't look like much right now, with little graphics and no sound effects, but that will absolutely change.
The idea for this game literally came on the day of the Juice kickoff, which was inconveniently held at the time of our first Science Olympiad invitational. During the free time we had in between the competition, we struggled to find a game concept that we all felt happy with before the deadline arrived. Eventually, we managed to submit a game idea, but it didn't really resonate with all of us. On the drive back home, one of us discussed an idea she had for a game that worked for everyone. I was at first reluctant since I had no experience in 3D and multiplayer, and thought it'd be too difficult to get into, but we were still passionate and confident in our idea.
Our game doesn't have a story (it was too difficult to think of one), but it does have a core: pure and utter chaos. Our game's philosophy is to keep players constantly moving on their feet and be prepared for anything. With smooth yet quick movement, players must master the game's controls while utilizing all the random items they've collected to defeat the other player. It's an exhilarating mix between popular modern shooting games and 3D platformers.

Description:
It's the year 2027, AI has finally matched human intelligence. After 2 years of faithful employment at Tetsu Incorporated, Coby-SP is finally thrown away and considered, “obsolete.” But Coby also happens to be the first of his kind: persistent. Now he must escape the bowels of his old workplace and make some friends along the way, too. Your job is to navigate the maze-like facility and keep Coby out of trouble, because it isn’t going to be easy.

Making this game wasn't always fun. In a way, my partner and I were like the character in the game, trying on things we'd never tried before (Godot and GDScript), with no one to help us at all. We gathered with three other people to create this game, but they sadly left due to circumstances early in development, leaving just two people to carry on the dream.
It almost felt crazy, setback after setback after setback and deadline after deadline after deadline, with all these what ifs and will we make it…? Boxthings and I grinded the final push to make it all the way to the top, collecting achievements, making progress... (just like Coby.)
I programmed nearly everything, with Boxthings sending art left and right. We didn't think about what could happen, we thought about what WILL happen.
And at last sweet victory came. We finally drank all 100 hours worth of juice alongside Coby.
- GB

Description:
Obscura

This story started, much like any other, with a series of roadblocks. Most notably, we hadn't figured out what we wanted to do, teammates kept giving up, and Yufan's computer died during most of February. Finally, somewhere around the start of March, we hopped on a call and figured out what we wanted to make. As a fan of base-building/automation games, I really enjoyed the game Mindustry (which is open source!). Similarly, Yufan really enjoyed the game Bloons TD 6. In the end, we decided to cross these two genres, resulting in Obscura. We went with Unity, mainly because Yufan has a lot of experience with it (personally, I would've preferred Godot). Overall, I have learned a lot through making this game, and arguably even more from the adventures this has allowed me to go on.

Description: ​Outlaw Heists is a fast-paced top-down RPG/multiplayer game inspired by the adrenaline-inducing chasing of Cops & Robbers or Subway Surfers but reimagined in a charming stardew valley kinda vibe. In this 2-player multiplayer heist, one player becomes the Thief, sneaking around the city and doing his best to collect as much as artifacts, coinbags and postboxes as possible and gets ready to offload his loot towards the end at a shady store but however time is ticking and the Police Officer controlled by the second player is on the mission to chase the thief down and bring justice.

Description:
Devil's Kitchen
Story of my game is pretty simple, two friends go for a hike on a nearby mountain, you were hiking up the cliff with your fren but he slips and fells deep down into the valley, so deep that even his painful screeches couldn't be heard. After that you have two choices left, either go home, eat dinner, forget about your friend and sleep, but WAIT you can't do that so you go with the second choice and that is to save your fren. So you follow the arrows, go into a valley, fight some underground mobs, solve some puzzles and save your friend.

seriously idk how this came into my mind, i just started making and ideas kept coming in. Making this game was a significant moment in my life as a developer as earlier i used to run to chatgpt for the smallest coding related problem but i cant do that for game dev, as you have to use real mind here. So yeah after this game, i really started coding things on my own, reading docs and debugging for hours rather than running to AI for every minor inconvenience, so this was huge!

Description:
Ever since I was a little kid, I always enjoyed gaming. I've played them, watched them, heck, I even joined an esports team. But greatest of all, I've always wanted to make one. But however close I got, I could never manage to finish one. I took a tried to teach myself, I watched videos, learned with my friends, and even took game design class. And while I always enjoyed them while time allowed, as soon as they ended, so did my progress. In the face of school, and extracurriculars, and college searching, I could never hold myself accountable to complete what I actually wanted to do FOR myself. Not until I joined hackclub, and took part in Hack Club Juice. This program, for better or for worse, FORCED me give game development a shot, and to stick with it, and I'm so glad it did. Even though I won't be taking part in the Shanghai trip, I'm still proud to have put in the 100 hours time and truly learned how to make time for doing what I love. At this point I've caught the game development bug, and I've caught it hard, so I look forward to seeing the rest of you in the game dev space in the future! 
Signed with love, 
Andre Snellings Jr.

juiceStretches.description: I did 3 main things over the course of a long discord call with my fellow developers. I added the ability to level up baubles, and added the ability for their stats to increase when you do so. To do this I added a system in which there are multiple ways for the baubles to receive exp, particularly by defeating enemies, giving them gemstone pickups, or finishing a level. I made it so each of these sources had an emphasis on different stats. So for example, giving a bauble a ruby pickup will give them an emphasis on improving their damage stat, but finishing a level gives a smaller boost, but will give a boost to all stats. Then when the bauble levels up it's take all of these values, and it'll use them to determine what stats actually go up, using a random number generator. I also made it so that the amount of exp needed to level up a bauble increases the higher their level is. I also added the ability for enemies to count how many baubles are attacking them at once. I did this so that I can add different functions to the enemies that they will only do when fewer baubles are attacking or when a lot of baubles are attacking. For now I just made it so that the earthworm can only shoot if less 6 baubles are attacking it. Last thing I did was export the game and create the initial itch page (restricted). The page doesn't have much, but I gave it the bare minimum to function and be usable. The export works but the enemies do not spawn in the exported version, I believe it's an issue with my file names not being case-sensitive.

This was a small session, mainly fixing bugs and glitches. I fixed the issue in my last session where the baubles would hold onto whatever the last input from before the player opened the inventory. I also made it so pausing the game will close the inventory. I changed some functions to "call_deffered" to remove some godot errors. I also changed the fade to black animation to not glitch out when it runs.

I just drew some silly little guys :)
They took a while cause I'm pretty bad at pixel art

Didn't get a lot of specific stuff done, just fixed bugs then started to build out the functions/signals for the inventory to communicate with the item slots. I fixed a bug where instead of lerping back to it's base position after being dragged, the item would teleport back. I added functions where the inventory will search through it's slots to find the nearest empty slot or the nearest slot with a particular item type in it, I'll use these for sorting the inventory items in order of when you get them and adding additional items to the stacks that exist instead of starting a new one every time. Sorry no video audio, too late :(
I refactored a chunk of the baublehead code to make it fit in more circumstances, added new states and transitions, and implemented pathfinding.

Finally finished the Inventory for good (for now :p). I fixed the bug that made the game crash when I spawned a guy from the inventory menu, I changed the way the menu updates to give the manager script priority, and I added an option to use a resource directly on an inventory slot.
I added code to the baublehead manager script, allowing it to spawn, despawn, and replace the baubleheads in a specified position.

I added a state machine to the level manager that differentiates if the game is in GAME, INVENTORY, or PAUSE mode, then added a function that makes it send that info to each necessary target. I did this so that I can filter inputs, so if the inventory is open, the baubles won't accept mouse inputs, and if the pause menu is open, the inventory menu cannot open. This took me a while, not because it was a complicated topic but because I needed to find a good approach. I spent a while reading and trying to implement InputEvents and having the UI accept specific inputs so they cannot go through to the baubles. While this would likely work, I do not have the knowledge of InputEvents to make it function, and eventually decided to pivot to the current strategy.

I added a "game loop" where rather than just roaming a prebuild space, now you can exit a level and enter a new one, you can click the start button on the home screen to enter that level, and all your stuff saves between levels. The saving took me the longest because I did not know where to start. I ended up finding a solution where each group of info that needed to be stored would be stored in a list in a global variable, then when the scene is reloaded we access that saved data and copy it onto the new scene. This was especially hard for saving the baubles in the party because they were originally stored as the exact nodes they were, and now they need to also be stored as their type and slot because when a new level is loaded, all previous party members are freed, so the type data can help me respawn them when they are needed. Aside from that I also tweaked the tilemap and made some new components (like enemy spawner) so that I can create new levels easier.
Coded in the pikmin, gave them their own state machine and movement code, gave them conditions for when to follow the player, etc.
Fixed state machine, added horrendous placeholder art, and added camera node as child of player :)

I started adding 2 new enemies. I made the very basic scene for one of them, then started working on art. I drew one big earthworm and one small one. The big one will shoot a big fireball into the air which will then explode when it lands on the ground. the small one will move towards the player and try to bite it I made an idle animation for the big one, a moving animation for the small one, and a shooting animation for the big one. I also touched up the old earthworm a bit, but not much.

Most of this session was spent drawing needed sprites, adding enemy animations, and implementing the enemies into the game. At the moment, the enemies don't function fully, but one of them will follow the player and dash at them intermittently, and the other will shoot a giant fireball into the air, which will then fall back down and cause an explosion. I was able to utilize a lot of previous code from other enemies and the baubleheads to make the enemy design process much easier, but I also had to learn to use some nodes that are ore new to me, such as the animation player. I also drew a few basic sprites to be added into the game to make it look less blank and dull.

Added the targeting state, and added function the targeting and attack states. Now the baubles with target an enemy if they are led near them by a player with the follow mouse ability. The bauble also now has a basic attack where they will go close to an enemy, then dash through them to deal damage, before moving to a new location and doing the same thing. Have a lot of plans to make it look and feel better, but that's all at the moment.

I created the project, added top down movement to the player, created a state machine the has walk and idle states implemented, and changed the project settings such as input maps and texture settings!

I spent the entire time fixing a stupid bug relating to case mismatching. The bug is stupid, but the only way to fix it was by renaming the files to fit what they need to be to match the error, then change the file name to something entirely different, then renaming it to the intended casing. In my case it went from "Enemies" at the very beginning, then I renamed it to "enemies" months/weeks ago, which is what caused the error to originally appear in the first place, now when I was trying to fix it I needed to rename the file back to "Enemies" to fix the error, change it to "Enemies2" to have the name change recorded, then change it back to how I wanted it "enemies". Basically godot (or git?) doesn't recognize that and uppercase and lowercase name is different, but it could tell the filenames didn't match, so you needed to change it originally to something entirely different in order for it to recognize the difference. The error was listed as "cpp 181 parse error failed loading resource godot" or something similar if you want to look into it.

Added player hurtboxes and enemy hitboxes so that the player can actually take damage. Spent a lot of time trying out different ideas with custom signals and stuff, spent a wile reading the docs and checking through forums to learn how to create my own signals, then eventually settled on something much more simple, but should be efficient going forward. I'd like to make the player's hurtbox code a component as well so that I can just slap it onto the enemies, baubleheads, and other destroyable objects in the future!

THIS SESSION SHOULD ONLY BE 7 HOURS. I added as much polish as I could, adding walking, attacking, holding, etc animations to each important character. Changed the settings, like background texture, to make it more cohesive to the tilemap. I started working on levels and made 8 that ended up in the JUICE final project. The game will cycle through them at random when needed, similar to a game like tboi. I added code that made it so you could only proceed to the next level when you defeated all enemies, and by proxy created a signal cycle that adds and subtracts enemies from the active enemies list. I added a system to reset the game, and a system to end the game for whenever the player leaves or dies. I added an enemy spawner that will spawn a designated number of enemies on a designated timer and will stop when all other enemies are dead or it has spawned the max # of enemies. I restructured the base level script and scene structure to be less unstable. Generally stabilized the game to remove as many red errors as I could find. Reuploaded a new version to itch. Added a fade to red for when you die. Likely added other minimal features that add to cohesiveness.

Added a new function to the pathfinding to help everything look/act more normal, now the baubles don't just follow one point, they follow a point that is within a certain range of the player, and that point switches up every few seconds so that the guys have a bit more movement. I refactored the pathfinding as a whole to make it applicable to other positions besides the player. I added bauble-enemy interaction, and added a few new states to the baubles

Worked on adding the inventory, particularly adding overall functionality to the inventory and party member slots. Now they each hold the information of their given resources and adapt as such. I started adding functionality to connect the UI to the bauble_manager script I made like 20 hours ago, but it's not quite done yet.

I added the ability to switch between levels, now the game will choose a random level from an array of preloaded levels whenever it needs to start another one, so the start of the game or the start of a new level. I made 1 new level to test this, and I made a new object called player_spawn, which is used to determine where the player should spawn. I also added the ability for enemies to drop pickups, which is the intended way of obtaining pickups, not just finding them on the floor.

I added a UI object that you can drag around and it will return to it's starting position when let go if it did not reach a target location. Added a scene for a inventory slot and started building a basic inventory scene.

Added a maximum count of baubles you can hold. Now if you are holding more than that amount, you will not be able to pick up any more, and any that were automatically picked up will go back to the floor. I fixed bauble throwing to throw one at a time, so if you are holding a stack, they will be thrown one at a time with a certain cooldown between them. I made it so you can't pick up more baubles mid throw (may change). I added a player sprint toggle so they can how run faster if they are not holding baubles. Edited Bauble PATROLLING state to make them stop once they reach the mouse and not stack on top of each other as much. Mostly just messed around with the Bauble throwing behavior and the other parts of the game that it effected, and changed some stuff to fit more cohesively.

I finally added the inventory! It's not fully functional but I need to finish this session haha (sorry cosmin D:). I created a scene for draggable objects which I then turned into an draggable inventory item, then I created inventory slots and party slots that have texture rects for sprites and center containers to hold the control nodes, then created an inventory scene that combines everything, but that broke because the center containers would stop the draggable objects, etc etc etc. Then I fixed all those issues and then added the inventory scene to the main scene... which then made it break again because it was was pinned to a particular part of the scene, so I fixed those issues, by attaching it to the player. I then made some placeholder sprites for item sprites, party slot sprites, and pickup sprites and turned them into resources for the individual scenes. I created a pickup and a signal bus that could be used to add items to the inventory, but I had never used custom signals before so I had to spend a while on that. Then I finally got stuff working at a basic stage... then immediately broke it again when I added the code for instantiating an item in the inventory, which is what I've been fixing for the last 2 hours, particularly I worked on the issue where my control node would shrink to 1x1 when the scene started and I had no Idea why, and initially thought it was just being deleted, yadadadada! And now we're here!

This was largely a debugging section. I fixed a bunch of issues with the Github, mostly merge conflicts from me and my partner accidentally getting seperated. I also fixed the code that they added when the added a pause menu and when they added the tilemap. Finally, I organized the whole project.

Added all 6 current bauble types as resources that can be applied to the base bauble scene and change how the look. Added a slight randomizer to the Bauble spawning so they spawn within a certain radius to the player instead of inside the player, meaning evin if a bunch are spawned at the same time they shouldn't overlap and push each other around. Added code to the bauble manager so that when a baublehead is spawned or replaces you can choose which type is spawned.

Finished adding/upgrading enemies, which involved fixing an issue with their bauble detection, and adding new abilities to the wiggly earthworm and the big earthworm. The wiggly earthworm now dashes on a timer, and the big earthworm's fireballs now explode, and create a marker for where they will land. I then started working on the item system, but there isn't much there yet aside from the basics for their resources and basic scene function.

Description: Our game is inspired by the Tom Hanks movie, "Captain Phillips", in which he must fight off pirates from his cargo ship. We thought this same idea would be interesting to implement in VR, so we decided to make Modern Day Pirates, an immersive VR experience in which you must take up arms, and fifth back to protect your cargo as you sail across the world!

Description:
Maze Escape

One day I got an email saying I could join the juice. I've never done anything like this before, but I thought I'd give it a try. I didn't know what kind of game I was going to do right off the bat. Then, while watching Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, it occurred to me that I could make a game where you escape from a maze :D As I wrote before, I had never made a game, and since Unity is one of the most famous Game engines, I started working in it. Using youtube tutorials I started to learn how to develop games in it. C# was also new to me. The game is still far from finished, but I plan to work on it after juice.

Description:
Fishing Fragments
It all started on a regular school day. Lunch time comes around, check my emails... BAM a message from Thomas. What was this? I would get the chance to go to China? Make a video game? Get it published on STEAM?????? I was in shock and my heart was racing with excitement. Of course, I was way in over my head, but we'll get back to that. 

The day after the juice call, I open up Godot and was ready to get started. I had an idea from the High Seas Jam that never got past a couple sprites, and I wanted bring this back to life as a full game - of course rethought a bit because of the no language theme. One of my favourite types of minigames found in sandboxes and rpgs is fishing - something about the rush of getting something rare, as well the simplicity of just standing around with your friends. I wanted to base my game around the potential of the fishing minigame with a cozy rpg about a water witch preparing potions (out of fish and other stuff) and getting small trinkets in return from the people she helps. I let this idea stew for about half a month while I worked on schoolwork and got myself accustomed to using GODOT and ASEPRITE. Eventually, I realised that this was not going to work out. I couldn't find a way to have a languageless story to fit this game without much more time than I had.

This was my first major hurdle, recycling my project for something similar but different. I still wanted to keep fishing as a major aspect, as it can be a rather silent hobby, especially if you're out on a boat for a while without any crew. This led to a new idea. The player would wake up on   boat, no memories, no one to talk to. Fishing to survive, they would catch fragments (pun intended) of who they used to be, their loved ones, and what happened. This would occur through dreams, stumbling upon familiar items or places, and as you filled out your fish compendium. 

Unfortunately I grossly overestimated the amount of time I would have, and time I would take implementing each feature. As of now, I don't have much more than a minigame and empty boat to walk around, but I have a roadmap in mind and plan to get the base game done before the end of the month, and update the game further afterwards.

The one major feature I did implement however, I am VERY happy with. I was always in love with games that have immersive controls and/or ui (Sneaky Sasquatch, NintendoLand, etc.) and fishing has so much potential for this. In Fishing Fragments, you use the mouse wheel to reel the fish in, and I plan on using mouse motion to cast and pull the rod as you would in real life.

Overall, Juice has been one of the best opportunities of my life. Even though I unfortunately won't be in Shanghai, nor will I likely have a full game by deadline, this jam has motivated me to do more game development in 2 months than I ever would have otherwise. Developing Fishing Fragments has also forced me to learn so much more about game development, programming, art, and even how to just plan better. This is my final year in Hackclub, and I am so glad I took part in Juice. Good luck to all future Hackers, and happy Juicing to everyone going to Shanghai!

juiceStretches.description: made idle out and idle in animations for fishing, and ensured that the cast is smooth from whatever point in the idle animation the cast is done. Actually used the animationstatemachine right this time as well.
Gravity fields to simulate fish floating
Figured out rigidbodies thanks to this: https://github.com/godotrecipes/rigidbody_drag_drop

tried to learn godot engine. started on making a game but then restarted as my old plan wasn't very well thought out in terms of both the jam theme and scope. I made a new mockup plan. made some temporary sprites and now i have a platform (soon to be boat), a player, and some temporary water/clouds. PS the whispers scared me real bad ;/

I made an object that shows a popup indicating that something is interactable (will change this to a sprite of the button you need to click). Honestly took me way to long to figure out the editable children thing :(

Drew fishing rod animation, foxed a bug with the fishing_level node getting returned as null (you need a _ready function that has more than just "pass" apparently). Created the animations for idle and cast and the animationtree state machine to go with it.
drew a cupboard for a new screen. Trying to figure out ball physics

Added a weight property to fish that affects your reeling speed.
Added a rarity system that replaces regular loottable weights. this took most of the time, as I wanted to make it so you could still use the exported weight on items that didn't have the rarity property. At first I tried a setter on the loottable item but this didn't actually affect it. I then created a getter for the loottableitem.weight that did the same check, but would return the rarity then instead of setting it. This still didn't work until I realised I had stored the rarities in an enum, and the first value is always 0 in enums, even if you assign it. As I write this I now realise that's why set didn't work and imma go change that because it's technically faster than running the get everytime
Finished book mechanics and added a reset save data option
Moved bucket level to its own script and adjusted its controls for leaving the screen. Also, the fish can move now on their own. Yay!

made a fishdata resource and integrated it with the fish object. The reason this took so long was because at first I tried to have a scene for each variant of fish. This doesn't work for a couple reasons, exported resources are set to null on object init, so when I create a new fish object, the exported data disappears. Secondly, this kind of defeats the whole point of using resources, since the data needed for each variant already exists as resources. Instead, I added an autoload script (item_manager) which has a function new_fish(type: String) that creates a new fish object and adds the data from a dictionary using type as the key. This also prevents slow initial loading at startup because resources are only loaded as they appear in game. Currently there is only a default fish and a swordfish,  but it should be easier to make new ones now
Drew some art for the outside and inside of the boat. It should be tilable so my boat can get as big or small as i want!

Drew up the background for and made the base of the fishing minigame. Continued fixing my very broken code (parallax bug turned out to be something to do with renaming nodes that have been instanced somewhere else, causing godot not to know what they are), reconfigured the popup screen to hide previous levels, and renamed interact_storage to interact_ui because both interactables function the same (popups), they just have different level scripts.
Boat sprites and put them into tilemap in godot

finished the rod animations except for the fish bob and created the abstract and rod state machines. The basics of the minigame are also now put together. You can cast, wait, reel (and play the mashing game - still need to put in animations for this), and pull in the line.
This took a bit longer, but I forgot to juice. Added Pause screen with resume, home, and quit, options
new room

Loot Tables, which are arrays loot table item resources. You add an item and and its weight to the loot table item and call the random_item method to get a random one according the wieghts. YOU CAN FINALLY FISH FULLY (just not actually keep your fish yet).
made test animations for player and blocked off incomplete areas for magazine demo
made bobber sink animation and made the fish bite part of the game.
bug fixes with teleporting through rroom. Also created better items rplling
Drew a logo, I suck at lettering and had my sister help me revise so thats why this took so long

I started work on the bucket storage, but ended up spending the rest of this moment fixing my popup open/close screen functions. When I would enter the bucket screen through another popup window, the node would stop processing, and the same would happen when I left teh bucket screen. I thought my initial code that paused/removed and unpaused/used add_child was solid, so I didn't realise where the bug was coming from until much later.

OMG got parallax down i think. SINCE my camera was zoomed in and not at (0,0), the scroll scale needed to be unlinked and the y scroll scale set to 1 to keep it aligned. FOR SOME REASON THIS VALUE KEPT ON CHANGING, THROWING ME OFF TRACK FOR 2 HOURS

Damn this should not have taken so long. Figured out parallax (i think), drew sprites for the sky  and clouds and stuff that I'm going to resuse for the fishing minigame background. t have to be the original resolution like before. I also drew many more fish sprites.

pretty much just forgot to submit the last OMG moment. This moment is where I fixed the random chance per tick thing so it didn't have to be so small, and so it's more intuitively controlled (chance per second vs chance per physics tick)

Description:
Preposterous Weaponry
it all started a very long time ago when i texted a friend about a game concept where you had a big gun that you added more and more functionalities to and then you overthrew the government, the aliens and God himself with your insane single weapon arsenal
when juice came and i had to submit an idea i reused this one, scrapping God to focus on the aliens because they're cool enough on their own
so i started coding and drawing, then eventually i spent more time thinking about what i was gonna make than actually making it, and when i saw i had to juice 3 hours a day with school to complete the 100h i gave up
thanks to everyone who thought my concept was cool

Description:
You are a goose stranded on Earth. One day, you encounter a golden goose who gives you a daring quest to reclaim the stolen golden egg from the tyrannical duck overlords. Your journey takes you across the plains of Earth, through the Moon’s craters, over Mars’s red deserts spoiled by the ducks’ asteroid machine, past the unforgiving asteroid belt, and finally into a strange, dreamlike realm. Only then, you reach the ducks’ massive mothership. You face the evil black duck in an intense battle, defeat him, and claim the golden egg. With your mission complete, you return the egg to its rightful owner at last. Be ready to be challenged by the vigorous obstacles and puzzling layout of levels! 

As we pondered upon the prompts given to us in that fateful markup document that we had to pitch our game in, there was a flood of bewildering ambition. Being the sadistic psychopaths we are, making players suffer is an obvious inspiration for the game mechanics. However, we also wished the game to be of enough quality such that the players wouldn’t be bored to death in part due to the difficulty. Despite our beating hearts, we had practically zero knowledge in game development with a sophisticated engine like Godot. Nevertheless, we were stably progressing in our initial weeks by flopping between tutorials, improvisation, and some vibe coding sinning. Interestingly, we found our knowledge to grow quite quickly with this model of creation. Though during March break, we were forced to lock in to speed up progress. Throughout this process, we were proud to see our game grow feature by feature, level by level, and our experience grow with the passing of each productive day.

juiceStretches.description: Guns (bullets) now kill all scenes under the group "enemies". Hahahah pew pew. Best part it wont crash when theres fast killings because I followed the set_deferred thing
Made a simple space sprite asset for the game.
The gun is now reloadable with all of the necessary UIs, appropriate responses to events like running out of bullets, etc is also implemented!

Finally figured out what was wrong. Previously, whenever you tried to tune the min_zoom (maximum zoom out before the camera switches back to the "follow" model), it would appear as if there was a random y - coordinate that acts as a boundary. Whatever value you set as the min_zoom, the camera would just zoom faster / slower as the player moves in y  such that when the player is at the altitude of that boundary, the zoom of the camera would be the value of the tuned min_zoom, which technically is correct but that was not the point of the code. Now that I fixed it, although nothing appears to be changed, we can now clearly define the bounds of the zoom model for the camera and the follow zoom scale as a variable. Apparently, the position of the camera in the workplace and ChatGPT's misinterpretation is to blame as the values which were being assigned to variables in the code concerning y-positions were relative to the position of the (either terrain or camera), and not a definitive "y = 0" in the workspace. Hence, although the code takes in values, say for y = 0, that appear to be correct, it is placed under the wrong context and would cause the player to only switch to the zoom camera mode when it is near the origin position of the terrain instead of the actual "ground" that we intended to be y = 0. Hence, we just had to set some offsets. ChatGPT 4o also helped to tackle the issue where the camera transitions were not smooth, and now it is.

Fixed the previously started dyanmic Y-tracking system for the camera by implementing two models:

1. "Zoom  model" In this model, the camera will zoom out to fit both the player and the ground into frame. This model is employed when the player is near the ground. 

2. "Follow model": This model is basically the previously added following camera system for Y coordinates (based on partners' following system for X coordinates). However, this time I fixed the offset such that the camera isn't staring into the ground all the time, unlike last time. This model will be used when the player is close to the ground (y = 0)

The way the game differentiates between when the player is near the ground or far (and by extension which model of the camera to use) is through computing how much the camera would need to zoom out to fit both the ground and the player into frame. If we need to zoom out more than a predetermined, fixed value representing the maximum zoom, then the "follow" model would be used instead. On the other hand, if the computed zoom out factor is in range of the predetermined maximum zoom out scale, the "zoom" logic would be used.

The switch between the "follow" model and the "zoom" model ensure that:

a. The player would be able to see what's underneath them (e,g., the spikes, terrain, etc.)  so that they don't just die

b. The player and terrain becomes more and more insignificant the more the camera zooms out, so we dont want the camera to zoom out indefinitely and for the player not see anything when they either get super high or super low. Hence, the "follow" model will be used instead in those conditions.

To be honest, this will probably be the camera model we will be using. Ima talk to my teammates about this, but in my opinion I am very pround of this as I think that it's very dynamic and it can fit well with basically any terrain we choose to add, whether that's as high as a mountain or a cave. It truly enables us to do some creative stuff with our levels (because it'd be very boring if its just a flat platformer level again and again).
The egg and bread had the same collisionmask problem as the door and key, so I just fixed it.

Nothing too complex, basically finished building the level whilst I was on the skytrain. Implemented a door-and-key system as well, which can also be translated into the main repo with my partners. Since last time I made some discoveries regarding the camera and why it's not working, I will implement those changes back to the main repo as well next.
My partner asked me to review his changes of a timer in the game in Github. I approved of it after reviewing

Fixed a bug caused by math where the camera would not show the player when the player is under the map. worked mostly on making the borders invisible but gotta stop now because theory class is coming up and tacomatchi thing is due

1. Fixed level 2's adaptability with the camera by extending texture coverage and moving the secret area up so that no space is unfilled and secret area is actually secret.

2. Finished level 3-area 1's terrain, need to implement portals next. Now the players cant jump through the ceiling

3. Correctly positioned the enemy and tuned the platforms in level 3, need to customise the location of the dropped items next. 

4. Added a debugging feature to jump levels by pressing "l" so that debugging dont take so long

1. Solved the problem with the "expecting [" when loading third level. Basically it was because somehow the file still had markers for github (those used during resolving conflicts) despite us already resolving the conflicts. Probably because I had to rename my level 1-3 to level 2-1 because one of their very nice looking Mars level is 1-3 as well. Hence it was blocking the square bracket. 

2. Teammate showed me how to load in their Mars level.

3. Fixed the weird camera offset for level 2-1 (my former level 3) only.

Set up development environment and project on my PC (I like working on it better because my laptop's storage has like 100 mb left constantly). Also quickly made it so that the display size variables for the cameras scale automatically because I noticed a problem w/ this computer.

Based on a variant of the AK-47, it may not be THE guy for the game, but definitely A gun. This will likely be one of the weapons used in the overworld. As you can see I've also animated a reloading animation to support reloading.

Made the majority (background, all tiles, most entities) second segment of the fourth level from the materials and mechanics already developed (platforms, entities, etc). Tuned camera for the second segment.

2. Oh yeah and also I reviewed my partners *rather troublesome* Pull Request.
Learned and did the whole github version control thing with my partner, cloned the repository on my device, opened a branch, committed the changes I've made and got approved

Integrated the doors and re-made the keys for the door-and-lock system. Previously I didnt know how to create a separate scene that worked like the egg so I simply replaced the sprite of the egg with the key and it served the same function. Now it is its own distinct scene that can have each instance of it call a separate door through the global Key_ID variable. 

However, I wasnt able to test it as everything seems to just fall right through level 3. I tried to debug it and repainting the physics_layer_0 in tileset but didnt get anywhere. Ill go to sleep now and do it tomorrow.

I thought that it would be difficult but no! 

Fixed the weird glitch for level 1 and 2 where after committing where the cameras of every level is funky. Turns out all it is was a custom offset value in the code

Its weird because with the offset it worked perfectly in the previous version, but now it can only work without it...

Began level 3 construction:

1. Finished layout of the level (as you can see its not complete yet...)
2. Made space ship background assets (this one took me the most time)
3. Reworked the moving platform such that different instances of it can have different parameters so that we can include more than one in levels (and also because I cant figure out how to use the old one).

I tried to tune the specific values for segment 2 of level 3, but just couldnt because there was a problem in the way which the camera's code handled the deadzone, where A. The game's interpretation of the camera's bounds are different from the location of the camera's actual bounds because it didn't factor in the offset. B. This wasnt noticed last time but when tuning, the camera refuses to go below a certain altitude (more specifically y = 0 plus whatever factors that was applied to it at the time). This is caused because a line of code "clamping" the coordinates of the camera was written above all of the conditional statements for handing level changes, and wasnt disputed later. Leaving the code to continue assuming that the level began at x = 0 (which is correct for all parts but the level 3 segment 2), and therefore the level_length to be useless despite being changed.

The bugs are now fixed and the camera is tuned properly to fit the level's dimensions. I also adjusted the position of some tiles on the second segment because it couldnt fit the goose.

1. Finished the terrain layout for Level 3's secret area, painted and added backgrounds for it
2. Added vent and tuned a teleporter for the secret level segment
3. Added eggs, enemies in the segment

There are two bugs with one being the lagspike and another being I believe a camera tuning issue, Ill fix it when I get back.

Fixed blocky y-movement of the mario-style camera model (by implementing a separate smoothening speed value for x and y, because when y is low and isnt blocky, x is too slow to keep up and vice versa) and its inability to track the player below the minimum height. 2. Re-adjusted the size of the background in the third level to better suit the scale of the goose. Made the tiles there have physics. As you can see, now we can go underneath the map in level 3

Debugging session to fix bug where the code would crash out due to things like dripstones and eggs being assigned to the enemy group, causing the code to crash out when calling the start_falling function that does not exist in things which it detects as enemy but are actually not functionally (like dripstones and eggs). All other items are now assigned to groups like items or entities, and the dripstone remains to be an "enemy" but I provided a start_falling function that makes it delete itself when killed (shot by a gun) so that theres no error of an expected function not being there.

FINALLY!!11! Added the ducking feature w/ the ducking sprite created previously, notably also adding a smaller hitbox. There will also unfortunately have to be ducking variants for basically all animations except for idle. Currently, the placeholders are arrows.
Pushed recent changes to main on Github
A cool goose sprite, may be converted to fit 3D-like variant if such an element is to be used
Got a working template of a platformer by following a Godot tutorial, tried to grasp what the C# Godot template script means.
Made the gun a pickupable (is that even a word?) item, similar to that of the egg or bread. Next up, I will likely make it reset for every level.
Teammates started game repo on Github, didn't merge w/ the repo but added my sprite and a double jumping feature, will consult them to add the worked materials!

1. Continued furnishing level 3 - all tiles are finished now

2. Made a teleportation system so that there can be separate "areas" inside of levels (like rooms in Mario). Simple, right? NO! Getting the player to teleport is super easy. However, the camera model Im using for this level has a lot of restraints. Often, though the player and camera is teleported to the new zone, the camera instantly begins to move back to its designated area. I tried to make it so that the teleporter can specify some of these values for each instance (so that the camera gets a new set of values for the new area), but it didnt work for a long time because Chatgpt wasnt comprehending it right either. In the end, I had to move the entire segment segment to the right of the first segment instead of under to try if a difference in X would work instead of Y. Ultimately, it worked. I still dont exactly know how, but I think it is because a sufficient amount of the correct variables are updated by the teleporter, in this case most notably probably being the coordinates where the camera registers as the "base" of the level's X and Y extents.

So far, the camera script is not super tuned, but I believe that this result is robust enough to customise, and I just need to go to sleep rn so Ill work on it tomorrow.

Implemented the idea I had a number of sessions ago about fixing the camera on the sublevel in the main level, tweaked around some variables. I feel like that I'm too obsessed with the camera because it's always going to be either too zoomed out or not sufficient to keep both the ground and the player in frame. For now Ill work on a deliberate attack mechanic, maybe for use during a boss battle. Also I need to pull my teammates' changes...

Fixed misaligned hitbox, in particular with the obstacles (hazards). The hitboxes of the obstacles seem seem to have shifted to the right quite entirely, as the death logic never triggered when the player's sprite is directly in contact with the obstacles' hitboxes, rather it was being triggered when in contact with a space on the top of and directly next to the obstacle's sprite on the right. I'd blame the fact that it wasn't me who worked on this so finding wheres where took quite a while, but other than that its a huge red flag when the assets of the obstacle and finish line appears quite distinctly in Godot. Anyways, tons of debugging. Quite a long time apparently now that I look at it on the wrong code, I also asked ChatGPT for what to do, and it constantly suggested that I did something wrong with the assembly and creation of the hitbox in respect to the sprite, hence causing the "shift". I checked that along with the code vigourously, making a lot of debugging changes and experiments. Because ChatGPT's instructions were unclear and often guessed, it made it difficult to navigate around Godot's UI and that did take me quite a while, inspecting and searching the project for traces of error related to the obstacle's hitbox. Eventually, I wasn't actually able to identify what caused it, other than find some pretty alarming red flags that I will talk about to my teammate soon. For now, I can say with slight confidence that this was not in fact an issue with setting up the hitbox, rather it was an issue with how the code interpreted it, as A. the obstacle hitbox code varied drastically from that of the finish line hitbox, which for now basically had the same functionings, and B. well, with every debugging feature I have used, I just couldn't identify any issues with setting up the sprite, and C. I redid the entire set up of the obstacles to MAKE SURE that it's not a problem with the set up process and with that I can confirm that it's the code that's wrong. Since I have then identified where in the code the player script handles interpreting the hitbox, (I know why isn't it in its separate code like the finish bar), detecting collision, and calls the death function, I basically put a not incredibly versatile fix to this problem which I have yet to discover the roots of, and that is to manually shift the interpreted hitbox to the left by a fixed amount, which has to be customised each time depending on the application of the obstacle and the size of the sprite, and also did I mention that this was only the horizontal changes, and you have to make changes to the y-vertical interpretations too?!?!!?!!!! Yeah funny, I'll go talk with my partner to see what he was thinking about. Anyways, it worked I guess, good night.

Gosh that was tolling
As mentioned before, I gotta fix the hitbox for the goose such that, though it won't be standing on thin air, it wont be "standing" on its beak and bottom either. I edited the collision polygon such that it would be more "slidy" on the edges and the character would fall off if its sitting on its butt or beak. Unfortunately, that yielded an error. I was confused so I asked ChatGPT, which often is helpful except for this time. I was told that it failed because my shape was either too complex, too concave, or just have two points lying ontop of each other (like last time) or whatever other reasons. Though I failed to provide it context. Turns out, the reason Godot weren't able to "find" the polygon of the "CollisionPolygon2D" was not because it was invalid, but rather because the script (I think the script?) was placed in the wrong location and thus was referring to a wrong parent. Hence why it's not able to find it. After I moved the files, the duck's collision system started to have errors and resulted in a crash whenever (later I found out) the "kill enemy" action was performed by jumping ontop of the enemy, but not exactly on top. It was apparently my fault this time (not my teammates') because when I first got the code I had to introduce new hitboxes while keeping the old ones in the goose scene. Thus why I changed all of the names referring to the changed hitbox to their equivalence changed name (INCLUDING THOSE MENTIONED IN THE DUCKS). For some errors in the ducks' scene (those referencing hitboxes in itself), this caused a problem because its own hitboxes have not been changed, so I basically pointed it to an nonexistant hitbox object / node (I don't know the official term form it). For other(s) (I believe, I forgot how many errors occurred that weren't about wrong names) in the ducks' scene, (I think one most particular that referenced their hitbox, was CHANGED BY CHATGPT IN ITS SUGGESTIONS BECAUSE IT THOUGHT THAT IT WAS SUPPOSED TO BE MENTIONING THE POLYGON HITBOX THAT I MISINSTRUCTED IT TO BELIEVE WAS PART OF THE DUCK IN THE FIRST PLACE. THERE WAS NO CHANGES TO HITBOXES, LET ALONE A POLYGON HITBOX (THAT IS ONLY ADDED BY ME SO FAR) IN THE DUCKS. And it was likely supposed to refer to the rectangular CollisionShape_2D instead, but by now ChatGPT's suggestion was imbedded the code for far too long of a time and I can't use Control + Z, which means that I can't go and retrieve or see the original code, so then I finally managed to round the problem down and good thing is that ChatGPT gave me a pretty innovated solution using some maths to evaluate an equivalence to the bounds of the original square hitbox (the thing the broken line of code was trying to get), thereby bypassing the reference completely and sparing me from some more hours of suffering. Also there's a funny little line on top for some reason and there's also hitbox problems with some other blocks such as the first two golden blocks placed at the very biginning, along with the spikes. Hopefully fixing those won't take as much trial and error that fixing this hitbox... but it should be fine considering that it was mainly a misplacement error.
Pulled changes from GitHub, added previously created jump and glide animations

1. Made the level 4 terrain tilemap on the right layer instead of making objects adapt to the terrain's wrong collision layers.

2. Re-integrated the cameramen enemy, this time as its own separate scene and replicated instantiating process because although I can change to sprite dynamically I cant change the hitbox dynamically.

3. Positioned the door, enemies, and some items on lvl 4
Background for another habitable planet in the game is made.

Made the game over screen button which my partner made actually functional. Encountered and fixed a problem where apparently due to the obstacles triggering the death function more than once, it sends out numerous signals that interfere with the code. A guard that detects and ignores repeated death handler function calls was installed and the problem was fixed.
Added wall jumping and corresponding airflow animation. Currently using a placeholder image, will work on more dynamic animations next time
Difficult to add wings! Added a gliding + glide / wing flap transition animation, can be modified to create a wing flapping animation if necessary in the near future.
----- Added jumping / falling animation for when standing up, added normal walking animation, applied to the animations, is going to create a merge request soon...
Version control w/ teammates

Added fade transition for teleportation (player cant move or be hurt during the teleportation). Tried to fix the bug of the camera pointing to a certain direction for a while (that was added by Chatgpt during the previous debugging session to ensure teleportation) but cant. I guess it will do for now.

I wasn't in the mood to work on the troublesome camerawork and invisible borders today, so I backed up a copy of the game file and started working on another level with other entities, mainly I just had to design a bunch of other sprites, as most are set. The level is not at all polished yet, but all the sprites are there and all it takes is some organisation of the level tomorrow. No frustrating debugging

Finished building (laying out all tiles) of the left bridge and main room of the next section of the third level. I could not test it yet because that would need me to first make a teleporter, which I will do next time.

Continued working on the other level, this time though I didn't try to touch the camera but I had to because it was broken for this level somehow. However through working on it I realised that it wasnt the zoom that was the culprit to the camera not revealing the ground no matter what, it was instead the offset we added to the camera in order for the player to be where we want it to be in the camera's frame. So we can instead add the offset's values to the variable which defines the level's ground's altitude and then the camera can show it by overcompensating. I also revamped some sprites that they dont look awkward both in terms of colour and pixel size. Worked on the level's obstacles as well.

Tested game, unfortunately it wont work. A couple of small errors caused by missing resources I fixed but the camera offset is going nuts and adjusting it didnt help so Ill wait until we merge. My teammate still has commits though so Ima work on some assets for now

Made a third camera model inspired by Super Mario, where the camera starts off with a large zoom and would only move when the player threatens to cross a certain bound in terms of y near the screen. This is very clean and dynamic. A lot of time (as usual) was spent towards fixing chatgpt's code

2. I feel like that having different camera models for different levels would fit. So the previously created follow model would be used for the first level, the zoom model on the second level, and this zoom model on the third level that I am making because it requires a lot of going up and down

Tres bien! Fixed the glitch where the goose would have a "seizure" whenever the player releases the duck (crouch) key when there isn't enough space for the goose to return to its default, neck-raised state. This would previously cause it to glitch around the terrain and sometimes even noclip out of bounds into the void. Now, even when the user lets go of the duck (down) keys / buttons, the duck would continue to remain ducking until enough an Area2D node stretching between the top of the hitbox for the ducking goose to the top of the hitbox for the default goose (covering the extended neck, basically) detected supposedly enough space for the goose's neck to be re-extended. This feature is also implemented without interrupting the other movement controls and dynamics in the game, so nothing too big. However, I initially used a CollisionShape2D node, thinking that since similar features are already well-built in the code, that I can just re-use it and instead just integrate it as a slightly more complex if-statement in the already-built ducking function. However, I encountered several logic issues about the if-statement, whether it be the hitbox being over sensitive or not sensitive enough, or just purely sensitive in the wrong ways, I had to make some big fixes. It all came down to nothing though as I found out that my initial hypothesis was actually incorrect; there wasn't any "collision" settings in the properties tab, so the goose now cannot go under ANY small, low space due to the hitbox colliding with the terrain, basically making the ducking feature useless. Hence, I reworked the entire thing except this time with an Area2D solution which is something new I learned. Either way, that took slightly less time because it followed a similar approach, only this time with a CollisionShape2D inside of an Area2D. Similar use of the Area2D node technology can also be used in the future for other stuff

Animated a walking variant of the crouch sprite, added the feature to the game such that it would only play if the player is crouching and moving horizontally. Similar logic can also be implemented for adding other animation variants into the game's movements.

WARNING: HELLO LOPA PLEASE DELETE 2640 MINUTES FROM THIS SESSION!

I worked on way too many things for this session. I dont even remember most of them but I suppose it is 

1. Made 8 fully complete levels, including the final boss room
2. Fixed many bugs (I can't recall fully but some significant ones are camera not being able to move above a certain Y-bound despite settings, repeated levels when switching with debug switcher, two players instances spawning, and RID (godot physics engine) overflow, the worst in my opinion). One significant thing done to solve these errors is a centralised camera setting code for each level so that similar errors do not happen again. Made logic for sublevel selector. Made many scenes that can be instantiated (customisable moving platforms, interface teleporters and level transitioners, activatable pistons, etc.)

This work was done over a week. Thanks a lot spring break! 

The video would, I believe, be too long for the juicer to show the entire thing. Here's a YouTube video instead. This video is from a slightly previous version from this same session that has some bugs and does not include the ending but those are fixed now as shown in my video, namely the last moon level, second mars level being broken and general misalignment issues in the new levels. It should also be mentioned that the camera is set to a low zoom for demo purposes and invincibility juice is constantly applied because I dont wanna die mid-recording

https://youtu.be/PeFPXIPcUbw

Implemented the gun pickup to the second level but encountered a bug caused by the reference to the nodes of gun, player, etc in the global script being reset when the level changes. Now, instead of there being a direct reference to the gun, a path is stored indefinitely so that even if we need to take away the gun after the level ends the game doesnt break because we are still not referring to something null.

Debugged and fixed the previously found bug where the secret segment's camera refuses to go below a certain y-coordinate. That was likely caused due to the way the Camer2D is calculated the "effective centre", which factors in the offset. I think that by removing it itll likely fall back to the error where the functional camera location and the camera location which the game is recognising to be different. I may test that out later but for now the problem was solved by extending the level length.

Re-wrote the camera code a bit because my partners did not like it very much for all levels. This may just be a variation, and we may just switch around cameras per level, heck even sections. Anyways I have a soccer practice so I gotta go despite there being some bugs

Fixed the issue with the key and door falling off

1. Collision receiving and output layers were misaligned not due to the terrain, but the objects
2. forgot to create global variable in global.gd (leading to no assignments), forgot to add call to the key_collected function after changing its name in the key

3. Global.gd's KeyID didnt reset
Organised files and previously miscellaneous file names, caused errors in code and conflicts in Github, debugged and resolved them, committed and pushing to main.

Implemented the previously created sprites and animations for an AK47 weapon in the game. (Made the weapon and bullet scenes). As you can see the gun is carried around by the player and can shoot bullets. I've also completed a reload mechanism. There's still some bugs and the gun is unable to kill or be naturally acquired at this moment. I'll likely finish bug-proofing the gun first, upload it to github, and then work on it when we develop our damage and purchasing systems.

Unfortunately my partner said that the changes which my other partner made (level system) basically overhauled everything since everythings in different positions now. Although my changes are getting merged by him nonetheless, its gonna be quite troublesome so I manually readded the gun I made it work w/ the structure of the modified version (this part is the difficult part). From now on I will be making changes from this version.
Erased annoying debug tiles... done!

Github stuff w/ my friends, its a pretty large commit cuz I havent been committing to github regularly recently (bad habit) but surprisingly not a lot of conflicts (likely cuz its mostly new content instead of fixes or improvements)
Github stuff guided by my partners to push my fixes to main
Fixed hitbox for y-axis offset, didn't take long at all because it's basically the same thing I did for the x-axis so no debugging needed

Added vertical camera following. My partners' already done horizontal camera following so it wasn't super difficult to implement. The only problem currently is that although it does follow, there seems to be a vertical offset. I'll fix it when I get back...
Began the creation of level 3 in godot, made some assets for essential locations for it. Level 3's gonna be a spaceship
Added gun audio sound effects (I recorded it myself) Ima check w/ my partners though to see if they accept the style.
Deleted debugging print scripts from the previous night
The dripstones now explode on impact as an action extension to the previously created start_falling function.
Merged with teammates on Github, pulled the latest version. As you can see there are still pleny of bugs to fix... that's just free juice hours!
Github commit and push for the last two changes I've made.

Sorted out version control, committed my changes to the branch and merged changes made by my partners from main. Unfortunately the first time something went wrong because I forgot that I was actually working under a copy of my original local game file (it is Spacegoose - Copy) after I messed up hard on the initial file and I decided just to abort the initial file. Unfortunately Github is still connected to that bad, aborted version of the game and I committed and merged the wrong files. I did it again, this time switching the original file by adding a "-Bad" at the end of it and deleting the "copy" in the file name of the copied game file to make both programs recognise the new, copied game file, then I just sorted out some changes conflicts and voila

Integrated a level made quite a long time ago into the game. It was stored on a separate machine and was from a version far back. Made it compatible with the current level system and did minor polishes like aligning / fixing textures, tuning camera, and adjusting the goose's previously pointy nose hitbox to not get stuck while walljumping on the pillars. Will expand this level and continue refining its quality next.

Added a custom hitbox for the goose, encountered errors w/ something like "failed to render polygon" because I think it broke the hitbox down into polygons. Awkward beak and hip though, will fix later. Took a while to figure out but apparently I just have to be careful when editing to not overlap too many points (because turns out they don't auto-delete). But yeah probably some mathematical geometry things going on here that I'm not certain of, will delete points instead in the future.

1. Smoothened out all tiles and textures on level 3
2. Added guns, enemies, and egg spawning locations for both segments of level 3
3. Adjusted some terrain to make the game actually beatable and terrain foolproofing
4. Made platforms movable in both the X and Y direction (mixed, sloped movement as well), customised each instance of the platform to work with the level
As requested by my partner, test out the game's compatibility with game controllers, added some extra keybinds.

Description:
The Labyrinth

I came up with the idea of a maze with moving walls when Juice first began, but I needed to expand on the idea to create a game. So I added abilities, traps, and hopefully eventually enemies.  I started by generating the maze, then created the script that allowed the walls to move. After that I stopped working on the project for the majority of the time, but decided to finish it in the last week. So with 80 hours over the course of a little over a week I began adding features. Art style, main menu, abilities, saving data, audio, ect... Which led to this final product. I plan to continue to work on the game and eventually list it on Steam and a polished and legitimate attempt at making an enjoyable game.

juiceStretches.description: Tried to make the sprint and wall destroy abilities but didn't get it working. Added a menu to the  game scene.
Made the gun boost ability work
Playtested more and fixed bugs with maze generation, and the same scene being called more than once. Tweaked ability costs and strength.
Created ability section for main menu with drag and drop.

Created player sprinting ability. Changed the way the player spawns, which created a bug where the player collider gets destroyed on start for some reason so i need to fix that. The timer ability also is now broken.
Made models for entering and exiting the game, and a model for one of the traps.
Continued work on the main menu, added a level selection system.
Made a system to detect which trap kills the player. Added audio for each trap that kills the player, used audacity to edit the audio.
Accidentally deleted the spawn and exit prefabs so had to remake them, made trap 2 and 3 in blender. Fixed Z fighting bug with trap spawning.
Worked on adding particles to the walls. Added ambient sounds in the main menu
Worked more on lighting, changed wall slide script slightly. Created wall and floor assets in blender. Changed the wall and floor and set up[ textures.

Finally got data saving and the shop completely working. Data saves to drive and between scenes properly using scriptable objects and json. The scriptable object handles all of the data while the game is running and then the json is used only when you close the game Remade the shop and made the frontend and backend of it work completely.
Reduced file size and sorted files. Submitted to the magazine. Fixed minor bugs.
Fixed the time ability. Worked on main menu UI animations. Fixed jittery platform movement when spawning and exiting the game.
Fixed minor bugs. Customized lighting for 9 different skyboxes which are randomly selected when the game starts.
Added a few more trap types to reach the 2 hour mark of coding for today.
Created a trap spawning system for the maze so I can use a list of trap prefabs and they will randomly generate throughout the maze.
Fixed wall sliding, made itch page look better
Fixed bugs preventing the game from building. Fixed other bugs with main menu, scene transitions, and the new floors in the maze. Created and uploaded a new build of the Labyrinth.
Improved the shop but it still has a long ways to go before it functions completely.
Worked on the itch.io page, and created a webGL version which took a long time because the build was having issues and the UI/windows size were messed up
Player movement, and better maze generation. Almost got wall sliding working but it still has some issues.
Made a flame trap, some small bug fixes.
Added scene fade to and out of black transitions. Added a spawn and exit animation. Fixed some trap/ spawn/ exit spawning bugs.
Created the wall destroy ability. Reworked maze generation so that inactive walls lose their wall tag to make the wall destroy ability work.
Improved trap, entrance, and exit spawning. Made the timer function in both scenes.
Improved the main menu AI and added music.

Made the level selection work and generate specific mazes based on the selected level, also added it to the data save so that it remembers what level you are on. Worked more on audio and the main menu.
Playtested fixing some bugs, worked on audio, and made the levels tougher/ just better.

Improved jitter when exiting and entering the maze, still there but much less noticeable. Fixed an issue with the gun boost ability working properly. Fixed the return to main menu UI. Created final 100hr build.
Generating the maze
Created a save system using json and fixed minor bugs.
Put my game on itch.io, made a main menu.
Worked on the shop a tiny bit but it still isn't working completely. Then started on lighting and shaders

Spent forever trying to add audio but couldn't get it working. I tried using animation events for the player footstep sounds but i couldn't get it to work properly with the player movement script. I tried making traps play noises, which worked, but caused terrible performance because so many sources of sound were spawned. I also tried playing a sound when the walls slide but i couldn't figure out how to play the sound only once each time it slides, and it also was terrible for performance.
Fixed minor bugs. Added the time increase ability.
Made a better main menu and fixed a few bugs with player input. Added audio.

Description:
Before the hackathon officially began, we were required to spend 100 hours developing a game in advance. By the time we arrived at the venue, we had already completed a game with that time. However, we quickly realized that the game wasn’t nearly as polished or engaging as we had hoped—it simply wasn’t fun to play.

So, during the three-day event, we made a bold decision: to start over from scratch.

With barely any sleep each night, we poured all our energy into building a brand-new game within those 72 hours. What we created durin

juiceStretches.description: Add functionality for randomized scenes (multi-room generator) and fix a lot of bugs

First time using Unity, starting from scratch to create various interactive behaviors for characters, doors, and cabinets!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

We even completed the automatic room generation feature!

Although everything is still in the early stages :/
Keep going!

The Cross Scene System feature is complete!!!!

第二幕：逃出實驗室 [20分鐘]
​​​| 目標
想辦法到實驗室1樓

| ​​​需求
玩家必須認識到自己位於實驗室的6樓中，必須想辦法到達1樓離開實驗室；在離開的過程中發現了散落在各地的殭屍預防海報/警示海報（認識到有喪屍危險）、並且實際看到殭屍，認識到自己身旁有許多殭屍的存在​；教導如何放置/移動/移除障礙物，以及該如何使用特殊道具（例如手榴彈以及槍枝）​

| 玩家可獲得
手槍、​​​

| 玩法
[門解密]
​​玩家將在手術室出口附近發現電梯以及電梯附近的配電室。配電室運用​​dead by deadline當作第一道門,而在通過之後會有warframe的lock當作第二道門,
每次失敗都會造成聲響吸引喪屍並生成1-3個喪屍

參考：
https://warframe.fandom.com/zh-tw/wiki/%E4%BE%B5%E5%85%A5
​
[電梯]
開啟門候會發現一個配電箱，但配電箱上的各種開關皆散落在各地，玩家必須在整層樓中去尋找這些遺失的配電箱​​​開關，一旦使用者找齊10個配電箱開關即可回到配電室中進行小遊戲。

該小遊戲參考 Roblox Doors level 100 的配電室遊戲玩法：​​
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JsqZdZ21wEQ&ab_channel=StereoGaming

[樓梯]​​
電梯將在降至3樓時發生故障卡住而無法繼續下降，使用者必須於3樓時離開電梯並找到樓梯下樓，而在該過程中將會​​​​遭到大量喪屍的追殺，玩家必須根據地形擺放障礙來抵禦喪屍的追殺。（樓梯將設大量喪屍以及小BOSS）

| 詳細說明
當使用者出​​​​
第三幕：存活並回家 [30分鐘]
​​​| 目標
想辦法找到車鑰匙並且登上車子前往從前的住家​
| ​​​需求
​要找到車鑰匙並且殺死中途阻擋的殭屍，玩家在尋找要使以及線索的途中還可以取得一些抵禦的物資/自動機槍，來抵禦喪屍。而在抵禦的過程中每一波喪屍會間隔1-2分鐘，讓玩家可以有時間出去找要使以及線索，但如果不回來的話將會無法存活(除非他技術夠好)。回來後可以繼續建造營地來更好的抵禦下一波，每一波會越來越強而且喪屍是無限的，如果沒有在時間內找到的話，也會因為子彈/物資耗盡而失敗。而要使的部分並不是每把都能用有些車是沒有油的。

障礙物、機器會壞，邊打邊維修，讓他們忙死​

一波1-10分鐘​；1~3分鐘

| 玩法
​在空曠的停車場以及實驗室1樓遇到大量的喪屍，要想辦法運用之前學到的技能來去擊敗他，同時還要找到鑰匙
第一幕：醒於手術室中 [5分鐘]
​​​| 目標
想辦法離開手術室

| ​​​需求
讓玩家認識到自己原來參加了軍方的計劃，而自己是計劃中的一名受試者，被注射了某種血清；教導如何查看東西(海報、道具等)、如何拾取物品以及使用物品、教導如何使用近戰武器

| 玩法
找鑰匙、輸入密碼​​​​

| 玩家可獲得
手術室鑰匙、手術刀​​​​​
第四幕：回到家裡發現沒人，找線索
​​​| 目標
讓使用者知道劇情發展​​，結束遊戲

| 玩法
遊戲名稱：Terminal Outbreak​​​
原型：Minecraft Hypixel Zombies minigame
背景：現代​
遊戲時長：60 分鐘
----------------------
背景設定
世界曾經爆發了一場毀滅性的戰爭，主角——伊森·卡特（Ethan Carter），是一名經驗豐富的特種部隊士兵，擁有極高的戰鬥技巧與生存能力。他曾參與多場險惡的戰役，執行過無數次極機密任務。然而，戰爭結束後，政府為了縮減軍隊規模，強制遣散大量士兵，伊森也在其中。

墮落與重生
回歸平凡生活的伊森卻無法適應。他長年處於高壓環境，飽受創傷後壓力症候群（PTSD）折磨，最終沉迷於酒精，導致家庭破裂，與妻子及女兒艾莉（Ellie）分開，生活變得貧困潦倒。某天，他收到一個神秘的軍方邀請——一項秘密計畫正在招募志願者，並提供可觀的報酬。出於絕望與對生活的厭倦，伊森決定加入，卻未曾想過這將改變他的一生。

殭屍病毒的爆發
這個實驗計畫的真正目的，是為了創造一種強化人類體能的血清，利用回收自感染體的病毒進行基因改造。然而，研究過程失控，病毒發生變異，導致整個研究設施爆發感染，軍方為了掩蓋錯誤，不惜封鎖整個地區，甚至進行無差別屠殺。然而，病毒還是透過各種管道擴散到了全世界，最終導致全球文明崩潰，人類社會瞬間陷入末日浩劫。

變異的伊森
伊森作為實驗對象之一，在病毒大規模泄漏前被注射了血清。他本應變成一具失去理智的怪物，卻因為未知的原因成功存活了下來，甚至擁有了異常的身體能力——他的傷口能夠迅速癒合，體能超越常人，五感變得更加敏銳。然而，這些能力並非沒有代價——他開始感受到體內的黑暗衝動，時不時出現幻覺，甚至隱隱約約聽見其他感染者的低語聲。

尋找家人之路
世界已經變成廢墟，城市裡滿是遊蕩的感染者與瘋狂的生存者。伊森唯一的目標，就是尋找他失散的家人。
----------------------
喪屍將從特定點位刷出，玩家可以透過獲得障礙來延長殭屍出現的時間（喪屍或配壞這些障礙）。
----------------------
其他設定:
有聲音跟​​​​​視力
聲音的部分:
0-5
0: 玩家慢走 吸引範圍:0
1: 玩家正常走 吸引範圍:2
1: 玩家用刀殺死殭屍 吸引範圍:2
3: 玩家快走 吸引範圍:3
4: 殭屍發出聲響 吸引範圍:10
5: 玩家用槍殺死殭屍​ 吸引範圍:12 (同時會生成殭屍5隻 30秒內不會成)
視力部分:
0: 殭屍不會有視力
1: 殭屍可以看到3格範圍
2: ​​殭屍可以看到6格範圍
​​​3: 殭屍可以看到6格範圍內(X-ray)
----------------------
控制:
W 前進
S 後退
A 左邊
D 右邊
shift 慢走
ctrl 快走​​​
右鍵 瞄準 (如果沒有瞄準就是滑鼠指向45度隨機 有的話根據槍決定)
左鍵 射擊​​​​​​​
R 換彈​
F 跟環境互動
Q 丟掉
E 拿起
1-8 物品欄
G 手榴彈
ESC 介面

---------------------------------

add so many basic setting
The item slot is realized! / and make a auto item slot setup tool!
Made the whole game from 0 and realized the initial scenes, characters, guns with setups, zombies!
done cross scene object(sync) system
Character movement, doors, cabinets, collisions! And countless hairs ....
health system!!!!!!!! and the ui bar / setup tool

Trying to integrate the previously made item bar, global lighting control system, UI system, item system into today's framework (while developing a cross-scene synchronization system, which is not yet implemented... This will be a major, major, major milestone :/
Integrate the Random Scene System with a scene made by a friend! (But there are still a lot of bugs :/)

Description:
Junggle Trek
"You find yourself lost in a jungle but you don't know how you ended up there. As you make your way out, mysterious, scary, unexplainable things occur. It sometimes makes your wonder; are you safe in the jungle?"

The idea popped in my mind when I went jungle trekking with my family. The experience felt like a never ending maze. Due to the lack of information, we sometimes stumble across forks, and forks, and forks... though we eventually made it out. It was a fun experience with many cool/mysterious encounters on the way (which I will implement further on!)

I decided to make this game because I wanted to learn Unity for the CS project later this year!!! It was confusing at first, but after a few tutorials, I eventually got the hang of it. As of now, it has basic game mechanics like player, title screen and jungle generation.

Sadly, juice and jungle must come to an end. Although they may be over, Junggle will keep progressing!! I'm so excited to continue on my journey of making games!!! ^o^

Realm of Rhythm

Tears tears tears
