Description:
SLIFT
SLIFT started back in June of 2025 (damn, feels like so long already). I started with absolutely no idea what I wanted to make, I had inspirations, plenty, but a unique idea, zip. Eventually, I turned to the single most reliable source for ideas: Other people. I teamed up with one of my friends, Nio, and we set to brainstorming. Early ideas were vague, we just pulled together a list of our favorite games, and wrote down what made us enjoy them. Unfortunately, we both had completely different ideas about what makes a game fun, I like environmental storytelling games, he likes fast paced, rhythm, horror games. (Nio, if you're reading this, I know there is a ton of overlap, don't roast). Eventually though, we settled on a mix, a fast paced(ish), smooth flowing game, with a focus on environment. Looking back, this might not have been the greatest idea, both of our art skills were severely lacking, and neither of us wanted to do anything somewhat easy, like pixel art (no diss). Regardless, we continued on with planning, and by the time the event started, we had a basic understanding of Godot and a semi functioning player movement.
A couple weeks into Juice, we were feeling confident enough, blocking out of the levels had been going swimmingly, and we had the first level nearly done and feeling okay. By the turn of the month, we had begun to create art for the first level. Despite our initial ideas, we settled on a pixel art style. I hate doing art, its hard, it takes ages and it never looks good until you're nearly done. Making the art was painful as hell, I started working on the player sprite, spent an hour trying to get the basic shapes, gave up, and restarted. Doing this, several times over, not just for the player sprite, but backgrounds, props, and all the other assets in the game was a truly transformative process. If I had to go through it again, I'd really say to just ignore perfectionism. Don't hunt for that perfect body shape, get it good enough. All the refining can come later.
Towards the end of juice, the pressure started to set in. Three weeks, no stress, we're on schedule, right? Well, at that point, we drafted up a schedule, and things were looking dire. 5 levels were planned, but we'd only be able to complete three, and even then, we were cutting it close as hell, leaving almost no time for bugfixes and playtesting. We worked hard over that next while (not really any harder than before tbh, just in more of a stressed fashion. Fun fact! I do not in fact work better under pressure. The next while sucked, every day I was just stressing about the game, not about the juice time, but just getting it to a level I could be proud of.
That brings me to today. I'm sitting here, on the 31/03/2025. Its a monday night, 7:30pm, this is due at 8 lol. The game’s done for juice, but we've only got three levels. Our plan from here out is not to stop development, we've got a free store page, a pretty decent game, and a plan for what we can do next, look out for the official (full) release of SLIFT sometime soon!

juiceStretches.description:
Second level room layout (w/ first level for scale)
First level takes around 8 mins, this should hopefully be around 10-15, bc a bit of backtracking, more exploring, etc.

Implemented the puzzle room and tether upgrade pickup. Basically, added the upgrade pickup, fixed some bugs with the actual tether upgrade and the smart shape system not working, added a boulder, made a boulder sprite, set up rigidbodies and door, set up button.

Redid all of the ruins smart shapes (again bc of git eating it.) Basically, the edges were way too large because the root node was scaled by two times, but i f we just scaled the root down, the actual points of the shape move, so this is not an option. Instead I just replaced them. Alongside this, I also connected more of the edges properly, so they transition between different smart shapes well.
expanded and reworked moving platform system
Finished layout for level 2 / 5 - Jungle. Just needs enemies, lights, lore, and art.
Made a door asset! also added the boulder, but art was already made.
Actually added a bunch of the fireflies to the level.
Started work on dash arm upgrade, did more layout of the jungle blockout

Finished adding physics based swinging. Works by have two modes, a kinematic mode and rigidbody mode, when moving on the ground regularly, it uses the kinematic body and the rigidbody follows the kinematic body's position, when swinging the inverse is true and a spring joint is connected between the rigidbody and target staticbody of the grapple. this took way to long bc of stupidity lol.

Fixed physics jitter (again)
bugfixes with grapple component + start working on dash arm upgrade rework.
Refactored teammates code lol.
figured out parallax backgrounds and drew some sillhouette sprites.
Added draggable ui for arm upgrades :)
Blockout of level 2 done room level, and started actual blockout
Grapple Rope animation and physics(ish)
Basic rope generation, will be used for both environment ropes and the new tether ability :)

Made it so the player angles when swinging and also added a 'falling swinging' animation. Basically, the player needs to rotate when swinging to look good, but we can't just set the player rotation to the players movement direction bc it feels really bad. I eventually came up with the system such that:
1. When actively swinging (the player is holding the mouse), the player rotation is directly towards the origin of the grapple target.
2. When the player is passively swinging (flying through the air but not actively connected with a spring), the angle slowly rotates to approach the player velocity. This second state is also where the new falling animation plays.
Lighting POC my faith in the godot lighting system is restored. :)
Added a boulder. Made art and made rigidbody.
Bugfixing auto light occluder generation
Made a boot splash screen and finally fixed the settings menu. Basically recoded all the logic for selecting the different screen modes and resolutions, but it works now so thats good.
Place all the polygons for the next section of the jungle. Currently just using the art for the previous area, but soon custom art for this section. The polygons suck to place lol.

Redid all the transitions between all the shapes. Nio did this before, but git ate it again so had to quickly do it. Basically, there are textures which wrap around the edge of the polygon, but where the polygons meet there are edges inside it, which makes it look weird. I just went over all of these internal edges and made them not render the edge material.
Made a prototyping tool so you can just draw a polygon and have it auto generate static body, light occluder, and sprite
Made it so there's screenshake when you're taking damage, and also fixed the reloading of levels, so the game doesn't crash after a few seconds.

Made a honking big door.
It uses a tilemap so can scale pretty well, and once it gets a bit of love with lighting it should look way better.
Made another door, this time it is a massive door as the entrance to the ruins, also did a ton more scatter terrain throughout the whole level, mainly in the section highlighted in the video.
Fixed physics frame jitter. now player movement is perfectly smooth while swinging. Think i need to do camera smoothing as well though
Added a death screen. published new builds, and swapped all possible language over to symbols.
Made grapples work with both arms. Can use lmb and rmb to send them, spring auto equalise length so player doesn't hold to one side.
Add grapple arm upgrade pickup to mountains. Already had it mostly coded, but had to rework it to do tweens and change the input prompt.
Made a parallax background, got it from itch io but added tons of stuff to fit the environment, and also had to spend like 20 minutes trying to get it to tile properly.

Fixed a crapton of funky lighting, and fixed some glitchy textures. Basically consisted of going through each of the smart shapes, making them less thick, playtesting and then manually adding additional light occluders where needed, took longer than expected lol.
change all the shape materials for this section over to the new material.
Made a site! Accessible at sliftgame.me
Made a jungle smart shape! this is for the surface, which is the first out of three sub areas.
Placed a crapton of slugs and cows. They need to just have their paths defined, but I also had to rework their movement code so they could go on curves properly.
Finished main menu, added settings menu, and made the loader so that scenes can be loaded (e.g starting the game.)
DASH! also i think this time I actually literally fully fixed the physics jitter.
Did more level design for the jungle area, finished up the lush caves sub section

Added a similar thing to the camera areas, but for the environment. Basically, when you enter a certain area, you get certain camera attributes and stuff tweened to. Atm, just used to have exposure lower in the cave and then brighten up when leaving it, but super easy to do other things with as well.
Made a freaking spider dude. No animations, (bc its gonna be a corpse) but I'm really really happy with how it came out.

Made the ui work properly in the jungle.
In godot, all control based nodes by default block the mouse, so when the player is under any of these, the ui didn't work. I went through and made sure all of the control nodes filters were correct, and I also fixed a bug in the arm upgrade system logic.
Added collisions while swinging
swinging working! with character body 2d following a rigidbody bc no springs on characters :(
Added slug dude art. he is cute and sluggy, but he does have a spike in him. Enemy logic not added to him yet.
Made a particle system which can have custom definable bounds (using a very cool shader) and also recovered some work lost to git.
did more art, this is similar to final product hopefully
Added modular enemy system

Made a corpse version of the spider. He only recently died, so not too worn away. There isn't any actual living ones in the game it this point, so this is pretty much the last remnant of the ancient spider empire. Also did a tiny bit of file management.
Player idle animation done (?)  I think it needs a littler refining, better integration into environment but very happy with it. first character ever made lol

added a bunch of lights to the grapes.

Added collisions to the moving fireflies! Now they can damage the player like the static fireflies do.
Reworked base grapple into a modular component. Also made it so when you grapple onto moving object the rope goes to the right place.
Basic Swinging

Finally fricking fixed the stupid, stupid physics jitter.
Third time trying this, took like an hour and a half lol

Craptons of bugfixes, several new features including but not limited to:
Pickups of the arm upgrades,
change of light system.
rework of grapple targeting system
general optimisations
fixed up transition between air and ground movement. Now its snappy on the ground and physics driven in the air
made a concept art / loading screen ig

Added collisions to all the shapes, also did a bunch of tweaking in the top area, fixing up shadows and sorting out colliders as well. Sorted a bunch of lighting up top as well, adding lights and removing shadows from some of the plants.
Placed all the background props for the shown area.

Added the cursed bird. Because the character is a bird, the birds are humans lol (but don't tell anyone)
Fixed up the parallax background for the surface. Godots parallax system absolutely sucks. it is so confusing. Next step is transitioning to the underground one when moving to the different area.

Added section for transition to level two. A tiny bit scuffed atm but its ok.
Had to do all the scatter / background for the section leading up to it as well, so took ages. Also implemented some more utility features in this thing.
Finished up the fireflies and tweaked some smart shape shapes. The fireflies are now everywhere in the level they're meant to be and I just removed some of the sharp edges on the smart shapes.
Started the conversion from blockout to high fidelity. Starts by changing my arbitrary blockout tool to someone elses arbitrary blockout tool lol.
Easy Light creation system. Handles collisions with player, physics, and all the bells and whistles.
Made it so that the jungle loads at the end of the mountains. Basically just calls a function in the root scene manager, but there were a bunch of errors with load order that sucked.
add firy things to the tunnel, they turn on when you get close and have flickery lighting.

Made a system to easily make moving particle systems. unfortunately, you can't just apply a force to all particles and particle attractors aren't yet implemented for 2d in godot, so I had to code it myself. All you need to do is place down the particles, add some points it will go to, and then you're done!
Designed layout of level 2, pathing was a big concern but I think its at an acceptable state, we'll see when the blockout comes I guess.
added a corpse and an upgrade pickup from it.
Rescaled player so pixel art works well. Required changing literally every variable and physics body params so took a while lol. Nearly back to how it was but still a bit scuffed.
Added light beams, really subtle but I think it makes a massive difference to the visual quality.
Made yank upgrade work with physics bodys.

Helped my friend fix the elevator system literal hell but its done now. Basically, the elevator stops at each 'level', and then when the player enters the next collider, it teleports and starts playing, so no matter what speed the player goes, the elevator will always arrive at roughly the right time. Unfortunately, godots animation player wasn't being nice so we had to try several different methods.
Refactored health component and various other code changes / improvements
Added light occluder system to polygon
Made a main menu. Just a mockup, so no functionality yet, but it does look pretty and the lightings all good.
Add the damage and logistical elements to the slug, also made the animation flip when it goes the other direction.
Smart shape 2d polygon textures setup, looks ok but needs work.
add transition area nodes so that we can change which parralax background is active where. Underground it should be the cave one, above ground the forest.
Add dynamic camera system + a bunch more art + a failed attempt at making lights go through the holes in the wall.

Added a new tileset for some hanging platforms and did some work on the lush caves area.
Also had to deal with git hell to get a bunch of stuff merged so that took a while.
Redid the speedrun room, because git ate my last one of it. Basically just a door and button, and then when you enter you enter an area2d which starts to slowly close the second door.

Added a ui for the arm upgrade system.
Currently only one type of upgrade, but soon more to be added.
Added chains to the hanging platforms so they're actually hanging platforms rather than floating platforms.

made the transitions between all the different smart shapes good. (In the video all of them on one individual shape are off, have to refix that one smart shape cos I added some more points lol.)

Add camera areas for jungle surface. They auto resize player camera. Already implemented, so super quick to set up here! Couldn't really show bcoz i don't have collisions for most of the level set up yet lol.
Added mini challenge room, didn't beat it here bc i'm bad, but it is easily beatable
Mossy rocks! They are very cute and I love them.
Added an animation for the dash upgrade. Works decent ig. Also did various bugfixes around the place as I went.
Lights system. It is a modular system, which both handles detection whether player is in the light through area collisions and raycasting but also handles visuals, physics, and damage.
added upgrade pool and made it so you can drag items off the menu to delete them

Fixed some bugs in the tether upgrade, and made it so rigidbodies can go along it.
First major bit of art i've done. made a texutre, got it in game, is working well. Yay!
Large variety of bug fixing and also variable jump height

Made the fireflies damage the player. Already had a system for this so it was super quick :)
Added a pause menu, fully functional and everything.
added tether arm upgrade. Mostly working, just need to fix on movable objects
Added easy, modular door / button system
Reworked to use multiple ground raycasts and also rewrote some code

Description:
Before the hackathon officially began, we were required to spend 100 hours developing a game in advance. By the time we arrived at the venue, we had already completed a game with that time. However, we quickly realized that the game wasn’t nearly as polished or engaging as we had hoped—it simply wasn’t fun to play.

So, during the three-day event, we made a bold decision: to start over from scratch.

With barely any sleep each night, we poured all our energy into building a brand-new game within those 72 hours. What we created during that time is something we’re incredibly proud of. In fact, the core concept of the new game was directly inspired by the theme of the event—Juice.

juiceStretches.description: I spent a lot of time dealing with the teleportation between different doors. After dealing with this, I made some rooms to make the whole game look more playable. On the other hand, these doors can also require keys, so it can give players more challenges :)

I created a hidden secret door that can blend seamlessly into the environment. Players can also find the key in different locations, adding variety to their experience. Additionally, I designed a massive dungeon for players to explore—and, of course, to be scared. As they navigate the dungeon, they'll need to search for the key to unlock the next room, making for a thrilling and immersive adventure. (Since completing the dungeon takes some time, I didn’t record the entire process.)







4o
Connect most of the scenes together and then put the created item slots on them to make the game look really playable.
Completed basic character movement
Basically we had a basic tilemap and then made character movements and visual restrictions to create a sense of terror.

We’ve developed a more comprehensive plan for the entire game, covering the plot, skills, and other key elements. After an intense 10-hour discussion on Discord voice chat, we now have a solid foundation—though the planning was done in Chinese.
Basically what i am doing is i going to make ton of room and then make it connect so player can run into diffrent house.
We made a tool that can generate maps more conveniently, and at the same time allow players to freely enter doors, etc. (This actually took two days of work)
We made a normal treasure chest and a monster treasure chest. In addition, we also added sound effects (this took a lot of time XD)
Complete the basic logic of the scene and the character's firing of bullets

Description:
SpringTime Life
It all started on a lazy evening when I was doom-scrolling, pretty fed up with how things were going. All repetitive. I've been following @starthackclub on Instagram for many years but never gathered the courage to take part in something. But I was feeling particularly ambitious that day. When I saw the Juice announcement reel, I just knew I would regret it if I missed this opportunity. This was my chance to do something different. Going to Shanghai has been on my bucket list ever since my dad went there in 2016. Although I never believed I would be able to make a full game by myself and more importantly convince my parents to let me go to China until each day passed with a little more progress. And here we are! As unreal as it seems I did make a little something that reflects my personality and I( a person who isn't allowed to hang out with friends even in nearby places) am going to Shanghai. This is more than a dream come true for me. 
When I first thought of a game idea, it wasn't the mechanics but rather a vision of something fun, colourful, engaging and relaxing. As a person born in Spring, I love the season more than anything and I feel it reflects in my personality too. And that is where the name "SpringTime Life" comes from! For the game mechanics, I went for something both easy to play and easy to develop since this is my first time making a proper game. Developing this has been nothing but a journey! Full of highs and lows. I had the biggest blow when I lost all my games due to the laptop glitch. Luckily it was only the beginning and I had enough time to rebuild it. And I'm glad it happened because it not only taught me how to keep my code safe but also my rebuilt game turned out to be better than it was originally. 
The BEST THING about Juice is the community. Every single person here has been so helpful and considerate. From Thomas to the reviewers and my fellow friends. I've made so many friends here. I'm usually hesitant in making online friends but I never felt uncomfortable here. 
Looking forward to meeting all these wonderful people in Shanghai. I hope to make memories that'll last a lifetime!

Description:
Signal Lost
Signal Lost is a 2D space platformer that I made! The story is that the player is an astronaut who crash landed on an alien planet and they need to find the parts to their spaceship which blew apart and reassemble them to return home. But of course, this task isn't easy. The planet is full of confusing paths, limited oxygen, and deadly alien plants! However, all of the aliens on the planet are friendly--if you can speak their language. The player needs to learn to get around on a new planet using the strange gravity and learn the symbols of the alien language to communicate with them! 

I got the idea to make this game from the "languageless" condition of Juice games. I wanted to somehow take that and make "languageless" a core part of my game, so I thought, what's a language that no human would ever understand, and some universal language? Alien language! It's universally unknown to us. And that's where the idea began. 

This is the first "real" game I've ever made! I've done some tinkering with games on Scratch before, but never committed to something so huge like this. Over the 100 hours, I definitely had lots of highs and lows. One of the hardest parts of making this game was coding up the alien communication system. There were plenty of tutorial for platformers, making enemies and very general things for games--but the alien communication part was very unique to my game so I really had to understand Godot to make it. After HOURS and HOURS of reading documentation, asking Cursor, and just struggle, I finally got it to work. I think that moment was my biggest "OMG moment" and all the work definitely was worth it because it made coding up alien conversations so much easier. Another thing I found fun while building this game was making the art! I previously used Procreate for all my pixel art, but I got Aseprite and learned how to use it--it was awesome!!

Overall, I'm super super proud of how my game is! It's been a LONG journey and it's crazy to think that I started this game TWO months ago with ZERO hours and a totally blank Godot screen. I'm still hoping to make my game EVEN better!! I think I've learned so much from making this game and honestly couldn't have done it with all the motivation and support from people in the Juice channel!! WOW :D

-Estella (@magic frog)

Description:
Our idea originally came from a friend who bailed on the project without putting in any hours… It hit us (or rather, him) in the school corridor: a top-down "level select" with platformer gameplay, kinda like Cuphead. Nothing too special about it at first.
Then we thought about copying a game where you can switch between 2D and 3D, but that wasn’t exactly new. So we kept brainstorming—how could we do something similar but different? That’s when the idea of layers hit us. A magician who can switch between different layers of reality…
For the engine, we figured a 3D engine like Unity or Unreal made the most sense. We settled on Unreal, planning to write everything in C++, but the only tutorial we found was for Blueprints… so yeah, our project ended up in Blueprints.
As for the art—our artist, Leon (who’s actually a dev, but his laptop was too weak for Unreal), had never done art before. His first designs? Questionable, to say the least, but he kept at it. And Maxi, who had never worked with Unreal before, had to figure everything out from scratch, which led to quite a few struggles early on.
But to be fair, both of them really pulled through in the end. Leon’s art improved massively, turning into something genuinely cool, and Maxi got the hang of Unreal, making things actually work. Those last two weeks? Everything just clicked. Suddenly, the game felt like it was coming together, and we finally saw our idea take shape.
Oh, and the cutscenes? We forced a friend to do them. Just like we forced another friend to make the music. And honestly? Both turned out AWESOME.
In the end, our game was barely a third of what we originally planned. But hey, it met the requirements—so that’s something, right?

I’ve finished the tileset for our dungeon (World 3). This dungeon will be divided into two sections: one that lies deeper underground—hence the red color scheme—and another at a more typical cave height. However, the process of creating it was more complicated than I initially expected, as I had to redo the tileset multiple times.  

At first, I designed it in a 48x48 resolution, but I later found out that this size isn’t ideal for Unreal Engine (source: Maximilian). So, I remade it in 64x64 pixels. However, I quickly realized that this resolution was too detailed compared to the other assets, which are all 16x16. In the end, I recreated the entire tileset in 16x16.

(Sorry for the "slightly" longer session—it was a hell of a lot of work!)

Description:
Mama's Jiaoziria
I started Juice initially with lots of optimism and excitement. I was ready to start steadfast. That is until I was met with the unfortunate news that I could not in fact go to Shanghai, China. Nothing was stopping me except well- my parents. I held out hope that maybe their mind would changed but I felt stuck. I wanted to create a cool project and go to a cool event and it definitely felt like all hope was lost. But I realized even if I'm not in Shanghai, i can still help make that cool project. Me and my friend teamed up and we had a lot of ideas in the beginning. We had this idea of a dreamscape that the user had to explore - it was a good idea but it was using the 3D world of Godot (which me and my friend were both unfamiliar with). It was clear to us that maybe it was time to shift gears so I (the most genius Einstein to have ever lived) came up with the idea that we mimic a Papa's Pizzeria game. And mimic we did because the idea was great! It also was nice because we got to add a little touch of Chinese culture in the mix, appealing to the people playing our games in Shanghai China. 
Obviously there are SOO many challenges in the game making process but I appreciated the moments where I was able to look at the progress me and my teammate made and say "we did this." 
I was in charge in mainly of the art and I'll admit there were times I was slacking but I think I'm really proud of all the progress I've made and considering I put a lot of effort into something that I was unfamiliar with. I'm not too keen on digital art and using an actual art software was difficult at first but putting in the work, learning new things, made this process all the more worthwhile. AND the art is so super duper fire. Our game has a little "hidden" easter egg as well so be on the look out of that :) (hint: it's a filling type for the dumpling... wonder what that could mean....).
I also want to take this time to share how much I value my teammate as well. Issac is such a good partner in crime and seeing his dedication and commitment to Juice made me appreciate the hard work, time, and effort he was putting into the code/project as well.
To end it off, I'd also like to say I'm extremely proud of myself as well. There are challenges I never expected to arise out of this project, challenges where I had to teach myself new things, but hey, as Thomas always says "in life we are always learning," and I think that's the joy of it.

juiceStretches.description: Created a bunch of icons for filling options and sauce options (also made splash art for the sauce options). These icons are to be used for the tickets and labelling filling options in the prep station. I'm not too keen on digital art so it took a lot of finicking around. Also I'm using a new app. I've tried digital art before on like sketchbook just for funsies but using an actual art app made me have to learn A LOTTT about the software and how to use it so the icons didn't look goofy. In the video, each icon has a little time thingy on the bottom. For example, for the first icon (the pig), it says 0:55, which means 55 minutes.

AHHH BIG STRETCH!! Well, I got a lot done. I finished A LOT of the assets. Unfortunately, I had to redraw the buttons, and also redraw/resize a bunch of the art :( I showed an example in the video of how I had to redraw one of the buttons (but just know I had to redraw all 4). But also I had to resize/redraw the backgrounds to make sure it fit the sizing of the godot screen (since i'm still learning how to use ibis ahh)
This is the first time in my life where I touched godot. Omg. My first challenge was literally setting up VS code with godot... Since i was coding on a project with files already on it (my teammate did a lot of the code), I had to learn the file structure and hierarchies. It had my mind boggled. BUT! The main thing is I got a function to work in the prep station. It's a mini prototype but you get to add filling to the dumpling skin and then it can become into a dumpling :D

Description:
3d World's Hardest Game
This game is inspired from the 2d Flash game The World's Hardest Game, and I wanted to make it in 3d. This was the first real game I ever made, I have made some projects in Unity but have never actually committed to them. I will be completely honest here: after making my game for 100 hours, I'm sick of it and I probably won't update it. But I'm not giving up on making games, I'm going to make a new one. Over the course of making my game, I had a lot of motivation at the beginning, but by the time I had worked on my game for 50 hours, my motivation was really low. I didn't work on my game for almost a week, but then I had lots of good ideas for my game and I worked on those. I finished the 100 hours right before the deadline.

ok i know this stretch is REALLY long but this took so long to do. i noticed that the player was not respawning at all on the unknown block level, and neither was the r key or ui button, and all enemies in general. The most part of this stretch was just trying stuff in the script and seeing if it worked, and at one point i rewrote the respawn function, but nothing worked. i even resorted to asking ai, but that didnt do anything. then i merged the script into player movement, but that didn't work. i knew that it was working and it was colliding, because the blocks turned green or red, it just wasnt respawning. I have no idea how this worked, but to fix it, i just used an empty gameobject for respawn refrence instead of typing in the axises in the inspector. but this only fixed the unknown block level, and the r key still did not work. i was using some legacy stuff, so i updated that and it worked. but the unknown blocks respawn didn't fully work, even though it respawned, it wasnt immidiate most of the time and the player could skip over death blocks. so after a while of trying to figure out what was wrong, i noticed that the player was falling a tiny bit and not colliding yet. to fix this, i changed the script to have an axis sort of thing, where it just detected the tag the axis under the player. after a few iterations of getting this to work, everything works now!!!!!
